webTitle: The tip of a frosty iceberg

fields.headline: The tip of a frosty iceberg
fields.trailText: In recent years, various match-fixing allegations, mainly on the subcontinent, have made the cricketing apple taste increasingly sour. The latest developments involving Hansie Cronje, however, throw up the chilling possibility that it really might be rotten to the core.
fields.body:
In recent years, various match-fixing allegations, mainly on the subcontinent, have made the cricketing apple taste increasingly sour. The latest developments involving Hansie Cronje, however, throw up the chilling possibility that it really might be rotten to the core.

Perspective is important - were Cronje's actions really much worse than those of Mark Waugh and Shane Warne a few years back? But so is context, and even in the sleazy environment of contemporary international sport, Cronje's actions are astonishing. When one reporter described England's victory in the fifth Test at Centurion Park as "the easiest in modern Test history," he surely did not mean this.

It is clearly the man, as much as the act, that so disturbs. Like the hard-boiled detectives of classic 1940s films noirs, Cronje has seen it all, done it all, and was the last person of whom we would expect such deviance. However, it would seem that the femme fatale - in this case $10-15,000 - has weaved her seductive spell once more. The only territory left unexplored by this narrative is how far Cronje was willing to go in the name of avarice. For him, there can surely be no happy ending.

Whether Cronje is guilty of match-fixing is still unclear, but the facts of the match in question do not do him any favours. It is said that there are lies, damned lies and statistics, but these may be the exceptions that prove the rule: Herschelle Gibbs, a man so impatient that he infamously dropped Steve Waugh in his haste to celebrate his demise, made 19 off 29 balls, and also grassed a straightforward catch in the field. Cronje brought himself on first change - ahead of Jacques Kallis, Lance Klusener and Nicky Boje - and bowled his full complement, despite returning figures of 10-0-69-1. Pieter Strydom, another implicated in these allegations, bowled four wides in three overs (although Cronje has since said no-one else was involved). Cricinfo, at the time, also commented that "Cronje fortuitously won the toss for the third time in a row, but in a change of strategy opted to bowl first." All, it would seem, fairly damning.

This is the problem: if you look hard enough, through sufficiently tinted spectacles, you could see match-fixing in virtually every cricket match ever played. A batsman may dump a full-toss straight to mid-off or bowlers spray the ball all over the place on a seamer's paradise. But these foibles, this unpredictability, is what makes the game so compelling.

If proven, the implications of match-fixing are quite startling: one thinks of the suicides in Pakistan after defeat by India in a 1996 World Cup quarter-final. While this is not to suggest that that game was rigged, it shows the enormous fanaticism that cricket engenders, and how vulnerable the game is as a result. It is to be hoped that Cronje's will prove a cautionary tale for all (including the authorities, who must dispense with the surfeit of meaningless one-dayers, and give an immediate, official context - the Wisden World Championship, anyone? - to Test cricket).

As it is, cricket is in some form of crisis, and yet this incident could prove to be the tip of a particularly frosty iceberg, which would threaten the very existence of the game. And, as the detective in the Coen brothers' neo-noir 'Fargo' uttered solemnly, "all that, for a little bit of money."

Rob Smyth is a post-graduate student at Nottingham University

webTitle: Barclays chief defiant on closures and pay

fields.headline: Barclays chief defiant on closures and pay
fields.standfirst:
MP says Barrett defence is arrogant and insensitive
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Matt Barrett, the chief executive of Barclays, promised his staff yesterday that he would learn from the bank's mishaps in recent weeks.
fields.body:
Matt Barrett, the chief executive of Barclays, promised his staff yesterday that he would learn from the bank's mishaps in recent weeks.

In a six-page letter, which he admitted was "a bit long-winded", Mr Barrett told his 55,000 staff in the UK that the decision to close 171 branches was "socially responsible" and hit out against "hype and lunacy" over calculations of a £30m performance pay deal.

Making his first comments since the outrage provoked by the branch closures and reports about his potential pay, Mr Barrett insisted that he "found it hard to detect a single defensible principle in the outcry over our branch closures", in the media coverage.

Customers should not be asked to subsidise operations that are no longer viable, he said, as he put the closures in the context of a wider socio-economic trend.

"We are told that access to financial services is important, and so it is. But so is access to health care, education, transport and nutrition. The fact is that these arguably more vital services have already disappeared from many of these communities," he wrote.

"Governments have had to recognise these trends and stop providing essential services in every town and village as a result. How can banks - private sector companies - be expected to buck the same trends," he said. If the bank did not adapt to such social and economic changes, he argued that it would be detrimental to the national interest.

Perplexed by the "paradox" over the way the media reacted to the assault on NatWest, Barclays' closest rival, by two Scottish banks which pledged to cut costs and axe branches, Mr Barrett described the changes at Barclays as a "picnic" by comparison.

Sending his letter to staff just days before he and his counterparts at Lloyds TSB and HSBC face scrutiny from a panel of MPs, Mr Barrett asked them to send it to customers, business contacts, families and friends.

"Never forget that it is in society's interest that we are big and that we are successful," he said. The bank made "huge" tax contributions of £649m last year which would bolster public funds and support the government's social programme, he said.

He insisted that the rationale behind his performance-related pay deal - known as an incentive share option plan - was "absolutely right". To receive the £30m potential payout, he said the share price would have to rise to £180 from £17 now.

"A ten-fold increase in market capitalisation would be an astonishing performance, outstripping anything seen in our industry or any other, with the possible exception of some of the dot.com meteors of recent times," he said.

Unifi, the financial union, noted Mr Barrett's comment that "we will all be well rewarded" if the bank achieved its difficult goals. "We will be holding him to that," an official said.

In the future, Mr Barrett said that the bank would continue to take "value maximising decisions without sentimentality or excuses". Telling staff it was important that they knew the truth, he said it was also vital they knew that the "leadership" of Barclays would learn from the lessons of the recent events.

"For though each of the decisions we have made has been right for Barclays - our shareholders, customers and you - we must clearly review the execution," he said.

He said it was important that all "stakeholders" understood the bank's actions were reasonable against the background of change in which they were taking place. The letter prompted an angry reaction from Martin Salter, the MP who chairs the cross-party group on banking. "I would describe Mr Barrett's comments as the height of arrogance and insensitivity," he said.

fields.headline: Time to prove your worth
fields.standfirst: The self-employed can get loans if they have the right documentation, says Gail Moss
fields.trailText: The self-employed have found it hard to get mortgages because of the need to provide three years' accounts, or similar documentation, to prove their income.
fields.body:
The self-employed have found it hard to get mortgages because of the need to provide three years' accounts, or similar documentation, to prove their income.

With changing trends in employment, however, high-street lenders have become more sympathetic to self-employed borrowers.

Brokers say there is a popular misconception that, if you are self-employed, you have to go for a different deal, but the key is whether you can prove your income. If so, you can get the same deal as an employed person on a status basis.

What constitutes satisfactory proof of income depends on the lender. Many high-street lenders allow self-certification, where they accept a statement of income signed by the borrower, without requiring any evidence that the amount is correct.

The latest convert here is Britain's biggest mortgage lender, the Halifax, which two months ago started allowing self-certification for existing customers, where the loan-to-value (ltv) is 75% or less. They still ask for back-up documentation such as bank statements. A higher ltv - a smaller deposit - requires an accountant's letter.

Other lenders, however, still insist on seeing audited accounts. Generally, the lower the total amount loaned, the less rigorous the demands.

But if you have to produce accounts, what do you do if your accountant has skillfully minimised your profit for tax purposes?

Many lenders work on the basis that you earn more than you say you do in the accounts so they may well accept that it is appropriate to state your income as being a few thousand more than it is for tax purposes.

This can also apply where the borrower owns a limited company, which both pays him a salary and produces a profit, which effectively belongs to him as well. Again, many lenders will take both figures into consideration.

In contrast, the Bank of Scotland offers a special status mortgage without requiring an income figure but your accountant must confirm how long your business has been trading, and that it is still going. With this arrangement, the bank can lend up to 80% ltv with a maximum loan of £300,000. Borrowers able to produce accounts could borrow up to 100% on a property. But the bank would take the borrower's income as being the net profit on the accounts, rather than some higher figure.

Just because you may not have to prove income, however, does not mean you will not have your credit rating checked. Some high-street lenders will ask for references from your existing mortgage lender, if you have one, and this will probably highlight any past or current arrears. It is not always necessary to have a squeaky-clean record.

"While you can't make generalisations, if you've missed one or two installments, you'd probably be OK," says Simon Pistell, managing director of Legal & General. "On the other hand, if you're six months in arrears that would be more of a problem."

Generally speaking, the first port of call for the self-employed should be the mainstream lenders, because you may be able to get a mortgage on the same terms as someone who is employed.

Failing this, a tailored product might be an option, though these tend to have relatively conservative lending criteria, with the maximum advance available normally 75%. And interest rates might be slightly higher than mainstream mortgages.

Legal & General is one of around 20 providers offering a product designed for the self-employed. Their Flexible Reserve Plus mortgage is an Australian-style loan that allows you to overpay or take payment holidays, and pay in lump sums or take money out, as long as you have built up enough of an overpayment.

The current interest rate on this mortgage is the same as on Legal & General's other products - 6.8% - but borrowers are not eligible for the new borrowers' discounts.

Finally, there are the lenders who specialise in mortgages for people unable to get finance from other sources. These include the Kensington Mortgage Company, RFC MSL, Platform Home Loans and Future Mortgages, and they usually get business via brokers.

One of the reasons they can offer finance is because credit risk is assessed on a case-by-case basis by an underwriter, rather than by computer, which happens with many mainstream lenders. But rates are likely to reflect the higher assumed risk, at least for a few years.

fields.headline: Find safety in trackers
fields.standfirst: When interest falls, bank rate-linked packages are a sure bet, says Rupert Jones
fields.trailText: Tracker funds have been one of the investment success stories of the past decade, and now the concept has been extended to home loans - but instead of shadowing a stock market index such as the FTSE-100, tracker mortgages follow the ups and downs of the Bank of England base rate.
fields.body:
Tracker funds have been one of the investment success stories of the past decade, and now the concept has been extended to home loans - but instead of shadowing a stock market index such as the FTSE-100, tracker mortgages follow the ups and downs of the Bank of England base rate.

With a tracker loan, the rate you pay is set a fixed amount above the base rate, which is currently 6%. This margin is typically 0.75%-1.5% above the base rate, though it can be as high 2%. When the base rate goes up or down, so does what you pay.

Tracker mortgages burst on to the scene less than two years ago, and last summer they seemed to be everywhere. Now people do not seem to be shouting quite so loudly about them.

Abbey National, Britain's second-largest mortgage lender, says most bank and building societies are testing and trailing them, although a spokesman adds: "I don't think anyone is selling them in great volumes." But it has included a tracker element in its new flexible mortgage.

The simple reason tracker loans are not such hot news is that interest rates have been rising and mortgages that promise to pass on the full amount of any increase are not flavour of the month. The clamour for trackers comes when rates are falling.

But some experts reckon that the time could soon be very right indeed for trackers. While the forecast is for one or two more interest rate rises this year, economists still predict that in the longer term they are likely to fall sharply. As soon as we hit the start of the downwards cycle, trackers will catch on again.

When rates do start to fall, we are likely to see a rerun of last year's debate about lenders not passing on rate cuts, according to Siobhan Hotten at mortgage brokers John Charcol.

Many readers will recall that a number of lenders denied their borrowers the full benefit of interest rate cuts in April and June 1999.

If this happens again, it will heighten tracker appeal because you cannot be diddled out of your rate cut.

For this reason, trackers have won the government's seal of approval. In drawing up new voluntary minimum Cat standards for mortgages, details of which were announced this week, ministers have said that to make the grade, variable rate mortgages must never be more than two percentage points above the base rate.

"Trackers are very much here to stay," says Ms Hotten. "I wouldn't be surprised if we start to see more and more of these products come onto the market. People do like the clarity that they bring."

But not all trackers work in the same way With some, the rate is guaranteed to stay a certain amount above the base rate for the life of the mortgage, while others only guarantee to track the base rate for a few years.

But the industry has been unable to resist tinkering with what was originally a simple concept, and adding bits here and there.

John Charcol is offering an exclusive tracker deal, funded by the Halifax, where you pay the bank base rate minus 0.26% for two years, giving a current payment rate of 5.74%, then for the next three years you pay base rate plus 0.95%.

The deal is available to those who can pay a deposit of at least 10%, and there is no lender's fee and no redemption penalties.

There are a number of deals around that combine a tracker with a cap. These have been designed to give people some protection from rising rates.

This sort of loan may appeal to those people who reckon we will see further interest rate rises in the short term but then are likely to see them falling.

fields.headline: Picking the right package
fields.trailText: Finding the perfect home is one of most difficult tasks many of us will ever have to face. But even if we are living in our dream residence, many of us want to remortgage to a better deal.
fields.body:
Finding the perfect home is one of most difficult tasks many of us will ever have to face.

But even if we are living in our dream residence, many of us want to remortgage to a better deal. And choosing the right package - and the best way of repaying - is also fraught with difficulties. A wrong decision could prove financially disastrous.

There are two types of mortgage payment vehicles, the repayment method - otherwise known as capital and interest - and the interest-only model. The choice between repayments and endowments, pensions and Isa-based plans can be complicated, especially as financial advisers can make a pretty penny from pushing the latter and very little from repayment mortgages.

The safest mortgage is the repayment plan. The payment is broken down into two elements, repayment of the money you have borrowed and the repayment of the interest on that loan.

Although it may take many years to pay the mortgage off, providing you maintain the payments, the loan will be paid off even if the stock market plummets - and you can easily accelerate repayments and reduce the interest bill with a flexible loan.

The interest-only method involves paying interest on the sum borrowed throughout the loan's life. Borrowers separately pay into an investment plan such as an endowment or an Isa in the hope that it grows sufficiently to equal or exceed the loan within the chosen period.

But many endowment policies sold in the early 90s will fail on current projections of investment growth. This month Jobs & Money revealed that up to 80% of current endowment mortgage holders face shortfalls.

Despite this, many advisers are still steering customers towards endowments. These were once sold to four out of five home loan applicants - now the figure is below one in three.

The mortgage experts we consult are under no obligation to sort the wheat from the chaff on our behalf because home loan advice is not regulated. Go armed with as much information as possible when you approach a lender.

But watch out for pitfalls. Whenever there is change in the interest rate, both repayment and interest-only rates will be recalculated. You should always ask for a range of forecasts of your future liability based on a variety of interest rates.

Kim North, an independent financial adviser at Pretty Technical Partnership in London, says only the cautious investor who has a good idea about their future should consider arepayment mortgage. Only 40% of her clients opt for repayment. Most of the others go for Isa-based loans that offer a mix of tax relief and flexibility.

Endowment mortgage business is falling at present as many customers switch to Isa-based mortgages. Apart from their perceived failure in some cases to pay off mortgages, they are also generally perceived to be inflexible.

If you are worried about investment market performances, then you should be wary of investment-backed plans which depend on strong returns to build up a pot of money to repay your loan.

But many endowment policies sold in the early 90s will fail on current projections of investment growth. This month Jobs & Money revealed that up to 80% of current endowment mortgage holders face shortfalls. Despite this, many advisers are still steering customers towards endowments. These were once sold to four out of five home loan applicants - now the figure is below one in three. The mortgage experts we consult are under no obligation to sort the wheat from the chaff on our behalf because home loan advice is not regulated. Go armed with as much information as possible when you approach a lender. But watch out for pitfalls. Whenever there is change in the interest rate, both repayment and interest-only rates will be recalculated. You should always ask for a range of forecasts of your future liability based on a variety of interest rates. Kim North, an independent financial adviser at Pretty Technical Partnership in London, says only the cautious investor who has a good idea about their future should consider arepayment mortgage. Only 40% of her clients opt for repayment. Most of the others go for Isa-based loans that offer a mix of tax relief and flexibility. Endowment mortgage business is falling at present as many customers switch to Isa-based mortgages. Apart from their perceived failure in some cases to pay off mortgages, they are also generally perceived to be inflexible. If you are worried about investment market performances, then you should be wary of investment-backed plans which depend on strong returns to build up a pot of money to repay your loan.

fields.headline: Early birds catch the worm
fields.standfirst:
The first funds to invest in the small hi-tech companies have performed outstandingly, reports Robin Stoddart
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The first funds to invest in the small hi-tech companies have performed outstandingly.
fields.body:
Smaller companies fared worse than old blue chips in the shake-out in shares that spread over from Wall Street. Technology issues that burn up money on their way to hoped-for riches in a few years are obviously the most vulnerable. Confidence would benefit most from a belief that interest rates have peaked. This is not yet the case, so small companies remain vulnerable unless they have a pile of cash or present appealing takeover targets.

The most successful funds investing in smaller companies owe their outstanding performance to the early selection of technology issues. While remaining small in turnover terms and barely visible as regards profitability, a score or more of these have become extremely highly valued.

The latest is Bookham Technology, the fibre optic hardware maker, which shot up to more than two-and-half times the issue price in otherwise grisly conditions for new technology shares on Tuesday.

Its valuation of more than 100 times turnover puts it among the most expensive by that ratio, though internet operators, rather than hardware suppliers have been, and remain, the most inflated. Bookham will join the top 100 shares in the main FTSE index if it remains near the present price. The giant 3i development capital trust is a main shareholder.

Although Lastminute.com has shaken new investors with a fall to little more than half its issue price, others, led by Freeserve and QXL remain well above their flotation cost and most small shareholders must be happy, if rather dizzy.

Suggestions that BT needs an internet portal to catch up on the European rivals that seem to be leaving it behind, in spite of its early start in the privatisation stakes, brought some support for Freeserve and its parent Dixons. On the other hand QXL's own takeover activity and hopes that it would extend to US internet auctions lifted its valuation above £2bn for a while, though American buyers are now licking their wounds.

But the inflation of UK and European internet companies is minor by comparison with those in Japan, including Softbank, the internet banker and investor in which several UK smaller company investment trusts have small stakes. Tens of billions of pounds were added and deducted from its valuation within a period of months and days. The gyrations in technology issues point up the advantages of investing in actively managed funds that can take advantage of such investment situations, but do not linger overlong in one share or section.

The outstanding performer among smaller company funds is AIM Trust which recently sold the holding in BATM Advanced Communications that was primarily responsible for the 600% leap in asset value seen last year. A couple of unit trusts performed as well in the last few months of the technology boom that continued into early March, with APAX Artemis and Close Beacon doubling in value in three months, like AIM, before the setback. Murray Smaller achieved gains of three-quarters in that period, but the much larger Dresdner RCM UK Small Cos and Edinburgh UK Smaller gained much more for investors in total.

Axa Sun Life's £800m fund appreciated only a third as much. Schroder's giant unit fund in the sector was a mediocre performer, too, though with a gain of a third in three months and almost three-quarters in a year private investors did a good deal better than holders of the institutional fund.

AIM Trust is a £200m investment trust managed by Friends Ivory & Sime of Edinburgh. Its spread of investments is wide ranging, with small publishing and mining companies in the list. Although the biggest successes have been in technology, including the pharmaceutical development company Alizyme and Robotic Technology, it also took good gains in the likes of Ramco Energy and optronics manufacturer Gooch & Housego. JSB Software, a favourite among small company funds, is now the largest holding. The shares are now down sharply from their peak and at a discount of a fifth to asset value. A strong flow of new issue flota tions is continuing, particularly on the Alternative Investment Market (AIM), where new and top-up issues qualify for income tax relief of 20% and even for buyers in the market capital gains tax tapers down to 10% after four years. Nevertheless the managers of small companies are frustrated at the red tape and employee regulations that they have to cope with, while the strong pound and high interest rates handicap them against European competition.

Soon to disappear from AIM with a view to joining the American Nasdaq list before long is Gartland Whalley & Barker, a small company acquirer and developer for resale or flotation.

After buying precision engineering and corporate services interests in the US recently, the director-controlled company is offering to buy out losing minority investors at the issue price four years ago. UK holdings, including lighting and furniture makers and the listed Aquarius and Quantica companies, still contribute a major share of assets, but the directors consider the environment for acquisitive small companies and their promoters to be much more favourable in the US. The currency is less of a factor there and share issues are easier to make.

webTitle: Towers puts in bid for Rover

fields.headline: Towers puts in bid for Rover
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: BMW was yesterday presented with an alternative offer for Rover from a consortium headed by ex-Rover boss John Towers.
fields.body:
BMW was yesterday presented with an alternative offer for Rover from a consortium headed by ex-Rover boss John Towers.

The German car maker said it had "received a letter containing a proposal for the take-over of Rover" adding that it would now examine the proposal.

The letter was handed over by Mr Towers to Rover chief executive Werner Sämaan yesterday afternoon. Thousands of jobs could hang on the fate of the Towers consortium's bid. BMW is already negotiating a deal under which venture capitalists Alchemy Partners would take over the Longbridge plant and concentrate on the MG marque.

Though few details of Mr Towers' bid have been disclosed it envisages the continuation of volume car production which would mean far fewer job losses than the Alchemy plan.

There has been speculation that Mr Towers will offer around £800m for Rover - excluding Land Rover which is being sold to Ford. There are suggestions that his bid has two alternatives: one including the new mini to be built at Cowley and one without.

BMW reiterated yesterday that it had no plans to give up the new mini. Mr Towers' bid came hours after thousands of workers were granted a jobs reprieve when plans to transfer workers from BMW to Alchemy were shelved after unions threatened legal action.

GMB general secretary John Edmonds said: "It gives a vital breathing space to allow the Towers bid to gather momentum."

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, said he hoped BMW would give serious consideration to an alternative bid. "The Towers plan offers a better prospect than perhaps anything else," he told a Midlands radio station. However, industry experts believe the bid faces formidable obstacles.

fields.headline: The stuff of nightmares
fields.standfirst:
The Hundred and One Dalmatians
Belgrade, Coventry
*
fields.trailText:
The Hundred and One Dalmatians
Belgrade, Coventry
*
fields.body:
This is not so much a dog as a mongrel. Bits of Debbie Isitt's production, which cleverly splices film and live action, are terrific and bits don't work at all. The trouble is that the two often don't seem to fit together. It makes for a very strange, very uneven evening.

Isitt's attempt to rescue Dodie Smith's book from Disneyfication is to be applauded. But to suggest that this story about saving your skin can be seen as a metaphor for the Jews in Nazi Germany or the Kosovans is stretching it too far. The same can be said of the moment when one of the baddies pretends to pour petrol over a Dalmatian and looks around for a light. I have seldom sensed such audience distress .

Isitt suggests in the programme that much theatre for young people is patronising. That's true. But here we've gone in one leap from fluffy bunnies to Auschwitz. (Yes, there is a gassing scene.) The show is too dark for the suggested age range of five and over.

There is a world of difference between the unflinching cruelty of productions for children set in a fictionalised world, and this. Dalmatian puppies are portrayed by cute babies with blackened noses and later by small children, who are seen on film being abducted from a playground. One is a safe way of dramatising the harsh realities of the world; the other just asks for disturbed nights.

This production is wonderfully atmospheric in a creepy kind of way, and there are some great set pieces, including a whirling snowstorm that engulfs the whole of the stalls. But why is Carren Waterfield's hyperventilating Cruella De Vil played as a cross between Norma Desmond and Miss Havisham? By the end, like Cruella, I felt like howling.
Until May 6. Box office: 02476 553055.

fields.headline: Swap to save money
fields.standfirst: A new deal can pay well, says Tracey Boles, but do your sums
fields.trailText: You may be paying over the odds on your mortgage without realising but there is a way round the problem - the increasingly popular route of remortgaging.
fields.body:
You may be paying over the odds on your mortgage without realising but there is a way round the problem - the increasingly popular route of remortgaging.

You could save yourself hundreds of pounds a year by switching to a lower fixed rate or discount deal, either with your existing lender or a new one. But do your sums to make sure it is worthwhile. All the savings and fees have to be weighed up.

You may be making inflated repayments on your mortgage if you are still paying it off at your lender's standard variable rate, which mortgage companies use to subsidise cheap fixed-rate and discount deals for other borrowers.

The same applies if you took out a five-year fixed-rate loan three or four years ago when rates were in the region of 8%, or if you have come out of a fixed-rate and been forced into your lenders standard rate for a couple of years under threat of a large penalty. The time to escape is the day you are free of the penalty period - it is only worth paying the fine in extreme circumstances.

But look before you leap. Remortgaging snags include legal expenses, valuations and application fees, which could add anywhere between £400 and £1,000 to the cost of remortgaging. Other pitfalls to look out for are compulsory insurance and overhangs, where you are locked into a lender well after the cheap deal has expired.

Cheltenham & Gloucester's Peter Mounty says: "There's no point going across too early for a quarter of a per cent rate difference if you are going to be hit with a big penalty. Do your sums."

Even so, remortgaging is becoming more and more popular. More than one in five loans taken out in January was a remortgage, according to the Council of Mortgage Lenders. Standard Life Bank grabbed 17% of the mortgage market last year, largely by offering a remortgaging service.

As well as enabling people to get cheaper deals, it can free up capital for pensions, home improvements, deposits on buy-to-let properties or settling debts.

So how do you go about it? First check you are not going to be subject to a penalty. The next stage is to decide if you want to stay with your existing company. An independent adviser can help.

Mr Mounty of C&G says the real key is to quiz your new lender to find out what contributions they will make to the process. The best of the deals offer free valuations and/or basic legal work or cashbacks to offset the costs.

Once you have done some information gathering you can go back to your existing lender with a strong hand.

Lenders do not always make remortgaging easy for their own customers. Many refuse to offer the best deals to customers who want to remortgage rather than move house, saying the latter have more expenses. Only when customers threaten to take their business elsewhere do some relent and reveal their best "under the counter" deals.

Mortgage advisers can help to push through the change more quickly. John Charcol has a high-speed remortgaging service that allows you to switch within 24 hours over the internet, or three days over the phone or in person. Some lenders such as the Woolwich offer a similar service and say agreement can be reached in two hours.

As to what mortgage to chose, two-year fixed rates with no redemption penalties are now a popular option with interest rates predicted to rise further before falling again over the next two years. These offer a painless exit in case rates fall further than expected.

fields.headline: Retailers move onwards - and upwards?
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Senior directors at two of the best-known high street chains passed through the checkout yesterday in search of bigger and better jobs.
fields.body:
Senior directors at two of the best-known high street chains passed through the checkout yesterday in search of bigger and better jobs.

Keith Hamill, finance director of WH Smith, and Donald Damask, marketing director of Body Shop, both walk away with generous compensation.

Mr Hamill, 46, will pocket some £300,000 after refusing to commit himself to staying for the next three to five years. He joined from hotel group Forte in 1996 and narrowly missed out on the chief executive's role in 1997.

Mr Hamill is understood to have been in talks with household products group Reckitt Benckiser about becoming chief financial officer. He has also been linked to the chief executive vacancy at BA.

Mr Hamill leaves in May, but next week will present Smith's half-year results and details of expansion plans. The company was "well advanced" with finding a replacement.

"His departure... does not come as a surprise and is unlikely to have caused any ill-will," said Matthew McEachran, retail analyst at Henderson Crosthwaite.

At Body Shop Mr Damask is to be replaced by product director Susan Falk, who will also oversee marketing. An American, Mr Damask joined 10 months ago. Body Shop has since passed many central functions to new regional executives. "The role wasn't as big as originally envisaged," said a spokeswoman.

Mr Damask's payoff, to be disclosed later this year, is likely to be some £300,000.

Body Shop closed down 1p at 100p; WH Smith was down 1p at 386p.

webTitle: Online searches can net you the best package

fields.headline: Online searches can net you the best package
fields.standfirst: The internet can help to calculate the best loan package for you, says Marianne Curphey
fields.trailText: Searching online for a mortgage has two advantages over tramping down the high street or using the telephone - speed and interactivity.
fields.body:
Searching online for a mortgage has two advantages over tramping down the high street or using the telephone - speed and interactivity.

Within a few minutes of logging on to a site the interactive calculators on the pages of banks, building societies and personal finance websites can give you an idea of how much you can borrow, based on your salary. You can add or reduce the amount of deposit you can afford to put down, stretch the length of the contract to its maximum, or factor in your wish to pay the loan off early. The web can reveal which repayment term is best based on your cashflow and lifestyle.

Before this, trying to calculate how much you could afford to borrow and the house you could afford was only available to you by consulting a mortgage broker.

Now, armed with this information in advance, you can arrange your mortgage with a better idea of what you want. It makes you a more powerful consumer.

One of the best calculators is at the Abbey National site which works out your spare income based on the information you input.

If you are remortgaging, Paragon Mortgages has a series of downloadable calculators.

Next you need to decide what sort of mortgage you want - fixed rate, capped, discounted, repayment or endowment.

The drawback of searching on the web is that there is no one there to give you advice on which to choose, although there is plenty of information for you to read.

Even if you do decide eventually to buy your mortgage through a intermediary such as a financial adviser or broker, you will still have more information than the average customer.

There is also MoneySupermarket, whose website has news about the best deals now available.

The joy - and the problem - of the internet is that there is an almost unlimited amount of information available. You could visit every mortgage lender's site but that would end up being as time consuming as shopping up and down the high street, and expensive.

An alternative is to use an online mortgage broker. For a list of brokers and lenders, try www.find.co.uk/mortgages.

One of the best-known high-street mortgage brokers is John Charcol. The company makes its money as a fee-based mortgage broker. As an online broker it does not charge a fee but allows you to compare mortgage products from up to 45 lenders.

But you need to be aware that there are the same potential pitfalls in selecting a mortgage online as in finding one the more traditional way.

webTitle: Get a fix on the best rates

fields.headline: Get a fix on the best rates
fields.trailText: Playing on fears of a probable rise in interest rates after next month's meeting of the Bank of England's monetary committee, mortgage lenders are launching tempting cut-price and fixed-rate home loans.
fields.body:
Playing on fears of a probable rise in interest rates after next month's meeting of the Bank of England's monetary committee, mortgage lenders are launching tempting cut-price and fixed-rate home loans.

The headache for housebuyers is that with a plethora of mortgage products on the market, finding the right deal is not easy.

And lenders seem to have decided that confusing customers is their route to riches. Novice homebuyers are most vulnerable because they tend to approach the building society or bank branch where they run their savings account, but these may not have the best deal.

Finding the best ways to balance the monthly repayments makes a big difference. Borrowers who pinch their household budget to meet their monthly payments should look for a fixed rate to avoid problems if interest rates go up. Current capped deals - which can disappear overnight - include a 6.25% cap from Newcastle building society until July 2002, a three-year deal from Woolwich at 7.29% and a five-year cap from Abbey National at 7.25%.

But, as ever, vigilance pays as banks and building societies are constantly updating their range of fixed-rate mortgage packages.

For existing homebuyers locked into fixed rates, remortgaging at a lower rate can be worthwhile, as each percentage point drop in the mortgage rate cuts around £63 a month on a £100,000 loan. To judge whether the time is right to opt for a fixed rate, first look at the movement of interest rates.

Economic soothsayers expect the Bank of England to raise rates at least once before banks' base rates gradually settle down to converge with lower levels in the EU. Many lenders now also offer special capped rate home loans under which borrowers benefit from falling rates but avoid any further rises in prevailing mortgage rates over prearranged lengths of time.

But if you are considering opting for a fixed-rate loan there are a few drawbacks to bear in mind when going for a fix or a cap.

A lender may inflict expensive compulsory insurance policies or upfront mortgage application fees, typically between £200 and £400, which are normally non-refundable. These can prove painful if your purchase falls through.

Finally, remember to budget for the risk that you may have to pay a much higher rate when the fixed-rate deal expires. Halifax is drawing first-time buyers into the housing market through a special deal fixed at 5.59% until December 31 2001.

And Lambeth Building Society is offering mortgages at 4.09% fixed for two years to first-time buyers with the usual 5% deposit, but they will have to stay with the lender for at least five years.

webTitle: Going flat out in the search for buildings insurance

fields.headline: Going flat out in the search for buildings insurance
fields.standfirst:
If your property is rather unusual, you may find it hard to get cover as insurers cherry pick and refuse to quote. Patrick Collinson reports
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: If your property is rather unusual, you may find it hard to get cover as insurers cherry pick and refuse to quote. Patrick Collinson reports.
fields.body:
Spending just a couple of hours shopping around for buildings insurance can save you hundreds of pounds.

But a survey this week by Jobs & Money found extensive cherry picking by direct insurance providers and refusals to cover properties outside the norm. I live in a maisonette, part of a terraced south London house split into three flats, where the three owners share the freehold.

I'm used to rip-off London prices but was shocked to receive a £1,075 bill from Eagle Star for my buildings insurance - and that did not include any contents cover or extended accidental damage. So I set about finding a better quote.

Three hours later I had managed to knock the premium down to £683 - a saving of nearly £500 - but brokers rather than the much-advertised direct providers found the best deal.

The first surprise was how many insurers refused to offer cover. Despite the fact that in London and other British cities houses split into flats is common enough, and shared freehold is taking over from leasehold, I was refused cover by AA Insurance Services, Axa Direct, Direct Line, Ecclesiastical Direct and Tesco Direct. I was fobbed off with explanations that they would sell you a policy only if you own the total freehold and are the sole owner occupier.

I ran into similar problems trying to obtain quotes from internet-based services such as Screentrade.co.uk, which work well for straightforward cases but come unstuck with more complex cases.

All the quotes I obtained (except from Cooperative Insurance Services) came from brokers, who contact a number of providers on your behalf to find a quote. The best quote was from Bradford & Bingley, at £683, marginally ahead of the £721 obtained by a small independent bro ker, Playle Russell Special Risks via a Lloyd's syndicate. The worst was from Heath Insurance, which markets under different names such as Key Connect and Simply Direct, which wanted £1,204.50.

The first step in taking out a buildings policy is to calculate how much the sum insured should be. This is not the same as the market value of the house or your council tax band, but the cost of rebuilding it in the unlikely event of its complete destruction in a fire or a flood.

Working out that figure is not easy. The rebuilding cost depends on the area you live in (London has the highest rebuilding costs, Northern Ireland the lowest), the type of property (detached houses are cheaper to rebuild than terraces) and the age of the house (pre-1920 houses are the most expensive).

To help you in the calculation, the Association of British Insurers this week issued new ready reckoner tables. First you have to calculate the floor space of your house, including external walls, then look it up on the ABI grid. Sadly, but rather inevitably, my house, a pre-1920 London terrace, occupied the corner of the grid with the highest rebuild cost, at £998 per square metre. That compares to the cheapest rate, £549 per square metre for a semi built between 1946-1979 in region four, which includes the North East, West Midlands and Wales.

It's a tedious task working out what your sum insured should be, but an essential one. For each £1,000 of rebuilding cost, insurers will charge you an annual premium of between £1.00 and £3.50.

Exactly what rate you get depends largely on your postcode, which reflects the risk of subsidence in your area. For example, Aberdeen, built on rock-solid granite, has the UK's lowest buildings insurance premiums. Soft and shrinking London clay results in hefty subsidence claims - and hefty buildings insurance premiums.

A string of freak weather conditions in the late 80s and early 90s sent subsidence claims soaring and insurers have been trying to recoup the cost ever since, even though the number of claims levelled off in the mid-90s.

Richard Playle of brokers Playle Russell says insurers are trying to push through increases this year of up to 25%, but says that he expects average premiums to rise by around 5% to 10%.

But subsidence, although the chief factor, is only one of many that insurers will take into account before quoting you a premium. Others include:

Trees. Willows, in particular, can devastate a home's foundation, and should be no closer than 40m to your house. Insurers do not like trees any nearer than 10m to your walls.

Age. Some insurers won't offer buildings cover to under 30-year-olds, and premiums are always higher for under 25-year-olds. The thinking is that older people take more care in looking after their houses.

Occupation. Certain occupations such as workers in the entertainment and sports industries are likely to be referred for special underwriting. So is anyone with a recent criminal record, although motoring offences don't count.

Claims record. Any claim made in the last three years will result in higher premiums. Failure to disclose previous claims against other insurers will invalidate your policy.

Security. Neighbourhood Watch membership, window locks, triple mortice door locks, external security lights, smoke alarms and fire blankets all help to reduce your premium. Areas with high crime rates are always up-rated - rebuilding broken door frames and locks is one of the major causes of buildings insurance claims.

Accidental damage. Standard accidental damage to porcelain bathroom fittings, oven hobs, etc is included in a buildings policy. Carpets are not. Most will want an extra premium for extended accidental damage cover to include items such as putting your foot through the ceiling when you are in the loft.

Excess. On typical policies you have to pay the first £50 of accidental damage and the first £1,000 of any subsidence claim. Accepting a higher excess will give you a lower premium.

The Association of British Insurers offers a free information sheet on buildings insurance plus a grid for calculating your sum insured. Write with an SAE to Kevin Wright, Public Affairs, Association of British Insurers, 51 Gresham Street, London EC2V 7HQ. It is also available at www.abi.org.uk

webTitle: Cracks are beginning to appear in the glass ceiling

fields.headline: Cracks are beginning to appear in the glass ceiling
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Opportunity Now campaign, which released its third annual Benchmarking Report and Index this week, reports a clear shift in workplace culture towards a level playing field for women.
fields.body:
The Opportunity Now campaign, which released its third annual Benchmarking Report and Index this week, reports a clear shift in workplace culture towards a level playing field for women. The campaign, which is now supported by 350 UK employers, was launched by Business in the Community in 1991 to tackle the under-representation of women in UK boardrooms.

While the number of women in the boardroom is not rising (8% of executive directors), more women can now be found in junior and middle management ranks. As a next generation of decision makers and board directors, Opportunity Now sees this as a crucial achievement.

The bad news is that only a handful of employers monitor the number of women from minority ethnic communities they employ, leaving no basis on which to work towards a truly diverse workforce representative of customers. The full report priced £35 is available from the Opportunity Now office, tel: 020 7317 2246.

Some 400 delegates will gather in Southport this weekend for this year's TUC Black Workers' conference. Delegates will debate motions dealing with a wide range of employment issues from institutional racism to more detailed sectoral and industrial problems.

A report entitled Black, Unionised and Better Paid will be launched to coincide with the conference. It demonstrates that average hourly wages for black and Asian workers who are covered by collective bargaining work out at £8.95 but only £6.77 an hour for those not covered by union agreements.

The research is based on an analysis of the autumn 1998 Labour Force Survey and 1998 Workplace Employee Relations Survey and was prepared by the Centre for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics.

The University of East London (UEL), through its new Thames Gateway Technology Centre (TGTC), is helping graduate entrepreneurs to make that leap from the lecture hall to the market place. The TGTC is home to a dozen companies which have moved into its incubator units for start-up businesses. The centre is holding a free one-day workshop for start-ups on April 19 at the UEL's Docklands Campus. Details on 020 8223 3321/3388 or go to www.tgtc.co.uk

fields.headline: Confident of success
fields.standfirst:
If I Ruled the World
CCA, Glasgow
****
fields.trailText:
If I Ruled the World
CCA, Glasgow
****
fields.body:
Over in Edinburgh, the British Art Show is raising vexing questions about art and life. Already the organisers have stated that the "British" bit of the title is anachronistic and will not be used again. Wandering round the eight galleries, it can indeed be hard to see what yokes together artists such as David Hockney and the young Glaswegian Jim Lambie. Place, history, culture, humour? Do any of these now hold up as nationally shared attributes?

Maybe not for the giant British Art Show, but in Glasgow there is a group exhibition all about place and identity - rootedness wherever you might be from.

If I Ruled the World is a kind of Summer Holiday of an exhibition, except that artists-turned-curators Ross Sinclair and Bryndis Snaebjornsdottir are driving the bus, instead of Cliff Richard.

Commissioned by the CCA, a group of Glasgow-based artists travelled to Reykjavik last year for an exhibition at the Living Art Museum. They soaked up the Icelandic vibes and made work shaped and inspired by the country. Then they came home and made more work, influenced as much by their travels as by their homecoming.

The result is a sharp, engaging show which provides us with more evidence of the flourishing Scottish art scene. There are names from the Becks Futures show at the ICA and BA5 - including Roddy Buchanan, Simon Starling and Martin Boyce - but there are others too.

The others include Claire Barclay and Clara Ursitti. Their joint project is informed by their research into women and salmon fishing, which was prompted by the fact that a woman, Georgina Ballantine, still holds the British salmon fishing record. This might not sound like the most promising of starting points, but the result - a lush, watery installation featuring a floor-level waterbed from which you can watch glossy, green, underwater film - gorgeously makes its point about how women's achievements get lost in the shadows of history.

Two noisy show-stealers give the exhibition its mighty confidence. These are Roddy Buchanan's Brazil v Italy (a way-too-loud burst of brass band national anthems without explanation or context) and Ross Sinclair's Real Life installation, a makeshift cardboard structure in sharp contrast to the high-ceilinged refinement of the galleries. Neon-lit and with a pulpit we can all take turns in speaking from, Real Life pumps out the crooning joy of Tony Bennett, with the song that lends its title to the show. "My world would wear a smile on its face", he sings.

While in Edinburgh brows are furrowed about Britishness, in Glasgow they are smiling and feeling uncomplicatedly at home.
Until 20 May. Details: 0141-332 7521.

webTitle: Look before you let, and then think long-term

fields.headline: Look before you let, and then think long-term
fields.trailText: The rush of private investors eager to snap up properties to rent out is now over, say property experts. Buyers looking to take advantage of buy-to-let mortgage deals to make a quick buck are selling up.
fields.body:
The rush of private investors eager to snap up properties to rent out is now over, say property experts. Buyers looking to take advantage of buy-to-let mortgage deals to make a quick buck are selling up.

But that leaves the field clear for long-term investors. Experts say the good times will return and this year could witness a rise in rents of up to 5%.

Rowena Wild of Chestertons Residential predicts that many younger people will return to the renting as house prices rise out of the reach of many first-time buyers.

Buy-to-let mortgages allow buyers to purchase properties with a view to earning a monthly income. Loans are granted with more of an eye to the ability to pay each month from the rental income flow than from more usual credit concepts such as borrower's income and other commitments.

But when the market became flooded with poor quality properties, amateur landlords were left struggling to let flats and houses. Every month a property is left empty is a "void", in lettings lingo, putting extra strain on the ability to pay off the loan and interest.

Landlords with a financial cushion can ride out the bad times and keep paying the mortgage. "These in for the long stretch will rely on the fact that in the mid- to long-term the value of their capital investment will increase," Ms Wild says.

Her company, which has offices all over London, reported at the end of last year that landlords had been forced to drop rents to achieve speedy letting. It followed this with a forecast that short-term opportunists would abandon the market, leaving it to serious investors.

John Lee, national sales manager at Halifax mortgage services, agrees. "Buy-to-let is very much a long-term investment," he says. "Investors should allow for one and probably two months a year of voids."

It is now a case of look before you let. Mr Lee advises those still willing to take the plunge to restrict their borrowings to 65% of the purchase price if they need to rely on the rent to cover mortgage payments.

Interest rate rises are keenly felt by the buy-to-let investor, says Ray Boulger at brokers John Charcol: "A year ago nearly all our clients were getting fixed rates which were usually under 6% for five and 10 years, now they are 7% to 7.5%. Whereas a year ago we were recommending fixed rates, now people are taking two-year tracker or discounted products and waiting until the fixes come down."

John Charcol's buy-to-let best buy mortgages include a deal from Legal & General, which is offering 6.99%, fixed-rate flexible mortgage under which borrowers can make unlimited penalty-free part redemptions; and one from NatWest, which is offering 6.75%. although the interest rate increases for borrowers applying for more than 60% of the loan to value.

And Clydesdale's 7.24% fixed for five years with a redemption penalty of six months' interest in five years, is also on the buy list.

 Before plunging into buy-to-let, try to get hold of a copy of The Complete Guide to Letting Property (Kogan Page). Written by Liz Hodgkinson - who rents out a number of properties herself, it's full of advice on everything from finding a property to finance via marketing and the tricky matter of finding tenants who won't be troublesome. The £8.99 cover price could be repaid thousands of times over.

fields.headline: Pay now, save later
fields.standfirst: Flexible loans are proving as popular here as they are in their native Australia, reports Sandra Grandison
fields.trailText: Flexible loans are proving as popular here as they are in their native Australia, reports Sandra Grandison.
fields.body:
The chance to repay your 25-year mortgage within 10 or 15 years, saving thousands in interest payments, is the best reason for the growing popularity of flexi-loans.

A truly flexible mortgage allows you to make overpayments and underpayments without penalty and, if you have built up enough credit in your account, the chance to take payment holidays.

If you have made overpayments, you can often borrow the money back again with no penalties, charges, setup fees or valuations. Another important feature is that interest is calculated daily or monthly, not annually in arrears.

This means overpayments have an immediate impact on the interest you pay. If you regularly make overpayments, this can significantly reduce the term of the loan.

The idea originated in Australia. Yorkshire Bank, a subsidiary of National Australia Bank, claims to have been the first lender to bring the product in Britain.

fields.headline: Sterling advice
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: With Easter and two bank holidays rapidly approaching, many of us are thinking of going away. A few hours searching for a deal will help ensure a stress-free holiday. Better still, it will save you money. And many companies let you buy over the internet, giving you instant cover.
fields.body:
It's that time of year again. With Easter and two bank holidays rapidly approaching, many of us are thinking of going away. The Association of British Travel Agents says around 1.5m Brits will be going abroad next weekend - so the chances are that this weekend will not be spent shopping around for the best travel insurance deal or lowest commission rate on travellers cheques.

However, a few hours searching for a deal will help ensure a stress-free holiday. Better still, it will save you money. And many companies let you buy over the internet, giving you instant cover.

Most insurers will give you an online quote if you fill in a form on their website. Search engines will lead you to the company's homepage, but you might want to visit www.find.co.uk first. It contains shortcuts to most of the country's best known insurers.

If you don't want to fill out endless online forms, but want to compare different companies' prices, a broker like www.screentrade.co.uk is probably a better bet.

Alternatively, pop into a high street branch or call the companies' sales lines. The time it takes to arrange cover will vary from insurer to insurer, but most will be able to sign, seal and deliver before you head off.

It's worth considering an annual policy, too. A search on www.screentrade.co.uk showed that a single trip policy for one person travelling to Western Europe would cost between £25 and £40. Annual or multi-trip policies start from £43 a year for Europe-only cover and £63 a year for the whole world.

There are also big savings to be made on foreign currency. The question of which method of payment - cash, travellers cheques or plastic - to take is one that has long plagued the holiday maker.

The simple answer is that it's best to take all three. But, at least, consider the relative benefits of each before making up your mind.

Cash is the cheapest and the most convenient, but is also the easiest to lose, and once gone, is gone forever. You can get foreign currency by changing sterling at the bank or bureau de change, or by taking it out of cash machines using credit and debit cards while on holiday. All methods incur a charge, so compare these.

Typical charges for changing sterling into foreign currency are between 1% and 2%. However, Marks & Spencer Financial Services and Travelex offer currency commission-free if you pre-order it. And, if you act before April 22, Thomas Cook will also change the money without commission.

By far the most common credit card charge is 2.75% on each transaction, although some issuers take less. This charge is additional to any charges incurred in the UK and includes a fee to the card issuer, ie your bank or building society, a fee to the credit card company, and a levy on the currency exchange costs. The Irish banks, Bank of Cyprus and Sainsbury's have a good track record of charging less than 2% on foreign currency transactions. Nationwide appears to be the only household name which doesn't charge anything.

The charge might seem high - and it is levied on all credit card purchases, not just cash withdrawals - but credit cards have the advantage of being very convenient.

Bank and debit cards like Switch are also a good choice, as long as they contain the Cirrus, Maestro or Visa Plus sign. Cirrus can be used to get cash from 400,000 machines in 100 countries.

Typical total charges of between 3% and 5% make travellers cheques the most expensive way of getting money, but if you lose them, they can usually be replaced in 24 hours. And if you have any left at the end of the holiday, most issuers buy them back for free.

Your bank account may entitle you to special deals on the cheques. Some companies, like Marks & Spencer Financial Services, provide cheques commission-free all the time. Just remember to make sure you're getting a good exchange rate as well.

Whichever method you choose, the strong pound will make your money go further. Thomas Cook calculates that you can get around 11% more foreign currency now than you could this time last year, so your holiday should be cheaper than before. The question is: will you use the savings to buy travel insurance?

fields.headline: Home in on big rewards
fields.trailText: Everyone's mortgage has gone up this month. And that applies whether the loan is a discount, a cashback, a standard variable, a fixed rate or one of any of the other types of home loan.The culprit is the chancellor of the exchequer who ordered the axing of Miras - the mortgage interest tax relief.
fields.body:
Everyone's mortgage has gone up this month. And that applies whether the loan is a discount, a cashback, a standard variable, a fixed rate or one of any of the other types of home loan.

The culprit is the chancellor of the exchequer who ordered the axing of Miras - the mortgage interest tax relief - which took effect at most lenders from April 1 even though it was not officially abolished until April 6.

The effect is that all mortgages of £30,000 or more went up by between £16 and £18 a month - a sum greater than the savings generated by the 1p in the pound basic-rate income tax cut for wage earners on typical salaries.

But the home loan rises do not stop there. Increases are likely for those on variable rate loans next month - borrowers should enjoy the bonus of no Bank of England action on interest levels this month while they can as this relief may be short-lived. All this is a long way from hopes some 18 months ago of rates moving downwards to converge with the euro-currency zone.

Homebuyers can fight back, however. A vital theme of this special report is the ability to swap one home loan for another without having to move home.

Remortgaging has become an increasingly popular way of reducing monthly payments - either by aiming for a flexible loan which enables borrowers to reduce the ultimate cost by cutting down the amount borrowed more quickly than in the original schedule, or through a discount-style loan that reduces the payments, or via a fixed rate which gives certainty for the future even if it does not guarantee you will always pay less.

Borrowers appear to split into two camps. The minority but fast-growing group consists of those who remortgage at every opportunity, taking advantage of offers to pay all or most of the legal costs to switch whenever they see an opportunity to cut costs without incurring disproportionate penalties.

And then there is the majority. They stick with their lenders even when they are paying over the odds. For some, this is out of a sense of loyalty - if so, they should ask what their mortgage company is doing to earn this. Certainly, paying more for a loan than a new customer is not a high recommendation.

For others, the lack of action can be put down to "inertia", that polite term for laziness. Inertia is, of course, the best friend of the financial services industry's propensity to treat existing customers worse than those it wants to attract.

The beauty of remortgaging is that homebuyers can do it at their own pace, devoting as much time as they want - unlike applying for a first loan on a property on house purchase when you may have scores of other worries such as selling a previous property or raising the deposit.

Many lenders and brokers take advantage of first-time borrowers to hassle them into buying an unsuitable loan. There is little regulation of mortgage advice for either first mortgages or remortgages. Sellers are under no obligation to consider your best interests.

The Council of Mortgage Lenders claims "taking into account both interest payments and charges, UK mortgages are among the most competitive". They have, the council adds, a high rating for "innovation".

But much of that innovation has been in areas that leave customers baffled. This "confusion marketing" has taken the shape of penalty payments, compulsory insurances and small print charges to cash in on unwary customers.

All this has led to allegations that the mortgage companies are part of "rip-off" Britain. Needless to say, the lenders themselves reject these charges.

Now, after some prodding from the government, lenders are preparing to offer Cat mortgages - loans where charges, access and terms are within set, government-approved standards.

To gain the Cat mark, loans will have to be free of any compulsory tie-in purchase, so out go high-price house and contents insurance, overpriced and all too often unnecessary redundancy cover.

Hidden charges will have to go for qualifying loans. Lenders will no longer be able to hit borrowers with penalties that extend beyond the life of the loan. It will be the end for great plans whose early promise turns into long-term nightmare as customers are forced to carry on in a high-cost variable rate loan. Discounts and cashbacks, originally banned, will be allowed. Interest rates must not go more than 2% above the bank base rate - not difficult as most of the expensive deals are currently within 1.74% of the 6% base.

And annual interest calculations where the amount you repay is only deducted once every 12 months are banned in favour of the daily calculation model used in "Aussie"-style flexible mortgages. Most of the big lenders are likely to have Cat standard mortgages by midsummer, giving loan purchasers a new feeling of confidence.

Whether brokers will sell them is another matter. The Cat rules say they cannot make a specific charge for advice on a loan. The fear is many will either steer borrowers to unsuitable deals or try to force them to buy unwanted endowment plans.

webTitle: Lifting an employer's head out of the sand

fields.headline: Lifting an employer's head out of the sand
fields.standfirst:
Whether you work for an 'ostrich' or 'greatest asset' organisation, an HR influence at top level is needed, says Professor Clive Morton
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Ten thousand people attended the Institute of Personnel and Development's first human resources (HR) development conference of the new millennium. But what is HR?
fields.body:
Ten thousand people attended the Institute of Personnel and Development's first human resources (HR) development conference of the new millennium. But what is HR?

There has been a continual debate among professionals over the most appropriate title for the "people business". It was and has been personnel, it later became human resources (or as some wags dubbed it human remains), sometimes human capital. At its heart HR is about human relationships. The label is in one sense insignificant, but the search indicates a profession seeking a strong identity and confirmation of role.

The good news is that the IPD has at last been granted chartered status by the Privy Council, putting the profession on a par with chartered accountants for instance, and making the IPD the third largest professional organisation in the UK.

Even more significantly, organisations are beginning to realise that people form, on average, 70% of the assets of a company - the intellectual capital as it is known. Unlike fixed assets, this crucial contributor can walk out of the door, switch off or simply not realise its potential, causing uncompetitiveness and/or decline.

HR has struggled for role recognition and now at the dawn of the 21st century it has arrived - or has it?

Very few of the FTSE 100 companies have HR directors on their main board, yet all recognise the crucial contribution of people and the importance of their development. However, the presence of HR directors is not the issue; it is whether the HR agenda is adopted by the corporate decision makers. So what is this agenda? What are the most important issues for HR that companies need to pursue for competitiveness and sustainability?

The holy grail is linking HR strategy to business strategy. It is only recently that this issue has been seen as relevant, aided by the shift towards process driven strategy whereby a wider range of people get connected to evolving strategy in enlightened organisations as opposed to the traditional "ivory tower" approach of more hidebound companies.

HR has to demonstrate that HR strategy contributes to long-term development, either through good people having potential to expand the business or by involvement policies enhancing corporate performance.

People strategies shape what sort of employer you are. Kelvin Delaney of PricewaterhouseCoopers proposes that employers can neatly fit into a number of categories. "Ostriches" see staff as only a cost to be minimised rather than amassed which will provide competitive advantage if developed and deployed effec tively. "Action not words" sounds positive but probably means too many initiatives with no structure or sense of purpose. "Greatest asset" organisations may be perceived as strong on rhetoric but weak on delivery. And "employers of choice" are organisations which are seen as doing the right things for good business reasons.

According to Kelvin Delaney, less than a third of companies surveyed in conjunction with Investors in People have a people management strategy. Small wonder, then, at the widening gulf in productivity between the UK and our continental neighbours.

Another important issue in people management concerns diversity. This to some extent has got lost in "what we ought to do" to fulfil the requirements of equal opportunities law rather than the compelling argument leading to a creative, competitive organisation.

HR should hammer home the business benefit of implementing decent diversity policies. Then in the current new economy paradigm, there is maximising intellectual capital. Karl Marx was right: labour does own capital, although not quite in the sense that he had imagined, with 70% of assets existing in the brains of people, including those of suppliers and customers.

What is different about that conclusion today is our understanding that knowledge makes the difference. We've always had brilliant people doing brilliant things but in their specialist, "silo" mentality areas. Today the challenge for corporate sustainability is to get the knowledge in the brains of employees shared across corporate boundaries.

Everybody agrees short-termism undermines future success. HR can help the balance between short term and long term by encouraging the wider stakeholder approach. The key is to link the development of the individual, the organisation and the community in a virtuous circle, not a vicious circle where the individual feels the victim of change, the organisation cannot see beyond tomorrow and the community is totally confused about direction.

However, all of the above can be undone by thoughtless, under-trained executives. This is a difficult area for HR, particularly if it is not represented on the board. However, it has to be tackled, as corporate failures, mergers that don't deliver and alliances that founder can often be traced to dysfunctional, under-developed boards.

 Professor Clive Morton OBE, who has been HR director at Anglian Water, Rolls-Royce IPG and Komatsu UK, leads the Morton Partnership, specialising in organisational development and sustainability. He can be contacted at clive.n.morton@talk21.com
