webTitle: Welcome to webworld, you really can survive

fields.headline: Welcome to webworld, you really can survive
fields.standfirst:
The salaries are climbing fast and the demand is there, so why haven't you got yourself a job on an internet start-up yet? Perhaps, like many, you believe your old-style skills are not what's required in this brave new world. But, as John Crace reports, a touch of creative thinking could result in a new career
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The salaries are climbing fast and the demand is there, so why haven't you got yourself a job on an internet start-up yet? Perhaps, like many, you believe your old-style skills are not what's required in this brave new world. But a touch of creative thinking could result in a new career
fields.body:
Dot.coms may have come off their recent stock market ratings but the flow of jobs available in internet start-ups shows no sign of tailing off. But what if you are an offline person who has never worked on an internet project or in a hi-tech environment - can you use your skills to hop on to the internet bandwagon? And will you be paid any more, or fobbed off with spurious share option schemes?

It is still bonanza time for internet job hunters. Check out the classified section of any national newspaper and you will find any number of situations vacant for positions in the internet industry. The even better news is that, although there is a growing influx of web literate graduates moving directly into dot.com world, net businesses are still struggling to fill their vacancies.

"It used to be the case that you got five applications for every job," says Selvei Aroldoff, who works in human resources for Organic, a US-owned company specialising in developing all aspects of online activity for businesses and whose clients include Boo.com, BT.com, Daimler Chrysler, Blockbuster and Chase Manhattan. "Now it feels as if there are five jobs for every applicant."

Organic itself is not immune to this syndrome. The company opened its London office in May last year with five staff; it now has more than 70 employees and is looking to expand still further. But like everyone else it is struggling to find the right people.

One thing's for sure, though. It's not the money that's putting people off. Long gone are the days when dot.coms were a synonym for underpayment. An analysis of comparative rates of pay in the online and offline sectors suggests that, quite apart from any company equity or share options on offer, basic salaries are up to 25% higher for equivalent positions online. Marketing consultants and business analysts who might be earning as little as £15,000 in the old economy can expect up to £60,000 in the new.

For graphic designers the salary range leaps from £10,000-£30,000 to £20,000-£50,000; for journalists the salary bracket rises from £10,000-£40,000 to £18,000-£50,000. And it's the same story for architects, IT engineers, accountancy, sales, PR and most of the other specialisms you care to mention.

Take advertising. "There are 300 new internet start-ups each week and they all need experienced account plan ners, marketers and advertising creatives," says Vincent Sheppard, managing director of newmediaHR, an advertising recruitment company for e-businesses. "There is a severe skills shortage in these areas and those who move can expect much higher salaries; for instance an account planner with two years experience can up their basic salary from £30,000 to £40,000."

However, those who do make the move often face a steep learning curve. "Even experienced creatives and account planners have to learn the new terminology and business matrices, such as cpm (clicks per mille - a method of determining payments for banner ads) and the effectiveness of interstitial adverts," Mr Sheppard continues. But, such is the demand for advertising personnel, newmediaHR goes out of its way to make the transition as painless as possible by offering potential applicants 12 hours free training, spread over four evenings, to get them up to speed.

Ms Aroldoff believes one of the main reasons that the new economy is failing to attract applicants in sufficient numbers is that most people working in conventional businesses do not have the imagination to appreciate how their skills can be transferred to web-based activities.

"They look at an ad, read the job description and automatically think they can't do it," she says. "We want to encourage people to look at the bigger picture, to have the confidence to see beyond your traditional role. Think laterally about your skills and come and talk to us about where you might fit in. It could well be that you apply for a strategic position but end up working in new media."

In webworld, every traditional job has an online equivalent - provided you're prepared to think creatively. So real-world architects morph into information architects, the people who decide how best to arrange webpage content, journalists become online editors, graphic designers become web designers and business consultants turn into interactive strategists. It is a world of apparent plenty, though the differential between online and offline salaries gradually disappears the higher you climb up the dot.com ladder.

Louise Campbell is the managing director of Venture Partnership, an executive search company for senior dot.com personnel with starting salaries in excess of £70,000. "Two years ago, there were far fewer e-business opportunities," she says, "and those wanting to take them were expected to take a cut in basic salary for the privilege, though they might well also have been offered a share of the company in comparison. These days, there are more dot.com openings and applicants can be far pickier, with the result that salaries have increased to the offline market rate."

Among the key positions currently proving trickiest to fill are marketing directors, content directors and chief technology officers, though Ms Campbell offers an important caveat. "Internet companies are still recruiting these personnel from offline businesses," she says, "but by this time next year this window may have closed and recruitment may be limited to those with internet experience."

So if you fancy your chances online, the message is clear. Do it now. But be careful of what you are getting into. Not every dot.com is rock solid, and even those with business plans that ap pear to be fireproof can fail. Very few internet companies offer pensions, and stock options and a mega starting salary will mean very little if the company goes under within a year. But there again, you might just think: "Who cares if the dot.com I'm working for goes down?" There are five more queueing up round the corner to pick up the fallout.

How to choose the right dot.com

Find out who the backers are and who is lending their name to the business.

Find out what stage of funding the business has reached. If it is still at venture capital stage then ask who they are and what their track record is.

Ask yourself how solid the basic business idea is. What is the business plan and is it realistic?

There is no such thing as an original business idea, so its success or failure will depend largely on who else is working for the company. Find out exactly who these people are.

Know the risk

Low : a traditional offline business that is looking to develop its online activities.

Medium : a start-up that has successfully floated in the US and is looking to launch in this country.

High : a UK start-up with no track record.

webTitle: Are you sure you want flexibility?

fields.headline: Are you sure you want flexibility?
fields.standfirst: Ian Wylie weighs up the pleasure and possible pain of current account loans
fields.trailText: Ian Wylie weighs up the pleasure and possible pain of current account loans.
fields.body:
Flexible mortgages are becoming commonplace as even the big lenders which said they could not cope with them have finally succumbed to the trend.

A number of banks such as Bank of Scotland and Legal & General offer flexible mortgages with chequebooks, allowing home buyers to "borrow back" amounts in accounts which are ahead of the agreed schedule. These normally put a £500 or £1,000 minimum on the sum withdrawn. They are intended for large purchase decisions.

But the current account mortgage (Cam) goes much further, linking a flexible mortgage to a replacement bank account you can use for everyday purchases.

They are controversial as you could easily build up a large amount of equity and then blow it all on a holiday. In some circumstances customers may never be free of their mortgage chains.

Like most other products that carry the flexible title, interest is calculated daily so any changes in your balance, for however short a period, change the interest payments.

You can make extra payments at any time, and of any amount, and it will reduce the interest you pay.

This facility allows you to pay off the mortgage early or arrange payment holidays where you pay less, or no money for a period of time.

But the distinguishing feature of a Cam is that it offers instant access to your mortgage account. You get a chequebook, cash card and a monthly statement to keep you on top of your finances. You can also arrange standing orders and direct debits.

Paying money into a Cam has advantages over salting it away in a savings account. By putting your savings into your Cam you pay less interest on your mortgage, say 8%, rather than gaining interest at, say, a taxed 3%.

You also avoid paying tax as technically you are not earning interest. Virgin Direct, one of only two lenders which offer Cams, reckons that over 30 years an average customer might pay £1m into a current account while an average bank account will pay only £40 interest on all that money.

Its Cam, which is offered with a credit-card facility, is called Virgin One.

First Active's current account mortgage is broadly similar, though there are a couple of significant differences. For example, First Active does not require borrowers to take the current account option, whereas Virgin obliges all borrowers to pay their salary into the loan account and pay their bills out of it.

That said, First Active claims that many people opting for its more traditional flexible mortgage are switching over to the current account loan later on.

And while First Active closes off the overdraft facility each month by the minimum repayment, helping people to keep a tab on their finances, Virgin does not. With Virgin One, borrowers also have the freedom to vary their payment frequency as they wish.

Neither lender makes any charge for arranging the mortgage, nor are there any redemption penalties or compulsory insurances. Current account mortgages can suit those with erratic incomes, the self-employed and the self-disciplined who want to pay their mortgages off quickly.

But the freedom offered by Cams also means you are free to get into trouble. They are complex to maintain and could be disastrous for some borrowers. Many of us, if we are honest, would need some one to stand over us and make sure we make capital repayments on a regular basis.

If borrowers are lulled into a false sense of security with Cams, some might end up never paying off their loans. Home buyers who keep on borrowing will face an increasingly steep repayment curve. A £5,000 car here, a £1,000 holiday there andbefore you know it, the mortgage debt has almost doubled.

Some mortgage advisers and lenders claim Cams may confuse many people and are best suited to the cautious and prudent, who will not let their debts run out of control. They say that selling current account mortgages on a no-advice, execution-only basis could be putting a millstone around borrowers' necks.

One of the country's most competitive mortgage lenders, the Chorley & District building society, has just launched a flexible mortgage, but it stopped short of offering a Cam because of such concerns.

"We believe that the vast majority of people would find it too easy to jack up their mortgage debt if it had a chequebook attached," says its chief executive, Stephen Bullock. "To run a current account mortgage safely, borrowers must have lots of time and discipline and we decided that the vast majority of people don't actually want that sort of product."

fields.headline: Get Egg on your Boots
fields.standfirst: A joint credit and loyalty card from a chemist and a bank is one of the web wonders discovered this week by Jessica McCallin
fields.trailText: Boots the Chemist and Egg, the internet banking arm of Prudential, have joined forces to offer the first combined credit and loyalty card from September.
fields.body:
Boots the Chemist and Egg, the internet banking arm of Prudential, have joined forces to offer the first combined credit and loyalty card from September.

The card will have the same 10.9% rate as Egg cards if bought over the internet, but applications over the phone and by post will incur a higher interest rate of 14.9%.

The card's launch is claimed to be the first time a mainstream financial service provider has used smart cards, which contain microchips, as a way of cut ting down the amount of plastic customers have to carry around. The dual function is thought to be one of its main selling points.

Wannabe share dealers have now got even more places to go for price information. Teletext is to list real-time share prices for 3,000 of the London Stock Exchange's most popular shares.

And financial services firm TD Waterhouse has launched an interactive share information service called TV Broker. The service will be offered initially through Cable & Wireless and Telewest and will be available to around 1 million customers with digital set top boxes by the end of the year. Both services are free.

If online share dealing isn't your cup of tea, how about a venture capital trust (VCT)? Downing Corporate Finance is launching an internet-focused trust called i-NET VCT into which individuals can invest. The company says the trust should interest small investors because it lets them spread risk over a number of different internet companies and comes with 20% income tax relief in the tax year monies are invested.

NewMedia SPARK and GlobalNet Financial are to start distributing equities and equity-related securities over the internet. The two partners run their business through the electronic offering platform EO and recently received regulatory approval from the Securities and Futures Authority. It will specialise in initial public offerings.

If you want to manage all your finances from one place, Investec's new online service may prove useful. Through its subsidiary Investec Connect, the bank is offering a web-based personal finance management product which lets users bring information about all their financial products together. The service is based on Quicken Online.

Little Fella, the computer-animated man featured in First Direct's adverts, is now giving customers online internet advice. Once down loaded, Little Fella suggests websites you might want to visit, based on your mood and emotions. Telling him you want to do something very adventurous, for example, could result in him suggesting a safari holiday.

Thinking of getting a divorce? Make sure you get a fair share of your about to be ex-partner's share options. Accountants Hacker Young, say shares and share options are likely to become an increasingly common part of pay packets. And if your partner's shares are in the dot.com or hi-tech sector, their potential earnings could be huge. As such, what might seem like a generous chunk of the shares now could look like peanuts in a few years time - so get good advice.

Online insurance broker Screentrade will guarantee that its prices are the lowest in the market or will refund the difference if you find something cheaper elsewhere. The price pledge comes after the web service, which offers home, car and holiday insurance, announced growth of 35% a month in recent times.

Private Medical Insurance Consultants has launched a website which will explain the benefits of private cover while helping you with the process of applying for it and buying it. Among other things, the website explores differing premium rates, costs associated with the cover and the types of facilities available in hospital. It is designed to be accessible to the average internet user rather than someone with experience of financial sites.

webTitle: Shares will not always be safe as houses

fields.headline: Shares will not always be safe as houses
fields.standfirst:
As baby-boomers start drawing their pensions around 2010, share prices may well be driven down, reports Patrick Collinson
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: As baby-boomers start drawing their pensions around 2010, share prices may well be driven down, reports Patrick Collinson.
fields.body:
As Clement Atlee cleared away the last vestiges of post-war rationing and austerity in 1950 few could have guessed that Britain stood on the brink of a stock market bonanza, or that government bonds, safe as houses during the deflationary 20s and 30s, would turn out to be an investment disaster.

An investment of £100 in shares in 1950 grew to £88,896 by the end of 1999, or £3,896 after inflation is stripped out. But £100 put into government bonds - known as gilts - would have risen to just £3,316, or a paltry £145 after being adjusted for inflation.

The figures come from Barclays Capital, which this week issued its annual equity-gilt study. It shows that in every decade since the war, the average annual return on equities has beaten the return from gilts, often by a large margin.

Surprisingly, the figures show that the shares bonanza was even bigger in the 50s than it has been in the last two decades. The three best years on the UK stock market in the last half century (barring the freak year of 1975) were 1959, 1958 and 1954.

In 1959 the stock market went up 54.8% - far ahead of the biggest increase in the last decade, 1993, when the market went up 27.5%. The freak years were 1973-1975, when the figures were distorted by runaway inflation and the near-complete, if very brief, collapse in the stock market. In 1973, the market fell 28%, slumped another 50% in 1974, then jumped 149% in 1975. Since 1975 the stock market has recorded a year-on-year fall only twice - in 1990 and 1994.

Barclays has produced its equity-gilt study for 45 years, and every year the message to investors is that buying shares rather than bonds is a no-brainer. The other message is that it is crucial to reinvest any dividends from your investments. Reinvestment of dividends makes up around half of the long-term gain on shares.

But the report cannot hide the fact that the figures on government bonds have started to look a lot better in recent decades.

Last year was a grim year for gilts, which dropped 3.5% in value. Likewise, it was a grim year for buyers of corporate bond Peps, which saw reversals of around 10%. But 1999 was only the second year in the past two decades in which the value of gilts fell. As inflation has dropped back from its peak in the 70s, and fallen to what many economists believe is near-permanent low levels, gilts have sparkled. In five out of the last eight years, they have given investors returns exceeding 15% a year.

Barclays believes that such superb gilt returns are a one-off adjustment to low inflation and are unlikely to be repeated over the next decade. But it is keeping its faith with shares, despite the stratospheric levels that equities have reached on most traditional valuation measures.

"We have plenty of reasons to be optimistic," it says. First computers and now the internet have speeded up the rate of technological change (and therefore economic growth) while the worldwide web in effect automates the process of change, by disseminating information almost immediately.

But rapid technological change will make stock markets far more speculative, as one hi-tech bubble is supplanted by the next. "The outlook is close to perfect for equities... but the rapid pace of innovation will ensure that equity markets will retain a strongly speculative character: cycling through booms, busts, panics and manias with an unprecedented frequency," opines Barclays Capital director Tim Bond.

But before you pile your money into shares, Barclays adds a very big caveat to its predictions about future returns. The big caveat is that Britain is ageing rapidly and the population will even start falling in the 2030s and 2040s. Right now it doesn't matter - it's positive for stock markets, as the post-war baby-boomers (now in their 40s) save hard for their retirement. That money goes into pension plans and thence on to the stock market, chasing share prices upwards.

The pain comes when the baby boomers start retiring - and the crunch point will be some time after 2010. Then the pension companies will have to start selling shares to pay out pensions, pushing share prices downwards.

Barclays says: "The demographics are good for 10 years. After 2010, demographics become less friendly for financial markets as the growth in the labour force slows or reverses and as dependency ratios rise in line with the ageing of the population."

So what does that mean for your pension? One thing for sure is that the spectacular total pension pot figures given in some projections are unlikely to be achieved.

A second point is that today's 30-year-olds ought not to rely on share investments alone, and should look at property investment as a supplement. While a prolonged sell-off of shares to pay income to pensioners will depress share prices, when we are all elderly we will still need somewhere to live.

The other message is that it is crucial to reinvest any dividends from your investments. Reinvestment of dividends makes up around half of the long-term gain on shares. But the report cannot hide the fact that the figures on government bonds have started to look a lot better in recent decades. Last year was a grim year for gilts, which dropped 3.5% in value. Likewise, it was a grim year for buyers of corporate bond Peps, which saw reversals of around 10%. But 1999 was only the second year in the past two decades in which the value of gilts fell. As inflation has dropped back from its peak in the 70s, and fallen to what many economists believe is near-permanent low levels, gilts have sparkled. In five out of the last eight years, they have given investors returns exceeding 15% a year. Barclays believes that such superb gilt returns are a one-off adjustment to low inflation and are unlikely to be repeated over the next decade. But it is keeping its faith with shares, despite the stratospheric levels that equities have reached on most traditional valuation measures. "We have plenty of reasons to be optimistic," it says. First computers and now the internet have speeded up the rate of technological change (and therefore economic growth) while the worldwide web in effect automates the process of change, by disseminating information almost immediately. But rapid technological change will make stock markets far more speculative, as one hi-tech bubble is supplanted by the next. "The outlook is close to perfect for equities... but the rapid pace of innovation will ensure that equity markets will retain a strongly speculative character: cycling through booms, busts, panics and manias with an unprecedented frequency," opines Barclays Capital director Tim Bond. But before you pile your money into shares, Barclays adds a very big caveat to its predictions about future returns. The big caveat is that Britain is ageing rapidly and the population will even start falling in the 2030s and 2040s. Right now it doesn't matter - it's positive for stock markets, as the post-war baby-boomers (now in their 40s) save hard for their retirement. That money goes into pension plans and thence on to the stock market, chasing share prices upwards. The pain comes when the baby boomers start retiring - and the crunch point will be some time after 2010. Then the pension companies will have to start selling shares to pay out pensions, pushing share prices downwards. Barclays says: "The demographics are good for 10 years. After 2010, demographics become less friendly for financial markets as the growth in the labour force slows or reverses and as dependency ratios rise in line with the ageing of the population." So what does that mean for your pension? One thing for sure is that the spectacular total pension pot figures given in some projections are unlikely to be achieved. A second point is that today's 30-year-olds ought not to rely on share investments alone, and should look at property investment as a supplement. While a prolonged sell-off of shares to pay income to pensioners will depress share prices, when we are all elderly we will still need somewhere to live.

fields.headline: The best medicine
fields.standfirst:
After Ronnie Reagan cost him a top job in the US, Jim Braithwaite founded the multi-media company that was to make him a millionaire. Julian Lee on an Epic story
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: After Ronnie Reagan cost him a top job in the US, Jim Braithwaite founded the multi-media company that was to make him a millionaire. Julian Lee on an Epic story.
fields.body:
If Jim Brathwaite has anyone to thank for his big break it has to be former US president Ronald Reagan. Mr Brathwaite had just been offered a top job in a multi-national American drugs company when Reaganomics was launched.

"America suddenly became for the Americans and the company just couldn't get me a work permit," says Mr Brathwaite, who still recalls the disappointment he felt.

Had he gone to the US, undoubtedly he would have risen through the ranks of the corporate world. Now he would be well on his way to getting the golden handshake that is due to long-serving senior executives.

But he didn't. Instead he and two friends, one a pharmacist, the other a TV producer, decided to set up a company making and marketing corporate videos for the medical profession.

"It was in the early 80s at about the time of satellite TV and dishes and I could see the power of what multimedia technology and interactive TV could do," he recalls.

As more drugs came on to the domestic market more training and sales expertise was required. Rather than invest in more staff to do the talking, the drugs companies welcomed the idea of videos to explain to their sales force and customers the benefits - both medicinal and commercial - that their new drugs offered.

The company they launched in 1982 with a £7,000 bank loan was VPS. The first contract was to make a film for the German company Bayer for the launch of its new cardiovascular drug, Adalat.

Instead of using the conventional 16mm film, which was both costly and time consuming, they used the relatively new and cheaper medium of video. The 15-minute film, which went by the strange title of Calcium Antagonism, had an instant effect on the industry.

"The drugs companies realised that this way they could make at least two or three videos a year at a reduced cost," he says.

This was vitally important in the increasingly competitive environment of the pharmaceutical industry where getting a new product out into the market first often determined whether the drug would succeed or fail.

Adalat was to become one of Bayer's most successful prod ucts; VPS' reputation grew with it and the contracts soon followed. From there, the company grew to become a business which employed 25 people and had a turnover of £2m.

It eventually became the Epic Group and Mr Brathwaite was its chief executive up until three years ago when, after making the difficult de cision to withdraw from publishing, he was forced to step down after a sharp decline in the share price.

"On reflection I was all the wrong things; I was black and I didn't have any experience of this field or running my own business. All I had was this weird and wonderful visionary plan," he says.

Now a millionaire, Mr Brathwaite is running another business he started two years ago; the publicly listed multi-media company XL Entertainment. Just like Epic before, Brathwaite saw the potential of yet another emerging media - the internet.

XL commissions and makes television programmes for broadcast on television networks as well as on the internet. Mr Brathwaite teamed up with acclaimed children's TV producer Floella Benjamin to make a TV series called Jamboree for three to six-year-olds, which has become a successful multi-media programme that both entertains and educates children.

To date the video has sold more than 20,000 copies and with the merchandise deals, Jamboree has powered XL's growth.

Mr Brathwaite remembers how as a young man he yearned to get into the more glamorous field of marketing. As a graduate trainee in the accounting department of Beecham's he attended a lecture given by a Beecham's employee who had switched from accountancy to marketing. "I just saw this guy with the flash suit, the dapper hair and the nice car and thought he was making the decisions whereas we were just counting the score."

As a route to marketing, he spent the next two years as a sales rep for Beechams. He toured the Sussex countryside in his yellow Capri - nicknamed the flying banana by his colleagues - selling Amoxil and becoming one of the company's top salesmen. By then he had established a reputation as a gifted sales and marketing professional and was well on his way to success.

fields.headline: Blue/Orange
fields.standfirst:
Cottesloe Theatre, London
****
fields.trailText:
Cottesloe Theatre, London
****
fields.body:
Joe Penhall's exuberant new play lifts the curse that has afflicted the National's new-writing policy for the past three years. Very much in the manner of Shaw in The Doctor's Dilemma, Penhall uses the medical trade as a metaphor for the vanity, self-deception and ostentatious certainty of all professions that work against the common interest.

Penhall's setting is a psychiatric hospital where two doctors engage in a Darwinian battle for survival. The catalyst for their conflict is Christopher, a young black patient who believes that oranges are blue and that Idi Amin is his father. The senior consultant, Robert, wants him thrust back into the community; Bruce, a first-year junior doctor, argues with equal vehemence that Christopher needs further treatment. What follows is a ferocious contest of wills.

Part of Penhall's success lies in keeping one's sympathies shifting. One moment you think Bruce has a protective idealism; the next that Robert has a paternalistic common sense. Gradually it dawns on one that they are both more concerned with confirming their pet theories than with responding to the patient. Penhall makes the Shavian point that all professions are a conspiracy against the laity and eventually become wrapped in hermetic self-regard.

Credibility is sometimes stretched, as when Robert naively swallows the idea that his junior rival is on drugs. But Penhall has the gift of making serious points in a comic manner and of conveying moral indignation without preaching. He also gets the benefit of a finely tuned production by Roger Michell played on a slightly skewed, in-the-round stage in which William Dudley's clinical conference room is gradually reduced to chaos.

Bill Nighy is excellent as the senior consultant whose willowy assurance gives way to bursts of rage. There is equally good work from Andrew Lincoln as his junior and Chiwetel Ejiofor as the schizophrenic patient. Sympathy for the victim is matched by Penhall's stinging satire on the arrogant assurance of professionalism.
Box office: 0171-452 3000.

fields.headline: Galatasaray seek Wembley switch
fields.trailText: Galatasaray have asked for their Uefa Cup semi-final second leg against Leeds United to be switched to Wembley. The Turkish champions have written to Uefa to highlight concerns about the security of their players if the match is played at Elland Road.
fields.body:
Galatasaray have asked for their Uefa Cup semi-final second leg against Leeds United to be switched to Wembley. The Turkish champions have written to Uefa to highlight concerns about the security of their players if the match is played at Elland Road.

"If we have to go to England we are asking for the game to be played at Wembley," said Galatasaray's vice-president Mehmet Cansun. "The fans in Leeds are very close to the pitch and we believe Wembley would provide better security."

However, Uefa appeared set to rule that the tie must go ahead at Elland Road. "I do not think it is any longer an issue of holding it at Elland Road," said a spokesman for the governing body, Graham Turner. "It took us three months to organise a venue for the under-21 play-off between England and Yugoslavia.... We don't have a queue of clubs lining up to stage the match."

Uefa is due to announce today whether Turkish fans will be banned from next Thursday's match after the murder of two Leeds supporters in Istanbul last week. Leeds have been backed by the FA and West Yorkshire police.

Turkey yesterday asked Britain to prevent attacks on Turks and Turkish businesses in England. Turkey's sports minister Fikret Unlu said his government was ready to give "all kind of financial or moral" support to the families of the slain men. The Turkish business community has launched its own fund for the families with a donation of £60,000.

webTitle: Wise fined but the FA looks foolish

fields.headline: Wise fined but the FA looks foolish
fields.trailText: The FA got itself into a complete mess yesterday trying to adjudicate on the tunnel bust-up after the Chelsea v Wimbledon game in February. But Chelsea were still left with a £50,000 fine.
fields.body:
The Football Association got itself into a complete mess yesterday trying to adjudicate on the tunnel bust-up after the Chelsea v Wimbledon game in February.

It decided to hear the cases of the two clubs separately. Its disciplinary commission spent five hours listening to Chelsea's case before fining the west London club £50,000 plus costs for failing to control their players, and also fined the captain Dennis Wise £7,500 plus costs after he pleaded guilty to insulting behaviour towards Wimbledon's defender Kenny Cunningham.

However, when the commission moved on to hear Wimbledon's side of the story, it was embarrassed to find that this apparently differed greatly from Chelsea's version of events.

So, after three hours in which it failed to come to a judgment, the three-man panel of Barry Bright, Frank Pattison and Alan Turvey decided to order a retrial of the Wimbledon case in front of a new commission. But it declared the Chelsea case closed.

It is not clear why the cases were dealt with separately. It would have made sense for the commission to hear both sets of evidence before making any judgment.

All that the FA spokesman Steve Double would say about the pickle the FA found itself in was: "Because of the conflicting nature of the evidence submitted on behalf of the two clubs, it was felt that in the interests of natural justice a new three-man commission should be convened to hear the cases of Kenny Cunningham, Mick Harford and Wimbledon." He added that the new hearing date might be weeks away.

Chelsea, who denied misconduct, are unlikely to appeal, according to their managing director Colin Hutchinson, although he was upset at the size of the club's fine. He felt that Chelsea had done all they could to prevent any trouble in the tunnel, with six stewards on duty there. Any more, he argued, would have been impractical given the confined space.

Double said the commission had accepted a guilty plea to a lesser charge against Wise, who had initially denied misconduct and violent conduct. He added: "It was the FA's case that an altercation took place between the two players which preceded a mass confrontation between players and officials of both sides."

It lasted about three minutes and was broken up by match officials. The truth about who started the brawl has yet to emerge but Hutchinson insisted Wise had not been involved in violence. The England midfielder had used "bad language" towards Cunningham, the commission heard, and acted in "self-defence".

The pair had started their argument during the game, which Chelsea won 3-1 after coming from behind, and it continued in the tunnel after the final whistle.

Hutchinson said: "Dennis was of a mind that he didn't do anything wrong. We debated long and hard about whether he should plead guilty to a lesser charge.

"It was very important that we stressed that there was no violence involved as far as Dennis was concerned. It would have been criminal if there had been a ban on the evidence heard today.

"It has been a big pressure hanging over him, and at the back of his mind was the fear that he might get a ban which would take him out of crucial league games or even the Cup final. His performances in the meantime say a lot about his professionalism."

Chelsea denied failing to control their players but the commission found them guilty after hearing evidence from witnesses, including the match referee Peter Jones.

webTitle: Joachim risks final place for St Vincent

fields.headline: Joachim risks final place for St Vincent
fields.trailText: The Aston Villa striker Julian Joachim has been called up by St Vincent for a World Cup qualifier on Sunday - but is hoping that it will not wreck his FA Cup final dream.
fields.body:
The Aston Villa striker Julian Joachim has been called up by St Vincent for a World Cup qualifier on Sunday - but is hoping that it will not wreck his FA Cup final dream.

Joachim flew out last night to join the St Vincent squad and is expected to make his debut for the Caribbean island in the tie in St Kitts.

It means he will miss Villa's match at Tottenham tomorrow and he is aware that it might cost him his place at Wembley against Chelsea on May 20. Joachim - who played for England at under-21 level - said: "I have given this matter a lot of thought and I believe I've made the right decision. I would regret it if I waited for an England call that never came."

Villa's manager John Gregory, meanwhile, has assured the England coach Kevin Keegan that he has no need to worry over the fitness of the central defender Gareth Southgate for Euro 2000. Southgate, who has not played in the Premiership for more than a month, has been given a 10-day holiday.

The West Brom striker Lee Hughes has been ruled out for the season after breaking a leg in the 1-1 draw with Ipswich on April 1.

Middlesbrough yesterday signed Ghana's international centre-back Emmanuel Armah on a month's trial. The 26-year-old, who plays for Accra Hearts of Oak, has 26 caps. The manager Bryan Robson said: "He's been recommended and we want to have a look at him. But, judging by the weather, he'll show he has the right attitude just by turning up."

Uefa will implement Fifa's new "six seconds" rule for goalkeepers from the start of Euro 2000 this summer. Under the rule, keepers will be allowed to hold on to the ball for only six seconds. The number of steps they take will be immaterial.

fields.headline: Walker in health scare
fields.trailText: Jack Walker's future at Blackburn Rovers was in doubt last night amid growing concern for his health. Walker, estimated as the 30th richest man in Britain last year with £600m, has been receiving lengthy treatment in hospital.
fields.body:
Jack Walker's future at Blackburn Rovers was in doubt last night amid growing concern for his health. Walker, estimated as the 30th richest man in Britain last year with £600m, has been receiving lengthy treatment in hospital.

He was discharged last night and is recovering at home in Jersey, where he has been a tax exile since 1974. Details of his illness have not been released but sources close to him said it was serious enough for the 68-year-old to be in hospital for the past month. There were unconfirmed reports that he had had an operation.

"He has been in hospital but I would not like to say any more than that at this moment," said his wife Carol. "The important thing is that he's coming home and he's absolutely fine."

Walker has prided himself on his hands-on approach, watching every match home and away and travelling to Lancashire for club business. Now, at a time when he is being advised to avoid stress, he must decide whether it would be in his better interests to take a less active role. Certainly there is a feeling inside Ewood Park that the past five years may have taken their toll.

Since Kenny Dalglish led the club to the title in 1995 Blackburn have been in steady decline, culminating in their relegation from the Premiership last season. Despite being the most expensive side in First Division history, they were perilously close to the relegation zone at one stage this season and Walker flew from Jersey to tell Brian Kidd his services as manager were no longer required.

Even though there has been a recent improvement since the appointment of Graeme Souness, the play-offs remain only a faint possibility. For the time being Walker's priority is to regain full strength and then it seems likely he will consider his position.

Whatever he decides, his bond with Blackburn is such that there is no suggestion he will stop financing the club with the money he has made in the steel industry.

Denis Irwin is close to agreeing a new one-year contract at Manchester United, which would take the 34-year-old defender into his 11th year with the club. United expect their longest-serving player to sign next week.

Teddy Sheringham, though, is no closer to sorting out his future in the face of interest from several foreign clubs. "I think Teddy will make his decision after the last ball of the season has been kicked," said United's chairman Martin Edwards.

webTitle: The rot under the carpet starts at the top

fields.headline: The rot under the carpet starts at the top
fields.trailText: This summer's European championship will be a farce if Uefa's handling of the Leeds affair is anything to judge by.
fields.body:
It is one of those imperishably great moments in sport: that wonderful fruity-voiced commentator John Snagge peering down the smoggy Thames at the Boat Race and saying: "I can't see who's in the lead but it's either Oxford or Cambridge."

This morning anyone with more than a passing interest in the mists and muddied waters of football and cricket must be similarly puzzled. At a time of gathering crisis in both these great sports no one has shown a lead, moral or otherwise. And the recent antics of some boxing bodies does not bear scrutiny either.

These officials demand that their players show responsibility while shirking it themselves. Some of those benign old dictators we loved to hate do not look so bad right now.

This week cricket and football have been betrayed, not principally by Hansie Cronje and certainly not by the footballers of Leeds United but by those official bodies that purport to govern them.

The indolent International Cricket Council appears to be heavily into denial over the little matter of match-fixing, the deepest and most insidious controversy the game has faced - or, in this case, not faced.

As for Uefa, this summer's European championship will be a farce if its handling of the Leeds affair is anything to judge by.

The decision to go ahead with last week's match between Leeds and Galatasaray after the killing of two visiting fans may be justified; all things considered it may have been the safest option. It is also uncertain how a minute's silence would have been observed in the notoriously hostile environment of the Ali Sami Yen stadium. From here, though, the decisions seem clear: next week's second leg should be played at Elland Road, and Turkish fans should not be allowed to travel.

Instead Uefa's Geneva headquarters has been paralysed by indecision and has postponed a final ruling until today. All it has done so far is charge Leeds with failing to control their players, which it says is an automatic response to four bookings.

The noises from the European governing body are hardly reassuring. Its president Lennart Johansson says that, one way or another, Turkish fans will find their way to the game. There they might be safe; what might happen outside is the greater worry.

Meanwhile the ICC appears in a state of shock over the Cronje affair even though there has been a considerable betting industry revolving around cricket for 15 years and match-fixing allegations have been made since 1995.

The case with Cronje, an apparently decent man and beyond suspicion, recalls the observation by that finest of all cricket writers, Raymond Robertson-Glasgow, in his outstanding autobiography 46 Not Out. On page one "Crusoe" writes: "In essence, everyone is a total stranger to everyone else, and falls to be misjudged on the few and occasional fragments that he or she uncovers to hurried and self-interested companions."

Every time there has been a whiff of corruption, though, the ICC, far from judging or misjudging, has swept it under some Asian carpet. India, Pakistan, Australia and now South Africa have had to look into the vast problem of betting and corruption. Yet the ICC says a worldwide investigation would be unwieldy.

It must be hoped that Malcolm Gray will show more stomach for the fight when he replaces Jagmohan Dalmiya as president in July, but do not bet on it.

The greed of cricket's various governing bodies, as well as that of Cronje, is also worth considering in this case. Without excusing the former South Africa captain, he has looked a tired and disillusioned man in recent months, at odds with the selectors, especially Kepler Wessels, and with the punishing and ever-increasing workload. Money, alone, did not turn his weary head.

Cricket suddenly feels like athletics in the early days of drug-enhanced performances, where seeing was no longer believing, where one could no longer trust the evidence of one's cynical eyes. If we really do get the leaders we deserve, we must be awful people.

fields.headline: Cronje's forecast upset by Klusener
fields.standfirst:
New evidence suggests captain controlled his bowlers better than the batting
The latest transcript
Indian pursued over debts
MacLaurin calls for hard line
fields.trailText: The disgraced South Africa captain Hansie Cronje was yesterday revealed to be an incompetent forecaster after new evidence emerged which showed that many of his predictions to a bookmaker were well off target.
fields.body:
The disgraced South Africa captain Hansie Cronje was yesterday revealed to be an incompetent forecaster after new evidence emerged which showed that many of his predictions to a bookmaker were well off target.

In a new transcript released by Delhi police to a private television station, Cronje predicted that South Africa would make 270 runs in their one-day match against India at Nagpur on March 19. In fact, after a swashbuckling performance by Lance Klusener who scored an unbeaten 75 runs, the South Africans reached 320 for seven.

The transcript sheds new light on the role of Klusener within the South Africa squad, after suggestions, which he denies, that he may have tipped off the authorities about match-fixing. Klusener is not among the four players implicated, besides Cronje: Nicky Boje, Herschelle Gibbs, Pieter Strydom and Henry Williams.

In an earlier transcript of a conversation with the London-based bookmaker Sanjay Chawla, Cronje boasts that he has four unindentified players "with him", but not Klusener. "No, no. Impossible. Impossible," he declares, when asked about Klusener's role.

The new transcript is one of at least 10 alleged calls between Chawla and Cronje during last month's one-day series. The calls were secretly taped by detectives and one conversation took place the day before the Nagpur game.

Cronje correctly reveals that "Crookes and Williams" will open the bowling: useful information to a bookmaker since Derek Crookes is an off-spinner who would rarely, if ever, be called on to take the new ball. Indian punters routinely bet huge sums on even arcane details of matches.

Cronje also accurately tells Chawla that Klusener would be the first-change bowler. "Don't worry. We will be bowling our non-regular bowlers," Cronje says. The claim was borne out by events: Strydom was given a full quota of 10 overs in Nagpur.

But his predictions proved wrong when India won the toss and put South Africa in to bat. Cronje had predicted that Gibbs would score fewer than 20 runs: instead he made 74 after an easy catch was dropped before he had reached 20.

According to police, Chawla grew increasingly frustrated with Cronje's erratic forecasting and, in another recorded conversation, even complained about it to his girlfriend.

Chawla is thought to have fallen out with his associate Rajesh Kalra after Cronje got it wrong during the India-South Africa match at Cochin. This may have delayed the alleged payments to the South Africa players involved. "The other guys are already angry with me because I have not received their money, you know," Cronje complains in a transcipt released last week.

Meanwhile India's sports ministry has asked the country's cricket board to submit a report within a week on the reasons for India's poor performances. "People talk about it. They have doubts in their minds that match-fixing could be one of the reasons for India's bad performance," said the sports minister SS Dhindsa.

He plans to meet India's coach Kapil Dev, the captain Saurav Ganguly, former captains Mohammad Azharuddin and Sachin Tendulkar, together with the board secretary Jaywant Lele and its president AC Muttiah on Thursday week.

fields.trailText: The most powerful man in English cricket has called for an urgent meeting of officials from the Test-playing countries to discuss the South African match-fixing controversy, with anyone found guilty of malpractice to be banned from international cricket for life.
fields.body:
The most powerful man in English cricket has called for an urgent meeting of officials from the Test-playing countries to discuss the South African match-fixing controversy, with anyone found guilty of malpractice to be banned from international cricket for life.

Lord MacLaurin, the chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board, revealed yesterday that he has sent a fax to the International Cricket Council, the ruling body of international cricket, suggesting that such a forum be set up as quickly as possible.

Speaking at the Cornhill lunch in London to recognise Andy Caddick as England's player of the year, MacLaurin said it was vital for all the leading cricket nations to meet so that their stances on the issue were the same.

"I sent a fax to ICC today," he said, "and I said that we could not afford this game of ours to fall into this sort of crisis. We should have a meeting of all the members of ICC to make sure that we are all singing from the same hymn sheet. I want to make sure that we all understand how each of us is thinking."

He added: "Anything that is untoward is unacceptable and anyone who transgresses the rules should never be allowed to play international cricket again."

Despite the assertion by Malcolm Gray, the ICC's president-elect, that there are measures in place to deal with betting - "adequate or as adequate as they can be" - as a result of last year's conference in Christchurch, the organisation has been severely criticised in the past few days. Several eminent cricketers have branded it toothless and apathetic.

On Tuesday the ICC revealed it had no plans for a panel from its code-of-conduct commission to initiate any wide-ranging investigation of its own, and instead was content to recognise the judicial inquiry that has been set up in South Africa, chaired by Justice Albie Sachs, a member of the commission.

The ICC president Jagmohan Dalmiya has kick-started a wider process by instigating a dialogue in Bombay with the Cricket Board of India, and MacLaurin's follow-up is bound to arouse interest at a time when the game can ill afford adverse publicity.

In South Africa, Hansie Cronje, the figure at the centre of the allegations, again denied malpractice beyond accepting money from a bookmaker for "supplying information and forecasting".

Speaking from his home in Bloemfontein the former captain confessed to being foolish and naive, in a prepared statement that echoed the one made two years ago by the Australians Shane Warne and Mark Waugh after they accepted money for offering pitch and weather information.

"All I will say is that I was not involved in the fixing or manipulating the results of cricket matches," he said. "I always play to win. I know of no member of any side that I have led who has done anything reprehensible or wrong. Speculation or criticism directed against other members of the team is wrong and unjustified."

Meanwhile Lance Klusener has denied reports that he had tipped off the police about Cronje after an argument between the pair. "Absolute rubbish," he said. "I certainly had no idea that anything untoward was going on in India while we were there so what was there to argue about? It's all utter nonsense."

fields.trailText: The Indian businessman at the heart of the Hansie Cronje scandal is facing action in the UK over alleged unpaid debts. Sanjay Chawla, who is accused of paying the former South Africa captain money during last month's one-day series in India, is being pursued for outstanding charges relating to his London-based clothing business.
fields.body:
The Indian businessman at the heart of the Hansie Cronje scandal is facing action in the UK over alleged unpaid debts. Sanjay Chawla, who is accused of paying the former South Africa captain money during last month's one-day series in India, is being pursued for outstanding charges relating to his London-based clothing business.

A property company, Super Miss Ltd, is to lodge county court papers demanding £1,829 in alleged unpaid rent and service charges. Chawla rented premises in London's east end for £7,000 a year from Super Miss in 1996 and used them to store women's clothes imported from India.

In July last year Super Miss repossessed the premises after he allegedly failed to pay his rent, but he resumed the tenancy for three months after asking for time to clear out his stock. Again he allegedly failed to pay rent, and the company last heard from him in October.

A spokesman for the company managing the property on behalf of Super Miss said papers would be presented to the county court as soon as Chawla surfaced. He has not been seen at his address in Hendon since the scandal broke, but his solicitors deny he is in hiding.

Chawla's company, Commercial Clothing Limited, is registered at his home address but directory inquiries has no record of a telephone line there.

The man named on the company register as co-secretary and principal shareholder claimed he had been registered without his knowledge. Rajeev Khurana said he had contacted Chawla and been told his name would be removed from the register "as soon as things quieten down".

One source who in the past three years has had dealings with Chawla, believed by Indian police to be a cog in India's illegal gambling industry, said: "He specialised in negotiating fag-end leases [short-term lets] on high street premises and setting up a retail outlet for six months or so. None of his cheques bounced, I just think he had a problem with organisation. Part of the problem was he travelled a great deal. He talked as if he knew very important people in Delhi. I find it hard to believe he could afford to offer people £250,000 as he is accused of."

webTitle: Leicestershire left-armer bowls Wisden a googly

fields.headline: Leicestershire left-armer bowls Wisden a googly
fields.trailText: "He's out!" exclaim the first words of this year's Wisden Almanack, and indeed it does appear that he is. But Wisden was soberly reflecting upon the unrivalled batting merits of Sir Donald Bradman, one of its five cricketers of the century, and it failed to spot that that was equally true of a certain Matthew Brimson.
fields.body:
"He's out!" exclaim the first words of this year's Wisden Almanack, and indeed it does appear that he is. But Wisden was soberly reflecting upon the unrivalled batting merits of Sir Donald Bradman, one of its five cricketers of the century, and it failed to spot that that was equally true of a certain Matthew Brimson.

Wisden, as far as can be ascertained, has never had a flasher. There is just a chance that the same remains true today. But many who turn to Leicestershire's team photograph on p657 of this year's edition will be convinced that Brimson is taking guard on middle.

Brimson is a left-arm spinner, which cricket history suggests makes him automatically a touch unconventional. To his mortification, picture editors were having to blow up the photograph yesterday to discover the truth. In his defence, pre-season photographs are traditionally taken in the Arctic nip of early April, which is a challenge to any man.

Brimson, it has to be said, is a county cricketer who has never before drawn such attention to himself: as left-arm spinners go, he has occasionally struggled to maintain a good length.

Wisden will make an official complaint about Brimson's exhibitionism. Matthew Engel, who has temporarily retired as editor with the hope that the millennium edition will prove to be among Wisden's finest, described it as "an insult to county members", which seemed a touch personal.

"I can see the funny side like everybody else," he said, "but I think you have to be a damn sight better at your profession to behave like this. It is all part of the syndrome that is affecting county cricket."

The same photograph, sources suggest, was innocently hung in the Lord's dining room throughout last summer. Leicestershire met inquiries yesterday with a dead bat.

"We have had a meeting with Matthew Brimson and we have accepted his explanation that it is not in his character to do anything that would cause offence," they stated. "He wishes to apologise to anyone who may have misinterpreted the published photograph."

It is all part of the syndrome that is affecting county cricket." The same photograph, sources suggest, was innocently hung in the Lord's dining room throughout last summer. Leicestershire met inquiries yesterday with a dead bat. "We have had a meeting with Matthew Brimson and we have accepted his explanation that it is not in his character to do anything that would cause offence," they stated. "He wishes to apologise to anyone who may have misinterpreted the published photograph."

webTitle: Improved Boro to beat Sky Blues

fields.headline: Improved Boro to beat Sky Blues
fields.standfirst: Mike Hodgkinson, our man with 'I love Papillon' tattooed across his forehead, gives you the lowdown on this weekend's best bets
fields.trailText: The search for a Premiership upset at the weekend leads inevitably to support for a pair of relegation battlers who met at Selhurst Park midweek.
fields.body:
It was only a matter of weeks ago that Middlesbrough were looking useless. In some faithless quarters, Bryan Robson's head was destined for the chopping block - but all that has changed. Now they're one of the most improved outfits in the Premiership. The recent win at White Heart Lane was very impressive and Monday night's classic tussle with the champions was, for many, match of the season. All of which points to a victory at Coventry on Saturday.

Robson's men beat the Sky Blues 2-1 at Highfield Road last season - and the same scoreline looks about right this time round. What's more, Coventry have lost eight of their last 11 games, so on the grounds of both history and recent form the 11-5 Hills are offering for the away win looks mighty generous.

Newcastle have had a pretty disheartening week but can pick themselves up at St James's Park on Saturday. The records suggest that the Magpies find it very difficult to lose to Leicester on home turf - they've won nine of their last ten and the Foxes recent away defeats at the hands of Derby and Wimbledon don't look too clever.

The search for a Premiership upset at the weekend leads inevitably to support for a pair of relegation battlers who met at Selhurst Park midweek - Wimbledon and Sheffield Wednesday. The Dons crashed 2-0, the crowd told Egil Olsen to pack his bags and storm clouds gathered to signal Liverpool's arrival on Sunday.

The Reds are on the back of a streak so hot you could cook a saveloy on it - but recent history gives the nod to Wimbledon. They've lost only one of the last ten at home to Liverpool and, spurred on by the small matter of survival, can keep this good record on the right track. Risk the widely available 4-1 on the win.

Wednesday will trot out at Hillsborough on Saturday facing the equally stern task of overturning Chelsea. The London side are unbeaten in their last six trips here; they're arguably the hottest side in Europe at the moment; and they won a bread-and-butter clash with Coventry two days ago despite going behind early doors. If those harsh facts don't set alarm bells ringing, you're deaf.

Still, it might be worth chancing a gritty draw on the grounds that the midweek win has given Wednesday a lifeline. New manager Peter Shreeves may have kicked off with a brace of defeats but can exploit the courage and determination he has at his disposal. You'll find 11-4 for the stalemate in some places.

fields.headline: The sound of violence
fields.standfirst:
Pop was pap until film-makers opened our ears to its subversive nature. Jonathan Jones trawls through the catalogue of sweet music and brutal images
Mean Streets | A Clockwork Orange | Performance | Scarface | Apocalypse Now | GoodFellas | Blue Velvet | Reservoir Dogs | Dr Strangelove | Superfly
fields.trailText: Pop was pap until film-makers opened our ears to its subversive nature. Jonathan Jones trawls through the catalogue of sweet music and brutal images
fields.body:
American Psycho is a novel that aspires to the condition of cinema. It has fade-ins and fade-outs, an obsessive visual detailing of what characters wear and what rooms look like, cinematic violence - and most of all it has a soundtrack. Mary Harron's film of the book is its inevitable consummation. In the very first paragraph, a character aware that riding in the back of a taxi through Manhattan venting spleen at the traffic may be a bit Marty-like, introduces another Scorsese allusion when he "tells the driver he will give him $5 to turn up the radio, Be My Baby on WYNN..."

The Ronettes' Be My Baby is the song on the opening credits to Martin Scorsese's Mean Streets, from 1973. American Psycho's narrator, Patrick Bateman, is a Scorsese psycho transplanted from the mean streets to Wall Street, living in a fantasy world structured by the soundtrack in his head. He interrupts his tale of killings with essays on the music that means most to him: he loves Genesis, but only since their 1980 album Duke - when Phil Collins emerged as leader. He loves Whitney Houston. He adores Huey Lewis and the News.

There is a history to this way of thinking about pop music. Cinema as we experience it began in the 70s with the new wave of US film-makers for whom the sound of pop and rock was integral to the way they saw the world. The pop soundtrack defines contemporary cinema and, ever since Taxi Driver and Apocalypse Now, the sound of pop has accompanied images of violence, murder and brutality.

In 1975's Taxi Driver, Travis Bickle was a character so out of sync with his times that he didn't know who Kris Kristofferson was, and watched blankly as people danced to a soul show on television. But Bateman, like all of us now, lives life to a soundtrack; pop has become a structuring presence in our lives, something that counterpoints every great event from falling in love to killing someone.

This is a habit of thought we got from the movies and most of all from the films of the 70s. "Do you enjoy K Billy's Sounds of the 70s? It's my personal favourite," says Mr Blonde as he prepares to torture a young cop to a radio show in Reservoir Dogs - when pop's history became long and gory enough for it to be quoted, discussed and analysed as part of the fabric of films. The generation of directors who transformed cinema in the 70s grew up in the 60s to a soundtrack of Motown, the Stones and psychedelia; they grew up in the counterculture; they were the first generation of film-makers for whom pop was something with deep emotional meaning.

But why is that meaning so blood-spattered? Why has pop music become so indelibly associated in films with brutality, mayhem and psychosis? It was one thing for Francis Coppola to suggest in The Godfather that Frank Sinatra - one of whose early hits the Godfather's protégé sings at his daughter's wedding before having the family advance his career with the help of a horse's head - provided the soundtrack to mob violence. It is another to take the hippy escapism of Mike Oldfield's Tubular Bells, as William Friedkin did in The Exorcist, and reveal this jingle-jangle music as the sound of Satan.

Pop became the soundtrack to violence in films when it became the soundtrack to violence in reality. The secret source for every ironic counterpoising of rock and slaughter may be the Maysles brothers' 1970 documentary of the Stones' Altamont concert, Gimme Shelter, which shows murder right in front of the stage as they play. But then rock 'n' roll began as music of rebellion, menace and outsiderdom, and Kenneth Anger's 1963 underground classic Scorpio Rising - perhaps the very first film to use a sampled rock soundtrack - dredges darkness from the heart of pop in juxtaposing the sweet ballad Blue Velvet with a biker gang's vicious rituals.

Through all the classic juxtapositions of sweet sounds and casual violence, interpretations of our music and our culture are being advanced. Is our culture banal and anaesthetised to violence? For Stanley Kubrick in A Clockwork Orange, pop is the soundtrack of psychosis; the synthesised Beethoven and musical numbers that Alex enjoys are the music of cultural death. In the record shop where he hangs out, pop culture is cruelly caricatured as teenagers buy records by The Heaven Seventeen, Black Christmas by Cyclops and The Sparks. Some of these groups later became real. In Scorsese's films, pop is not something to satirise but the core of his sensibility; he has remembered how when he grew up in Manhattan's Lower East Side there would always be music playing and before he directed anything he edited the film of Woodstock.

In Scorsese's films, music is full of meaning and passion and hints of redemption; the music that plays when violence is being done hints at another world in which this could not happen. In his most violent film - emotionally if not physically - The King of Comedy, the streets are full of music (with cameos by the Clash) that Robert De Niro's fascistic TV wannabe doesn't hear. If he did, he would be a different person. Patrick Bateman would be a different person if he could understand why Phil Collins' sversion of You Can't Hurry Love is not, as he claims, a huge improvement on the 60s original. "How can we stand the violence?" asks Van Morrison over the end credits of The King of Comedy, and that's the question all these films ask.

Mean Streets
(Martin Scorsese , 1973)
Please Mr Postman, The Marvelettes, 1961

Charlie (Harvey Keitel), Johnny Boy (Robert De Niro) and their crew visit a pool hall on New York's Lower East Side to collect a debt. Everything is going fine, and they are about to shake on the deal to the sound of Motown from a jukebox, until Johnny Boy launches into a stream of unprovoked insults at the pool hall, its clients and its proprietor.

"That's it, we're not paying," says the guy. "We're not paying because he's a mook." "A mook, what's a mook?" They fight, in a sequence edited to the rhythms of Please Mr Postman. As the Marvelettes sing of love and longing - all they want is a love letter - Johnny Boy bestrides a pool table beating away three men with a broken-off cue. As the film progresses, the choreography of music and violence becomes ever darker until Johnny Boy is shot to an Eric Clapton guitar solo.

More about Mean Streets

A Clockwork Orange
(Stanley Kubrick, 1971)
Singin' in the Rain, Gene Kelly, 1929/1952

In Anthony Burgess's novel Alex has a passion for Beethoven, which means he has a soul. Kubrick is more sceptical about the value of art, and in the film, when Alex is made to watch Nazi atrocities to Beethoven (as part of the Lodovico Method of behavioural therapy) the music seems to go all too well with the horrors on screen. Alex's most memorable musical moment is when he performs Singin' in the Rain as he cuts off Adrienne Corri's clothes before raping her.

Singin' in the Rain was a hit in 1929 before being used in the Gene Kelly musical, where it's a celebration of rebirth after a silent star's career is ended by the arrival of soundtracks. After seeing atrocities to a Beethoven soundtrack, Alex can no longer listen to the composer; after seeing A Clockwork Orange, you can never hear Singin' in the Rain in the same way.

More about A Clockwork Orange

Performance
(Donald Cammell and Nicolas Roeg, 1970)
Uncredited blues guitar solo

Gangster Chas (James Fox) wants to put the frighteners on a lawyer so he and his lads barge into the mews garage where the lawyer keeps his Rolls-Royce. They beat up a chauffeur, tie him to the radiator and shave his head. Then Chas starts to pour acid on the car - it bubbles and hisses, burning and scarring the smooth paint. We are terrified he is about to start on the chauffeur. A gangster turns on the car radio and we hear sleazy Keith Richards-style guitar.

Doing it to music seems to suggest that there's a vicious art to Chas's violence, his "performance": his grotesque ritual of torture is choreographed. It rocks. The camera dwells on the patterns his acid makes on the car body and it looks like abstract art. The blues guitar - later to return when Mick Jagger performs Memo From Turner - implies that violence is beauty, beauty violence.

More about Performance

Scarface
(Brian De Palma, 1983)
Shake It Up, Elizabeth Daily, 1983

Cuban gangster Tony Montana (Al Pacino) and colleague try to do a drug deal in a Miami hotel room while the rest of the gang wait outside in the car. A row with the dealers results in Tony and his brother-in-law being tied up in the bathroom as the head drug dealer produces a chainsaw.

As he prepares to cut Tony's brother-in-law to pieces, the camera sidles out of the bathroom, through a window, across the street to where the back-up are listening to Shake It Up - a piece of nondescript MOR rock by soundtrack composer Giorgio Moroder - on the car radio. Then we pan back, to the growl of the chainsaw... De Palma often uses this kind of music (bad rock, bad synth) in a way that is oddly affecting because it reflects the desperate lives of his characters. Tony Montana's life and death are played out to disco kitsch.

More about Scarface

Apocalypse Now
(Francis Ford Coppola , 1979)
The End, The Doors, 1972

"Everyone wanted me to do it, even he wanted me to do it," says Martin Sheen in voiceover as he prepares to slaughter Marlon Brando's Major Kurtz. Coppola intercuts the killing with the sacrificial slaughter of a beast by Kurtz's crazed followers, and on the soundtrack come the dung-dung-dung opening notes of The Doors' attempt to translate Greek tragedy into psychedelic pop in The End.

Apocalypse Now puts the counterculture that imagined itself in opposition to Vietnam on the frontline of the war itself. The use of The Doors is particularly apt as Jim Morrison's father was a US admiral, and Jim's psychotic confession in The End ("Father, I want to kill you") was clearly genuine. Here, metaphorically, his wish comes true.

More about Apocalypse Now

GoodFellas
(Martin Scorsese, 1990)
Atlantis, Donovan, 1968

Mobsters Jimmy (Robert De Niro), Tommy (Joe Pesci) and narrator Henry Hill (Ray Liotta) are drinking in a bar owned by Henry while Billy Batts, a senior gangster just out of jail, has a sparsely attended coming-out party at the other end of the bar.

Batts taunts Tommy by reminding everyone how he used to shine shoes as a boy. They make up and everything seems settled. "Now go and get your fucking shine-box," says Batts. After being pulled off him, Tommy returns at closing time and, as Henry locks the door, he and Jimmy kick and stamp Batts to death (so they think - actually he has to be finished later). Over the entire kicking sequence we hear the incongruous sound of Donovan's 1968 psychedelic idyll Atlantis, which he wrote after visiting the Maharishi with the Beatles. Like a lot of the music in GoodFellas, this is the sound of another reality that the gangsters, with their Sinatra style, don't know exists.

More about Goodfellas

Blue Velvet
(David Lynch, 1986)
In Dreams, Roy Orbison, 1963

Frank (Dennis Hopper), the underworld weirdo, gets innocent do-gooder Kyle MacLachlan alone in his car in the woods at night. On the car radio is Frank's favourite song, In Dreams. Hopper kisses his victim on the mouth. They are both covered in Isabella Rossellini's lipstick. He speaks the song's lyrics, out of sync with Orbison, his face contorted in pain: "In dreams... I walk with you." Then he begins to punch MacLachlan in the face. Blue Velvet reads astonishing depths of menace in Orbison's 1963 hit, which is played again and again in ever weirder ways. It's the most disturbing use ever made of pop in that it convincingly makes early 60s music sound like a source of unnameable horrors.

More about Blue Velvet

Reservoir Dogs
(Quentin Tarantino, 1991)
Stuck in the Middle with You, Stealer's Wheel, 1973

As Mr Blonde (Michael Madsen) begins to torture an undercover policeman (Tim Roth) in a warehouse, this song comes on the car radio. This is, in a sense, a pastiche of all the scenes listed on this page; it marks the moment when we become so aware of pop's - and film's - quotability that the moment Mr Blonde puts on the radio, you know this is going to be really horrible.

Stuck In The Middle With You is a song whose meaning is elusive and uncomfortable ("I've a feeling that something ain't right") and somehow vacuous; the horror lies in the lack of meaning implied by Mr Blonde's liking it. He does his torture as a dance to the music. It's only when the spell of the music is over that we are freed, and the cop shoots him.

More about Reservoir Dogs

Dr Strangelove
(Stanley Kubrick, 1964)
We'll Meet Again, Vera Lynn, 1939

As the first bomb is dropped, Peter Sellers' Dr Strangelove wrestles with his artificial arm and explains how it would be possible for the world's elite to live underground for 100 years to escape nuclear death. Then we cut to real films of nuclear tests to the sound of Vera Lynn.

"We'll meet again," promises that brassy 40s voice, as mushroom clouds and lateral flashes of light illuminate the sky. The song comes from a time when war could be contemplated as a necessary, noble cause; but now war is this post-human spectacle of beautiful mushroom clouds, each one signalling hundreds of thousands of deaths. We'll Meet Again - it's a promise, too. We will meet this scene again, says Kubrick, and this time we won't be watching from above. Or perhaps, as Dr Strangelove expounds his eugenic plans, we'll meet the Nazis again.

More about Dr Strangelove

Superfly
(Gordon Parks Jnr, 1972)
Think, Curtis Mayfield, 1972

A black drug dealer is driven off by white cops - who are in reality working for the city's police commissioner and top gangster - to the sound of a soulful instrumental by Mayfield, whose soundtrack to this blaxploitation thriller is a brilliant commentary on the film and its violent world. As the music goes on, the car pulls up in the shadow of the elevated railroad, and a cop takes out a syringe. As the victim pleads for his life, he is injected with a lethal dose of heroin and left to die. We see his face one last time through the window, to the sweet melancholy music.

Mayfield appears in the film singing Pusherman, an ironic counterpoise to the story of how a pusher gets out of the business. Mayfield's darkest song and the biggest hit on the soundtrack album, Freddie's Dead, is not in the film, but even so, his bouncy yet sad music gives Superfly a poetic quality that lingers.

More about Superfly

It's the most disturbing use ever made of pop in that it convincingly makes early 60s music sound like a source of unnameable horrors. More about Blue Velvet Reservoir Dogs (Quentin Tarantino, 1991) Stuck in the Middle with You, Stealer's Wheel, 1973 As Mr Blonde (Michael Madsen) begins to torture an undercover policeman (Tim Roth) in a warehouse, this song comes on the car radio. This is, in a sense, a pastiche of all the scenes listed on this page; it marks the moment when we become so aware of pop's - and film's - quotability that the moment Mr Blonde puts on the radio, you know this is going to be really horrible. Stuck In The Middle With You is a song whose meaning is elusive and uncomfortable ("I've a feeling that something ain't right") and somehow vacuous; the horror lies in the lack of meaning implied by Mr Blonde's liking it. He does his torture as a dance to the music. It's only when the spell of the music is over that we are freed, and the cop shoots him. More about Reservoir Dogs Dr Strangelove (Stanley Kubrick, 1964) We'll Meet Again, Vera Lynn, 1939 As the first bomb is dropped, Peter Sellers' Dr Strangelove wrestles with his artificial arm and explains how it would be possible for the world's elite to live underground for 100 years to escape nuclear death. Then we cut to real films of nuclear tests to the sound of Vera Lynn. "We'll meet again," promises that brassy 40s voice, as mushroom clouds and lateral flashes of light illuminate the sky. The song comes from a time when war could be contemplated as a necessary, noble cause; but now war is this post-human spectacle of beautiful mushroom clouds, each one signalling hundreds of thousands of deaths. We'll Meet Again - it's a promise, too. We will meet this scene again, says Kubrick, and this time we won't be watching from above. Or perhaps, as Dr Strangelove expounds his eugenic plans, we'll meet the Nazis again. More about Dr Strangelove Superfly (Gordon Parks Jnr, 1972) Think, Curtis Mayfield, 1972 A black drug dealer is driven off by white cops - who are in reality working for the city's police commissioner and top gangster - to the sound of a soulful instrumental by Mayfield, whose soundtrack to this blaxploitation thriller is a brilliant commentary on the film and its violent world. As the music goes on, the car pulls up in the shadow of the elevated railroad, and a cop takes out a syringe. As the victim pleads for his life, he is injected with a lethal dose of heroin and left to die. We see his face one last time through the window, to the sweet melancholy music. Mayfield appears in the film singing Pusherman, an ironic counterpoise to the story of how a pusher gets out of the business. Mayfield's darkest song and the biggest hit on the soundtrack album, Freddie's Dead, is not in the film, but even so, his bouncy yet sad music gives Superfly a poetic quality that lingers.
