fields.headline: la Nouvelle Eve
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: The uncompromising seriousness and emotional forthrightness of this movie makes it worth seeing
fields.body:
Karin Viard gives a performance of great commitment and intelligence in Catherine Corsini's La Nouvelle Eve , about Camille, an unmarried thirtysomething woman in Paris, content with her swingingly adventurous existence, until she falls passionately in love with Alexis, a happily married socialist party official.

This can be, as American network executives say, a tough watch - especially when Camille is driven to the hysterical edge of self-harm. (I rather preferred Viard in the gentler, less hectoring role of Emma, the young woman coming to terms with cancer, in Solveig Anspach's film Haut Les Coeurs.) But the uncompromising seriousness and emotional forthrightness of this movie makes it worth seeing.

fields.headline: Of Freaks and Men
fields.standfirst: Alexei Balabanov's film about 19th-century Russian porn may not be to everyone's taste, but Peter Bradshaw   is unsettled and impressed
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A disturbing, erotically creepy, funny and touching film whose images will live in your memory... This is a film of pungent and distinctive flavour, maybe not to all tastes; but, for its originality and style, it must be seen.
fields.body:
In a week of films intent on telling you what you know already, Alexei Balabanov's proto-Freudian bad dream Of Freaks and Men stands out as a compelling experience, sinuously original and deeply refreshing - although refreshing is perhaps not the exact word for this uniquely unsettling movie. Balabanov's brutal study of modern Russian gangsterism, Brother, is already on release here, and now this director's later picture marks him out as a distinctive and very remarkable talent.

Shot in a glittering, wintry monochrome, which attains a heavy sepia tint, Of Freaks and Men is set in turn-of-the-century St Petersburg. It imagines the bourgeois origins of Russia's fledgling porn industry: specifically that catering for images of flagellation and sado-masochism - catching this industry on the cusp of its movement from still photography to rudimentary moving pictures. The film's periodic silent-movie captions and its daguerreotype-hue are in homage to both media.

For this flourishing new porn culture, Balabanov invents a milieu of secrecy, exoticism and aberrant strangeness. The result is a disturbing, erotically creepy, funny and touching film whose images will live in your memory.

It concerns a doctor and his beautiful, blind wife who have adopted a pair of Siamese twins joined at the hip - Tolya and Kolya. The twins' singing ability in adolescence is exploited by their adoptive parents on the stage and they inspire an obsessive following with musical audiences, becoming the toast of polite society.

Nearby, a widowed engineer lives with his daughter Lisa in slightly less genteel circumstances, and the two households become connected by a below-stairs taste in pornography. Elaborate studies of naked women being spanked and thrashed with birch twigs are being turned out with fanatical artistic care by the glacial, deadpan Johann (Sergei Makovetsky) and his sinister, grinning sidekick Victor Ivanovich (Victor Sukhorukhov), as a sideline to their respectable portraiture business.

Johann and Victor insinuate themselves into both houses: and their influence coincides with the descent of one of the twins into alcoholism, and the other's erotic obsession with Lisa. Victor, too, conceives an interest in Ekaterina, the doctor's wife, and the scene in which he tweaks up her skirts to examine her genitalia - while she appears to stare glassily, ambiguously ahead - is an extraordinary moment.

There is something very gamey and very kinky in the way Balabanov represents the consumers of Johann's wares as being women, and this conceit has its own element of pornographic whimsy. Balabanov's juxtaposition of pornography with the trim, prim world of stage performance and bourgeois musical taste - in the form of Tolya and Kolya's sensational career on the stage - endows this secret theatre of sexuality with a vulnerability and a terrible pathos.

The weird rapture of the beatings, which are first photographed, and then filmed, are overlaid with a sadness and an absurdity as Balabanov reveals the emotional relationship that exists between Johann and the old woman - "nanny" - who is wheeled out on camera to administer the punishment.

Balabanov's St Petersburg is shown as having something in common with Arthur Schnitzler's Vienna, in which heavily furnished front parlours, upright pianos, mob-capped maids and antimacassars are the primal scenes for unacknowledged yearnings and sexual awakenings, both real and imagined. In Of Freaks and Men, Balabanov parodically invents a kind of prehistory of pornography, or a prehistory of sexual modernity: a deadpan world of suppression, displacement and exclusion in which nameless desires have an intensity for being hidden, but also a mortal and overwhelming sadness.

Of Freaks and Men is close to early David Lynch in its grotesqueness and Balabanov's images are faintly reminiscent of the photographs of Diane Arbus, with a suggestion of Joel-Peter Witkin, though they have always the solvent of tenderness. And, as in Balabanov's early movie Happy Days (released here last year), the bowler-hatted Johann and Victor have Beckettian severity and absurdity.

The extended sequence in which Johann is silently conducted by riverboat to Lisa's house, where he intends to propose marriage, icily impassive at the prow with his bunch of flowers, is riveting. It is a tremendous performance from Makovetsky, whose inscrutable mien gives him Buster Keaton's eerie self-possession. Balabanov's regular player Sukhorukhov is similarly watchable as Johann's subordinate, displaying low cunning and bad teeth. This is a film of pungent and distinctive flavour, maybe not to all tastes; but, for its originality and style, it must be seen.

fields.headline: L'Ennui
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Kahn's movie, taken from a novel by Alberto Moravia, moves with assurance and style, and elegantly evokes both the ennui that breeds the affair, and the deeper ennui of desperate futility that ends it
fields.body:
Cédric Kahn's L'Ennui is an urbane fable of destructive sexual obsession. Charles Berling plays Martin, a jaded Parisian philosophy lecturer. His intellectually barren life is electrified when he visits the studio of a painter who has died while having sex with his 17-year- old model, Cecilia (Sophie Guillemin). Inevitably, Martin becomes obsessed with her, too: the plump, sexy, slatternly Cecilia, who is utterly unintellectual and unreflective, and who makes no secret of another, younger lover - which pushes Martin into an abyss of jealous hatred.

There is something a little cliched and misogynistic in the myth of the younger woman as an enigmatic cipher, who functions as an anti-muse to an older, more cerebral man. But Kahn's movie, taken from a novel by Alberto Moravia, moves with assurance and style, and elegantly evokes both the ennui that breeds the affair, and the deeper ennui of desperate futility that ends it.

fields.headline: Sacred Flesh
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A campy, kitschy slice of Gothic naughtiness about a convent somewhere in 17th-century Europe
fields.body:
In the honourable tradition of Walerian Borowczyk's Behind Convent Walls, Nigel Wingrove's Sacred Flesh is a campy, kitschy slice of Gothic naughtiness about a convent somewhere in 17th-century Europe. Here a bunch of comely, masturbating nuns with breast implants have entirely neglected matters of the spirit and appear to spend their time liberally applying lipstick and mascara, prior to the next sapphic debauch. One of them is "ravished" by two leering older men, although, in a very gallant, soft-porn way, their attentions stop short of penetration.

A rousing finale is provided by the visionary crucifixion of what appears to be a page three girl. Hark! Is that the sound of Basil Hume shifting in his grave?

fields.headline: Mission to Mars
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: It's got an outrageously silly ending and, for the first 20 minutes, is quite unbelievably slow
fields.body:
The astronauts in Mission to Mars may be living in AD 2020, but they evidently have a sweetly old-fashioned Jim Lovell-style taste for buzz-cut greying hairdos for the senior officers, and fervently uxorious marital situations which they display in the traditional pre-launch barbecue.

Brian De Palma's space shot, starring Gary Sinise and Tim Robbins, is a mish-mash of plenty of stuff we've seen before, including Kubrick's 2001 and - as the red planet's sands whip up an occult storm - The Mummy. The first batch of guys discover something absolutely incredible, in every sense, on Mars's surface, and then they have to be rescued.

It's got an outrageously silly ending and, for the first 20 minutes, is quite unbelievably slow.

fields.headline: Pippi Longstocking
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: I wanted to reach into the screen and throttle her, but it's efficient entertainment and you could do worse than take the children to see this
fields.body:
Pippi Longstocking is a relentlessly cheery, cheeky, chirpy animated musical from 1997 about the mischievous little Swedish girl who goes around being so loveable she makes Tigger look like Eeyore.

I wanted to reach into the screen and throttle her, but it's efficient entertainment and you could do worse than take the children to see this.

fields.headline: Up at the Villa
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: It's an ingenious story, but needs credible passion between Penn and Scott Thomas, and that is nowhere forthcoming
fields.body:
Up at the Villa is, sadly, not a biopic of Andy Gray but a sort of Merchant-Ivory noir drama set in Florence in the late 30s, and based on a novella by W Somerset Maugham.

Kristin Scott Thomas plays an Englishwoman of a certain age, staying at an exquisite villa, drawn and faintly equine, tough, and yet with a heart as fragile as Lalique glass, and about to make a convenient marriage to James Fox's kindly yet unexciting ambassador. She is drawn, however, into an affair with an urbane American played by Sean Penn - a very dangerous liaison. Scott Thomas gives a firework display of glassy-eyed staring, highly-strung quivering and sobbing self-loathing. But Penn just doesn't get much to do. He looks around faintly abstractedly, as if searching for a paparazzo to thump.

It's an ingenious story, but needs credible passion between Penn and Scott Thomas, and that is nowhere forthcoming.

fields.headline: The Tigger Movie
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A nice film for the Easter holidays, but it is rather sad with lots of the principals in tears as poor Tigger tries to find some real tiger relatives. Perhaps not for the very young or melancholy
fields.body:
Disney's The Tigger Movie puts the irrepressibly bouncy tiger centre-stage, and creates a charming and amiable little film, with plenty of nice touches, although I could never quite escape the suspicion that AA Milne without the Bear is Hamlet without the Prince. Actually, Pooh has a lot of scenes and close-ups, and the film definitely picks up during these; he has a cracking song called Pooh's Lullabee, in which he soothes some bees to sleep, the better to relieve them of their precious honey. Nothing Tigger does quite matches Pooh's natural star quality, but writer/director Jun Falkenstein gives the stripey one some very funny lines, including his aghast sense of failing in hospitality to his guests: "Where the heck are my mannerisms ?"

All in all, this is a nice film for the Easter holidays, but it is rather sad with lots of the principals in tears as poor Tigger tries to find some real tiger relatives. Perhaps not for the very young or melancholy.

fields.headline: Pok&eacutemon: the First Movie
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This film is humourless, boring, impenetrable and with animation of such staggeringly low quality that it constitutes an insult to cinemagoers of all ages
fields.body:
Pokémon: the First Movie - what a very disheartening subtitle that is.

It is traditional for pundits to abnegate all critical responsibility on the Pokémon Issue, and ventriloquise the views of their six-year-old nieces. My own six-year-old niece, for the record, is a passionate Pokémon scholar and is saddened by my ignorance. Anyway, Pokémon is the most effortless Japanese invasion of western pop culture since Mighty Morphin Power Rangers, with its video game software, trading cards and TV show. But since Super Mario Bros, we know what a downer it is to have to actually sit down and watch a film based on a computer game - the pleasures of surrendering to a narrative being insurmountably different to those of mastering events with a games console.

This film is humourless, boring, impenetrable and with animation of such staggeringly low quality that it constitutes an insult to cinemagoers of all ages. But are any of the aforementioned considerations the point with Pokémon? You've got me. The story, such as it is, concerns Ash and his buddies, who control a stable of benign Pokémon creatures. These Pokémon "masters" are human, though with their weird feline vertical irises and pupils, they are like no human racial group you've ever seen. Trouble comes when an uppity Pokémon, indeed a genetically modified Pokémon called Mewtwo, aspires to human status. The cutest Pokémon is the teddy-ish creature Pikachu whose cooing voice made me long for someone to give him an old-fashioned violent Power Ranger kick.

webTitle: Once Upon a Time in the West

fields.headline: Once Upon a Time in the West
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This classic western moves with an epic deliberation and is utterly mesmeric from beginning to end
fields.body:
Sergio Leone's 1969 western Once Upon a Time in the West , now re-released by the British Film Institute in an uncut Cinemascope print moves with an epic deliberation, is, from first to last, utterly mesmeric.

Leone's languorous credit sequence, showing three gunmen waiting like desert reptiles, twitching and malevolent in the noonday sun, is masterly - especially the endlessly repeated two-note squeak of the wind-wheel, which becomes a kind of bluesy incantation. Against Ennio Morricone's shrill, harsh, declamatory score, Leone evokes the parched mass of his principals' looming faces, endowing them with a rugged landscape of their own. Henry Fonda, Claudia Cardinale, Jason Robards and Charles Bronson give magnificent performances, particularly Cardinale as the ex-prostitute who hovers ambiguously between cynicism and love.

Bronson has "something inside - something to do with death" says Jason Robards at the end, and this death instinct is in all of them, in the DNA of Leone's unforgiving opera of the old west.

fields.headline: Pretend you know all about...
fields.standfirst: ...Collette Dinnigan
fields.trailText: ...Collette Dinnigan
fields.body:
Once upon a time, you knew where you were with Australians. Big rucksack, huge alcohol tolerance, good-natured. Then they started getting all sophisticated on us. First of all it turned out that Oz isn't actually anything like Ramsay Street but is in fact all passion fruit smoothies and power yoga and postmodern architecture. Then Cate Blanchett and Nicole Kidman started swanning around with the kind of sleek-haired, whip-thin elegance that makes everyone else feel like Wombles by comparison. And now, Australian designer Collette Dinnigan is bringing a slice of Sydney chic to the Northern hemisphere, with the opening of her Chelsea store, the first outside of down under.

Dinnigan was born in New Zealand, but moved to Sydney in her late teens to launch a career in fashion, working for the costume department of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. In 1990 she left to set up her own-name label, but the influence of the time spent working on period costumes can be seen in her highly embroidered, colourful, romantic clothes. Since 1995, Dinnigan has held a coveted spot on the Paris fashion week schedule with collections snapped up by the smartest department stores, including Harvey Nichols in London and Barney's in New York.

The new store, which opened yesterday, has boudoir-pink walls, chandeliers, and flouncy curtains - pretty, but not nearly as pretty as the spring/summer collection currently in stock. Dinnigan's trademark style (see below) is girlish and embellished in a style reminiscent of our very own Elspeth Gibson - you may find you have to fight off the likes of Cameron Diaz, Sandra Bullock and Jerry Hall for the summer frocks with muted tea-dress prints, ruffle-edge pink skirts and dresses, and lace-edged camisoles in sky blue satin. Just don't expect hats with corks on.

 Collette Dinnigan is at 26 Cale St, SW3 (0171-589 8897).

In 1990 she left to set up her own-name label, but the influence of the time spent working on period costumes can be seen in her highly embroidered, colourful, romantic clothes. Since 1995, Dinnigan has held a coveted spot on the Paris fashion week schedule with collections snapped up by the smartest department stores, including Harvey Nichols in London and Barney's in New York. The new store, which opened yesterday, has boudoir-pink walls, chandeliers, and flouncy curtains - pretty, but not nearly as pretty as the spring/summer collection currently in stock. Dinnigan's trademark style (see below) is girlish and embellished in a style reminiscent of our very own Elspeth Gibson - you may find you have to fight off the likes of Cameron Diaz, Sandra Bullock and Jerry Hall for the summer frocks with muted tea-dress prints, ruffle-edge pink skirts and dresses, and lace-edged camisoles in sky blue satin. Just don't expect hats with corks on.  Collette Dinnigan is at 26 Cale St, SW3 (0171-589 8897).

webTitle: Murdered fans did not provoke Turks, says Ridsdale

fields.headline: Murdered fans did not provoke Turks, says Ridsdale
fields.trailText: Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale has countered claims by Galatasaray president Faruk Suren that Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight lost their lives after provoking a group of Turks.
fields.body:
Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale has countered claims by Galatasaray president Faruk Suren that Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight lost their lives after provoking a group of Turks.

Earlier today, Suren codemned the murders but seemed to imply that they were in retaliation to the behaviour of the Leeds fans. "There must have been something that happened," said Suren. I was not there [in Taksim Square where the murders took place] but some might have provoked. The people who did this must be sick or psychologically unbalanced to attack singing supporters because this has never happened here.

"But I'm not trying to justify murder. We are very sorry two young men have lost their lives and I hope Turkish justice swiftly prevails and those that carried out this inhuman action will soon be punished."

But Ridsdale was quick to counter. "We had British police in Istanbul, and their reports are unequivocal that Christopher and Kevin were with a group who had behaved impeccably all evening," he said.

"I'm not suggesting that everybody who travelled from Leeds did because I don't know. But I've seen some of the comments in the Turkish papers about what is supposed to have gone on. I have no direct evidence of that. But what I do have direct evidence of is that they did nothing to provoke this."

Meanwhile the English FA, who have stood by Ridsdale and Leeds throughout the ill-fated saga, have applauded Uefa's decision to ban Galatasaray fans from Elland Road.

Spokesman Steve Double said: "Obviously we welcome the decision. For us it was the common-sense option. We hope the game can now go ahead in a respectful atmosphere and that the families of the two men who died can continue to grieve without any further distractions."

webTitle: Winnie the pig, and other tales from the farmyard

fields.headline: Winnie the pig, and other tales from the farmyard
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: If you can't use the word "bullshit" during agriculture questions, when can you use it? James Paice, the Tories' agriculture No 2, suggested the crisis in dairy farming was now so grave that "soon the only source of bullshit left will be what is coming out of Downing Street".
fields.body:
If you can't use the word "bullshit" during agriculture questions, when can you use it? James Paice, the Tories' agriculture No 2, suggested the crisis in dairy farming was now so grave that "soon the only source of bullshit left will be what is coming out of Downing Street".

Nick Brown, the minister of agriculture, who looks like an amiable heifer, paused and turned his large head towards the Speaker, who administered the expected slap to Mr Paice. Suitably chastised, he substituted the phrase "bovine verbal excrement".

"Clearly the Conservatives have nothing to contribute to this debate except bad language," mooed Mr Brown. "You lost that one," barked Dennis Skinner at the byres opposite. Mr Skinner - who later likened one Tory MP to Snowball in Animal Farm - may have mellowed, but he can still play the gundog when the mood takes him.

Agriculture questions is a visceral occasion. Judging by the size of the stomachs on both front benches, food is a subject close to the house's heart. Nicholas Soames, "the Crawley food mountain" as Tony Banks christened him, strode in as the argument raged over the crisis in pig farming. The farmyard scene was complete. He stayed for 10 minutes, snorted a great deal, and then headed out, perhaps truffling for lunch.

Farming brings out the worst in MPs. Mr Brown and his opposite number, Tim Yeo, swapped insults over who was to blame for the BSE crisis; Mr Skinner thought the Tories should be made to stump up the £4.2bn BSE had cost; and Mr Yeo raised the spectre of French BSE being exported to the UK. Food seems incompatible with thought.

Xenophobia ruled. Dutch and Belgian fishermen were impossible; the French and Spanish were worse. There was not a cat in hell's chance of reforming the common fisheries policy, said one Labour MP. The phrase was unfortunate as pet passports were also under discussion. Everyone thought these were a jolly good thing, except Eric Forth, who appeared to see them as illegal immigration by another means.

The pets discussion also turned into an attack on the French. Dale Campbell-Savours was worried that vets in northern France providing pet-passport documentation might overcharge gullible Brits. Joyce Quin, the junior agriculture minister, promised to be vigilant and said discussions were taking place with the French vets' organisation (which has the unhappy acronym Snivel). One day the Commons will forgive the French for the Norman Conquest.

Margaret Beckett, leader of the house, was also challenged at business questions over the farming crisis. Nigel Evans referred to Winnie the pig's vigil in Parliament Square - a brave act of porcine patriotism. But Mrs Beckett had been well briefed: Winnie was not one pig; there were pigs working in shifts to keep the pen opposite the house occupied. Otherwise, said Mrs Beckett, the poor animal would have been poisoned by car fumes. Those who had made Winnie a hero, she suggested, had bought a pig in a poke.

The leader of the house is like the host a late-night radio chat show. All sorts of weirdos come on the line to raise whatever issues spring to mind. Could the government make time to discuss the closure of a car components company in north Wales, GM crop trials in Swindon, making kerb-crawling an arrestable offence ("what about making crawling to ministers an arrestable offence?" shouted one Tory wit).

A John Wilkinson called from Ruislip. "Could we have a debate on the worsening situation in Rhodesia?" Mrs Beckett, performing faultlessly, did not hang up: "At Foreign Office questions, 40 minutes were spent on Zimbabwe, which is the country's name."

Oddly, the Speaker let Mr Wilkinson's ignorance pass. Now that really is bullshit.

fields.headline: Black union leader accuses 'hostile' Straw
fields.trailText: Britain's most prominent black trade union leader has launched a ferocious attack on the government's handling of race relations, accusing Jack Straw of "playing a hostile tune for black Britons".
fields.body:
Britain's most prominent black trade union leader has launched a ferocious attack on the government's handling of race relations, accusing Jack Straw of "playing a hostile tune for black Britons".

Bill Morris, the general secretary of the Transport and General Workers' Union, claimed that the Home Office has unveiled a series of policies on asylum and immigration which have created a climate of fear and "given life to the racists".

The intervention by Mr Morris severely undermines the government's claim to be tackling the institutionalised racism uncovered by the Macpherson report into the murder of the black teenager, Stephen Lawrence.

Mr Morris said that black people would reserve judgment on the government's response to the report in the light of Mr Straw's policies on asylum seekers and the immigration bonds imposed on visitors from the Indian Subcontinent. "The UN has charged the Tories with whipping up racial intolerence," Mr Morris writes in today's Independent. "But the home secretary and the Home Office team must accept responsibility for creating the environment in which this is acceptable.

"The mood music is playing a hostile tune for black Britons. But it is the Home Of fice and indeed the ministers who are playing their part in the orchestra. By heralding measure after measure to stop people entering Britain the Home Office has given life to the racists."

His intervention, which will embarrass ministers, came as Tony Blair and William Hague were upbraided by the Commission for Racial Equality for their handling of the crisis over asylum seekers. The commission's acting chairman called on the prime minister and the Tory leader to "consider very carefully" the language used in recent weeks. Hugh Harris also called on Mr Hague and Mr Blair to reaffirm their commitment to the commission's principles signed by party leaders in 1996.

Mr Harris said: "It is for the leaders of all parties to consider very carefully the language being used by themselves and their members on asylum seekers, immigration and race relations issue." He also pointed out that many asylum seekers had were in "genuine risk of persecution and attack in their own country".

He intervened after the Liberal Democrats lodged a complaint about the language used by the Tories and Labour. The Lib Dem home affairs spokesman, Simon Huges, said: "The nature and content of the debate was in danger of replacing fact with fiction."

webTitle: Racist views widespread in Northern Ireland

fields.headline: Racist views widespread in Northern Ireland
fields.standfirst:
Race issues in the UK: special report

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Racist views are twice as likely to be encountered in Northern Ireland as sectarian ones, according to the province's most comprehensive study of prejudice.
fields.body:
Racist views are twice as likely to be encountered in Northern Ireland as sectarian ones, according to the province's most comprehensive study of prejudice.

A University of Ulster survey, based on 1,267 interviews, found twice as many respondents would be unwilling to accept or mix with members of ethnic minority communities as would be unwilling to accept members of the opposing religion.

The survey comes amid an increase in race crime in Northern Ireland, where ethnic minorities, including the travelling community, are 1% of the population. The RUC is investigating 10 assaults on the Chinese community this year, and said earlier this month it was notified of 195 racially motivated incidents last year, a four-fold increase on 1997. The most recent attack was two weeks ago, on two students of Chinese race at Queen's University.

Paul Connolly, co-author of the study, said yesterday that Protestants were more likely to express racist views than were Catholics; the difference was small but significant, and increased when the self descriptions unionist and nationalist were applied instead.

The study found that, in the abstract, a significant majority held liberal attitudes, with 83% supporting equal opportunities in work and housing, and 87% agreeing children should be taught about minority ethnic cultures.

But 25% were unwilling to accept an African-Caribbean, Chinese or south Asian as a neighbour, while 40% would reject anyone from these groups as a close friend. Opposition towards travellers was much higher. The survey said 54% were unwilling to accept a person of south Asian origin as a relative through marriage, compared with 37% in a similar survey four years ago; for Chinese it was 53% compared with 32%.

The Chinese community is the largest minority, numbering 8,000; there are 1,400 travellers, 1,200 in the south Asian community, and slightly fewer African-Caribbeans.

fields.headline: Sukur, Suker and Surgery
fields.trailText: GALATASARAY FAN BAN
fields.body:
GALATASARAY FAN BAN

Leeds United's Uefa Cup semi-final second leg clash against Galatasaray will go ahead at Elland Road next Thursday with no Turkish fans. Uefa said the decision was taken because West Yorkshire police could not guarantee the safety of the 1,750 Galatasaray supporters. However the Turkish club will be given 80 complimentary tickets to distribute amongst their VIPs and club directors.

Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale was predictably pleased with the outcome. "I never doubted for one moment that Uefa would come to this decision. It is a victory for common sense. What we now have to do is get on, organise the game and make sure those people who do come from Galatasaray are afforded the appropriate hospitality."

But the verdict was greeted by outrage in Turkey. Galatasaray club deputy chairman Mehmet Cansun described it as "disgusting" while the Turkish FA accused Leeds of "intentionally increasing tension in an incomprehensible manner". Even striker Hakan Sukur expressed his disgust, telling Turkish TV: "We shall make Leeds pay for not welcoming our supporters to the match. We shall take great satisfaction in making sure it is Galatasaray who play in the final."

Meanwhile a Turkish prosecutor has formally charged four men with the murders of Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight in Istanbul last week and demanded they spend up to 30 years in prison. Those charged were named as Ali Umit Demir, Ozkan Balci, Suleyman Aydin and Suleyman Gokhan Guven.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

HAVE A LUCKY WEEKEND

Enter First Direct's Little Fella Challenge and you could win a VW Beetle or a Sony Wega Widescreen TV.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

I LOVE LONDON

"Tee hee! 11 goals in 14 starts! That'll easily be enough to secure me another year's contract in lahverly London, innit!" That's what we imagine top Anglophile striker Dagenham Davor Suker chuckled to himself as he slipped out from under his Big Ben duvet cover this morning, full of optimism and the joys of living in the world capital of crumbling transport infrastructure.

How wrong could he have been? Arsene manager Arsenal Wenger today took the jaunty stride out of Suker's Lambeth Walk when he decided not to take up the further year's option on Suker's contract. "There is no animosity. Davor has done a good job for us," explained Wenger without mentioning how the Croat had effectively kicked the Arse out of both domestic cups with his comedy cock-ups. "He has become a victim of Thierry Henry's explosion of form," continued Wenger diplomatically, picking shards of French football shrapnel out of Suker's face.

Wenger's bombshell means that Suker will be a free agent this summer and may have to face the prospect of leaving the city of his dreams (that's London). But Daggers needn't worry yet - here comes Appy Arry Redknapp, riding in like the cavalry on his cockney carthorse. "I think Davor already knows that we would like to have him here," said the desirous West Ham manager. "Now I know he is definitely leaving Arsenal I shall have a chat to Igor Stimac [Suker's friend] and ask him to speak to Davor on our behalf." Sorted! What a diamond geezer!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I don't go to as many parties as people think. I'm never at any parties three or four days before a game. I'm a quiet lad and I just stay in most of the time" - David Beckham during a rare appearance on the television this afternoon.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

20% off 10 classic top footy books from BOL!!! Including:

All Played Out by Pete Davies - the classic account of England's 1990 World Cup campaign;

Football in Sun & Shadow by Eduardo Galeano - a poetic parade of bizarre tales from the underbelly of world football;

Football Against the Enemy by Simon Kuper - winner of the William Hill Sports Book of the Year Award in 1994.

Click here to see more.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ASHEN-FACED RON & KNEE

It's a disaster that has wrenched hearts across the world. A real tragedy that has left man and child and sportswear executive in shock. It's not the famine in Ethiopia, nor the plight of Britain's estates. It's not even the new Oasis album. No, it's a lot bigger than that. It's Ronaldo's knee and, inflammation aside, it's only going to get bigger.

A statement released by Internazionale this morning confirmed that Ron had undergone surgery on a "traumatic break of the right rotula tendon". The op was judged a "perfect success" and Ron's recovery time is reckoned at around seven to eight months. Which means all the talk about his career being over is nonsense. So why are Inter president Massimo Moratti and Wanderley Luxemburgo kipping at his bedside while the Brazilian President faxes his condolences?

"My dear Ronaldo," wrote President and media ingenue Fernando Henrique Cardoso. "We Brazilians are praying for your speedy recovery. You are a great source of pride for our country." And a great source of headlines too. Which brings us neatly on to Diego Armando Maradona. The stumpy dumpy cardiac-challenged cokehead sent a message of support to Ron last night which read: "Your pain is my pain. I wish you a speedy recovery." The Fiver echoes those sentiments, but is also willing to lay on some pills if Ron wants them.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Spurs are reported to have made a £2.5m bid for the star of Nigeria's African Nations Cup campaign, Julius Aghahowa. The 19-year-old striker, famous for his multiple back-flip goal celebration, plays for Tunisian side Esperance who are believed to be holding out for £4m.

Harry Kewell is being chased by Inter as a replacement for the injured Ronaldo. Kewell, who has been linked with Inter in the past as the man to provide crosses for the Brazilian, is one of three potential signings, along with Lazio's Marcelo Salas and Vincenzo Montella of Roma.

Bobby Robson will move for his former charge, Portuguese international Sa Pinto in the summer. The winger looks set to leave his current club Sporting Lisbon at the end of the season, and is a big fan of the Newcastle boss.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Former Middlesbrough legend Wilf Mannion has died at the age of 81 after a prolonged illness. During his time at Middlesbrough he scored 110 goals in 368 games. 'The Golden Boy' won 26 caps for England, scoring 11 goals.

George Graham has been rushed to hospital with chronic joint inflammation likely to keep him off work for the rest of the season. The Spurs manager, 55, awoke on Thursday morning with an extreme fever that is expected to keep him hospitalised for a week. His deputy, Stewart Houston, will take over for tomorrow's match against Aston Villa.

Former Dutch manager Guus Hiddink has rejected an offer from Celtic and decided to stay at Real Betis, according to Betis president Manuel Ruiz Lopera.

There will be a minute's silence before tomorrow's matches, which have been put back to 3.06pm as a mark of respect on the 11th anniversary of the Hillsborough tragedy.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Hold The Back Page (11pm, 3.30am)

It's the weekend so it must be Brian Woolnough. And if it's Brian Woolnough it must be Brian Woolnough's One Night Noticeboard! "Shaun, put your clothes back on, put away that guitar and stop staring out the window at us! Sully and Monty." Any perverts skulking around your house? Help is at hand when McCaff's Message Board comes back on Monday - the.boss@theguardian.com.

Sky Sports 3: First Division Football - Live (7pm, 1am SS2, 4.30am SS2)

Alan Curbishley takes time off from starring in risible soap operas about football to watch his team get promoted.

ONsport 1: Don't Mention the Score - Live (5.55pm, 10pm)

If we could, we would.

Uefa Big Cup Magazine (9pm)

Magazine in the sense of a device for continuously recharging a stove with solid fuel?

webTitle: Ahern to tax Blair over BNFL influence with ministers

fields.headline: Ahern to tax Blair over BNFL influence with ministers
fields.standfirst: Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: The Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, is to ask Tony Blair why British Nuclear Fuels appears to be able to dictate the wording of a reply to an Irish MP who wrote to him about Sellafield.
fields.body:
The Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, is to ask Tony Blair why British Nuclear Fuels appears to be able to dictate the wording of a reply to an Irish MP who wrote to him about Sellafield.

Dublin is also to demand a full explanation from Helen Liddell, the minister of state at the Department of Trade and Industry, of how the company appears to influence the release of information on the nuclear plant.

The Irish government's anger grew from the leaking of scores of confidential memorandums to the Channel 4 Dispatches programme and the Guardian, which revealed that BNFL was involved in "dirty tricks" operations to mislead and undermine MPs.

The documents showed that when Mildred Fox, an independent MP for Wicklow, wrote to Mr Blair asking him to consider the closure of Sellafield her query was passed to the Department of Trade and Industry and then straight to BNFL.

A confidential memo from a BNFL manager told the DTI: "In reply to an Irish MP we believe that it is important to be assertive and not to be appearing to justify or apologise for the UK nuclear industry."

It went on to say that Ms Fox as "one of a handful of independent MPs" did not merit a reply from the prime minister of the trade secretary. BNFL dictated what to say and Mr Battle, then junior energy minister, used most of the information verbatim to reply to Ms Fox.

Yesterday Ms Fox - who is furious about the way she has been treated by the British government - met Mr Ahern, who told her he would raise the issue with Mr Blair when he next met him.

Mr Ahern told the Guardian in an official statement: "I am concerned that representations by a member of this house appeared to have been dealt with in this way and intend to ask the energy minister, Joe Jacobs, to raise this issue in the first instance with the British minister for energy, Helen Liddell."

Privately the Guardian has been told that the Irish government is furious about the cavalier attitude taken by the Department of Trade and Industry in replying to what is regarded as a very sensitive issue in the republic - the pollution of the Irish sea by discharges from the Sellafield plant.

fields.headline: Classic children's library: 0-3
fields.trailText: It is never too soon to buy your child's first book. Even the tiniest baby can learn about the world from looking at books and about language from hearing you read. These very first books will be as loved, misused and possibly as chewed as a teddy bear (many of the most popular titles now come in sturdy board versions)
fields.body:
It is never too soon to buy your child's first book. Even the tiniest baby can learn about the world from looking at books and about language from hearing you read. These very first books will be as loved, misused and possibly as chewed as a teddy bear (many of the most popular titles now come in sturdy board versions).

Books for this age group need to be simple and bright. That doesn't mean they can't be either poetic or profound, although there are few really great books for the under-threes. There are, however, plenty of highly enjoyable ones. Pick those that you will enjoy reading over and over and over again; children of this age like familiarity and will never tire of the books they love. You, of course, might, so those books with a sly glance in the direction of adult humour are much appreciated.

10 Minutes Till Bedtime by Peggy Rathmann (Puffin, £4.99)

Ten minutes is a lifetime when you are little and almost anything can happen. It certainly does in this surreal, almost wordless tale in which, as the countdown to bedtime begins, the house is invaded by a busload of hamsters arriving for the bedtime tour. They get everywhere, from the bathroom to bedroom. The great thing about this funny, odd little book is that it is so matter of fact in the way it presents a skewed reality. Neatly bridging the gap between reality and dream worlds, this book may encourage children to make a connection between their dream lives and their waking lives. At the very least, it will make them laugh and help them learn to count backwards from 10. The drawings are like detailed cartoons, busy and full of perceptive little touches that make this as enjoyable for adults as it is for children.

Daisy and the Beastie by Jane Simmons (Orchard, £4.99)

When Daisy the Duck's grandpa reads her and little Pip a story about the Beastie, Daisy is determined to find the Beastie for herself on their own farm. So it's off to the chickens to see if the Beastie is lurking there, and down to the barn in case the Beastie is with the cows and the sheep. But it turns out there is something nasty in the woodshed. Simmons's vivid picture book knows that it is the beasties you can't see that are the most frightening, and it soothes small fears by revealing the terrible, fearsome beastie to be two playful kittens. Cynical adults will know that this alliance between beak and claw cannot last into adulthood but children fall for this gentle story without fail. Best of all, the pictures have a direct quality that cleverly captures the intensity of the world as experienced through young, not-yet-jaded eyes.

Spot Bakes a Cake by Eric Hill (Puffin, £4.99)

Originally written for his own small son, Eric Hill's collection of lift-the-flap books never date as they tell of the adventures of the loveable little dog that rates in the nation's consciousness along with the Andrex puppy. But the Andrex puppy can't help you learn to read. The great thing about these big, bold books is that they bear repeated readings and introduce the very young to new situations and experiences such as going to school, going to a party, staying overnight and going to the circus.

Meg and Mog by Helen Nicholl and Jan Pienkowski (Puffin, £4.99)

There remains something very stylish and attractive about these extremely simple books about a witch and her cat that is always getting into scrapes. The text is kept to a minimum and for lots of children it is the few words in these books that become the very first that they read.

The Very Hungry Caterpillar by Eric Carle (Puffin, £4.99)

It is almost 30 years since Carle's wondrous book first appeared but it is still a marvellous thing, never bettered in the age of the pop-up and the cut-away. The life cycle of the butterfly is recounted in the very simplest terms using bold blocks of colour and minimal language as the caterpillar emerges from the egg and nibbles his way through the pages. This is a colour book, a counting book, a days of the week book and a nature lesson. It is transforming in every sense from the final triumphant emergence of the butterfly to the finger-sized holes in the pages that demand exploration by tiny hands. A book that is quite crucial to happiness.

The Baby's Catalogue by Janet and Alan Ahlberg (Puffin, £4.99)

The lives of six babies (including a set of twins) living in five different families are dissected under various headings such as Mums and Dads, Baths and Bedtimes, Shopping and Dinners and Accidents (falling down the toilet, feeding your birthday cake to the dog). In effect it is a book of lists, but all the paraphernalia surrounding a small child's life is detailed with wit and affection. For a small child it is like looking in the mirror and seeing a reflection of a life that is both recognisable but also less ordinary. Peepo (Puffin, £4.99) is a variation on these themes set during the last war.

Each Peach Pear Plum by Janet and Allan Ahlberg (Puffin, £4.99)

"In this book/With your little eye/Take a look/And play I spy..." A delectable little book with a poem on each page that gives a clue to the characters from a well-known fairytale or nursery rhyme hiding in the picture opposite. Encourages eagle eyes as the stories of Tom Thumb, the Three Bears, Cinderella and others become joined in a seamless thread of nonsense.

We're Going On a Bear Hunt by Michael Rosen and Helen Oxenbury (Walker, £4.99)

In fact you'll be going on it very frequently once this book joins your library. Rosen's version of the old familiar game has a comic slant as a family set off on a imaginary bear hunt, find a real one and get chased back home. The language is delightful to small mouths, all swishy swashy, squelch squerch and hooo wooo, and the chanting rhythm completely infectious. Oxenbury's lovely watercolours add to the effect. Not just a book for sharing but one for acting out with the whole family.

Where the Wild Things Are by Maurice Sendak (Collins Picture Lions, £5.99)

Quite possibly one of the best books ever written. Sendak's story about Max who gets into mischief and is sent to his room and who "sails through night and day and in and out of weeks and almost over a year to where the wild things are" is a masterpiece of the subconscious. The anger of the child who longs to eat up the mother who calls him "a wild thing" creates the monsters who despite roaring their terrible roars are rather benign figures totally under Max's domination. This is a book about the terrible frightening storm of anger that wells up in the breast of the two-year-old and the warm safety of home and a good hot dinner when "the wild rumpus" is finally over. No home with children should be without it.

The Tiger Who Came to Tea by Judith Kerr (Collins, £4.99)

Just as Sophie and her mum are settling down to tea, the doorbell rings and an uninvited guest arrives. One of the comic joys of this book is the sang-froid with which Sophie and her mum accept the tiger as if they are perfectly used to having dangerous beasts roaming the kitchen, eating all the food in the fridge and drinking all the water out of the taps. All the better if it means Sophie can't have a bath and the family has to go out for supper in a cafe. A really delightful, friendly book. Just like the tiger.

Can't You Sleep Little Bear? by Martin Waddell and Barbara Firth (Walker, £9.99)

Little Bear is frightened of the dark. At bedtime he can't sleep, not even with the Biggest Lantern of Them All at his bedside. But fortunately Big Bear finds an ingenious way to reassure him. Beautifully written story that dispels all fear of the dark with captivating drawings that display the kind of wit that keep adult interest even after many readings. Well Done, Little Bear in which Little Bear demonstrates all the clever things he can do and falls in the river is the latest in a series that now runs to four books.

Brown Bear, Brown Bear, What Do You See by Bill Martin Jr (Puffin, £4.99)

Another brilliantly simple book that works on the "I Spy" principle as animals in bright colours spot their friends. Good for chanting, learning colours and animals.

The Elephant and the Bad Baby by Elfrida Vipont and Raymond Briggs (Puffin, £4.99)

Runner up for the Guardian Award this is a really beautiful little book in which an elephant and a bad baby wreak havoc as they embark on a glorious chase through town.

Dear Zoo by Rod Campbell (Puffin, £4.99)

When a small boy writes to the zoo to ask for a pet he isn't offered many suitable candidates. Lift the flap and you'll get a surprise too. Delightful book for the very young.

Strange Bear by Hilary McKay (Hodder, £4.99)

Simon is a toddler who loves his teddy bear, Snowtop, whose fur is covered in jam, paint and sand. Mum and Gran are not so keen. So Gran takes him out for the afternoon, and on their return a Strange Bear is waiting for Simon. That night they go on a Snowtop hunt. The story works on two levels, so it is satisfying both for adults which will enjoy the throwaway humour and small children who know the importance of your own special teddy with his own special smell.

Isabel's Noisy Tummy by David McKee (Red Fox, £4.50)

Isabel has a noisy tummy. Nothing can stop it burbling and gurgling. Isabel gets embarrassed and her friends get the giggles. But, on a school visit to the zoo, Isabel's roaring tum saves the day. Very sharp modern drawings combine with tummy humour to make this a winner.

Five Minutes' Peace by Jill Murphy (Walker, £4.99)

Mrs Large is desperate for just five minutes to herself. But everywhere she goes in the house the children follow her. Murphy's lovely, witty books about an elephant family show situations recognisable to every child and every mother who has ever wanted her own five minutes of peace.

Spot Goes to School by Eric Hill (Puffin, £3.99)

Engaging series of brightly coloured lift the flap books that tell of the everyday adventures of a small puppy and his menagerie of friends. Very good for early word recognition.

Coming To Tea by Sarah Garland (Puffin, £4.50)

Garland takes familiar events in a toddler's life such as having friends to tea, going swimming or doing the washing and turns them into mini-aga sagas. The humorous illustrations make these good books to share and talk about.

Maisy Goes to Playschool by Lucy Cousins (Walker, £7.99)

One in a best selling series about a loveable little mouse who does all the things a toddler would do. The drawings have a flat, childlike quality that small children find appealing and they love the sturdy pull the tab and lift the flap elements.

Mog and Bunny by Judith Kerr (Collins, £9.99)

Consistently good series of books about a cat called Mog and the family with whom she lives. Everyday tales of family life made special by Kerr's sympathetic storytelling.

Nice Work, Little Wolf by Hilda Offen (Puffin, £4.99)

When Little Wolf fell into the Porker's cucumber frame, he was forced to work hard to make up for it. But one day he gets his own back. Smarties award winner that will delight any child who knows that wolves and pigs are one bad combination.

Mr Archimedes' Bath by Pamela Allen (Puffin, £4.99)

Science comes easily to tots with this story in which the animals wonder where all the water has come from when Mr Archimedes' bath overflows. Everyone takes turns getting in and out until they discover who is responsible for the mess.

webTitle: Take a break:  a guide to awards for young designers

fields.headline: Take a break:  a guide to awards for young designers
fields.trailText:
New Generation Award
Sponsored by Marks and Spencer. For British cutting-edge designers who have been in the business for fewer than four years. The scheme provides free exhibition space at London Fashion Week and catwalk show support.
How to enter: apply for sponsorship for London Fashion Week in September, to Tonie Myles-White at the British Fashion Council, 5 Portland Place, London, W1N 3AA.

Various awards for students at colleges that participate in Bhs Graduate Fashion Week, June 5-8, including Collection of the Year Award, Bhs High Street Excellence Award, Amex Innovation Award, Fashion Journalism Award, Media Award and the Bodyform Bodywear Award. fields.headline: Cutting edge
fields.standfirst: London Fashion Week might propel the lucky few to catwalk stardom, but the bulk of British talent is helped along by smaller events and awards.  Laura Craik  reports
fields.trailText: London Fashion Week might propel the lucky few to catwalk stardom, but the bulk of British talent is helped along by smaller events and awards.
fields.body:
In a small room just off Oxford Circus, students from all over the country are busy making plans for the future. Portfolios featuring colourful sketches and fabric samples are spread out on trestle tables, the odd plate of sandwiches floats by, and the buzz of excited conversation is night-club-loud. This is the open day of the British Fashion Council's colleges forum, a rare opportunity for manufacturers, designers, retailers and press to get a sneak preview of the work done by students who will graduate in June.

It might not be as flashy as Graduate Fashion Week - there are no catwalk shows here - but it is an invaluable way of linking up students with the industry, and has a proven success rate in getting them jobs. More than 60% of graduating students gain employment in the industry in the UK, and a further 9% find jobs abroad.

"Some retailers come along with a shopping list - they'll need a cutting-edge sportswear designer, for example. A number of links have been established since we set up the first forum eight years ago," says Simon Ward, the administrator for BFC. "We've looked at making it bigger and more glamorous, but it works as it is."

It certainly seems to: representatives from Arcadia, Miss Selfridge and Coats Viyella, as well as smaller boutiques, including Koh Samui, are all making the rounds in a bid to spot fresh new talent. No clothing samples are on show, but, as one retailer explains, being talked through a portfolio is often a far better indication of talent, business sense and dedication than watching a student's wares float down the catwalk.

This is one of the many behind-the-scenes events BFC organises with the aim of helping students to a brighter future.

The BFC is chiefly known in Britain for owning and organising London Fashion Week, the biannual extravaganza where stars are born, catwalk slots are fiercely fought over and an over-packed schedule means, sadly, that not everyone gets the recognition they deserve. But it does much more besides.

In the cutthroat world of fashion, awards are a vital way of helping talent achieve increased funding and greater recognition. The most widely publicised is the New Generation Award, sponsored by Marks & Spencer.

Since its inception in 1993, it has given financial help to more than 50 designers, including now-famous names such as Antonio Berardi, Julien Macdonald, Clements Ribeiro and Matthew Williamson. "The number of companies that haven't survived are in single figures," says Ward. "I always remember the first lot of entrants - [Alexander] McQueen rolled his rail of clothes into the Ritz and promptly rolled it out again, presumably thinking they would sell themselves."

The Princess of Wales Charitable Trust is the newest award set up by the BFC. It was organised in 1998 to give a student who would otherwise be unable to afford it the chance to go on to study an MA course after completing their BA. Course fees are paid, along with a contribution towards living expenses. "Princess Diana supported our events; she loved talking to students about their work and often stayed longer than she was supposed to," says Brian Godbold, vice-chairman of the BFC. The award is funded by six industry-related private patrons and is expected to provide support for at least 15 years.

Its first recipient has just graduated. Germaine Sharpe, 25, was finishing her final year at the University of Northumbria at Newcastle when a tutor suggested she try for the award. "I wasn't going to do an MA because I couldn't afford to. I'm really pleased I did, though - it was the next step along. I've developed my knitwear so much more."

Sharpe, who did her MA at Central St Martins, says the extra 18 months of training added vital polish to her skills. "It was a difficult, hardworking course, but that's what I expected. It has definitely given me more confidence, made me experiment more." She describes her work as "minimalist, but deceptively so", and is currently freelancing for a number of design houses including Ghost.

Last weekend saw the fruits of another competition, this time sponsored by Topshop. Ten student finalists showed their collections in front of a panel of judges at Topshop's flagship Oxford Circus branch; the winner, Alexandra Stylianidis, gets a six-month work placement, including a trip to Hong Kong with a buyer, as well as the opportunity to have her collection sold in selected stores.

Most students are, of course, lured into the fashion industry by the promise of their name shining off a shop front in Bond Street, but the sad reality is that only a very small number achieve solo success. Most find jobs working for someone else. This is why the BFC is so committed to forging links between colleges and the industry: such links result in bona fide employment.

Ann Tyrrell, chairman of the colleges forum, helped set up the BFC Pattern Cutting Award in 1997 after realising that the industry was crying out for skilled workers. "I get endless calls asking if I know of a good pattern cutter," she says. "I don't think students realise it's a very creative job, and that the career prospects are fantastic. Pattern cutters are queen bees on the continent. Designers like John Galliano and Hussein Chalayan have done a lot to push the notion - they've emphasised that it's all about the team behind them as well."

Simon Ward agrees: "It's all about craftsmanship and bringing all these different craftspeople together, which is what the old ateliers are all about. [In] the weeks building up to Fashion Week, a pattern cutter could ask for any money they wanted to." After a series of successful seminars held at colleges throughout the country, Ward hopes the the profile of pattern cutting has been raised.

For all the negative talk about less foreign press and buyers attending London Fashion Week, its squeezed-in slot between New York and Milan and the Brits' perennial lack of interest in fashion, the enthusiasm of British students remains undented. Little wonder: the British clothing industry is the sixth-largest manufacturing sector in the UK, employing some 300,000 people.Let's just hope more retailers dig deep into their pockets and see the virtue of financing an award or a scholarship. In the wake of a lack of strong governmental support, their help would be invaluable. And in doing so, they might discover the designers who will take their companies forward in the 21st century.

webTitle: Noye guilty of M25 'road rage' murder

fields.headline: Noye guilty of M25 'road rage' murder
fields.standfirst:
Killer of Stephen Cameron jailed for life
On the trail of a killer
Noye's defence
Excerpts from the testimony
fields.trailText: Kenneth Noye was today jailed for life after being found guilty of murdering Stephen Cameron during a road rage fight four years ago on the M25 Swanley interchange in Kent.
fields.body:
Kenneth Noye was today jailed for life after being found guilty of murdering Stephen Cameron during a road rage fight four years ago on the M25 Swanley interchange in Kent.

The jury took more than eight hours to reach its 11-1 majority verdict. In returning their decision, the eight women and four men rejected Noye's argument that he had stabbed the 21-year-old electrician in self-defence.

The fatal knifing on Sunday May 19, 1996, occurred after Noye, 52, swerved his Land Rover Discovery in front of the small red van driven by Cameron's fiancee, Danielle Cable, 21, who had passed her driving test seven months before.

Lord Justice Latham said: "The jurors, having found you guilty of murder, as you know, there is only one sentence I can impose and that is life imprisonment. I don't propose to say anything more at this stage."

Cameron's parents leapt up at the back of the court, clasping each other's hands and shouted "Yes" when they heard the verdict.

In a prepared statement, Ken and Toni Cameron said: "We are happy that justice for Stephen has been done, but this is not a joyous occasion. Our lovely son Stephen is dead and our lives will never be the same again ... We are still experiencing overwhelming grief, as any parents who have lost a child will understand."

Mr Cameron, a cleaning company manager, added that he had been unable to sleep for several days and had not worked since the murder in 1996. "It's cost me my job. I just couldn't cope with the pressure of it. It's the price you have to pay. Perhaps we can get on with the rest of our lives, hopefully."

When pressed about seeing Noye in the dock, Mr Cameron said: "It really was hard. But for Stephen's sake, you keep strong. It shows you how far they were struggling to dig up so much rubbish about Stephen. He was a normal 21-year-old. He had a temper - I had a temper when I was 21."

Julian Bevan QC, for the prosecution, said Cameron's murder, shortly after 1pm at the Swanley interchange of the M25, was born out of "anger and pride" resulting from a punch-up between the two men. Within minutes of the attack, Mr Bevan said, Noye set about covering his tracks before fleeing the country with a suitcase full of cash.

"What he did following this (attack) clearly tells its own story," Mr Bevan said. The prosecution described how Noye made several phone calls from his mobile phone to associates and his wife, Brenda, to make arrangements for his getaway. He flew by helicopter to France and then by private jet to Madrid, before going further south in Spain. There was evidence, the jury heard, that the Land Rover Noye was driving had been disposed of.

In one of the highlights of the trial, Ms Cable told the Old Bailey how Cameron, 21, stumbled towards her with blood seeping from his two wounds as Noye drove off.

"I saw Steve clutch his chest," she told the jury. "He said 'He stabbed me Dan, take his number plate.' I saw blood on his chest. It was dreadful. I was screaming and crying for someone to help me. Then Stephen collapsed on the floor."

Witness Alan Decabral said he saw Noye smile as he sped from the scene.

On the witness stand, Noye said he had stabbed Cameron in self-defence, after the 21-year-old had flown at him in a "wild rage" during a simple misunderstanding.

During the trial, witnesses gave conflicting evidence on who started the fight. Heather Titley said she saw Cameron grab the collar of Noye's shirt and scuffle with him at the Swanley interchange of the M25. Helen Merral also told the jury that Cameron landed the first punch. But Stephen Darling said Noye landed the first blow, hitting Cameron in the face with his right fist, in a version similar to Noye's account.

"That was definitely the first action of violence when they met," Mr Darling said. "The younger fellow was getting the better of the older one. I saw him throw punches and kicking. The older bloke was backing off. I thought the older fellow got out to give the young one a clout, then the young one got the better of it. I thought 'Fair enough, he deserves it'."

Police tracked down Noye to his hideout in Spain in August 1998. They flew Ms Cable out and she identified him as he sat in a restaurant. He was immediately arrested and extradited last May, following several appeals. Initially he told Spanish police he had not been at the scene of the stabbing, admitting in court that it was a total lie. He then changed his story to self-defence. Noye told the court he survived life on the run because he had money in Spain, as much as he wanted because he had been "doing deals" previously.

webTitle: Why Uefa finally made the right decision

fields.headline: Why Uefa finally made the right decision
fields.standfirst: Mail your comments to sean.ingle@guardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Even on the sunniest of days, during the most meaningless of pre-season friendlies, Elland Road can seem like an imposing place to visit. The ground stands above the city like an open prison, and the Leeds fans carry a certain reputation before them.
fields.body:
Even on the sunniest of days, during the most meaningless of pre-season friendlies, Elland Road can seem like an imposing place to visit. The ground stands above the city like an open prison, and the Leeds fans carry a certain reputation before them.

Usually visiting supporters find their fears are unfounded: Elland Road is no better or worse than any other ground in the country.

But the tragic murders of Kevin Speight and Christopher Loftus last week, mixed with the explosive issues of race and religion (which always seem to rear themselves whenever an English side plays against Turkish opposition) meant that next week's Leeds v Galatasaray match was another Istanbul waiting to happen.

Which is why, despite days of dithering, Uefa has made the correct decision. It was right to ban Galatasaray fans from the return leg at Elland Road.

Of course nobody likes seeing away supporters barred - we all recoil at the mere mention of David Evans and his membership scheme at Luton - and there are understandable fears that Uefa's decision could create a precedent. But extraordinary circumstances sometimes demand an extraordinary response.

For those of you still not convinced, let's look at what's happened in this country since the stabbings of the two Leeds fans. First of all, a Turkish man in London was beaten up and his shop vandalised in an apparent 'revenge' attack. Other attacks on Turks soon followed. Then Muzzy Izzet - Mile End born and bred - faced a barrage of booing from some Everton fans because of his Turkish roots.

And every day since the stabbings the press has vilified Galatasaray - now surely everybody's favourite demon - for being at best insenstitive and at worst indirectly cupable for the murders.

If Uefa hadn't reacted, Elland Road next Thurday would have been a war zone. Even the sight of thousands of officers lined up in riot gear wouldn't have stopped a few mindless idiots, dressed up in the flag of St George and tooled up with Mr Stanley, from fulfilling their Alexander the Great delusions and starting a mini Holy War.

Simply put, the 1,700 Galatasaray fans - no matter how well protected - were at risk. That's why Uefa had to make the decision to ensure their safety. Thankfully, after days of indecision, it finally did.

Even the sight of thousands of officers lined up in riot gear wouldn't have stopped a few mindless idiots, dressed up in the flag of St George and tooled up with Mr Stanley, from fulfilling their Alexander the Great delusions and starting a mini Holy War. Simply put, the 1,700 Galatasaray fans - no matter how well protected - were at risk. That's why Uefa had to make the decision to ensure their safety. Thankfully, after days of indecision, it finally did.

fields.headline: Labour's withering grass roots
fields.trailText: More than 200 constituency Labour parties are not sending delegates to this year's Labour party conference. We ask why
fields.body:
Labour's grassroots activists have delivered a devastating snub to the party leadership by voting with their feet to stay away from the party conference in Brighton in the autumn.

Today's Guardian reveals that more than 200 constituency parties have failed to nominate representatives for conference, traditionally the high point of the political year.

The clear implication, that Labour's rank and file is no longer willing to provide the spear-carriers for the party's lavish productions on the seafronts of England, must be deeply worrying for the leadership and the apparatchiks of Millbank. They have all but succeeded in stamping out dissent, but now seem dangerously close to stamping out the party itself where it counts, at ground-level.

A former Labour stalwart in Bury, Lancashire, summed up the mood today: "If I was still working for the party I don't think I would feel like going. Partly it's the north-south divide, which looks very real from where I stand, but also it's a general feeling of disillusion, of being let down. I know that it all looks different when you're in opposition, and that when you get into power reality sets in. I know they don't have all the answers, but there doesn't seem to be any room for passion or sparkiness in the party," she said.

Another long-serving party supporter, in Wiltshire, was less charitable. "Why bother with conference? It's a waste of time and money. It's not as if it has any influence any more, let alone the power to change things. Now it's just a spectacle; a show with stars and a chorus line," he said.

Most long-serving card-carriers can remember when conference was an affair of strong passions and tortuous manoevres, as left and right wrestled with the complexities of the block-vote, elaborate procedural disputes, and the quintessentially old Labour device for mangling the English language, known as the compositing committee.

Long hours would be spent in smoky hotel rooms hammering conflicting motions into an ugly mass of verbiage, to be further hacked around in shrill plenary debate and then incorporated into party policy - often to the visible horror of the leaders on the main platform.

But these days, the main worry for the leaders is whether they have got the right camera angle, or a speech crammed with soundbites trite enough to make primetime television news.

As a former lobby correspondent for the Guardian, I can remember heroic nights on the seedier margins of conference, with the big cats of the Labour jungle slashing and snarling at each other, wild-eyed young ideologues denouncing their elders and betters, and activists in dungarees drumming up support for saving gay whales.

And that was when the party was in government. Later, during the Foot/Kinnock era, the fun was even faster and more furious.

Returning to conference last autumn, after a break of more than 15 years, I was astonished by the transformation. All was calm and serene. Everyone was polite, neat, and well-behaved. The agenda ran like clockwork. The setpiece speeches were dutifully applauded, and the fringe meetings were models of consensus. In other words, nothing happened. That's why poor John Prescott got such a lot of publicity for using his Jaguar instead of walking to the conference centre.

fields.headline: At your convenience
fields.standfirst: Toilet trouble, getting the blues, an old cow and a noisy neighbour
fields.trailText: Toilet trouble, getting the blues, an old cow and a noisy neighbour
fields.body:
Down the pan
It's been an inconvenient week for the inhabitants of Pennan, in north-east Scotland, where the community's only public toilet is to be closed by Aberdeenshire district council. The tiny seaside village shot to fame as the location for Bill Forsyth's 1983 film Local Hero, and attracts thousands of visitors every year. But now, in an effort to save money, Aberdeenshire council has targeted 69 of its 105 public loos for closure, including the one in Pennan. "It's ludicrous," fumed local publican Brenda Kutchinsky. "How on earth are we supposed to encourage tourism when we can't provide people with a simple facilty like a toilet?" Now residents have now started a petition urging the council to rethink - although not everyone mourns the toilet's closure. "It's only the English who need all this flushing toilet rubbish," opined one local man. "There are private places amongst the rocks, and seaweed to clean yourself up with." Aberdeen Press and Journal

Spot of bother
Picasso had his blue period, and now the village of Brereton is having one too. The tiny Cheshire hamlet, one of the prettiest in the north-west, has broken out in a sudden rash of large blue spots. "They've everywhere," commented one villager. "On trees, gateposts, walls. Great big blue splodges. It's like the village has contracted some sort of pox." Initially it was thought the spots were the work of vandals. But further investigation revealed that they were left by a North West Water employee, who sprayed blue marks around the village to identify the position of water meters. "I appreciate that meters need to be identified," said parish councillor Stuart Yarwood. "But they could have been a bit more discreet about it. If it had been children painting these obscene blobs the police would have been called." North-West Water admits that its meter-man may have been overzealous in his application of the blue spray, but has refused to remove the marks, a stance that is supported by at least one local resident. "They're great," he enthused. "The village was rather drab before. Now it looks like the set of the Magic Roundabout." Crewe and Nantwich Chronicle

Bovine boozer
Despite its pejorative overtones, the phrase "old cow" accurately describes Erica Glendale of Milfield, Northumberland. Ms Glendale is 20 years old, making her one of the oldest dairy cows in Britain. Erica was named after the Twickenham streaker Erica Roe. She has lived three times longer than the average cow, and has delivered 238,000 pints of milk during her long life. "It's not often you get a cow as good as Erica," said her owner, farmer Bob Maxwell. "If you work with an animal for 20 years you get pretty attached to it." As a special birthday treat Erica was taken to the Red Lion Inn at Milfield for a slice of cake and a pint of milk stout. "All the regulars love Erica," enthused one drinker. "But I think the Red Lion ought to think about getting a new carpet." The Berwick Advertiser

Brassed off
A cruel blow was this week dealt to Thornton Cleveleys brass band when Ted Sykes, its euphonium player, was issued with a noise abatement order by his local council. The order came after complaints from Mr Sykes's neighbours in the Lancashire town. "It was like torture," commented one woman. "Hour after hour of 'oom-pa-pa, oom-pa-pa'." Mr Sykes, 58, has played in brass bands since he was a child. The council order leaves him liable to a £5,000 fine for the merest toot or parp from his instrument. He fears it could spell the end of his career. "I'm worried that I won't be able to keep up to the high standards of the other 27 musicians," he sighed. "I need to practice at home at least three times a week to stay note sharp for galas on the Fylde coast." He has lodged an appeal against the order, and is experimenting with an electronic euphonium silencer, although he says that it isn't the same. "Euphoniums are meant to make a racket," said one band member. "A quiet one is a contradiction in terms, like a handsome Yorkshireman." Blackpool Gazette

Letter of the week
"It was a sickening sight: blatant criminal activity in broad daylight in central Aberdeen. Passers-by, too afraid to take action, looked on as crime after crime was committed. It shook me to the core. I feel duty-bound to provide a description of these criminals in the hope that the police might be able to track them down and prosecute them for the heinous crimes. The criminals were female, about 5ft 2ins tall and wore grey/brown raincoats, stockings or tights, ankle-length boots possibly zipped up at the sides, fluffy hats reminiscent of tea-cosies and each had a brown leatherette shopping bag over one arm. The most dangerous of the pair also had a carrier bag into which she placed her ill-gotten gains. They were both aged perhaps in their late sixties. The crime was an undoubted drug-related incident, as the stolen items are well known to add to the uplifting effect of a nice cup of tea. In case you haven't guessed, I'm talking about the annual crimewave of picking flowers in public places. Ladies, please leave them alone! DA Robinson, Aberdeen Press and Journal

webTitle: Uefa ban Galatasaray from Elland Road

fields.headline: Uefa ban Galatasaray from Elland Road
fields.standfirst:
Uefa's statement
Full background
fields.trailText: Leeds United's Uefa Cup semi-final second leg clash against Galatasaray will go ahead at Elland Road next Thursday with no Turkish fans.
fields.body:
Leeds United's Uefa Cup semi-final second leg clash against Galatasaray will go ahead at Elland Road next Thursday with no Turkish fans.

Uefa announced this morning that all 1,750 away tickets will be withdrawn from sale and declared invalid, but that 80 complimentary tickets will still be given to Galatasaray officials. The club will be able to distribute the tickets to "persons who, in the opinion of the club will behave in a dignified and restrained manner" , according to a statement.

The announcement was confirmed this morning nine days after the deaths of Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight following violent clashes in Istanbul ahead of the first leg. European soccer's governing body had spent the last few days weighing up reports from both sides and the West Yorkshire Police before finally backing the plan put forward by Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale.

Ridsdale was pleased with the decision this morning: "At the end of the day, we have said since the events in Istanbul, it's far better for everybody if we could guarantee there would be no further incidents.

"I think this decision confirms it is easier to manage and we are delighted with the Uefa decision. What we now have to do is get on, organise the game and make sure those people who do come from Galatasaray are afforded the appropriate hospitality."

Galatasaray chairman Frank Suren reluctantly accepted the decision. "We will certainly come and play our game, but we want guarantees for our safety and security", he told BBC Radio Five Live, expressing disappointment that Turkish fans will not be able to travel. "I cannot accept that the British police will be unable to control 1,700 spectators within the stadium," he said.

Turkey's sports minister Fikret Unlu was less restrained in his opinions. He told Turkish TV that Uefa had made "A bad decision. Such a thing cannot be. No doubt [Galatasaray] will win. This victory will show to the whole world that the British attitude is wrong," he said.

Uefa's statement read: "The return match in the Uefa Cup semi-final between Leeds United and Galatasaray will go ahead as scheduled.

"The West Yorkshire Police informed Uefa that they would be unable to guarantee the safety of any visiting supporters travelling independently to the match. This report was submitted to the Turkish club who proposed that the match be played behind closed doors or at a neutral venue. This point of view was endorsed by the Turkish Football Association."

Uefa also insisted that the charges brought against Leeds for failing to control their players during the first leg of the tie were not an attempt to "persecute" the club.

"Any club in any of the European club competitions which has four or more players cautioned in a single match is automatically sanctioned for improper conduct of the team", said the statement. "This matter, therefore, has no relationship whatsoever with the tragic incidents which took place in Istanbul."
