webTitle: A flashing spread on the flashing spread

fields.headline: A flashing spread on the flashing spread
fields.standfirst: Dave Podmore takes a long, long look at Matthew Brimson only to unearth a betting scandal
fields.trailText: "A fantastic effort which fully justified the faith I had in the lad." Dave Podmore takes a long, long look at Matthew Brimson only to unearth a betting scandal
fields.body:
After a career in cricket as long as Dave Podmore's, you've obviously got to be looking at ways to put a bit back into the game. Coaching is something I've come to fairly recently, and let me tell you it gives me just as much of a buzz to see a youngster like Matthew Brimson produce the goods as it ever gave me to smear a single or grab a pole in a brown-trouser situation.

Some would say that at 29 Brimsony is still a bit young to be thrust into the big arena, but he's certainly shown that when the questions are asked there's one English cricketer who's ready to put his hand up - or down in this particular instance - and prove that if you're long enough, you're old enough. Turn to the Leicestershire team photo in the millennium edition of Wisden's Almanack and there Matthew's achievement is, for all time, for everyone to see. At the end of the day it was a fantastic effort which fully justified the faith I had in the lad.

But then I read the transcripts of conversations with an unnamed Indian bookie. It seems that the whole thing was fixed and the Leicester boys had cleaned up by buying the 'flashing' spread at 0-1! It would not be an overstatement to say Pod was disappointed. It's true that when I first started playing I thought betting on the spread meant what kind of Shippam's you'd get during the tea interval, but since then I haven't missed too many tricks. Thanks for including me in the scam, lads.

Obviously you've got to earn a living somehow with the derisory rates of pay we have to suffer (my last benefit didn't even make seven figures). And the problem is even worse on the subcontinent. Guys having to play in unacceptable temperatures, miles from a decent curry, and for what? Score two hundred in an hour and if you're lucky you might win a moped. It was natural that professional cricketers wanted something to put in those panniers.

Having said that, I have nothing but contempt for Hansie Cronje. I suppose it explains his poor run of form in the one-dayers against England - that string of 4 noughts in a row. Fortunately there was a 1 in front of them but even so - ten grand for throwing a match, I ask you! He's selling guys down the river. Graham Cowdrey was right - the Springbok skipper has not only let himself down, but abused the good name of the spread.

webTitle: On the trail of a killer

fields.headline: On the trail of a killer
fields.standfirst: How a chance sighting by a British tourist in Spain proved the linchpin that put Kenneth Noye behind bars, by crime correspondent Nick Hopkins
fields.trailText: Kenneth Noye's life on the run came to an end on a warm Friday evening as he sipped a glass of Rioja outside a restaurant in Tarifa, southern Spain.
fields.body:
Kenneth Noye's life on the run came to an end on a warm Friday evening as he sipped a glass of Rioja outside a restaurant in Tarifa, southern Spain.

He was taken by surprise as he was bundled to the pavement by plain-clothed officers at 10.25pm.

Police had almost lost hope they would ever find Noye, who had slipped out of the country 24 hours after stabbing Stephen Cameron, pulling strings in the underworld to cover his tracks.

Detective Superintendent Nick Biddis, who was in charge of the inquiry, suspected Noye was in Spain, but had, thus far, failed to pinpoint him.

When, in April, 1997, a Sunday newspaper speculated that Noye had been killed by criminals, a Briton on holiday in Spain saw someone who resembled the photograph of Noye in the story. He rang local police and the information was filtered back to DS Biddis.

Police desperately wanted to capture Noye. He was, after all, "a cop killer", whose rise from the council estates of Bexley Heath to a become a multi-millionaire had been achieved, to some degree, by manipulating the police.

Born in May 1947, Noye had turned to crime as a teenager, becoming involved in a stolen car ring which ended with him serving one year in a borstal.

When Noye met future wife Brenda Tremain, he became friendly with used-car dealer Micky Lawson, who lived opposite her house.

Lawson introduced him to influential figures in the London underworld, and, by 30, Noye had become a wealthy man, with a 20-acre home in West Kingsdown, Kent, a villa in Cyprus and a £500,000 yacht.

In the late 1970s, he began dealing illegally in gold. But it was not until the Brinks Mat gold bullion robbery of 1983 - which saw two of the men involved jailed for 25 years without any of the £26m stolen being recovered - that a full-scale investigation into Noye's activities was launched.

Before the investigation was complete, however, the operation was blown wide open, when, in January 1985, Noye stabbed DC John Fordham, an undercover officer he found in the grounds of his house.

At trial, Noye claimed he had killed Fordham in self-defence, and was acquitted. Eight months later, he was back at the Old Bailey accused of dishonestly handling Brinks Mat gold. He was sentenced to 14 years.

After his release in 1994, Noye became paranoid about reprisals from the police and carried a knife everywhere. On Sunday, May 19, 1996, he used it, on Stephen Cameron.

Noye and Cameron came to blows after a road-rage incident at the M25 Swanley interchange. The fight ended with Noye stabbing Cameron to death and driving off in his Land Rover Discovery.

The following afternoon Noye flew to Madrid, later moving south-east, to Atlanterra, on the Costa de la Luz. Brenda visited him twice, not realising that Spanish police had already started an investigation after the tip-off.

Within weeks, DS Biddis knew Noye's whereabouts and flew Stephen Cameron's girlfriend, Danielle Cable, out to Spain to identify him. DS Biddis decided to arrest him immediately. On Friday August 28, 1998, his team followed Noye to the El Campero fish restaurant and made their move.

The restaurant owner, Jose Melaro, said: "They threw him to the ground, handcuffed him, bundled him into an unmarked car and drove off. It all happened in about 30 seconds."

 This is an excerpt from a longer article by Nick Hopkins which will appear in full in tomorrow's Guardian

When, in April, 1997, a Sunday newspaper speculated that Noye had been killed by criminals, a Briton on holiday in Spain saw someone who resembled the photograph of Noye in the story. He rang local police and the information was filtered back to DS Biddis. Police desperately wanted to capture Noye. He was, after all, "a cop killer", whose rise from the council estates of Bexley Heath to a become a multi-millionaire had been achieved, to some degree, by manipulating the police. Born in May 1947, Noye had turned to crime as a teenager, becoming involved in a stolen car ring which ended with him serving one year in a borstal. When Noye met future wife Brenda Tremain, he became friendly with used-car dealer Micky Lawson, who lived opposite her house. Lawson introduced him to influential figures in the London underworld, and, by 30, Noye had become a wealthy man, with a 20-acre home in West Kingsdown, Kent, a villa in Cyprus and a £500,000 yacht. In the late 1970s, he began dealing illegally in gold. But it was not until the Brinks Mat gold bullion robbery of 1983 - which saw two of the men involved jailed for 25 years without any of the £26m stolen being recovered - that a full-scale investigation into Noye's activities was launched. Before the investigation was complete, however, the operation was blown wide open, when, in January 1985, Noye stabbed DC John Fordham, an undercover officer he found in the grounds of his house. At trial, Noye claimed he had killed Fordham in self-defence, and was acquitted. Eight months later, he was back at the Old Bailey accused of dishonestly handling Brinks Mat gold. He was sentenced to 14 years. After his release in 1994, Noye became paranoid about reprisals from the police and carried a knife everywhere. On Sunday, May 19, 1996, he used it, on Stephen Cameron. Noye and Cameron came to blows after a road-rage incident at the M25 Swanley interchange. The fight ended with Noye stabbing Cameron to death and driving off in his Land Rover Discovery. The following afternoon Noye flew to Madrid, later moving south-east, to Atlanterra, on the Costa de la Luz. Brenda visited him twice, not realising that Spanish police had already started an investigation after the tip-off. Within weeks, DS Biddis knew Noye's whereabouts and flew Stephen Cameron's girlfriend, Danielle Cable, out to Spain to identify him. DS Biddis decided to arrest him immediately. On Friday August 28, 1998, his team followed Noye to the El Campero fish restaurant and made their move. The restaurant owner, Jose Melaro, said: "They threw him to the ground, handcuffed him, bundled him into an unmarked car and drove off. It all happened in about 30 seconds."  This is an excerpt from a longer article by Nick Hopkins which will appear in full in tomorrow's Guardian

fields.headline: Mobile phone licence auctions
fields.standfirst: The government has raised £19.5bn from its mobile phone auction in which companies have been bidding for frequencies for the third generation of mobile phones. Mark Tran explains how the government came into this unexpected windfall and what it intends to do with it.
fields.trailText: The government has raised £19.5bn from its mobile phone auction in which companies have been bidding for frequencies for the third generation of mobile phones. We explain how the government came into this unexpected windfall and what it intends to do with it.
fields.body:
What are the phone companies bidding for?
The government is auctioning five licences to create the networks for the third generation (3G) of mobile phones - devices that can deliver voice, fax and video. The 3G phones will be capable of offering virtual banking, online billing, home shopping, video conferencing and internet access.

What are the five licences?
The most powerful of the licences, Licence A, is not open to the existing four mobile phone companies in the UK. This is to ensure that a newcomer, without an existing network, can take on the current operators. Licence B is the most powerful licence available to the firms which already operate mobile phone networks in Britain. The others, Licences C, D and E, have less capacity and are roughly of the same level. Each licence will last for 20 years.

How does the auction work?
The auction takes place in a sequence of rounds, with bids submitted by fax to the Radiocommunications Agency's headquarters in London's Docklands. In each round, participants bid simultaneously for any one of the five licences - with Licence A reserved for new entrants. At the end of each round, bidders are informed of all bids. The holder of the highest bid on each licence is required to remain inactive in following rounds until outbid. The auction ends when no more bids are received.

Why did the government decide on an auction?
It says auctions are fast, transparent, fair and economically efficient. But consultants who advised the government on spectrum pricing warn that bidders could significantly overpay for the licences based on the returns they would achieve from mobile internet commerce in the future. The Smith Group constultancy, which carried out the original work with the Radio Communications Agency on spectrum pricing, is concerned that the winners will have to charge a lot for G3 services, undercutting the government's goal of mass, cheap access to the internet. Finland avoided auctions for this reason.

Who else has taken the auction approach?
There was a similar auction in the US last year, which ended in a shambles. The winners defaulted on their payments, forcing a rerun which pulled in only 10% of the $4bn (£2.7bn) bid the first time round.

How many companies entered the bidding?
Thirteen started - the four existing mobile operators and nine potential new entrants. The top bidders after 126 rounds are: Licence A, TIW, £4.1bn ; Licence B, Vodafone, £5.1bn; Licence C, BT3G, £3.4bn; Licence D, One2One, £3.4bn; Licence E, Orange, £3.6bn. The total comes to £19.8bn and analysts expect the final figure to reach £22bn. The four incumbent operators, Vodafone, BT Cellnet, One2One and Orange, are driving the bidding. Vodafone and BT's networks are overstretched and need more capacity in order to get more customers.

How much did the government expect to receive?
Gordon Brown's budget made a provision of less than £3bn for the proceeds.

What does Mr Brown plan to do with his unexpected good fortune?
He does not plan to give it to his cash-hungry cabinet colleagues at education, defence or transport. The Treasury said: "The prudent and sensible way forward is to pay off debt." The chancellor has already come under criticism from the International Monetary Fund for going on a spending spree by pledging a big increase on health.

webTitle: Pressure grows to halt Zimbabwe tour

fields.headline: Pressure grows to halt Zimbabwe tour
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office minister Peter Hain came under political pressure last night to call off the Zimbabwean cricket team's tour of England, which is due to begin in May.
fields.body:
The Foreign Office minister Peter Hain came under political pressure last night to call off the Zimbabwean cricket team's tour of England, which is due to begin in May.

The Labour MP Tom Pendry, a former shadow sports minister and a long standing anti-apartheid campaigner, said that if promised elections were not held in the southern African country in May and President Robert Mugabe's government failed to push squatters off illegally occupied farms, then the cricket tour must be called off.

Mr Pendry said he would be supporting an early day motion, likely to be tabled next week, demanding that the tour, which is due to include two Test matches, be called off.

Whether the early day motion will halt the tour remains to be seen. Yesterday it was given the go-ahead by the English and Zimbabwean cricket authorities.

Mr Pendry, who campaigned against South African tours of Britain in the 60s, said Mr Hain would be inconsistent if he failed to call for the tour to be abandoned. Mr Hain was a leading campaigner in the Stop Tour demonstrations of the 70s, which ruined South African rugby tours.

A ban on sporting contacts played a large part in forcing the South African regime to change its views on apartheid. Mr Pendry believes a ban on Zimbabwe's cricketers might also concentrate minds.

The England and Wales Cricket Board confirmed last night that they had held talks with the Foreign Office about the tour.

So far the Foreign Office has insisted that the tour should proceed. The shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, yesterday refused to join the calls to stop the tour, saying Britain's quarrel was not with the people of Zimbabwe, but with Mr Mugabe and his corrupt dictatorial regime.

However, other senior Conservatives on the foreign affairs select committee supported the call for the tour to be called off if it became clear that the elections were not going to take place.

fields.headline: Anthony Hopkins
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the Welsh boy made good, then gone US-mad on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the Welsh boy made good, then gone US-mad on the net
fields.body:
1. "When I get out of bed in the morning, I want my wife to say: hello, big boy. I don't want to make little deals, I want to make big deals... I want a big bank." Yes, it's actor Anthony Hopkins in his ode to Barclays Bank.

2. Some people think Anthony is indeed getting too big for his boots. Yesterday he became an American citizen.

3. Born in a small village near Port Talbot in Wales, Hopkins was, by his own admission, "screwed up and antisocial". He joined the RADA drama school and worked in the theatre before concentrating on films.

4. Despite acting in 90 movies, it was the role of Hannibal Lecter in The Silence of the Lambs in 1991 that made his name.

5. Hopkins excels in reserved, slightly sinister parts - Americans tend to regard him as the epitome of Britishness - which makes his rejection of Wales even more galling. "It is disgusting what he has done. He has lost touch with his roots and should be ashamed of himself," opined a Port Talbot resident.

6. It hasn't been a good year for the actor. The Guardian described him as "looking and sounding like Hannibal Lecter's boring twin brother" in anthropological thriller Instinct.

7. In January, a fire broke out at his Kensington pad. Luckily, his Oscar statues were saved and Hopkins was in LA, where he moved in 1998.

8. Then Barclays announced that they were closing hundreds of rural branches - just as Hopkins was seen extolling the virtues of size in the TV advertisement.

9. Yet only 15 months ago, he said he was having the time of his life.

10. No doubt he's pinning his hopes on the release of Hannibal later this year, when he reprises the unquestionably evil character of Dr Lecter.

fields.headline: Excerpts from the testimony
fields.trailText:
Julian Bevan QC, for the prosecution: "Mr Noye, the truth is that so far as this incident is concerned you became angry with that young man and deliberately stabbed him, didn't you?"
Noye: "No, I am quite a placid man. I did not do that. It is not true."
fields.body:
Julian Bevan QC, for the prosecution: "Mr Noye, the truth is that so far as this incident is concerned you became angry with that young man and deliberately stabbed him, didn't you?" Noye: "No, I am quite a placid man. I did not do that. It is not true."

Noye on violence: "I said to my sons from when they were little, 'If you ever get into a fight, just walk away. You are not being a coward. You never know what will happen.'"

Noye on the incident: "I said, 'Sorry mate, I thought you were someone else.' He just started. I said, 'Sorry,' and he said: 'You will be, you C-U-N-T - I will kill you.' As he came at me, I see his face, and I knew I was in trouble."

Noye: "I cannot fight, I was worn out. I didn't have nothing left. I thought, I cannot take much more, and no one has tried to stop the fight. So I struck out."

Heather Titley, a witness: "The younger man came up behind the older one and grabbed at his left shoulder with his right hand and then punched the older man with his left hand. I believe the punch landed on the jaw. They then exchanged a couple of blows in quick succession."

Helen Merral, a witness: "The first thing I saw, it is horrible to say, as the young boy is not here now, but the younger man hit the older one. But I don't know, it was a fight, and it was not all on one side. I just saw the younger man hit the older man in the face. The older man broke away and began to walk away. I saw the younger man go up as if he was going to carry on."

Alan Decabral, a witness: "I could see him [Noye] shut the blade with both hands and put it back in his right-hand pocket. He nodded at me, as if to say `That's sorted him out'."

Michael Kelly, a witness: "As far as I was concerned, I just saw two stupid people having a fight that shouldn't have happened."

Danielle Cable, Stephen Cameron's fiancee: "I saw Steve clutching his chest. He said, 'he stabbed me Dan, take his number plate.' I saw blood on his chest. It was dreadful. I was screaming and crying for someone to help me. Then Stephen collapsed on the floor."

Stephen Darling, a witness who said Noye struck first: "That was definitely the first action of any violence when they met. The younger fellow was then getting the better of the older one. I saw him throw punches and kicking. The older bloke was backing off. I thought the older fellow got out to give the younger one a clout, then the younger one got the better of it. I thought 'Fair enough, he deserves it.'"

fields.headline: Noye's defence
fields.trailText: Kenneth Noye said he left home on Sunday May 19 1996 to drive to a pub in Chislehurst, Kent, to have a drink with friends. On the way, he saw a red Rascal van but said he did not remember "cutting up" the vehicle, as the prosecution claimed. He thought he recognised the driver, Danielle Cable, as a woman he met in a nightclub with his friend Mickey Taylor.
fields.body:
Kenneth Noye said he left home on Sunday May 19 1996 to drive to a pub in Chislehurst, Kent, to have a drink with friends. On the way, he saw a red Rascal van but said he did not remember "cutting up" the vehicle, as the prosecution claimed. He thought he recognised the driver, Danielle Cable, as a woman he met in a nightclub with his friend Mickey Taylor.

When the van started flashing its lights at the next set of traffic lights, he got out. The moment he saw the couple he realised it was a case of mistaken identity, but Cameron, the passenger in the van, had got out to confront him, the court heard. The men, who did not know each other, became involved in a fight. In his testimony, Noye said Cameron had shouted at him: "I will kill you" and ignored several pleas to calm down.

Noye, who testified for four and a half hours, described how he staved off Cameron by pulling a 4in lock knife from the pocket of his jeans. But the younger man kept punching and kicking him. Noye, fearing Cameron would seize the knife from him, then stabbed him, he told the jury.

Noye denied being a violent man, saying: "I've never hurt anyone. I've never hurt an animal." The day after the killing, Noye fled the UK with a suitcase of cash, fearing that he would not get a fair trial because of previous brushes with the law. In December 1985, Noye had been acquitted of the murder of John Fordham, an undercover officer. Noye stabbed him when he found him hiding in the garden of his home in Kent. Fordham was wearing a balaclava and camouflage.

As in this road rage case, Noye pleaded self-defence. Noye also admitted during the trial being sentenced to 14 years for dishonestly handling gold stolen during the notorious Brink's-Mat gold bullion robbery at Heathrow airport in 1983. After his release from prison in 1994, Noye said he had feared "being fitted" up by the police and being kidnapped by criminals who believed he knew where three tonnes of missing gold had been hidden. Noye said he carried a knife because he was in constant fear of his life.

fields.headline: Uefa's full statement
fields.trailText: Uefa has decided that the return match in the Uefa Cup semi-final between Leeds United AFC and Galatasaray SK will go ahead as scheduled. The match will be played at Elland Road on 20 April 2000 at 20.00 hours BST.
fields.body:
Uefa has decided that the return match in the Uefa Cup semi-final between Leeds United AFC and Galatasaray SK will go ahead as scheduled. The match will be played at Elland Road on 20 April 2000 at 20.00 hours BST.

This decision was taken by the Bureau of the Committee for Uefa Club Competitions at a meeting chaired by Jean Fournet-Fayard of France, based on reports submitted by the official Uefa Delegate at the first leg in Istanbul and the Uefa security officer, followed up by a review of the situation by the Uefa Stadia Committee, statements received from both clubs and a report from the West Yorkshire Police.

On 11 April 2000, the West Yorkshire Police informed Uefa that they would be unable to guarantee the safety of any visiting supporters travelling independently to the match. This report was submitted to the Turkish club who proposed that the match be played behind closed doors or at a neutral venue. This point of view was endorsed by the Turkish Football Association.

In reaching its conclusion, Uefa was aware that the decision would not meet unanimous approval but decided to cancel the sale of tickets to Turkish supporters.

This means that the 1,750 purchase tickets allocated to Galatasaray SK for the match at Elland Road are declared invalid and must be returned immediately to Uefa. These tickets will be retained by Uefa and the areas to the stadium to which they relate will, in principle, remain empty.

However, the 80 complimentary tickets allocated to Galatasaray SK may be distributed by the Turkish team to persons who, in the opinion of the club, will behave in a dignified and restrained manner. They, along with directors, players, staff and media representatives, will be regarded as Galatasaray SK's official party.

Leeds United AFC will be instructed to ensure that the local police authorities do everything possible to guarantee the safety of the Galatasaray SK official party from the moment of their arrival in England until their departure.

In addition, Leeds United AFC have been instructed to ensure that supporters will be screened on entry to the stadium in order to prevent any 'independent' Turkish supporters from being admitted to areas occupied by Leeds United AFC fans. Any such persons in possession of a valid ticket will be escorted to the area initially reserved for the 1,750 Turkish fans.

Subject to the wishes of Leeds United AFC and subject to approval by the security authorities, Uefa has proposed that both teams and the match officials will wear black armbands during the match and that the game will be preceded by a period of silence.

The decision, which is final and binding, is designed to guarantee the safety of all participants and spectators. Uefa also wishes to emphasise that Galatasaray SK are not responsible for the tragic deaths of two Leeds United AFC supporters in the streets of Istanbul and that the match in Istanbul was played without any incidents. Leeds United AFC have also expressed their satisfaction at being treated properly and respectfully by Galatasaray SK and will do everything in their power to ensure that representatives of the Turkish club are treated with the same respect in Leeds.

As a result of the tragic incidents in Istanbul, there has been a great deal of public comment, some of it emanating from representatives of both clubs, which has been of a partisan and inflammatory nature hardly conducive to calming a volatile situation.

It has even been suggested that Uefa is persecuting Leeds United AFC because the English club has received notification that it is liable to a fine for improper conduct of the team during the first leg match in Istanbul.

Uefa wishes to stress that any club in any of the European club competitions which has four or more players cautioned in a single match is automatically sanctioned for improper conduct of the team. This matter, therefore, has no relationship whatsoever with the tragic incidents which took place in Istanbul.

Uefa requests that all parties concerned, including the media, out of respect for the lives that have been lost, should refrain from making any further controversial statements and should concentrate instead on ensuring that the second-leg match is played in an atmosphere of peace and safety.

This means that the 1,750 purchase tickets allocated to Galatasaray SK for the match at Elland Road are declared invalid and must be returned immediately to Uefa. These tickets will be retained by Uefa and the areas to the stadium to which they relate will, in principle, remain empty. However, the 80 complimentary tickets allocated to Galatasaray SK may be distributed by the Turkish team to persons who, in the opinion of the club, will behave in a dignified and restrained manner. They, along with directors, players, staff and media representatives, will be regarded as Galatasaray SK's official party. Leeds United AFC will be instructed to ensure that the local police authorities do everything possible to guarantee the safety of the Galatasaray SK official party from the moment of their arrival in England until their departure. In addition, Leeds United AFC have been instructed to ensure that supporters will be screened on entry to the stadium in order to prevent any 'independent' Turkish supporters from being admitted to areas occupied by Leeds United AFC fans. Any such persons in possession of a valid ticket will be escorted to the area initially reserved for the 1,750 Turkish fans. Subject to the wishes of Leeds United AFC and subject to approval by the security authorities, Uefa has proposed that both teams and the match officials will wear black armbands during the match and that the game will be preceded by a period of silence. The decision, which is final and binding, is designed to guarantee the safety of all participants and spectators. Uefa also wishes to emphasise that Galatasaray SK are not responsible for the tragic deaths of two Leeds United AFC supporters in the streets of Istanbul and that the match in Istanbul was played without any incidents. Leeds United AFC have also expressed their satisfaction at being treated properly and respectfully by Galatasaray SK and will do everything in their power to ensure that representatives of the Turkish club are treated with the same respect in Leeds. As a result of the tragic incidents in Istanbul, there has been a great deal of public comment, some of it emanating from representatives of both clubs, which has been of a partisan and inflammatory nature hardly conducive to calming a volatile situation. It has even been suggested that Uefa is persecuting Leeds United AFC because the English club has received notification that it is liable to a fine for improper conduct of the team during the first leg match in Istanbul. Uefa wishes to stress that any club in any of the European club competitions which has four or more players cautioned in a single match is automatically sanctioned for improper conduct of the team. This matter, therefore, has no relationship whatsoever with the tragic incidents which took place in Istanbul. Uefa requests that all parties concerned, including the media, out of respect for the lives that have been lost, should refrain from making any further controversial statements and should concentrate instead on ensuring that the second-leg match is played in an atmosphere of peace and safety.

fields.headline: Radical departures
fields.standfirst: Gilles Dufour's sacking by Balmain highlights an increasing tension in fashion houses. How can they give spirited designers freedom to attract new clients without destroying their image?  Hadley Freeman  reports
fields.trailText: Gilles Dufour's sacking by Balmain highlights an increasing tension in fashion houses. How can they give spirited designers freedom to attract new clients without destroying their image?
fields.body:
Judging by the reactions of the audience and the press, the autumn/ winter 2000 show for Balmain's pr t-à-porter line was a triumph. Yet just two weeks later, creative director Gilles Dufour was sacked by the fashion house's management. For although the show had been widely viewed as a success, in the eyes of the august fashion house it had categorically failed. Failed, that is, to be true to the spirit of Balmain.

The problems at Balmain have highlighted an increasing tension in the fashion industry. As the older generation retires, a slew of younger designers are taking over the eponymous lines of these couturiers.

Kenzo Takada of Kenzo has handed over to Gilles Rosier, Tom Ford is now be the creative director at Yves Saint Laurent. But not every transition has gone quite so smoothly as these. Already this year the fashion world has witnessed some clumsy upheavals. After three seasons as director of Yves Saint Laurent Rive Gauche, Alber Elbaz found himself expected to answer to two masters - the daunting combination of Saint Laurent and Tom Ford - when the Gucci group bought out Yves Saint Laurent and Ford was installed. Elbaz announced his resignation last February.

More embarrassing was the case of John Bartlett at Byblos. Bartlett's relationship with Byblos's management had been fractious throughout his three years as creative consultant, and things came to a head this winter when Bartlett staged a form of fashion rebellion, allegedly telling US fashion editors not to bother going to the Byblos show that year.

So what is more important - the identity of the fashion house or the creative expression of the designer? And how much freedom should the designer have within the fashion house?

Fuzzy statements released by fashion houses when new designers are appointed emphasise the sense of confusion. Kenzo Takada's hopes for Rosier, for example, are typically vague and contradictory: "I'm sure he'll be able to renew the line while respecting our style."

Yet despite their anxiety, fashion houses know that modernisation is necessary for survival, as Ford demonstrated when he resuscitated the Gucci label 10 years ago. The difficulty is balancing new trends with the tradition of the fashion house.

An incoming designer has to decide what the brand name represents (such as the Ab Fab-ness of Lacroix, or the Parisian chic of Yves Saint Laurent) and ensure that his or her designs accord with that image.

This season's trend of "logomania" - in which items of clothing and accessories are speckled with G's, CD's and YSL's - could be seen as a reminder to the public of the brand name's cachet. As Dufour says: "When I designed at Balmain, I designed Balmain. I did not design Gilles Dufour. The general look was dictated by the management, but I did have creative freedom with the clothes."

Victoire de Castallaine, designer of the haute couture jewellery at Dior, says that other designers are even more constrained: "Some in the past have been told they have to sacrifice their ideas. Absolutely."

Of course, the ideal situation for a designer is to work for a fashion house as well as his or her own line, such as John Galliano, design director of Dior and of his own label. The designer then has financial and creative freedom.

Alexander McQueen sums it up: "If you want a starving Ethiopian on a jacket, come to McQueen. If you want luxury, come to Givenchy. I can do both." Although after Givenchy's autumn/winter 2000 show, which featured a luxe take on punk, some fashion insiders were wondering if London's most outrageous designer had gone too far in re-inventing Givenchy.

Total creative freedom doesn't always yield delights. For Dior's autumn/winter show, Galliano produced an imaginative collection heavily influenced by hip hop (frayed denim, shiny leather, outsized gold jewellery) and it divided the fashion world over its suitability for the venerable house of Dior.

When Yves Saint Laurent took over as creative director at Dior 40 years ago, his first col lection was a shocking departure from the classical style established by his predecessor - sexier, and now hailed as a work of genius. Inevitably, it did scandalise some Dior devotees, but Saint Laurent kept his job. Pretty soon, though, he craved total freedom and left to create his own label.

Ironically, former Byblos designers Keith Varty and Alan Cleaver thought they had found the ideal freedom at the Milan design company. "A company like Byblos doesn't exist in England," they enthused in 1990. "In Italy, designers are treated like pop stars." They were fired in 1995.

Even more ironically, Dufour and Elbaz had both been successful at Balmain and Yves Saint Laurent. Within three seasons, Dufour rejuvenated a label that had all but fallen into obscurity, making it the darling of young Hollywood and chic Parisiennes. And yet he found himself ousted after alleged management displeasure over two vest tops in Balmain's show emblazoned with the words "Whore" and "Bitch".

Dufour has launched a lawsuit against his former employers.

Elbaz's collections had been highly praised for their com- bination of YSL classicism with touches of moder nity. Yet even such success was not enough to withstand the incoming might of the Gucci group and polymath Ford. Unsurprisingly, both Dufour and Elbaz are said to be considering starting up their own labels.

According to fashion writer Linda Watson, Tom Ford at Gucci and Karl Lagerfeld at Fendi and Chanel have succeeded because they have taken "established labels and given them modern twists". But the truth is simply that these two designers are powerful enough (their own names are as famous as the labels they design) to have the freedom to experiment without fear of being sacked.

It is smaller designers such as Dufour and Bartlett who are at risk from nervous financial backers and over-protective management boards. Moreover, some fashion houses, such as Balmain, foster an image of conservatism, yet still want to attract a new generation of consumers. Dufour says this paradox is most apparent at the fashion shows. "British designers, especially McQueen and Galliano, exemplify this, as they show their clothes in a provocative way. You want to get them noticed. But they must be wearable, and go [with the label's image]. Also, they [financial backers] have to learn that it always takes at least three seasons for a line to make any money."

Despite the fate of Dufour, Elbaz and Bartlett, Rosier is optimistic about Kenzo. "I will work with lots of colours and prints," he has said, "but in my own way. I'd like people to say about my collection that it's new and different - but still Kenzo."

Dufour, however, offers Rosier some more concrete advice. "Be free, be creative... but have guts."

webTitle: Development of gene test drugs pose ethics dilemma

fields.headline: Development of gene test drugs pose ethics dilemma
fields.standfirst: Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: A revolution in the way new medicines are brought to market by genetically screening patients to weed out those who cannot benefit from drugs is planned by one of the world's biggest pharmaceutical companies in a move with enormous ethical and financial implications.
fields.body:
A revolution in the way new medicines are brought to market by genetically screening patients to weed out those who cannot benefit from drugs is planned by one of the world's biggest pharmaceutical companies in a move with enormous ethical and financial implications.

In as little as two years, Glaxo Wellcome hopes to market its drug Ziagen, a newly licensed anti-HIV treatment, in tandem with "DNA chips" - small disposable blocks that, treated with a sample of a patient's blood, will report whether or not that person is genetically preset to respond to the medicine.

The system seems to open the way to safer and more efficient prescribing of drugs: a world where patients will get prescriptions confident that a medicine will work and will not have harmful side-effects.

But in a proposal that is likely to generate heated debate, Glaxo wants to use the system - medicine response profiling, part of a new field called pharmacogenomics - to shorten the time between the development of a drug and government permission market it.

There will also be concern over the cost of the DNA chips and the ethical issue of who will have access to the findings garnered from mass genetic testing of patients.

For some people with diseases, there will be a difficult situation - the discovery that there is a drug designed to treat their condition, but that their doctor will not prescribe it because the genetic lottery has decreed it would not help.

In an article for today's edition of the Lancet, Allen Roses, head of genetics research at Glaxo, says the technology for tailormade medicines is almost ready and it is time to start changing the law to allow it to be used.

At present in Britain, expensive new drugs are rationed according to where people live - so-called "postcode prescribing". Other drugs, such as Glaxo's flu medicine Relenza, have been barred from NHS prescription pads altogether.

"Our ability to determine the right treatment for an individual patient before it is prescribed is not that far away," said Dr Roses. "This will remove the 'one size fits all' style of prescribing and allow for tailormade treatments."

Dr Roses argues that medicine response profiling has the potential to cap the spiralling cost of health care. "Economic rationing of effective medicines can be worse than having no treatment at all," he said.

As well as dividing patients into responders and non-responders, profiling can filter out patients doomed to suffer side-effects if they take a drug. This could lead to medicines now banned as too dangerous being put back on the market.

Glaxo's hope of using profiling to shorten the drawn-out business of testing drugs is also likely to be controversial.

New medicines now have to go through at least three stages of testing on humans before regulators certify them for sale: a test for safety, a test to see if they work, and a test to see if they work better than other treatments.

The pharmaceutical giant's vision is radically different. In the second and third stage, non-responding patients would be weeded out, making the tests quicker. The drug would then be put on restricted sale to patients who agreed to be genetically profiled. During the restricted sale period doctors who prescribed the drug would be obliged to report any new side-effects, and the DNA chips used to identify responders modified accordingly.

Many of the top dozen pharmaceutical firms, whose combined revenues add up to more than £120bn a year, are working on pharmacogenomics. A spokesman for the Swiss company Novartis said: "It's far too early to talk about it now. It's not yet ripe for the market."

Last month a leading researcher at another of the pharma top five, Peter Ringrose of Bristol-Myers Squibb, said: "We intend to ultimately apply pharmacogenomics across all of our therapeutic areas. We believe it will revolutionise the treatment of many diseases."

Richard Ashcroft of the centre for ethics in medicine at Bristol University said research in the US suggested people would be prepared to pay more for medicines they knew were tailored to suit them.

"Whether this would help the NHS from a financial management point of view, I doubt. But it would save people a lot of heartache and suffering."

He said he was worried that the subtle differences in drug response between ethnic groups could lead to medicines being tailored to the commonest genetic profiles in rich countries, at the expense of treatment for, say, north-east Africa.

"In the hi-tech, high-spend countries of western Europe and North America, pharmacogenomics will probably be a good thing, and will refine the drug development process to mean less risk to people in trials, and drugs coming on to the market more quickly. But on the global scale, I'm not sure it will be so positive."

Linking prescriptions to patients' genes depends on three scientific breakthroughs that have been, or are about to be, made. One is a map of hundreds of thousands of potential variations in human DNA. These variations distinguish one human being from another. This map is being prepared by a non-profit consortium and will be ready by the middle of next year.

A second breakthrough is robot and computer technology that can scan the genes of each patient in drug trials.

Finally, the DNA chips, made to check for the few hundred genetic variations that predict whether a patient should take a drug, will be mass produced.

webTitle: The further trials and tribulations of American Psycho

fields.headline: The further trials and tribulations of American Psycho
fields.trailText: Star of American Psycho Christian Bale has been defending the most controversial film to hit the screens since Oliver Stone's Natural Born Killers
fields.body:
Star of American Psycho Christian Bale has been defending the most controversial film to hit the screens since Oliver Stone's Natural Born Killers. Many people loathed Bret Easton EllisÕs portrayal of Patrick Bateman, a status-obsessed yuppie turned serial killer, and have been critical of the film ever since the idea of it was first mooted.

But Bale and director Mary Harron want audiences to know before heading to the cinema that their version is less about murder than it is a depiction of one man's descent into insanity and society's obsession with material possessions. As much as anything, they argue, it portrays a misogynist and racist whom society would reject.

"I think there is such a controversy about it, and many people just have a vague notion about the piece, that they are expecting it to be incredibly macabre. Now, it is violent, but that's rather the atmosphere and the tone, and the physical violence tends to be off camera. You finish the whole piece and what you really have witnessed is a real indictment of men,"

Harron has revealed that in Toronto, where Psycho was shot, she had to change the location of Bateman's office because the building owner feared negative publicity after a local newspaper wrote about the movie. She also described how a British tabloid called the film "disgusting" before it was even edited and how an American lawyer threatened a lawsuit against the film before reading the script or seeing it. Bale was advised that taking the Bateman role could ruin his career, with fans forever associating him with the serial killer. fields.bodyText: Star of American Psycho Christian Bale has been defending the most controversial film to hit the screens since Oliver Stone's Natural Born Killers. Many people loathed Bret Easton EllisÕs portrayal of Patrick Bateman, a status-obsessed yuppie turned serial killer, and have been critical of the film ever since the idea of it was first mooted. But Bale and director Mary Harron want audiences to know before heading to the cinema that their version is less about murder than it is a depiction of one man's descent into insanity and society's obsession with material possessions. As much as anything, they argue, it portrays a misogynist and racist whom society would reject. webTitle: Caine mutiny opens acting class divide

fields.headline: Caine mutiny opens acting class divide
fields.standfirst: Oscar winner's outburst unites stars from humbler backgrounds against snobbery in British film and theatre as valleys lad quits for States
fields.trailText: Oscar winner's outburst unites stars from humbler backgrounds against snobbery in British film and theatre
fields.body:
The acting profession was last night thrown into a tizz over the five letter word that is still its greatest taboo - class.

Nudity, violence and strong language hardly raise a hackle these days but pulses have been set racing after three "working class" stars branded British film and theatre "class ridden" and "snobbish".

Michael Caine set the cat among the pigeons by using his acceptance speech for his lifetime's achievement award at the Baftas to complain about how as a south Londoner with a "duff accent" he felt ignored and unloved, like "a stranger in my own country and profession".

The former meat market porter turned Hollywood star was promptly dismissed as an ungrateful, grouchy "millionaire whinger" until Jane Horrocks, who played alongside him in Little Voice, rallied to his defence.

Horrocks, 36, insisted there was "a lot of snobbery" in the film industry and said she was told to ditch her broad Lancashire accent at drama school. "Juliet Stevenson, Judi Dench and Maggie Smith are always getting awards. That isn't to say that they don't deserve them but it's much easier for them," she said. "It happens a lot with the middle and upper classes in the profession while a lot of people in the lower classes are ignored."

Bob Hoskins piled in to confirm that the British industry was indeed full of "lunatics" who judged actors on their accent and backround rather than their talent. "There is still a class aspect in this country. It is ridiculous," he said.

Last night the plebeian thespians found support from an unexpected quarter. Actor Corin Redgrave, head of the nearest thing British stage has to a royal family, said there was "sadly a lot of truth in what they say".

What is more, he claimed, it is much more difficult now for working class kids to become actors than it was even in Caine's day. "If it was hard for Michael Caine in the sixties, it's harder now. Back then there were a lot of working class actors and writers coming through. Take Albert Finney or Tom Courtenay. They could get grants to go to drama school but they are only given now on a discretionary basis, which means more often than not they are not getting them at all. I get heartbreaking letters all the time from young people working all hours to get through drama school. It's wrong and that is leading to working class people not being represented in the way they should."

Philip Headley, artistic director of the Theatre Royal Stratford East, said the class divide still held. "You only have to look at the careers of someone like Ann Mitchell, who was so brilliant in Widows on TV. She should be a mainstay of the National Theatre and the RSC but only now in her sixties is she getting to play the Greek tragedies on really big stages, and that is with Peter Hall in America."

Headley said the real unfairness came at awards, where middle and upper class actors usually clean up. Occasionally, working class actors do scoop the big awards though. Kathy Burke won best actress at Cannes for Nil By Mouth, but even she has not entirely buried the class hatchet.

When Helena Bonham Carter complained that you "have an easier time if you're not pretty and you're working class", Burke wrote her a little note to sympathise: "As a lifelong member of the non-pretty working classes, I would like to say to Helena Bonham Carter (member of the very pretty upper middle classes): shut up you stupid c***."

Even so, film and the theatre are still far less exclusive than many areas of British life, maintained producer Stephen Woolley. The bias emerges at award ceremonies.

He added: "Award committees will inevitably always go for the face that fits or that seems to be right and respectable.

"That's why maybe John Hurt who played Stephen Ward in [the Profumo film] Scandal never won a Bafta for his performance - people did not want to be seen as backing his character."

Actor Ray Winstone, a former boxer who won huge acclaim but few prizes for films such as Nil By Mouth, is much less circumspect. "People say there's no class system. Let me tell you, there f****** well is."

The oiks

Sir Ian McKellen: Don't let the knighthood fool you. Famously fled the "middle class" West End for down to earth Leeds.

Ray Winstone: Started as a boxer and was an amateur English champion before the director Alan Clarke spotted him.

Jane Horrocks: Lancashire-born actor who refused to lose her accent while at Rada

Kathy Burke: describes herself as "a north London working class Irish peasant and proud of it"

The toffs

Helena Bonham Carter: Aristocratic blue blood from a long line of bankers and politicians.

Rupert Everett: Scion of wealthy Norfolk gentry, who was packed off to Ampleforth when he was seven.

Ralph Fiennes: Can trace his lineage right back to the Norman Conquest where his forebearers built a castle at Hertsmonceux in Sussex.

Kristin Scott Thomas: Got that cut-glass accent at Cheltenham Ladies College.

webTitle: In brief and the latest casting news

fields.headline: In brief and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: Gary Oldman back on for Hannibal; Joseph Fiennes gets into the saddle, Miramax's Colditz drama, Richard Attenborough plans royal biopic, and why the Harry Potter film may be delayed
fields.body:
 Gary Oldman is back on the menu for Silence of the Lambs sequel Hannibal. Negotiations had reportedly stalled over the issue of Oldman's billing. But he has resumed talks to play the role of Hannibal Lecter's former victim and nemesis Mason Verger. Hopkins will reprise his Oscar-winning role, Julianne Moore replaces Jodie Foster as FBI agent Clarice Starling and Ridley Scott will direct.

 Joseph Fiennes is to play a cowboy in the western Dust for Yugoslavian director Milcho Manchevski.

 Today's Daily Mail reports that Harvey Weinstein's studio Miramax has acquired the rights to Major Pat Reid's best-selling books which tell the tale of his time as a Prisoner of War in Colditz and his successful escape from the supposedly escape-proof fortress. As for casting, "I've spoken to Tom [Cruise], Matt [Damon] and Ben [Affleck] and they're up for it and very interested," said Weinstein, "I'd like to match them up with all the young great British actors like Jude Law, Jonny Lee Miller and Ewan McGregor." The movie is still months away from pre-production.

 Richard Attenborough plans to make a film of the life of 19th century Austrian empress Elizabeth, the Hapsburgh royal murdered by an anarchist in 1898. The veteran British director has not yet found a star for the biographical project but has secured backing from German and Dutch investors. Attenborough is still looking for finance for a feature on Thomas Paine, the 18th century political activist.

 Bad news for Harry Potter fans. Warner Bros may have to delay the release of the movie based on the schoolboy wizard. Although the official word is that the project is still on track for a summer 2001 release, sources say that the delay in finding a director, partly down to of Steven Spielberg's prevarication, may make a winter 2001 release more likely.

fields.headline: Welsh angered by Hopkins' "betrayal"
fields.trailText: Two years ago he gave £1m to save Snowdon for the Welsh nation, but yesterday Sir Anthony Hopkins turned his back on the mountains and valleys of his homeland for the Hollywood Hills
fields.body:
Two years ago he gave £1m to save Snowdon for the Welsh nation, but yesterday Sir Anthony Hopkins turned his back on the mountains and valleys of his homeland for the Hollywood Hills.

In a short ceremony in a Los Angeles courtroom, the Oscar-winning actor became a US citizen, pledging allegiance to his adopted home and provoking outrage from Port Talbot to the Welsh assembly.

The ceremony was conducted outside normal hours, with press and public barred. Steven Spielberg and his wife, Kate Capshaw, and the producer Paula Wagner were present to hear the actor swear to bear arms on behalf of the US if required, and to renounce "any foreign prince [or] potentate".

Sir Anthony, 62, who in taking citizenship forfeits the right to use his title in the US, was accompanied by his girlfriend, Francine Kay, and his mother.

"He has been here [in the US] for a long time, and it seems like the right thing to do. Anthony is very happy about the citizenship," said a spokeswoman for the actor. The same could not be said for the citizens of Port Talbot, his birthplace.

"Anthony Hopkins is a local boy. It is disgusting what he has done. He has lost touch with his roots and should be ashamed of himself," said Glanville Mills, 67, a resident of the south Wales town.

The postmaster, Asghar Ali, 45, said: "Sir Anthony is always harping on about his Welshness, but when the chips are down he decides to go away. To be honest I think he is a hypocrite, but I'm still hopeful he will keep in contact with his home village. He is our most famous son."

The Welsh assembly member Gwenda Thomas said: "I'm shocked and disappointed by his behaviour. He grew up here and this is his background. Everyone here has always thought a lot of him, but his reputation has been dented recently."

Sir Anthony was criticised for appearing in adverts for Barclays Bank, which last week closed more than 100 rural branches, including one near Port Talbot.

To qualify for US citizenship he had to take a test on his knowledge of American history, undergo an FBI background check and an interview with immigration officials to establish, among other things, that he was of "good moral character".

His love of America contributed to the break-up of his second marriage, to Jennifer Hopkins, who wanted him to spend more time in the UK.

Explaining his fascination with America, and Los Angeles in particular, he said: "There's no past there. The desert burns off your memories."

Sir Anthony, whose career underwent a renaissance after his portrayal of the psychopath Hannibal Lector in Silence of the Lambs, will continue to be viewed as a UK national in Britain and will be free to work and use his title, which he received in 1993.

fields.headline: The Godfather
fields.standfirst: What kind of man would buy a maggot-infested cow's head? Or pay £1m for a huge bronze version of a £14.99 kids' toy? Step forward Charles Saatchi, Britain's most influential modern art collector. In the final instalment of his revealing series,  Gordon Burn  profiles the media-shy advertising executive who bankrolled Britart
fields.trailText: What kind of man would buy a maggot-infested cow's head? Or pay £1m for a huge bronze version of a £14.99 kids' toy? Step forward Charles Saatchi, Britain's most influential modern art collector
fields.body:
I must have got him on a good day, because he came back and the answer was yes. After years of asking and years of nononono, it was suddenly yes. Yes, he would agree to... well, let's not call it an interview, but anyway an... informal chat. On the record. Maybe over coffee. But (this was being relayed by the curator of the Saatchi gallery, Jenny Blyth) he wanted to keep it fun and, you know, light. Fun. But yes!

In fact I know I got him on a good day because it was a day Charles had gone to look at a new toy. With the New York dealer Larry Gagosian, who Saatchi has long used to "disperse" works from the collection that he has blown cool on, or judged are right for the market at that moment, he had been Rollered down to the West Country to cast a hungry eye over Damien Hirst's first new work for many years, at his studio near Stroud. A day out shopping. So he was up.

But he had been down, a friend had told me - dragged low by the reaction to the Sensation show - "Young British Artists from the Saatchi Collection" - towards the end of last year in New York. Instead of being a celebration of his collecting acumen and confirmation of his "modern Medici" status, it had all been elephant dung and city politics and the showboating of Mayor Giuliani instead. "He was very high in New York," the friend said. "He went in to install the show every day. And he was very pleased. But then it didn't go the way he expected at all."

Plus, in London the New Neurotic Realism debacle had reportedly got him into a bit of a grump. Neurotic Realism. The last big art movement. Remember it? No? That's OK. Nobody else does either. It was a synthetic attempt at having lightning strike twice. To hurry things on. Didn't work. Saatchi himself was rumoured to have found the NNR book he put out, with its tawdry cover and vapid boostering of a new "tinsel-camp aesthetic", a misjudgment and an embarrassment; evidence that perhaps it isn't so easy to engineer change - to invent the history of British art before it has happened.

So he had been down. But the day I called there was a song in his heart and a spring in his step and he was up. Almost every major talent attracts at least one or two important collectors at an early stage in his or her career. And, to his credit, Saatchi has supported Damien Hirst and a handful of that generation of artists almost from day one. He bought A Thousand Years in 1990 from a Hirst-curated show called Gambler. With its maggots and flies and rotting cow's head, and the attendant, almost impossible, problems of storage and installation, it was a work that almost every other collector in the world would have shied away from.

A year later, he paid for the trapping, transportation and preservation of the now-notorious tiger shark and then used his "top ad-man" abilities to turn it into a weirdly potent symbol of the age. Pictures of the shark were reproduced with a frequency which invested it with considerable power as an image and deepened its mystery: silent, immobile, latently lethal, suspended for eternity in its secure vitrine, it became a kind of logo of the times; a blank and yet peculiarly charged emblem.

Saatchi says that he believes a thumbnail history of the art of the last half-century would go: Jackson Pollock - Andy Warhol - Damien Hirst. His belief in Hirst's talent - Saatchi has been known to call it his "genius" - has never been in question. He has always been prepared to get his chequebook out for Damien. And on the day I phoned him he had apparently been in a quandary over which of nearly two-dozen pieces to stump up for first. He left Stroud at around four in the afternoon and was apparently still enthusing over the new work with Larry Gagosian at one o'clock the following morning.

So he was up. He had had the pick of some important new work by his favourite living artist and he had come good. Hymn, the 20ft, 10-ton bronze cast of an anatomical children's toy that he had bought for £1m, was already on its way to the Saatchi gallery in north London, trailed by a TV documentary team. The interview was on. But then he seemed to be down.

Supercollector, a book which billed itself as "a hostile critique written from a socialist standpoint", authored by two British academics, was published in mid-March. "A new book came out yesterday," the Bond Street dealer Bernard Jacobson told me. "Charles must be feeling very hurt." Jacobson and Saatchi went to school together; they have remained lifelong friends. "They've tried to make him look ugly on the cover, and he's not ugly. A horrible picture. Charles is a good-looking guy. They've tried to make him look Jewish ."

The next day Jenny Blyth called from the Saatchi gallery. Our "informal chat" had been set up for March 24, a Friday. I could tell from her voice that there was a problem. "This is embarrassing. I'm not backtracking. But I seem to have misunderstood. Charles doesn't want to do the chat walking around the show. Um, or over coffee. Oh this is all my fault. I said it would be just coffee, but he said it would be like an interview. Charles doesn't do interviews. What he wonders is, could you let him have your questions by fax, and he'll fax you back his replies. It's not very satisfactory, I know. But if you could do that to start with, I'll try and warm it up a bit later."

A few days later Jenny Blyth called again. She was pitching the idea of writing about some "post-YBAs" who had been taken into the collection - some Neurotic Realist artists, in fact. I said I was planning to write about some post-YBAs who weren't in the collection. One of these was Richard Woods, whose new show I'd seen the night before. "Oh we like Richard Woods," Jenny said. "We've been watching him for a long time. I'll tell Charles to get down there."

Tuesday March 21: I call Jenny with a suggestion. What if I delivered the Q and As by hand? Just handed them over to Charles, with no attempt to speak to him or accost him? Jenny: "I don't think that's a good idea. I think that would really irritate him. I think it really would. No, Q and A is the way to go. And then if he likes them, the chances are he would just chill."

It is well known that Saatchi never attends his own openings. Some employees worked for his ad agency for years without meeting him. An often repeated anecdote describes Saatchi pretending to be an office cleaner rather than meet clients touring the building. Everything he does that isn't directly centred on his collection (and a lot of what is) revolves around concealment, seclusion, ways of evasion. He seems to be convinced that serious trackers are moving in with their mobile phones and zoom lenses. It's an irrational way of life that has a powerful inner logic. This involves investment in himself as an enigmatic Svengali figure and creating value in the works of art in his collection.

He was able to bring himself to the teetering edge of the interview ordeal, it seems, only as a way of promoting Ant Noises (it's an anagram of Sensation) the show of post-Sensation work by YBA artists which opens at the Saatchi gallery next week.

His brother, Maurice, once joked that Saatchi was an acronym for "Simple And Arresting Truths Create High Impact". If there is a recurring factor in Charles Saatchi's collecting, then it is surely an attraction to art with high visual impact and shock value - what Bernard Jacobson once described as "soundbite art". And the bite about the £1m bronze that was Saatchi's latest acquisition - that it was copied from a £14.99 Humbrol plastic toy - was soon planted safely in the papers. A full-page story appeared in the Sunday Times almost within hours of Hirst's "big guy" arriving by transporter at the Saatchi gallery. More importantly, the story was accompanied by a large colour picture of the sculpture which, with the wind in the right direction and the full apparatus of publicity and promotion behind it, was about to begin the crossover to icon status. "Every photograph," as Don DeLillo writes in one of his novels, nodding towards Walter Benjamin, "reinforces the aura . . . An accumulation of nameless energies."

Much of Hymn's aura at this point resides in the (much reported) price. One million pounds. The magic six noughts. Hirst himself seems to have realised this when Saatchi at one point seemed to be sticking at £950,000 and he insisted on holding out for what he believed was the right amount. "I said to my accountant, Frank: 'Don't forget you can buy a three-bedroom house where I grew up in Leeds for £53,500. It's almost an insult to go 50,000 short of it.'"

Unlike many artists, Hirst is unembarrassed about the money element in his work. In the past he has talked about liking the fact that the work becomes a commodity when it leaves the studio; that it is part of its life in the world. In one of the new sculptures, From the Cradle to the Grave, a Coutts gold card signed "Damien Hirst" balances on its edge on the surface of a desk. "Whereas art and science and religion you can just about get your mind round," he says, "money you can't. People can tell you what things are worth, but it's not what they're worth. Money seems to skitter through everything and be ungraspable."

Recently, he says, he felt peculiarly wounded when he thought Charles Saatchi had volunteered to deposit half a million pounds ("Pounds, Charles - pounds") in the bank to secure the big bronze man, a sculpure that, as far as Hirst was concerned, Saatchi had never seen. "I couldn't believe you would do that. I hated the idea that he would buy something sight unseen. Because you make visual art. And for him to do that would mean that it was nothing to do with that. It was all to do with gambling. I thought it was all market concerns. I was quite relieved to find out that he'd seen a polaroid of it. Basically, he was behaving like a man who'd seen it, and he had seen it. Somebody had slipped him a picture."

Richard Wentworth taught Hirst and a number of his contemporaries at Goldsmiths College. He is an acutely perceptive commentator on, as well as a wised-up consumer of, popular culture. And Wentworth believes it is significant that Charles Saatchi's latest fetish object started life as a child's plastic toy. "The joke is that the piece has got aura because Charles cherished the desire to own. If you could ask a five-year-old they could tell you. I guess the message we take away from this is: Charles must have his toys."
