In fact I know I got him on a good day because it was a day Charles had gone to look at a new toy. With the New York dealer Larry Gagosian, who Saatchi has long used to "disperse" works from the collection that he has blown cool on, or judged are right for the market at that moment, he had been Rollered down to the West Country to cast a hungry eye over Damien Hirst's first new work for many years, at his studio near Stroud. A day out shopping. So he was up. But he had been down, a friend had told me - dragged low by the reaction to the Sensation show - "Young British Artists from the Saatchi Collection" - towards the end of last year in New York. Instead of being a celebration of his collecting acumen and confirmation of his "modern Medici" status, it had all been elephant dung and city politics and the showboating of Mayor Giuliani instead. "He was very high in New York," the friend said. "He went in to install the show every day. And he was very pleased. But then it didn't go the way he expected at all." Plus, in London the New Neurotic Realism debacle had reportedly got him into a bit of a grump. Neurotic Realism. The last big art movement. Remember it? No? That's OK. Nobody else does either. It was a synthetic attempt at having lightning strike twice. To hurry things on. Didn't work. Saatchi himself was rumoured to have found the NNR book he put out, with its tawdry cover and vapid boostering of a new "tinsel-camp aesthetic", a misjudgment and an embarrassment; evidence that perhaps it isn't so easy to engineer change - to invent the history of British art before it has happened. So he had been down. But the day I called there was a song in his heart and a spring in his step and he was up. Almost every major talent attracts at least one or two important collectors at an early stage in his or her career. And, to his credit, Saatchi has supported Damien Hirst and a handful of that generation of artists almost from day one. He bought A Thousand Years in 1990 from a Hirst-curated show called Gambler. With its maggots and flies and rotting cow's head, and the attendant, almost impossible, problems of storage and installation, it was a work that almost every other collector in the world would have shied away from. A year later, he paid for the trapping, transportation and preservation of the now-notorious tiger shark and then used his "top ad-man" abilities to turn it into a weirdly potent symbol of the age. Pictures of the shark were reproduced with a frequency which invested it with considerable power as an image and deepened its mystery: silent, immobile, latently lethal, suspended for eternity in its secure vitrine, it became a kind of logo of the times; a blank and yet peculiarly charged emblem. Saatchi says that he believes a thumbnail history of the art of the last half-century would go: Jackson Pollock - Andy Warhol - Damien Hirst. His belief in Hirst's talent - Saatchi has been known to call it his "genius" - has never been in question. He has always been prepared to get his chequebook out for Damien. And on the day I phoned him he had apparently been in a quandary over which of nearly two-dozen pieces to stump up for first. He left Stroud at around four in the afternoon and was apparently still enthusing over the new work with Larry Gagosian at one o'clock the following morning. So he was up. He had had the pick of some important new work by his favourite living artist and he had come good. Hymn, the 20ft, 10-ton bronze cast of an anatomical children's toy that he had bought for £1m, was already on its way to the Saatchi gallery in north London, trailed by a TV documentary team. The interview was on. But then he seemed to be down. Supercollector, a book which billed itself as "a hostile critique written from a socialist standpoint", authored by two British academics, was published in mid-March. "A new book came out yesterday," the Bond Street dealer Bernard Jacobson told me. "Charles must be feeling very hurt." Jacobson and Saatchi went to school together; they have remained lifelong friends. "They've tried to make him look ugly on the cover, and he's not ugly. A horrible picture. Charles is a good-looking guy. They've tried to make him look Jewish ." The next day Jenny Blyth called from the Saatchi gallery. Our "informal chat" had been set up for March 24, a Friday. I could tell from her voice that there was a problem. "This is embarrassing. I'm not backtracking. But I seem to have misunderstood. Charles doesn't want to do the chat walking around the show. Um, or over coffee. Oh this is all my fault. I said it would be just coffee, but he said it would be like an interview. Charles doesn't do interviews. What he wonders is, could you let him have your questions by fax, and he'll fax you back his replies. It's not very satisfactory, I know. But if you could do that to start with, I'll try and warm it up a bit later." A few days later Jenny Blyth called again. She was pitching the idea of writing about some "post-YBAs" who had been taken into the collection - some Neurotic Realist artists, in fact. I said I was planning to write about some post-YBAs who weren't in the collection. One of these was Richard Woods, whose new show I'd seen the night before. "Oh we like Richard Woods," Jenny said. "We've been watching him for a long time. I'll tell Charles to get down there." Tuesday March 21: I call Jenny with a suggestion. What if I delivered the Q and As by hand? Just handed them over to Charles, with no attempt to speak to him or accost him? Jenny: "I don't think that's a good idea. I think that would really irritate him. I think it really would. No, Q and A is the way to go. And then if he likes them, the chances are he would just chill." It is well known that Saatchi never attends his own openings. Some employees worked for his ad agency for years without meeting him. An often repeated anecdote describes Saatchi pretending to be an office cleaner rather than meet clients touring the building. Everything he does that isn't directly centred on his collection (and a lot of what is) revolves around concealment, seclusion, ways of evasion. He seems to be convinced that serious trackers are moving in with their mobile phones and zoom lenses. It's an irrational way of life that has a powerful inner logic. This involves investment in himself as an enigmatic Svengali figure and creating value in the works of art in his collection. He was able to bring himself to the teetering edge of the interview ordeal, it seems, only as a way of promoting Ant Noises (it's an anagram of Sensation) the show of post-Sensation work by YBA artists which opens at the Saatchi gallery next week. His brother, Maurice, once joked that Saatchi was an acronym for "Simple And Arresting Truths Create High Impact". If there is a recurring factor in Charles Saatchi's collecting, then it is surely an attraction to art with high visual impact and shock value - what Bernard Jacobson once described as "soundbite art". And the bite about the £1m bronze that was Saatchi's latest acquisition - that it was copied from a £14.99 Humbrol plastic toy - was soon planted safely in the papers. A full-page story appeared in the Sunday Times almost within hours of Hirst's "big guy" arriving by transporter at the Saatchi gallery. More importantly, the story was accompanied by a large colour picture of the sculpture which, with the wind in the right direction and the full apparatus of publicity and promotion behind it, was about to begin the crossover to icon status. "Every photograph," as Don DeLillo writes in one of his novels, nodding towards Walter Benjamin, "reinforces the aura . . . An accumulation of nameless energies." Much of Hymn's aura at this point resides in the (much reported) price. One million pounds. The magic six noughts. Hirst himself seems to have realised this when Saatchi at one point seemed to be sticking at £950,000 and he insisted on holding out for what he believed was the right amount. "I said to my accountant, Frank: 'Don't forget you can buy a three-bedroom house where I grew up in Leeds for £53,500. It's almost an insult to go 50,000 short of it.'" Unlike many artists, Hirst is unembarrassed about the money element in his work. In the past he has talked about liking the fact that the work becomes a commodity when it leaves the studio; that it is part of its life in the world. In one of the new sculptures, From the Cradle to the Grave, a Coutts gold card signed "Damien Hirst" balances on its edge on the surface of a desk. "Whereas art and science and religion you can just about get your mind round," he says, "money you can't. People can tell you what things are worth, but it's not what they're worth. Money seems to skitter through everything and be ungraspable." Recently, he says, he felt peculiarly wounded when he thought Charles Saatchi had volunteered to deposit half a million pounds ("Pounds, Charles - pounds") in the bank to secure the big bronze man, a sculpure that, as far as Hirst was concerned, Saatchi had never seen. "I couldn't believe you would do that. I hated the idea that he would buy something sight unseen. Because you make visual art. And for him to do that would mean that it was nothing to do with that. It was all to do with gambling. I thought it was all market concerns. I was quite relieved to find out that he'd seen a polaroid of it. Basically, he was behaving like a man who'd seen it, and he had seen it. Somebody had slipped him a picture." Richard Wentworth taught Hirst and a number of his contemporaries at Goldsmiths College. He is an acutely perceptive commentator on, as well as a wised-up consumer of, popular culture. And Wentworth believes it is significant that Charles Saatchi's latest fetish object started life as a child's plastic toy. "The joke is that the piece has got aura because Charles cherished the desire to own. If you could ask a five-year-old they could tell you. I guess the message we take away from this is: Charles must have his toys."

webTitle: Report damns prison care for mentally ill

fields.headline: Report damns prison care for mentally ill
fields.standfirst: Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: Mentally ill prisoners are being locked up for all but a few hours a day in poor facilities, in the charge of doctors who are not psychiatric specialists and nurses who do not usually have mental health training, a damning report published today reveals.
fields.body:
Mentally ill prisoners are being locked up for all but a few hours a day in poor facilities, in the charge of doctors who are not psychiatric specialists and nurses who do not usually have mental health training, a damning report published today reveals.

The standard of care for mentally ill prisoners falls far short of what they could expect if they were treated in the NHS. "Patients' lives were unacceptably restricted and therapy limited," the report says.

John Reed, the medical inspector of the inspectorate of prisons, and Maggi Lyne, its nursing inspector, reveal their findings in the British Medical Journal. They claim that the standard of treatment is an opportunity missed.

Levels of mental illness in prison are significantly higher than in the community. The majority of patients suffer schizophrenia or other delusional disorders.

"A period in prison should present an opportunity to detect, diagnose and treat mental illness in a population hard to engage with NHS services," say the inspectors. "This could bring benefits not only to patients but to the wider community by ensuring continuity of care and reducing the risk of reoffending on release."

In 1998 the office for national statistics published figures suggesting there are around 5,000 people with psychosis detained in prison at any one time. There is little difference, from a medical point of view, between the mentally disordered in prison healthcare centres and those in NHS secure psychiatric units. "Yet the management, staffing and facilities of prison inpatient units is much worse than in the NHS," says the report.

Only one healthcare centre had adequately clean patients' lavatories - the report comments that staff toilets were cleaner. On daytime activities, the units fell down badly from the healthcare standard which says prisoners must spend 12 hours a day out of their rooms, engaging in at least six hours of planned activity, including education and the development of interpersonal and daily living skills.

No prison met these standards, according to the report. Patients averaged 3 hours out of locked cells, much of it spent watching TV, playing pool and cleaning. Four prisons gave details of the amount of time prisoners spent in seclusion. The average episode lasted 50 hours.

"Most nursing staff had no mental health training and no doctor in charge of inpatients had completed specialist psychiatric training," say the inspectors. Only one prison out of the 13 they visited had a full multi-disciplinary team.

The inspectors condemn the lack of action to improve the dire state of prison health services. Since 1991, the prison service has been supposed to provide care equivalent to that available in the NHS.

An earlier report by the in spectors, in 1997, found standards were variable and, in some parts, of low quality. "Despite the requirement to implement NHS healthcare standards, we found little to show that the prison service had attempted to ensure the standards were met," they said.

The inspectors note that the government has "recently renewed its commitment to improving the healthcare of prisoners", basing a new policy unit in the NHS executive instead of in the prison service.

They suggest that either the system must be upgraded, or all mentally ill prisoners who require full time nursing care be transferred to the NHS.

The inspectors surveyed 13 prisons with inpatient units during 1997-98 as part of their routine programme of inspection. The prisons had 348 beds between them - a fifth of the entire inpatient prison capacity. Eight were local prisons, three high security prisons, one a category B training prison and one a young offenders institution.

fields.headline: Relatives defy Elian order
fields.standfirst: Uncle releases video of child pleading to stay in USMore about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText:
The agonising five-month battle of nerves over a
six-year-old Cuban boy, Elian Gonzalez, boiled down
yesterday to a standoff in the sidestreets of Miami's
Little Havana after Elian's great-uncle Lazaro defied the
justice department's orders to hand the boy over to his
father.
fields.body:
The agonising five-month battle of nerves over a six-year-old Cuban boy, Elian Gonzalez, boiled down yesterday to a standoff in the sidestreets of Miami's Little Havana after Elian's great-uncle Lazaro defied the justice department's orders to hand the boy over to his father.

As the deadline for the handover came and went, several hundred Cuban exiles gathered around the small white house owned by Lazaro Gonzalez, who warned that federal agents would have to take Elian "by force".

But the threat of an immediate police raid was lifted by the federal appeal court, which issued a temporary order banning Elian from leaving the country, in effect delaying the handover. The injunction, granted at the request of the great-uncle, set lawyers scrambling to unravel the latest twist in the saga. Late last night the justice department conceded that it would delay a final showdown for "three or four days".

In Little Havana, the streets around the house filled with cars driven by Cuban-Americans flying Cuban flags and honking their horns in a show of solidarity. Scores of locals took the afternoon off to join the protest vigil, which by evening had turned into a street party.

An effigy of Fidel Castro in stained combat fatigues dangled from a telephone post from which he had been ceremonially lynched. A representation of President Clinton as a spineless straw man was paraded up and down.

The crowd chanted and vowed to form a human barrier around Elian to prevent immigration officers taking him back to Washington, where his father, Juan Miguel, has been waiting for more than a week to take him back to Cuba.

The US attorney general, Janet Reno - who has staked her reputation on the outcome of the drama by flying to Miami to mediate - said earlier that her orders would be enforced "in a reasonable, measured way". But she did not specify how, other than to promise that US marshals would not force their way into the house as soon as the 2pm (7pm BST) deadline passed.

After talks broke down late on Wednesday night, the boy's relatives in Miami ratcheted up the emotional stakes by releasing a video of Elian asking to stay in the US. The video shows Elian sitting on a bed talking into the camera and addressing his father. "Papa, if you would like, stay here. But I do not want to go to Cuba," he said, wagging his finger. It was not clear to what extent he had been coached.

Hundreds of policemen surrounded Opa Locka airport, on the outskirts of Miami, where the justice department had ordered Elian to be handed over.

Lazaro Gonzalez, apparently thriving on the attention, emerged from his house several times to acknowledge the cheers of the crowd, for whom Elian has become a symbol of their struggle with President Castro. "We will not turn the child over," he declared, warning that federal agents "will have to come into the house and take him."

"That way," he said, "the world can see how they train people to attack this humble house where we have lived _ just so they can have their way and make sure this little boy goes back to Cuba."

He said he would offer no resistance if officials were sent to collect Elian, but wanted TV cameras to be there to record the event. Cuban exile leaders urged the crowd outside to offer only passive resistance.

In the event of a direct confrontation, it is unclear what role the Miami police would play. The city's mayor, Joe Carollo, said the local force would not become involved in any attempt to return Elian to his father.

Yesterday, police lieutenant Bill Schwartz told journalists: "It's not a Miami police operation. However, we are here to keep the peace and make sure nobody gets hurt."

President Clinton yesterday backed Ms Reno, saying: "I think the issue here is the rule of the law. We have a legal system and it has to be followed."

Ms Reno, a former Miami prosecutor, appealed to the Cuban-American community to remain calm. Praising the community's fierce sense of independence, she appealed to its pride, saying: "Let us not have violence. Let us create a model in this community that defies the model of Castro."

The attorney general said Elian's Miami relatives had turned down a justice department offer to fly them to Washington to discuss the boy's future with his father. But one of Lazaro Gonzalez's lawyer's, Manny Diaz, said the meeting had been made conditional on Elian being turned over to his father.

"What is on the table today is not an offer," Mr Diaz said. "What is on the table is a demand. This family does not respond to demands."

webTitle: Reno faces judgment day over Elian

fields.headline: Reno faces judgment day over Elian
fields.standfirst:
US attorney general stakes her reputation on finding peaceful solution to bitter custody battle

More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: Janet Reno's decision to fly to her home town of Miami to try to resolve the Elian Gonzalez crisis shows the extent to which the family dispute over the custody of a six-year-old boy has become the defining moment in the US attorney general's turbulent career.
fields.body:
Janet Reno's decision to fly to her home town of Miami to try to resolve the Elian Gonzalez crisis shows the extent to which the family dispute over the custody of a six-year-old boy has become the defining moment in the US attorney general's turbulent career.

It sometimes seems that much of the American media - and almost all congressional Republicans - do not have a good word to say about Ms Reno, 62, who took office in 1993 and is the longest-serving US attorney general since the late Robert Kennedy.

But if she solves this crisis gracefully, without incurring the blame for the inevitable turmoil of the final days of the Elian custody battle, Ms Reno may have the last word.

Throughout her headline-grabbing career as head of the justice department, she has rarely appeared to be put off her stride by events such as the siege at Waco, Texas, the Monica Lewinsky affair and the Microsoft monopoly.

Nor has she appeared fazed by pressure from people as powerful as Bill Clinton, Bill Gates and Kenneth Starr or groups such as Miami's Cuban exile population.

Ms Reno is probably better qualified to handle the conflicting pressures of the Gonzalez case than any of her predecessors or her colleagues at the head of US law enforcement.

As a prosecutor with a background in children's law, who spent all of her earlier career in Miami, Ms Reno is steeped in the tempestuous politics of southern Florida, and is well aware of the power of the Cuban exile community.

Associates said that she made the trip to Florida this week because she felt comfortable in the high octane politics of Miami, a city which she praised again yesterday.

But she went south for legal and political reasons as well - to show for the record that she had taken every possible step to resolve the Elian dispute peacefully.

Ms Reno needs to prove that she has taken all reasonable steps before a decision can be taken to send in federal officers to enforce the law.

If the Elian case goes to appeal, or if there is a high-level post mortem on its denouement, Ms Reno has her own defence prepared well in advance.

Nevertheless, the trip to Miami is an enormous gamble. If she succeeds in reuniting Elian with his father Juan Miguel without violence breaking out, it will be a huge achievement. But if she cannot draw the sting of the case which has convulsed Florida ever since Elian was rescued and sent to live with his Miami relatives last November, it could be a disaster, personally and politically.

One clear sign of the high stakes involved is that Ms Reno, who has sometimes driven colleagues to distraction with her unwillingness to delegate, has off-loaded many of her other responsibilities to subordinates as the Elian case has continued.

She has spent days on nothing but the Gonzalez family battle.

Some observers say that she has loosened up in the process. Certainly, she has seemed to become more expansive in her remarks on the case as it has continued.

In the past, Janet Reno press conferences were deadpan, minimalist events in which the attorney general appeared to tease reporters by saying as little as possible in as undramatic a way as possible - even when she was announcing a major development in a story which was front page news.

She told colleagues this week that she was deeply moved by her meeting with Juan Miguel Gonzalez, the boy's father, and that she believed that she was right to insist that the law must be enforced and that Elian should be returned to his father.

If that happens, then the long years of mockery of America's first woman attorney general will look even more undeserved than they do already.

If it does not, Ms Reno's enemies - who have never forgiven her for her decision to authorise the teargas attack which ended the Waco siege in 1993 - will hound her more ruthlessly than ever until she leaves office next January to return to Miami.

She told colleagues this week that she was deeply moved by her meeting with Juan Miguel Gonzalez, the boy's father, and that she believed that she was right to insist that the law must be enforced and that Elian should be returned to his father. If that happens, then the long years of mockery of America's first woman attorney general will look even more undeserved than they do already. If it does not, Ms Reno's enemies - who have never forgiven her for her decision to authorise the teargas attack which ended the Waco siege in 1993 - will hound her more ruthlessly than ever until she leaves office next January to return to Miami. fields.headline: Arsonist kills young couple
fields.trailText: Detectives are questioning work colleagues and other contacts of a young couple who were killed when an arsonist poured inflammable liquid through the letterbox of their home.
fields.body:
Detectives are questioning work colleagues and other contacts of a young couple who were killed when an arsonist poured inflammable liquid through the letterbox of their home.

Company manager James Murphy, 28, and his partner Jane Pemberton, 23, a personal assistant, died of smoke inhalation when fire gutted their semi-detached house in Normanton, near Wakefield, early on Wednesday.

Det Chief Supt Paul Johnston, leading the inquiry, said that police and neighbours were deeply shocked by the murders, which came soon after Ms Pemberton moved in with Mr Murphy. He said yesterday: "This is a callous, cold-blooded murder of two absolutely lovely people. We are still struggling for a motive. The worst case scenario is that this is a random, motiveless attack."

fields.headline: My lips are sealed
fields.trailText: For years literary scholars on both sides of the Atlantic have been arguing that it was only Sylvia who ever picked her nose. But now we know from her Journals that Ted picked it too (by which I don't mean that Ted picked Sylvia's nose, but his own, though Ted's still-to-be-published Journals may well prove that he indulged in the former activity too).
fields.body:
Like most truly civilised people, I love literature, hate gossip. To me, books are a passion. Short books, long books, medium-sized books: I've got masses of time for them all. I love the way one word follows another, and then comes another, then another - and before you know where you are they have all been built into sentences, then paragraphs, then chapters. And finally, there they stand, shrouded in glory, my beloved books.

But gossip is a very different business. Frankly, who cares exactly who was doing what with whom where when? To be honest, it's a matter of no interest to me. It's literally decades since I read a gossip column, and if ever I hear something remotely "interesting" (note the inverted commas!) about someone famous, I make sure it goes in one ear and out the other.

But literature, ah, literature! I have just finished soaking up The Journals of Sylvia Plath, and there's no other way of expressing it - I've basically been totally knocked sideways by them. At last, in easy-to-understand words, we are in a position to determine exactly what she and Ted were on about in their poems. To my mind, the Journals offer us a far deeper understanding of their domestic arrangements than ever before, and present a far greater range of evidence on which to judge the pros and cons of both their cases than their poems ever did.

For example, for years literary scholars on both sides of the Atlantic have been arguing that it was only Sylvia who ever picked her nose. But now we know from her Journals that Ted picked it too (by which I don't mean that Ted picked Sylvia's nose, but his own, though Ted's still-to-be-published Journals may well prove that he indulged in the former activity too).

Ah, literature! I have long been a fully paid-up fan of the works of Margaret Drabble and Antonia Byatt. Indeed, I am widely credited as the inspiration behind the indomitable yet strangely domitable character of Belinda Bigjack in Margaret's magnificent 70s State-of-England trilogy, Darkness in the Night, particularly in the uplifting but strangely saddening final volume, The Last Drop, in which Belinda's attempt to drown herself goes awry when Julian inadvertently switches off the shower. So it grieves me greatly that newspaper gossip about a "feud" between these two sisters is in danger of overshadowing their contributions to literature.

Needless to say, those of us who know them both well have been studiously ignoring their spats for goodness-knows-how-long. I suppose it was when they both shared a platform at the Cheltenham literary festival at some time in the early 70s that I first detected modest differences between Antonia and Margaret.

While Margaret was standing at their shared table reading out that moving passage from her early novel The Blocked Drain (1966) in which Matilda strangles her uppity sister Agatha with a slimline leather bookmark ("You've lost my place!" gurgles Agatha, to which Matilda replies, "It's The End!"), I couldn't help but notice that Antonia Byatt was beneath the table busily tying Margaret's shoelaces together, causing her to plummet headlong into the vase of cut flowers upon venturing forth to take a bow.

It was now Antonia's turn to take the platform. She was reading a passage from her new novel of ideas, and had just got to that bit where the good idea is horrified upon coming home to find a very bad idea sitting slumped in the kitchen with nothing to do, when I found myself glancing in the general direction of Margaret's chair, and noticed it vacant. Further investigation revealed that Margaret had crept behind Antonia, then struck a match, and was even now covertly setting fire to the back hem of Antonia's strikingly floral summer frock.

Before long Antonia Byatt was engulfed in a thick black fog of smoke (the frock, it later emerged, was 78% viscose), causing her to splutter uncontrollably, thus ruining her delivery of the climactic confrontation between the two ideas ("Huh! You're not such a big idea after all!" "I may not be big, but by God I'm a better idea than you'll ever be!"), and ending what should have been a pleasant literary afternoon in a splurge of extinguisher foam.

Over the next two decades, one sometimes heard of other incidents between the two sisters - an impromptu arm-wrestling session at the Adelaide poetry festival, an ill-judged appearance by the two of them in the ring at WWF in Madison Square Garden, a shouting match on the "My Sister Hates Me Because She Writes Worse Novels Than Me" edition of the Jerry Springer Show - but, by and large, they carried themselves with great dignity. So let us hope that this newspaper, at least, can refrain from retelling any tittle-tattle about them, for gossip's loss is surely literature's gain.

webTitle: The Clematis Tree, by Ann Widdecombe

fields.headline: The Clematis Tree, by Ann Widdecombe
fields.standfirst:
Weidenfeld & Nicolson, £9.99, digested in the style of the original
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Mark and Claire Wellings were goodish eggs, but despite being comfortably well-off, the strain of looking after their son Jeremy for seven years had taken its toll. Their marriage was an empty loveless shell.
fields.body:
Mark and Claire Wellings were goodish eggs, but despite being comfortably well-off, the strain of looking after their son Jeremy for seven years had taken its toll. Their marriage was an empty loveless shell.

"I've booked a holiday," said Mark.

"We can't leave Jeremy," Claire replied defiantly.

Mark knew his marriage was doomed.

Their daughter Pippa picked up a severe dose of gastro-enteritis. "I hope Jeremy doesn't get it," Mark muttered to himself. "It could kill him."

Jeremy spent the next two weeks in intensive care, hovering between life and death.

"That does for the holiday," said Mark over supper one evening. "By the way, did you know your sister Sally is planning to introduce a euthanasia bill into the Commons?" He wondered what the bill might mean for Jeremy and whether the press would discover his link to Sally.

Mark took himself off on a week's holiday to Estoril. Lying on the beach, he was awoken by some ice-cream dropping on his stomach. He looked up to see a girl with a hideous disfigurement.

"She seems very accepting of her condition," Mark said later to the girl's mother.

"I've taught her to be serene," she said. "I'm a widow, incidentally."

They had dinner. Mark resisted the temptation of an affair, but still knew his marriage was doomed.

"I'm a shopaholic and I occasionally hit Jeremy," Claire confessed on his return.

"I'd better talk to the vicar, then," Mark concluded.

"I'm getting married to Ben," said Mark's sister Ruth. "His first wife and two children were all killed in a car crash."

Work was hotting up at the firm of solicitors where Mark worked. They took on extra staff, including Ginny, a short-skirted Australian secretary. Mark resisted the temptation of an affair, but still knew his marriage was doomed.

Mark and Claire woke to find the press camped out on their doorstep. "They've found out about Jeremy," said Claire. Mark invoked the second Person of the Trinity.

As Claire's father, Sam, lay in hospital after a severe stroke, Mark waved Pippa off on her school trip to France. "Have a safe journey," he shouted, as the coach departed.

Reports came in of a major accident, with several fatalities, on the M20.

"I'm afraid Pippa was on the coach," said the headmaster. Mark and Claire waited anxiously for news.

"Actually, she was on the other coach after all," said the headmaster. "Pippa's fine."

Sam died of a heart attack and several months later the brake failed - or did aunt Isabel release it? - and Jeremy's wheelchair rolled into the river. Despite Mark's efforts to revive him, he drowned.

"Could I have done more," Mark anguished. "He looked so peaceful. But am I at peace?"

"I want a divorce," he said firmly.

"You can't," said Claire. "I'm pregnant."

Mark knew then he would stay in his doomed marriage of deepening unhappiness.

And if you really are pressed - the digested read, digested:
 The Book of Job rewritten for High Church, High Tory matrons from the shires.

webTitle: Famine threat is receding, says Ethiopian PM

fields.headline: Famine threat is receding, says Ethiopian PM
fields.standfirst: Ethiopia: special report
fields.trailText: The spectre of mass starvation in Ethiopia is receding now that foreign governments have promised enough grain to feed the estimated 8m people at risk, the prime minister, Meles Zenawi, declared yesterday.
fields.byline: David Gough  in Addis Ababa and Jonathan Steele
fields.body:
The spectre of mass starvation in Ethiopia is receding now that foreign governments have promised enough grain to feed the estimated 8m people at risk, the prime minister, Meles Zenawi, declared yesterday.

His surprisingly optimistic statement came after meeting Catherine Bertini, the UN's special envoy to the region. Mr Zenawi rowed back from earlier Ethiopian criticism of governments being slow to deliver the grain they had promised. The statment seemed to mark a truce in the war of words with the international community, which has demanded an end to the war with Eritrea as a condition for increasing long-term aid.

Mr Zenawi said he was pleased with his discussions with Ms Bertini and announced what he called a new chapter in relations "when humanitarian issues are separated from political issues".

The Ethiopian government has requested 800,000 tonnes of aid. The European Union recently pledged 430,000 tonnes for this year, of which Britain will provide about 17%.

The 20,000 tonnes in direct British aid, already pledged on top of its EU commitment, makes London one of the largest single donors, at an estimated cost of £25m.

Ethiopia claims to be the victim of aggression in the border war with its former ally and friend, which western analysts in Ethiopia estimate is costing Ethiopia more than £600,000 a day. Given that the war has been raging for the past two years, that would put the cost of the war to date at £500m.

Many observers feel this is an unacceptable price for any government to pay when the lives of millions of its citizens are at stake, but Mr Zenawi said: "We do not believe that protecting one's sovereignty is a luxury for the rich alone."

Meanwhile, new research shows that the majority of Ethiopian households have difficulty maintaining adequate nutrition even when there is no famine. Interviews with 140 families conducted by Oxfam last year found that they spent more than 90% of their income on food, and that more than two-thirds owned no livestock or only a tiny plot of land.

Over-population in the northern highlands means that people are farming smaller and smaller plots and moving to less fertile land on steep hillsides. Many families produce only enough grain to feed themselves for three or four months a year, and it takes only one or two harvests to fail to push millions to the brink of starvation.

Life expectancy in Ethiopia is 43 years. Oxfam says that unless the outside world increases its development aid the cycle of crisis and poverty will not be broken. Ethiopia spends twice as much on servicing its debt as on primary education.

The charity says that donor governments should agree a substantial package of aid and debt relief for Ethiopia and Eritrea. It urges the two countries to make peace. Without linking the two issues directly, Oxfam says that the outside world should create major incentives for both governments to end the war.

fields.headline: Journalist 'in contempt' of inquiry
fields.standfirst: The Bloody Sunday inquiry: special report
fields.trailText: A Daily Telegraph journalist, Toby Harnden, has been placed in alleged contempt of the Bloody Sunday inquiry, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
A Daily Telegraph journalist, Toby Harnden, has been placed in alleged contempt of the Bloody Sunday inquiry, it was announced yesterday.

The tribunal chairman, Lord Saville of Newdigate, told the public hearing in Londonderry that Mr Harnden, the newspaper's former Ireland correspondent, had refused to comply with an order to identify a soldier who he had interviewed, and to give a full account of what the soldier had told him.

The matter had been referred to the high court in Belfast for a decision, he added.

Lord Saville said that the journalist, now in Washington, maintained that his duty of confidentiality entitled him to take that course of action "notwithstanding a contrary view" given by the tribunal last October.

fields.headline: Byers and buyers
fields.standfirst:
The minister is not in the clear yet
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Stephen Byers may have been cleared by the Trade and Industry committee of a failure to read the signals in the sad case of BMW's clumsy, cruel, and callous dumping of Rover, but the minister and the government as a whole still have a great deal of work to do.
fields.body:
Stephen Byers may have been cleared by the Trade and Industry committee of a failure to read the signals in the sad case of BMW's clumsy, cruel, and callous dumping of Rover, but the minister and the government as a whole still have a great deal of work to do. These are not purely commercial matters and the government, as the committee makes clear in the useful report it published yesterday, must review some of its hands-off attitudes to industry and think again about where intervention may be necessary.

As long as Rover's sale to Alchemy is not finalised, the government must exert pressure on BMW to be more open to rival bidders so that they have full information on which to prepare their offers and business plans. The stake which the government took in Rover by making money available during BMW's early years of management at Longbridge did not qualify as a shareholding, but it surely gives it a moral right to insist that BMW is more open. The justifiable shame which BMW has incurred, not only in Britain but also in the German media, for its secrecy ought to be another factor persuading it to become more forthcoming before it finally withdraws.

The British government must also insist that the redundancy terms are made clearer both by BMW and by any new owner of Rover, whether it is Alchemy or another consortium. Mr Byers has to be energetic here. But the Rover crisis has much deeper lessons for the obligations of all companies to consult their workforces properly. The committee is right to point out that the government's opposition to stronger Europe-wide regulations puts it out of line with most of its European partners. New Labour likes to rail at the forces of conservatism, but on this issue it is such a force itself. The committee reports that its soundings in Brussels show that other European governments are running out of patience. The government owes Rover workers a rethink.

webTitle: MPs lash 'chaotic' BMW over Rover crisis

fields.headline: MPs lash 'chaotic' BMW over Rover crisis
fields.standfirst:
'Incompetent and secretive' carmaker's actions prevented rescue moves | EU attacked for aid delay | Byers cleared of concealing facts
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: MPs yesterday launched a furious attack on BMW for its handling of the Rover crisis, accusing the German car maker of "incompetence and excessive secrecy".
fields.body:
MPs yesterday launched a furious attack on BMW for its handling of the Rover crisis, accusing the German car maker of "incompetence and excessive secrecy".

BMW's exit strategy from its problems at the loss making UK business, which is likely to lead to the loss of thousands of jobs, was "chaotic, incomplete and incoherent", according to the trade and industry select committee.

It unanimously cleared Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, of knowing BMW's intentions to dismember Rover in advance, and said allegations of DTI doctoring of minutes of discussions with BMW "have not been substantiated".

Differences in wording of the text of a statement from Joachim Milberg, the BMW chairman, put out by the DTI and BMW "seems to have arisen from confusion between the parties... rather than any wilful intent to deceive".

However Mr Byers and his department did not escape unscathed from the committee's review of the events leading up to BMW's decision to break up the Rover group by transferring the Longbridge plant to the venture capital group Alchemy Partners and selling Land Rover to Ford.

The crossed lines between London and Munich could be "symptomatic" of poor liaison at a senior level between the DTI and BMW and, potentially, other manufacturers, which needed to be reviewed urgently.

The committee said it was surprised that, given the hard line on state aid taken by Mario Monti when appointed European Union competition commissioner in August last year and the subsequent inquiries by competition officials into British aid for BMW's investment programme at Longbridge, it was not until December 11 that BMW was told there was likely to be a formal investigation into the aid package "and then by an unrecorded call from his [Mr Byers's] home".

Mr Byers's department was ticked off too for not picking up early warning signs "of BMW's waning commitment to Long bridge in particular and the Rover group in general".

The European commission also came under fire from the MPs. The committee regretted that it had taken four months for the commission to decide to launch a formal inquiry into the aid package for Longbridge. The delay - at a time when Rover was haemorrhaging cash - was "unfortunately timed and largely unnecessary".

But the most serious criticisms are reserved for BMW. Although the car group had argued that it had sent out a number of signals about the mounting problems at Rover, the committee concluded that it could have chosen "far more effective means" to get its message across.

As the crisis intensified at the end of February and during the first two weeks of March Mr Byers and his officials were given some indications of BMW's intentions. But "the plans of which they were given notice bore no relation to what the BMW board decided on March 16. There was no suggestion that Longbridge and Cowley were for sale, let alone Land Rover, nor that BMW had begun hawking them around the world's principal car makers."

Although the information might have been given in good faith "it proved worthless and positively misleading".

By not giving the DTI the information about what was happening BMW denied Mr Byers and his officials the chance to argue the case for keeping Rover intact or to explore realistic alternatives.

Yesterday BMW said it was surprised by the criticisms. "The report is carefully written and we have to read it care fully. No one would be happy with an over-reaction," said a spokesman.

The committee, which is planning a review of the automotive industry in the coming months, is not enthusiastic about the planned transfer of the Longbridge plant to Alchemy, which is expected to lead to thousands of job losses - both at the plant itself and among components suppliers. However it recognises that, at the moment, it is the only option on the table.

"It does offer a genuine if risky prospect for Longbridge re-emerging as a centre of manufacturing excellence."

It calls for the government to make sure any alternative buyers get the minimum information needed to make a proper bid. But the committee warns: "Current prospects for Longbridge are bleak. More money will be needed both from the government and the EU to help the area around Longbridge to recover from the current plight.

But John Redwood, the former Tory trade spokesman, condemned the report as "not a whitewash, but a greywash", and said Mr Byers could not hide behind his officials for his "abject failure".

There is likely to be a further shake-up at the DTI, which has seen its role squeezed for years.

 Byers could not have anticipated break-up of Rover.

 Aid package distracted both BMW and DTI.

 DTI needs to review liaison with car makers.

 Taping of ministerial phone calls should be considered.

 Government should ensure alternative bidders for Rover get sufficient information.

 Longbridge workforce entitled to assurances Alchemy is the best option.

webTitle: Buyer to build sports saloon under MG name

fields.headline: Buyer to build sports saloon under MG name
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The venture capital firm set to take over Rover will build a sports saloon based on the award winning 75 model and sell it under the MG name.
fields.body:
The venture capital firm set to take over Rover will build a sports saloon based on the award winning 75 model and sell it under the MG name.

Alchemy, which is buying the bulk of Rover from BMW, is due to flesh out its plans for the UK car maker in a statement next week.

In an interview with the Guardian, Jon Moulton, Alchemy's managing partner, said the statement should include a clearer indication of how many jobs are likely to be lost.

"We will not know the number of employees being transferred to us till tomorrow," he said last night. "But I want to give an indication of redundancies [next week] if I can clear it with the legal boys."

Mr Moulton rejected union claims that Rover workers who lost their jobs would not get their full redundancy enti tlement because BMW was not providing enough cash. He said the new company would pay contractual arrangements for all employees in full. "But if the unions want more, that is a different matter."

Mr Moulton said MG Cars, the Alchemy company that will acquire Rover, would launch new MG models within 18 months of taking over. He played down the threat of a rival bid by a consortium being led by the ex-Rover executive John Towers.

He said the consortium would need up to £2bn of financing and would have to make a firm bid without the benefit of essential information from Rover or BMW. "I cannot see anyone taking a punt on that," he said.

Industry sources have suggested Mr Towers may unveil details of his bid today.

Mr Moulton said BMW could not stop Mr Towers tabling a bid, but "they cannot negotiate with him without being in breach of their agreement with us".

He said once his deal with BMW was complete the Rover 25 range would be ditched and the medium-sized Rover 45 would be more "appropriately marketed".

He said the 75, which will continue to be built at the plant in Cowley, Oxford, which BMW is retaining, was "a very good car which has suffered from marketing and pricing".

Mr Moulton also criticised BMW's decision to cut Rover prices by up to £2,000. "Would we have done it? I doubt it."

He added that MG Cars expected to boost sales of the existing MGF sports car which he felt had been held back because it competed with BMW's own sports car.

Alchemy, he said, was on course to complete its deal with BMW by the end of April. "We have got down to pretty small negotiations," he said.

fields.headline: Save our post offices
fields.standfirst:
They must be linked to the new economy

Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Rural post offices must be kept open. They are the arteries of country living and of the rural economy. It is very sad that the government has only been forced into devising a strategy for survival because it failed to see the obvious consequences of its decision to pay benefits directly into bank accounts instead of over PO counters by 2003.
fields.body:
Rural post offices must be kept open. They are the arteries of country living and of the rural economy. It is very sad that the government has only been forced into devising a strategy for survival because it failed to see the obvious consequences of its decision to pay benefits directly into bank accounts instead of over PO counters by 2003. Many sub-post offices rely on money from this source for 40% of their incomes. But at least the government is at last thinking about a long-term solution, under pressure from public opinion, including this week's 3,000 strong demonstration of sub-postmasters in London and the outcry against Barclays' decision to close outlying branches. This problem will not be solved by leaving it to market forces. Companies and banks will not rush in to fill the rural gap because the profits are simply not there. Nor can a single post office do much because it is only one spoke in a solution that must involve the underlying strength of post offices: the fact that they are a network and there are 19,000 of them. The seeds of survival are waiting to be planted.

The first requirement is a change of mindset. We must stop thinking of sub-post offices as if they are part of an inevitably declining old economy when they could be part of the infrastructure of the new economy. Instead of feeling threatened by the rise of online shopping as being another nail in their coffins after the spread of out-of -town supermarkets, they should grasp the opportunities. The missing link in online shopping is an effective distribution system which delivers products when people are actually at home. Rural post offices could, for a small charge, be the delivery point for goods ordered over the Internet which could then be delivered by the post office along with the papers or else held until collected. The government talks of bridging the digital divide - but what better way than placing an internet kiosk in every rural post office where local people can search for information, book their holidays, use an internet bank and, maybe also, buy something from the shop once they are there. The PO is thinking along these lines but the whole thing needs a sense of urgency. Many post offices are already offering banking services and, as we reported yesterday, the PO is within weeks of signing a £200m deal to prevent a stampede of closures. There are lots of ways in which this could be extended to reach the unbanked poor. Post office staff could be given incentives to train people how to use low-cost internet banks, including that of the Coop, and to learn how to make use of telephone banking since virtually everyone has a telephone.

How could it be financed? Partly from the government's funds to bridge the digital divide, but mainly by making use of some of the estimated £400m saving arising from the switch to benefits being paid directly into banks (though people should be aware that they can continue to receive benefits at their post office). And if that is not enough, would anyone even notice a few hundred million being siphoned off from the windfall gains arising from the auction for radio spectrum (which rose yesterday by another £1bn to £19bn)? The inflationary consequences of resuscitating post offices in this way would not even register on the radar screen in the way that other increases in public spending might. In any case, the cost of not doing anything will also cost the government money because of the increased social costs that would arise if the rural economy is run down further. That cannot, and must not, be allowed to happen.

fields.headline: Police ordered to evict squatters
fields.standfirst: Government in Zimbabwe urges end to white farm occupationsZimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The Zimbabwean government called for an end to the occupation of white-owned farms by poor blacks yesterday within hours of the Harare high court ordering the police to evict thousands of the squatters from hundreds of properties.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal in Harare, and  Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
The Zimbabwean government called for an end to the occupation of white-owned farms by poor blacks yesterday within hours of the Harare high court ordering the police to evict thousands of the squatters from hundreds of properties.

But with the police showing no signs of obeying the order - and the leader of the government-backed war veterans who are spearheading the land seizures saying the court could "go to hell" - it is not clear whether Zimbabwe's leaders are trying to defuse the crisis or merely distance themselves from responsibility for further confrontation.

Yesterday's court ruling has forced the country's political crisis to a decisive stage. Zimbabweans are now waiting to see if the government sends the police on to the farms and, if it does, whether that provokes violent resistance by the war veterans, which could set supporters of the ruling party at each other's throats.

The vice-president, Joseph Msika, said last week's constitutional amendment permitting the government to redistribute white-owned land without compensation had negated the need for farm seizures.

"There is no need for the war veterans and the povo [people] to continue demonstrating or occupying farms in a haphazard manner. We have passed the land bill, which will allow us to resettle people in an orderly manner," he said.

Mr Msika is acting president while the Zimbabwean leader, Robert Mugabe, is in Cuba for a summit of developing countries.

His statement came after a high court judge, Moses Chinhengo, ordered the police to obey a ruling made last month that required the authorities to evict the squatters.

On Monday, the attorney general, Patrick Chinamasa, told the court the police were unable to carry out the order because they lacked the manpower and fuel to deal with a situation that is "a racially and politically charged powderkeg ready to explode".

The leader of the war veterans vowed yesterday that the farm seizures would go on. "The high court can go to hell," said Chenjerai "Hitler" Hunzvi. "More invasions will be taking place, and serious ones. The land must be given to the people.

"We have been waiting for 20 years. There is no way you can stop a revolution."

The Commercial Farmers Union has filed contempt of court charges against Mr Hunzvi for violating an order not to encourage more land seizures.

Amid growing confusion about the government's intent, Zimbabweans are looking to Mr Mugabe to clarify his position when he returns from Cuba at the weekend. Opposition leaders are demanding that the president publicly confirms that he will adhere to the rule of law.

Mr Mugabe's office says he will address the nation during Tuesday's celebrations to mark 20 years of independence. He may use the occasion to announce a date for parliamentary elections which must be held by August. His Zanu-PF party is likely to retain control of parliament but with a greatly reduced majority.

But some opposition MPs fear the government plans to ratchet up the crisis by fomenting violence, to justify imposing a state of emergency and calling off the elections. They say that to carry that off, the government needs to appear to be trying to end the crisis.

The main opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change, welcomed the court ruling but did not expect it to be obeyed. Tendai Bitti, the party's spokesman on land, said: "The reality is that unless Mr Mugabe orders those bandits off the land you have a problem. I don't think he will do it."

The MDC's leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, is expected to arrive in London today to put the case for increased international pressure on Mr Mugabe. Mr Tsvangirai is expected to meet the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, this afternoon.

The Zimbabwean government yesterday announced that it plans to send a delegation to London at the end of the month in an attempt to improve soured relations.

Mr Cook welcomed the news: "I have said all along that we would rather have dialogue than confrontation and I hope that will now be possible."

Harare's delegation is to include John Nkomo, the minister responsible for land, and Stan Mudenge, the foreign minister. Britain says it is seeking a neutral envoy to mediate between Mr Mugabe and the international community.

fields.headline: Auction bid breaks £5bn barrier
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: British Telecommunications stole the limelight in the government's auction of third generation mobile phone licences yesterday, when it became the first bidder to offer £5bn.
fields.body:
British Telecommunications stole the limelight in the government's auction of third generation mobile phone licences yesterday, when it became the first bidder to offer £5bn.

BT took the values being placed on the five licences on offer to new heights as its tussle with Vodafone to win licence B escalated. Licence B is attractive to both Vodafone and BT as it offers the biggest spectrum available to an incumbent operator.

However, the soaring prices were too much for WorldCom which withdrew from the auction, leaving seven companies in the bidding. The auction is now in its fifth week and the total bids have reached £19.3bn.

NTL Mobile, backed by France Telecom, offered £4bn for licence A, which has been reserved for a new entrant. Spain's Telefonica and One2One, owned by Deutsche Telekom, both offered £3.4bn for licences C and D respectively.

TIW, which is being supported by Hutchison Whampoa, offered £3.5bn for licence E.

BT chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield yesterday criticised those who thought the company had given up on bidding for licence B because it was becoming too expensive. "The only thing you're guaranteed of is you're wrong," Sir Peter said.

"I'm not going to tell you my bid details at all," he said, adding: "any auction is not over until it's over."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
Like Pavlov's dogs slobbering at the ring of a bell, the Labour hierarchy just can't seem to resist rigging elections. The latest to get the Millbank treatment is for Labour's ruling body, the NEC, and the continuing attempts by Raghib Ashan - who is also suing the party for racial discrimination - to stand. As the Diary disclosed last week, the West Midlands party has claimed Raghib's nomination from his Perry Barr constituency was invalid because the meeting which nominated him was inquorate. But Bill Challis, secretary of the Perry Barr party, says that is "bollocks". The local party then sat on Raghib's forms (which had to be submitted by last Friday), so he filled out another set, which Bill himself took to Millbank Tower the day before nominations closed. webTitle: Sandford cashes in on filmgroup float

fields.headline: Sandford cashes in on filmgroup float
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Serial internet entrepreneur Cliff Stanford is in line for another £100m-plus windfall after video-on-demand company filmgroup announced plans for a flotation that could value the two-year-old firm at around £300m.
fields.body:
Serial internet entrepreneur Cliff Stanford is in line for another £100m-plus windfall after video-on-demand company filmgroup announced plans for a flotation that could value the two-year-old firm at around £300m.

Mr Stanford and 28-year-old former investment banker Simon Franks hold a majority of the shares in the company which Mr Franks claims will become the dominant European force in the battle to bring video-on-demand services into people's living rooms.

Mr Stanford has already made multi-million pound fortunes from the sale of internet service provider Demon and flotation of the Redbus internet investment group.

Mr Franks claims the technology filmgroup has developed to broadcast video over the internet and the breadth of exclusive film content it has acquired will make it an "unshakeable choice" for consumers and give it a competitive advantage over rivals such as Yes TV, Diva and Videonet.

Yes TV, which claims to be the first provider of video on demand on cable and digital subscriber lines, is planning a £600m flotation of its own shortly.

"We'll be delivering high-quality movies to anyone with high-speed internet access, regardless of their delivery platform, by the end of the year," Mr Franks said.

"All our rivals haven't even thought of this yet. We've also spent the last two years buying just about every blockbuster you can imagine. I feel we're in an unassailable position."

Mr Franks predicted volatile technology markets would not derail plans to float filmgroup within the next couple of months.

"There's no way I'm going to put off my IPO just because the market has been dickering about for a few days. The proceeds of the flotation will enable us to expand in the UK and internationally."

Filmgroup's assets also include Redbus Film Distribution, an off-line film distributor. Management is made up of former PolyGram and Demon executives. ABN Amro Rothschild is broker to the float.

fields.headline: Chatroom
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: It was at a function only recently that Sir Iain Vallance chose to shoot the breeze with Chris Gent, chief executive of Vodafone Airtouch.
fields.body:
It was at a function only recently that Sir Iain Vallance chose to shoot the breeze with Chris Gent, chief executive of Vodafone Airtouch.

The two would have had an interesting conversation given Sir Iain, chairman of British Telecommunications, has watched Vodafone outpace BT to become the world's largest mobile phone operator.

Its £107bn takeover of German rival Mannesmann is testament to that.

BT is now about a third of the value of Vodafone which barely existed when BT was privatised in 1984.

This fact is perhaps one of the most telling of where BT has found itself: running 100 yards behind most of the telecommunications pack.

The proof is clearly in the company's share price, which has fallen 25% since December to yesterday's £11.33 and also in the company's poor third-quarter results.

But BT's lag behind other telecommunication operators has only been the case for the past 18 months.

Prior to that BT was regarded as the leader across mobile telephony and ahead of its peers in assembling a strong portfolio of assets in most European markets. Where BT really slipped was in responding to the rapid growth in the internet and broadband services to meet the growing appetite for high-speed data transmissions.

By not establishing a first-mover advantage in internet and broadband, BT has allowed some competitors to get ahead in Europe and its home market.

Other former state-owned monopolies, including Deutsche Telekom and France Telecom have not been as slow to act in these markets as BT.

BT also missed out on the dot.com valuations rubbing off on its share price. Instead of putting its divisions to work in the e-commerce world, it just raked in the profits from the deluge of internet traffic going across its local loop.

These problems were well recognised by the City and BT shareholders who have brought increasing pressure on management to act.

The action came yesterday in what many would describe as a long overdue restructuring.

The reshuffle of BT's structure sees the separation of the British fixed line business into wholesale and retail arms. The rest of the business has been split into four divisions - broadband, internet, mobile and Yell, an international directories and e-commerce business.

Immediately this answers the call for more transparency in BT's operations, strategy and management. Yet rearranging the puzzle does not immediately bring results. The responsibility lies with management in making the new structure work. A shake-up of some of the top line yesterday should hopefully be a step towards this.

BT has earmarked a £4bn spend for broadband technology in the next three years, which will be a good test on whether the restructuring has been supported by strong management.

BT also confirmed it would float Yell, but did not comment on possible sales of its mobile arm BT Cellnet or Open, the interactive television venture, it co-owns with BSkyB, HSBC and Matsushita.

The company says these will not be floated to get a short-term blip in the share price. However, BT does need to improve its share value if it wants to use its make takeover, raise capital or fend off the prospect of a hostile takeover.

fields.headline: Showstopper
fields.standfirst:
Job today not jam tomorrow says DJ

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Mark Goodier, the Radio 1 presenter, is to sacrifice stock in an internet company worth a potential £7m to keep his job hosting the UK Top 40 chart show.
fields.body:
Mark Goodier, the Radio 1 presenter, is to sacrifice stock in an internet company worth a potential £7m to keep his job hosting the UK Top 40 chart show.

The BBC have asked Mr Goodier to relinquish his 2% stake in Worldpop.com, a fledgling internet music firm chaired by former Radio 1 DJ Peter Powell, which yesterday became the first sponsor of the chart.

The company, which was recently valued at £50m by the US investment bank Merrill Lynch, could command a valuation of £400m if it floats on the stock market later this year as planned. Mr Goodier's firm, Wise Buddha, is likely to get £1m for a stake that could have been worth £8m on flotation.

The BBC said Mr Goodier was giving up his holding as corporation guidelines prevented employees from having a financial interest in programmes with which they had an involvement.

The BBC, which is set to sign next week a new three-year contract to broadcast the charts, said this would not be affected by the sponsorship deal.

BBC guidelines allow Worldpop credits on both the Top 40 radio show, and the Top of the Pops television programme.

Although the BBC name-checks sponsored events like the Martell Grand National and Carling Premier League this will be the first weekly programme to include sponsor credits.

"There will be no jingles featuring Worldpop's name," the BBC spokesman said. "No programme on the BBC's public service is sponsored or will be sponsored as a result of the deal.

"However, in an ever more competitive world, it was inevitable that the music industry would seek to secure a sponsor for this national weekly event."

Current number one Craig David helped launchthe Worldpop sponsorship. The chart show is Radio 1's most popular programme, with a Sunday audience of nearly 3.5m.

The chart is commissioned by the British Phonographic Industry, representing producers, and Bard, the retail association. The BPI said that the BBC could have lost the chart if it had refused to use Worldpop's name.

Worldpop.com will pay £4m to sponsor the chart for three years, Mr Powell said. The company, which has backing from 3i and Amadeus Capital Partners, hopes to turn the UK Top 40 into a global brand.

webTitle: Tobacco's foes try to smoke out a solution

fields.headline: Tobacco's foes try to smoke out a solution
fields.standfirst:
Punitive awards against tobacco companies has the industry gasping for breath

Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: Punitive awards against tobacco companies has the industry gasping for breath
fields.body:
If cigarette manufacturers were cancer patients, most doctors would have them on life support. For years, the industry has been seeking to stub out lawsuits that have popped up in courtrooms all over the US. A $246bn (£158bn) settlement with the US government last year had already brought promises of better behaviour in the future when, last week, a court in Florida delivered a massive and potentially fatal attack.

A six-member jury found in favour of three sick smokers against industry giants such as Philip Morris, RJ Reynolds and Brown & Williamson, the US group owned by British American Tobacco. Angie Della Vecchia, Mary Farnan and Frank Amodeo were awarded a total of $12.7m, the highest amount in damages ever awarded against cigarette manufacturers.

The almost entirely negative ruling found that smoking had caused cancer and that the tobacco industry was guilty of fraud, misrepresentation, negligence and intentional emotional distress.

But far, far worse than any of this was the fact that, for the first time, a jury allowed a so-called class action case against the large tobacco companies. This means that the three plaintiffs appeared on behalf of all Florida residents who have smoked.

With about 500,000 possible victims under consideration, the eventual liability for the industry could run into hundreds of billions of dollars. Industry-supporting analysts have predicted a liability of between $10bn and $50bn.

An already ailing industry went into shock. Although the US tobacco sector had already almost halved in value since last June, shares fell further on Monday. Philip Morris, the largest company in the sector, fell 5% to hover just above $20, down from more than $40 last June. On the London stock exchange, BAT fell 10% in a day.

Most of the immediate concern involves the posting of a financial security to cover any eventual cost. Under Florida law, this bond could be as large as 115% of the expected payout. Unlike the industry's multi-billion deal with US states, which is to be paid out over the next 25 years, this penalty would have to be paid soon after the jury delivers its verdict in the next punitive phase of the trial, which starts in mid May.

Tobacco lawyers argued in court that the industry would be bankrupted by such a penalty. On Wednesday, they managed to defeat the latest of more than 20 class action lawsuits when a court in California threw out a smaller complaint. But two more cases are pending in Maryland and Louisiana.

Legal twists and turns

The extent of its potential financial illness has prompted some odd physicians to step forward with life support machines for the industry.

Bob Butterworth, the state Attorney General who launched and won his own $13bn suit against tobacco companies last year, is one. Following last week's verdict, the Florida legislature is to consider a law that protects the tobacco industry from such crippling awards by setting a maximum annual payout and a maximum bond.

In doing so, the state hopes to protect its own award. The enormity of a potential class action payout has also led Stanley Rosenblatt, the Florida lawyer, to scale down his own comments on a potential punitive award, prompting cynics to argue that the winning legal team is worried about the payment of its own fees.

Wall Street analysts have welcomed these legal twists and turns and have this week published more positive notes on the industry than appears warranted.

Some have based their upbeat outlook on details of the case itself. Martin Feldman, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said: "The ruling was clearly a tough one for the industry, but within the detail there were some points that called into question the whole concept of a class action."

These details include the fact that one of the victims was found to have lodged his complaint too late under state laws. Each defendant was also found personally liable to differing degrees for their own ill health. These differences, magnified hundreds of thousands of times, would make a possible ruling in favour of all Florida smokers difficult to uphold.

Mr Feldman says the jury is being asked to rule on compensation for hundreds or thousands of people without even rudimentary evidence that they smoked. "This is not the way the law is supposed to work," he says.

Maggie Lotts, industry analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, agrees. "We believe the verdict underscores the fact that class action litigation is not appropriate for health claims."

Both have argued that investors are over-reacting to last week's ruling. The industry has been largely silent this week as it gears up for more legal battles. Next week, for example, the New York state senate is to propose a bill that would force companies to sell cigarettes that go out more quickly in an attempt to reduce the risk of fire. The industry must be wishing they could produce a chemical that extinguishes lawsuits faster still.

webTitle: NHS chief attacks 'spin doctoring' over cash boost

fields.headline: NHS chief attacks 'spin doctoring' over cash boost
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: A senior figure in the NHS yesterday attacked what he called "disgraceful spin doctoring" of the government's increased funding for the health service.
fields.body:
A senior figure in the NHS yesterday attacked what he called "disgraceful spin doctoring" of the government's increased funding for the health service.

Ken Jarrold, one of the most respected NHS managers, said the relief and joy felt at the extra funding had been undermined by the briefing of journalists that health authorities could not be trusted to spend the money as ministers wanted.

"Ministers are right that money is not enough. The NHS does need modernisation," said Mr Jarrold, former human resources director of the NHS executive and now chief executive of Durham county health authority.

"The NHS also needs political leadership rooted firmly in consistency and integrity."

Mr Jarrold's decision to speak out, in a letter to the Health Service Journal, reflects the depth of unease among health managers - mirrored among their opposite numbers in local government - at what they see as Labour's over-centralisation.

After Alan Milburn, the health secretary, announced allocation of the first £600m extra funds, the press was briefed that he would for the first time use powers to send the money straight to "frontline" doctors and nurses. Previously, it was said, funds had not all reached the intended recipients.

Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS confederation, which represents health authorities and trusts, reacted angrily and asked in the Guardian if it was being insinuated that managers had "stuck the money in their back pocket and spent it on foreign holidays".

It is understood that Mr Thornton has faced a severe dressing down for his comments. Pointedly, Mr Jarrold's letter expresses "many congratulations to Stephen Thornton for his robust response".

The government's tactics have prompted the resignation of at least one health authority leader - Joan Firth, who chaired the Bradford body for more than two years and who is a former deputy director of finance at the Department of Health.

She said yesterday that, having put more than 30 hours a week into the part-time chairing role, she had reluctantly decided to quit in protest at what was happening. "The response from Mr Milburn is notable for its curtness and the total absence of any thanks."

The extra funds for the NHS are being routed through health authorities as usual, but with specific instructions - backed by statute - that they must be passed straight on to primary care groups and trusts.

webTitle: Patients 'as happy to see nurse as GP'

fields.headline: Patients 'as happy to see nurse as GP'
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Patients with minor illnesses are just as happy to see a nurse as a GP, and are more satisfied with the consultation they get, according to new research.
fields.body:
Patients with minor illnesses are just as happy to see a nurse as a GP, and are more satisfied with the consultation they get, according to new research.

The study is one of four in the British Medical Journal that suggest nurses, whether taking consultations or giving advice on a telephone helpline outside surgery hours, are not only popular but good value for money. While nurses themselves, who feel underpaid, will not be surprised at the results, the findings will fuel the drive from the health secretary, Alan Milburn, to give nurses more responsibility and tear down the demarcation between them and doctors.

The four studies are part of a joint issue of the BMJ with Nursing Times, designed to explore the possibilities for collaboration and cooperation that have sometimes eluded the two professions. "The differences of power, perspective, education, pay, status, class and - perhaps above all - gender have led to tribal warfare as often as peaceful co-existence," write Richard Smith and Jane Salvage, the journals' respective editors.

In the studies, it is the nurses who win out every time. Researchers from the University of Manchester compared the health outcomes and costs of nurse practitioners and GPs in 20 practices in England and Wales. There are 5,000 nurse practitioners, who have taken a three-year qualification on top of their basic nursing training, and several thousand more doing the same job on the basis of extensive experience. They diagnose and treat minor illnesses, referring more complicated illnesses to a GP, who must also sign any prescription they write.

Pamela Venning and colleagues who carried out the study of just under 1,300 patients attending for a same-day appointment, found that consultations with nurses were twice as long as with GPs. Nurses were two-thirds more likely to order tests, carry out more on-the-spot screening and ask the patient to make a repeat appointment. But there was no significant difference in the drugs they prescribed or the outcome for the patient.

The cost of nurse consultations were 12.5% lower than with GPs, which is not significant. Dr Venning and colleagues suggest they could be lower. "If nurse practitioners were able to work in different ways - for example, to shorten their consultation times (which our results suggest will not alter higher patient satisfaction with nurse practitioners) or reduce their return consultation rate - they could be more cost-effective than general practitioners for this group of patients."

Two more studies, in south-east London and Kent, also found patients were very happy with nurses, who took two minutes longer on average than the eight minute GP consultation.

The fourth study, on the cost effectiveness of an out-of-hours nurse-run telephone helpline, found that it could save the NHS money. Val Latimer and colleagues from Southampton University reported that the helpline serving 55 practices in Wiltshire cost just over £81,000 in 1997, but more than £94,000 was saved by the drop in the numbers of people going to casualty.

But whatever the advantages for the NHS of employing nurses in roles that used to be the province of doctors, no commentator doubts the transition to an equal partnership is going to be rocky.
