webTitle: Russia talks to rebels in Chechnya

fields.headline: Russia talks to rebels in Chechnya
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: The Russian government said yesterday that it was talking directly to rebel representatives in Chechnya - a reversal of its refusal to enter into dialogue with "terrorists".
fields.body:
The Russian government said yesterday that it was talking directly to rebel representatives in Chechnya - a reversal of its refusal to enter into dialogue with "terrorists".

The announcement by Russia's foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, indicates that Moscow is finally ready to start negotiations in an attempt to end the war which has devastated the separatist region.

The timing of the revelation - just days before President Vladimir Putin's debut on the stage of international diplomacy - is crucial. European states have been critical of Russia's campaign in Chechnya, and the comments appear to be an attempt to pre-empt further condemnation when Mr Putin meets Tony Blair in London next week.

But some commentators suggested yesterday that the move was not a response to western pressure, but a reflection of the government's deep anxiety about ongoing military setbacks in the region.

Mr Ivanov said the government was conducting a "direct dialogue" with the Chechens and was "confident that this would lead to concrete results". His comments were interpreted as an indication that talks were being held with the Chechen president, Aslan Maskhadov.

Chechen sources confirmed yesterday that talks had been under way with Mr Maskhadov since the beginning of April through local intermediaries - the president of Ingushetia, Ruslan Aushev, and the president of North Ossetia, Alexander Dzasokhov.

Mr Ivanov said the "Russian leadership has always advocated political settlement in Chechnya, been prepared for dialogue and never closed the door on anybody".

But until very recently, the Kremlin had insisted that the only talks it would contemplate would be held within the prosecutor's office as criminal charges were brought against the Chechen leaders. Mr Maskhadov's offers to negotiate were publicly rebuffed.

It was only this week that the Kremlin spokesman on Chechnya, Sergei Yastrzhemsky, began to hint at a change, commenting: "We have repeatedly made Moscow's point of view known to Maskhadov - in an attempt to launch some kind of political process."

Mr Maskhadov eased Moscow's about-turn on Monday when he publicly distanced himself from two leading warlords. He said they were responsible for starting the war, in comments which are seen as an indication that he is ready to compromise.

"For the majority of the Chechen population it is clear that the war has been lost. They are tired and what they want now is the return of gas, electricity and stability. Maskhadov knows that they are ready for talks," said Alexei Malashenko of the Carnegie Institute in Moscow.

Now that he has secured the presidency, Mr Putin faces the difficult question of how to resolve the Chechen problem.

In the last month, the number of Russian dead has risen to 2,119, and military experts warned that the onset of spring would bring a big increase in casualties, with rebels using foliage as cover to mount attacks.

But even if the talks prove to be more than rhetoric to placate Europe, it is unclear how much they can achieve. Russia's military is unlikely to be satisfied with anything less than a full capitulation by the Chechen rebels, and Mr Maskhadov may not have the power to enforce a laying down of guerrilla arms.

webTitle: Paddington disaster: track fault may have altered signal

fields.headline: Paddington disaster: track fault may have altered signal
fields.standfirst: Paddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText: The driver at the centre of the Paddington rail disaster may have passed a "false" green signal caused by a track fault, an official report by the railway inspectorate declares today.
fields.body:
The driver at the centre of the Paddington rail disaster may have passed a "false" green signal caused by a track fault, an official report by the railway inspectorate declares today.

Doubts about whether the inexperienced driver, Michael Hodder, could be blamed for the crash are raised in the third interim report of the heath and safety executive into last October's crash in which 31 people, including both train drivers, died.

It says that railway inspectors have found a track joint "with significant misalignment" between the rails near signal 109, which has since been taken out of commission by Railtrack.

The report says further work is in progress to assess whether there is any possibility "however remote" that Hodder's train passed over the track joint, causing a vibration of the automatic warning system (AWS) magnet near SN 109.

This could have caused a "mal-operation" which could have led to Mr Hodder receiving "a false green signal ahead indication" as he approached SN 109.

The AWS system was on board the Thames Train operated by Mr Hodder, who had only qualified as a driver 13 days before his train collided with a Great Western express.

Railtrack's chief executive, Gerald Corbett, said that it had only just been informed of the theoretical possibility that the AWS system was not working properly and had not so far been provided with any scientific report to support the HSE's theory. He pointed out that AWS had been in use for decades. "Had the railway inspectorate considered this was a major railway problem, no doubt it would have informed us well before now."

Rob Gifford, secretary of the parliamentary advisory committee on transport safety, said: "Going for driver error may seem like an easy answer, but the true situation is far more complex."

The railway inspectorate, which has submitted the report to Lord Cullen in preparation for his public inquiry into the Paddington crash on May 10, is also examining a theory that the AWS equipment on the Thames train was loose, potentially a more serious problem than misalignment of the track joint.

Unpublished evidence collected by the HSE suggests Mr Hodder was travelling at 40mph by the time he passed SN 109. If so, he could not have stopped in time to avoid hitting the high speed express.

There is no evidence that Mr Hodder was distracted at the time of the accident. He passed his drivers' rules examination last April and was assessed competent to drive at the end of May. Before the accident, he had completed nine shifts as driver in charge.

The report draws attention to the "unusual design" of SN 109. Before the crash Railtrack held several meetings following complaints about the signal, but the issues had not been resolved. The inspectorate is examining other factors, such as low bridges, the design and positioning of overhead electrification equipment, and the curve of the track outside Paddington.

Investigators have painstakingly reconstructed a carriage from 18 wagon loads of wreckage, and reconstructed a fire to determine why coach H at the front of the Great Western train was so severely burnt.

Work is being carried out to link the deaths and serious injuries against structural damage in each of the coaches.

Mr Corbett said the HSE report reaffirmed that the signals were not at fault, and the height of SN 109 conformed with requirements. The investigation into this "tragic accident" was far from complete, he said, and it would be "quite wrong" to pre-empt Lord Cullen's inquiry.

webTitle: Race watchdog tells parties to mind language

fields.headline: Race watchdog tells parties to mind language
fields.standfirst:
Refugees in Britain: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and William Hague were both upbraided by the Commission for Racial Equality yesterday for their handling of the crisis over asylum seekers.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and William Hague were both upbraided by the Commission for Racial Equality yesterday for their handling of the crisis over asylum seekers.

In a rare move, the commission's chairman called on the prime minister and the Tory leader to "consider very carefully" the language they have used in recent weeks. Hugh Harris also called on Mr Hague and Mr Blair to reaffirm their commitment to the commission's principles signed by all party leaders in 1996.

Mr Harris, acting chairman of the commission, intervened in the asylum row after the Liberal Democrats lodged a formal complaint over the inflammatory language used by Labour and the Tories.

Simon Hughes, the Lib Dems' home affairs spokesman, accused Mr Hague of breaking his undertaking not to stir up racial divisions by declaring in his local election manifesto that Britain was being "flooded" by bogus asylum seekers. Labour was also criticised for using language which ran against the spirit of the CRE commitment in which political leaders agreed not to "incite hostility" between racial groups.

In his response to Mr Hughes, Mr Harris made clear that the CRE believed that the two parties had overstepped the boundaries. He said: "Like you we are keen that all politicians stick to the terms of the CRE's principles of good practice and conduct that was signed by the leaders of Britain's five main political parties. Like you, we wish the leaders of these parties to reaffirm their commitment."

Mr Harris reminded Britain's political leaders - his letter was copied to Mr Blair and Mr Hague and other party leaders - of their pledges not to stir up racial divisions. "It is therefore for the leaders of all parties to consider very carefully the language being used by themselves and their members on asylum seekers, immigration and race relations issue."

The CRE acting chairman also reminded party leaders that many asylum seekers had were in "genuine risk of persecution and attack in their own country".

"Any debate on the issue of asylum seekers should avoid stirring up resentment towards those who may be genuinely in need of help, and avoid impacting on race relations more generally," Mr Harris added.

Mr Hughes welcomed the commission's "constructive" response to his letter.

"The nature and content of the debate was in danger of replacing fact with fiction," he said.

fields.headline: Children from hell
fields.standfirst:
The government is trying to stop heads excluding problem pupils. What else can be done with them?
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government is trying to stop heads excluding problem pupils. What else can be done with them?
fields.body:
The figures are frightening. The Metropolitan police estimates that 40% of robberies, 25% of all burglaries and 20% of thefts are committed by school-age children during school hours. Truanting or excluded, they roam the streets with nothing to do and nowhere to go: they are the crime wave, not waving but drowning.

A report yesterday from the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders (Nacro) shows how closely crime is associated with school exclusion. Every year, 100,000 children are excluded temporarily and 12,000 permanently. That is a lot of children wandering about all day with trouble in mind. Many get only a few hours teaching a week. Many never get back into school again. What happens to them after that? No one knows, but studies of young offenders show that 42% have been excluded from school. The Nacro report is asking another important question: how much worse does school exclusion make them? The answer is this: excluded children commit 50% more crimes in the year after they are excluded than they did in the year before.

What's to be done? One solution looks relatively simple: keep them in school and at least reduce their time on the streets. Finding that school exclusions had risen an astonishing four-fold in the 1990s, this was what the government set out to do and the social exclusion unit chose it as its very first subject to tackle. Two years ago it set tough new targets: truancy and school exclusion was to be reduced by one-third. The screw was tightened on schools suspected of dumping their failures in a bid to climb up the league tables.

A stern circular was sent out demanding elaborate and complex procedures before any child could be excluded. Head teachers had to show that, before expulsion, children must have had a "pastoral support programme" to try to amend their behaviour. They needed a long record of previous offences and the last straw had to be something very serious. After much protest from schools, the circular was slightly amended this year: children don't have to see an educational psychologist before expulsion since the waiting lists are so long that it often takes six months. But it remains official policy to make it very difficult to get rid of a child. So far there's been a reduction of 3% in exclusions.

Teachers are complaining that the policy is too tough. Curiously, the attitude towards these nightmare children is the opposite to the government's attitude towards neighbours from hell, whose removal is regarded as an essential ingredient in renewing disaster neighbourhoods. When it comes to schools, head teachers are supposed to hang on to them. Some heads have the worst children sitting beside them all day for lack of anyone else to guard them, which can't do much for the smooth running of their schools. The head who resigned recently from a showcase fresh-start school said he could have succeeded if only he had been able to expel seven hell-raisers.

Yesterday I called one head in Liverpool, Tony Hardman of Archbishop Beck Roman Catholic High School, but there was a screaming siren down the telephone. A harassed secretary said sorry, but this was the third time today the fire alarm had been set off by one group of pupils. When I called again, the head was storming around in search of the troublemakers. Eventually he rang back: he said he'd never excluded more than one or two a year but he'd had a rash of brutal behaviour from some thugs recently and, yes, he had to get rid of them for the peace and sanity of the school and the parents. "I've got two at the moment who are determined, really determined to be excluded, for kudos. What can you do?"

Under the government's excellence in the cities education programme, he's got £80,000 extra a year to help prevent exclusions. He's trying to set up a pupil-support unit in a derelict pavilion near a playing field far from the main school. "But every time I exclude one child I lose money too. I've lost £20,000 from the project through exclusions. That's money that could and should have helped support some of the younger ones now to stop them getting excluded later on."

This dowry system, where the money follows the child, has its own odd perversities: exclusions now follow the financial year. Tony Hardman says many more children are thrown out in March, at the end of the financial year, so that no money is lost, than after April when a whole year's money would follow them out of the school. This is all highly mechanistic and the heads complain there is no flexibility, no appeal. How can Hardman get his preventative unit built and staffed, as he hopes, with an educational psychologist and a welfare worker if he keeps losing money when he is forced to expel pupils?

Labour is spending £500m over three years and has set itself a difficult target of getting every excluded child into full-time education by 2002 - that's 12,000 special-unit places required. More of these units are being set up inside schools, often linking together neighbouring schools. It's expensive treatment and Nacro reckons the money will be nothing like enough. They already run schemes around the country for children who have been (or are in grave danger of being) excluded from school. The idea is to engage their attention in something, anything that might interest them, leading to literacy and skills training or a way back to school. Some of their schemes work inside schools, all try to build close connections with families.

Despite the success of these projects, with measured outcomes proving how well they work, there is very little money around for spreading them everywhere. While praising what the government has done so far, Nacro reckons the huge scale of the problem and the intensity of treatment these children need will require far more money. These scary crime figures are intended to show what good value the right intensive investment here would be.

It isn't a zero-sum question. The government doesn't say no children should be excluded - but sometimes they seem not to grasp the full horror of life in the toughest schools. Imagine the places where young teachers have their backs against the door to stop wild children storming into their lesson. With a huge drop-out in teacher training courses and difficulty recruiting at all, exclusion has to be an important part of the armoury of any school head trying to keep a grip.

True, some of the old sin bins for excluded children were dreadful. But there were some wonderful therapeutic projects that were shut down too in the slash-and-burn Thatcher era when education welfare and educational psychology were also cut to ribbons. One monolithic state programme will not be enough: imaginative successful projects run by innovative voluntary organisations will be a vital resource. The right kind of projects for children's very different problems will still be desperately needed to take in the hard cases head teachers will still need to throw out.
fields.bodyText: The figures are frightening. The Metropolitan police estimates that 40% of robberies, 25% of all burglaries and 20% of thefts are committed by school-age children during school hours. Truanting or excluded, they roam the streets with nothing to do and nowhere to go: they are the crime wave, not waving but drowning. A report yesterday from the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders (Nacro) shows how closely crime is associated with school exclusion. Every year, 100,000 children are excluded temporarily and 12,000 permanently. That is a lot of children wandering about all day with trouble in mind. Many get only a few hours teaching a week. Many never get back into school again. What happens to them after that? No one knows, but studies of young offenders show that 42% have been excluded from school. The Nacro report is asking another important question: how much worse does school exclusion make them? The answer is this: excluded children commit 50% more crimes in the year after they are excluded than they did in the year before. What's to be done? One solution looks relatively simple: keep them in school and at least reduce their time on the streets. Finding that school exclusions had risen an astonishing four-fold in the 1990s, this was what the government set out to do and the social exclusion unit chose it as its very first subject to tackle. Two years ago it set tough new targets: truancy and school exclusion was to be reduced by one-third. The screw was tightened on schools suspected of dumping their failures in a bid to climb up the league tables. A stern circular was sent out demanding elaborate and complex procedures before any child could be excluded. Head teachers had to show that, before expulsion, children must have had a "pastoral support programme" to try to amend their behaviour. They needed a long record of previous offences and the last straw had to be something very serious. After much protest from schools, the circular was slightly amended this year: children don't have to see an educational psychologist before expulsion since the waiting lists are so long that it often takes six months. But it remains official policy to make it very difficult to get rid of a child. So far there's been a reduction of 3% in exclusions. Teachers are complaining that the policy is too tough. Curiously, the attitude towards these nightmare children is the opposite to the government's attitude towards neighbours from hell, whose removal is regarded as an essential ingredient in renewing disaster neighbourhoods. When it comes to schools, head teachers are supposed to hang on to them. Some heads have the worst children sitting beside them all day for lack of anyone else to guard them, which can't do much for the smooth running of their schools. The head who resigned recently from a showcase fresh-start school said he could have succeeded if only he had been able to expel seven hell-raisers. Yesterday I called one head in Liverpool, Tony Hardman of Archbishop Beck Roman Catholic High School, but there was a screaming siren down the telephone. A harassed secretary said sorry, but this was the third time today the fire alarm had been set off by one group of pupils. When I called again, the head was storming around in search of the troublemakers. Eventually he rang back: he said he'd never excluded more than one or two a year but he'd had a rash of brutal behaviour from some thugs recently and, yes, he had to get rid of them for the peace and sanity of the school and the parents. "I've got two at the moment who are determined, really determined to be excluded, for kudos. What can you do?" Under the government's excellence in the cities education programme, he's got £80,000 extra a year to help prevent exclusions. He's trying to set up a pupil-support unit in a derelict pavilion near a playing field far from the main school. "But every time I exclude one child I lose money too. I've lost £20,000 from the project through exclusions. That's money that could and should have helped support some of the younger ones now to stop them getting excluded later on." This dowry system, where the money follows the child, has its own odd perversities: exclusions now follow the financial year. Tony Hardman says many more children are thrown out in March, at the end of the financial year, so that no money is lost, than after April when a whole year's money would follow them out of the school. This is all highly mechanistic and the heads complain there is no flexibility, no appeal. How can Hardman get his preventative unit built and staffed, as he hopes, with an educational psychologist and a welfare worker if he keeps losing money when he is forced to expel pupils? Labour is spending £500m over three years and has set itself a difficult target of getting every excluded child into full-time education by 2002 - that's 12,000 special-unit places required. More of these units are being set up inside schools, often linking together neighbouring schools. It's expensive treatment and Nacro reckons the money will be nothing like enough. They already run schemes around the country for children who have been (or are in grave danger of being) excluded from school. The idea is to engage their attention in something, anything that might interest them, leading to literacy and skills training or a way back to school. Some of their schemes work inside schools, all try to build close connections with families. Despite the success of these projects, with measured outcomes proving how well they work, there is very little money around for spreading them everywhere. While praising what the government has done so far, Nacro reckons the huge scale of the problem and the intensity of treatment these children need will require far more money. These scary crime figures are intended to show what good value the right intensive investment here would be. It isn't a zero-sum question. The government doesn't say no children should be excluded - but sometimes they seem not to grasp the full horror of life in the toughest schools. Imagine the places where young teachers have their backs against the door to stop wild children storming into their lesson. With a huge drop-out in teacher training courses and difficulty recruiting at all, exclusion has to be an important part of the armoury of any school head trying to keep a grip. True, some of the old sin bins for excluded children were dreadful. But there were some wonderful therapeutic projects that were shut down too in the slash-and-burn Thatcher era when education welfare and educational psychology were also cut to ribbons. One monolithic state programme will not be enough: imaginative successful projects run by innovative voluntary organisations will be a vital resource. The right kind of projects for children's very different problems will still be desperately needed to take in the hard cases head teachers will still need to throw out.

fields.headline: and as for Irving ...
fields.trailText: Bill Abbott asks (Letters, April 13), as did Irving, why Jews have been hated for 3,000 years. As a Jew who has only been on this planet for 81 years, I am also puzzled as to why I have been hated for 3,000 years.
fields.body:
Bill Abbott asks (Letters, April 13), as did Irving, why Jews have been hated for 3,000 years. As a Jew who has only been on this planet for 81 years, I am also puzzled as to why I have been hated for 3,000 years. It may be that the Romans and the early Christians, in the true spirit of David Irving, also falsified their version of history to suit their own prejudices. As far as I am concerned, I have led a respectable commercial and social life, having paid my rates and taxes. I served in the Royal Regiment of Artillery for the whole of the second world war, including operations with the Desert Rats in three theatres of operations. I have a reasonably free conscience.
Julius Mindel
Bournemouth

 Jeff Wells (Letters, April 13) suggests that every time the figure of 6m dead Jews is mentioned it denies or excludes anyone else. If so, talk of genocide of native Americans would "deny" the deaths of African Americans; discussion of deaths in the gulag would "exclude" the deaths under Latin American dictatorships. Most accounts I've read of how the 6m went include passages on all the other victims of Nazism, including groups Jeff Wells failed to mention: eg Jehovah's Witnesses, "criminals" and 3m non-Jewish Poles. If he wants a memorial for dead socialists, he would do well to remember the words of Joe Hill: "Don't mourn, organise." Socialists shouldn't expect others to build their memorials, we do it ourselves.
Michael Rosen
London
rosenmichael@hotmail.com

 I was amazed by your refusal (Fight for truth, April 12) to open a debate about the Holocaust in the wake of the Irving case.The estimated 6m Slavs killed in the Holocaust have their own tragedy cheapened by the west's view of the Holocaust as a solely Jewish affair.
Andrew Champney
Utrecht, The Netherlands
achampney@hotmail.com

 While your concerns about David Irving's libel actions are understandable (Leader, April 13), there is more at issue than the libel lottery. Irving has used the court case very effectively to promote his denial of the Holocaust and to obtain publicity for it. His arguments have been reported in detail by all the major news media, including the Guardian. Now we are told that the cost he will bear for three months' propaganda is likely to be less than £100,000 - which he would have known before he began. This has been an abuse of the legal process.
Paul Spicker
University of Dundee

fields.headline: It's Burchill we loathe ...
fields.trailText: As Tony Cliff's children, we are disgusted by the lack of any political or personal understanding of our dad's life displayed by Julie Burchill (Letters, April 13). Dad had nothing to hide by using an alias rather than his birth name, Ygael Gluckstein.
fields.body:
As Tony Cliff's children, we are disgusted by the lack of any political or personal understanding of our dad's life displayed by Julie Burchill (Letters, April 13). Dad had nothing to hide by using an alias rather than his birth name, Ygael Gluckstein. In fact, when asked why he had changed his name, he said: "I worked for 13 years in illegal conditions in Palestine ... there we had to use pseudonyms and I think it just became habit-forming" (David Widgery, The Left in Britain).

When then asked if it was following the Bolshevik tradition, he replied: "Nothing as romantic." The loathing dad had was not for himself, but for racism in any form, be it anti-semitic, anti-Arab or any other. It is no accident that he helped form the Anti-Nazi League. Julie Burchill's implication that Tony Cliff loathed his Jewish background is petty and contemptible. Anna Gluckstein,
Danny Gluckstein, Donny Gluckstein, Elana Dallas
London

 My family changed its name in the 20s. Yizhak Morrensky was unable to get work outside of the Jewish community because of his name. When he changed it to Jack Morris he soon got his London cabbie's licence. His five brothers followed suit. Hardly any wonder they retained their affinity with the Communist party. At least it was one area of their community where they were least bothered by the kind of infantile racism underpinning the wretched prejudiced bleatings of Burchill's letter.

Old Jack's dad, my grandfather, changed his name once before. He arrived in this country as Simeon Maranov, but later changed it to Morrensky in the belief this would confuse authorities searching for him during the recruitment campaign for the first world war. Having walked from Pollok in eastern Belarus to Hamburg to escape Russian conscription, he was buggered if he would die in the trenches for the English tsar.
Robert Morris
London
maranov@lineone.net

 I've spent the last 46 years (give or take) spelling my surname laboriously to everyone I meet. Even so I still get letters addressed to Perkins or, less charmingly, Piskin. Of course, I too could change my name, but I am one of those whom Ms Burchill would apparently prefer to retain the names they were born with for ease of identification - a left-wing Jewish immigrant. Or, more accurately - let us by all means be accurate since labels are so important - a left-wing Jewish descendant of my immigrant great-grandfather.
Linda Peskin
London

 I was shocked to read of Tony Cliff's death in Paul Foot's obituary (April 11) and then by Julie Burchill's letter. A significant number of Guardian readers will have heard of Cliff and many, like me, will have been inspired and charmed by this extraordinary man. Carrying a revolutionary spirit and helping sustain a socialist organisation for nearly 50 years can't be done by someone suffering from "self-loathing". An infliction that Julie, unfortunately, may know something about.
Matthew Bowles
London

 Einde O'Callaghan (Letters, April 13) is mistaken. There certainly were theoretical works describing the USSR as capitalist in Marx's sense prior to Tony Cliff: For example World Crisis: Towards State Capitalism (Otto Rühle, 1931), Theses On Bolshevism (by Dutch council communists, 1934), and An Analysis Of The Russian Economy (Raya Dunayevskaya, 1943). Few of the theorists after 1955 owed much to Cliff either.
Clyde Strathers
Glasgow
socialquestion@hotmail.com

fields.headline: Cricket put to the test
fields.trailText: Before consigning Hansie Cronje to eternal damnation (Leader, April 12) we should consider the difference between throwing a game and predicting an outcome. The new Wisden supplement quotes Leveson-Gower from Wisden 1937, in which he tells how he obtained a sapphire pin by predicting the Varsity Match of 1896.
fields.body:
Before consigning Hansie Cronje to eternal damnation (Leader, April 12) we should consider the difference between throwing a game and predicting an outcome. The new Wisden supplement quotes Leveson-Gower from Wisden 1937, in which he tells how he obtained a sapphire pin by predicting the Varsity Match of 1896.
Brian Austin
Weston-super-Mare, Somerset

 We can still show the world a thing or two about sportsmanship: no one would ever think of bribing our cricketers to lose a Test match.
Peter McCourt
West Bridgford, Notts

 Why was Hansie Cronje approached to forecast specific cricket matches? I could have provided a blanket prediction of the outcome of all cricket matches - total tedium.
DJ Browning
Timperley, Cheshire.

 Re: IMF warns chancellor (April 13): let me see if I've got this right. British governments held down health and social expenditure for decades to boost the economy. Now the government should still restrict expenditure because the economy is doing well.
B Jones
Bath

 Dr Stevenson (Letters, April 13) wonders at the regularity with which mobile phone users state their whereabouts. Usually this is in reply to the person at the other end. Hopefully when mobiles become truly commonplace, people will stop asking. On my bus, anyway.
Vince Paver
London

 I was intrigued by your headline "London TV calls in dubbers to tone down Scots accent" (April 12). Growing up in Liverpool in the 70s, the word "dubber" meant a lady of ill repute. Are the women of Lime Street now offering elocution lessons?
Richard Cohen
London

fields.headline: A richer grasp of poverty
fields.trailText: Your report on the new Index of Local Deprivation (Cities lose out in poverty league table, April 3), contains too many mistakes to be ignored.
fields.body:
Your report on the new Index of Local Deprivation (Cities lose out in poverty league table, April 3), contains too many mistakes to be ignored. As I pointed out in a letter on the same day, the draft rankings are a public document available on the internet: they are not restricted to local authorities as you implied, so there is no need for them to have come from a leaked document. The review of the index has been carried out by a well-respected and independent team from the University of Oxford. There has been no manipulation of the results to suit areas represented by cabinet ministers. The position of areas is not "the result of lobbying by non-London authorities". Your article is especially misleading when you discuss areas moving up and down the index. The rankings you quoted are from just one of the five proposed measures: the degree measure. For example, although Sheffield is 90th on this draft measure it is 5th, 6th, 15th, 48th on the other four draft measures. The new index will be based on 33 indicators - not six as you report - compared with the 12 indicators which made up the 1998 index. The new index is based on up-to-date information for local wards rather than the previous index which was based on averages across entire cities and boroughs.

The new index picks up pockets of deprivation missed by the previous index. You report that the new index "underplays factors such as ... ethnic minorities among whom English is a second language" - in fact the use of English as a second language is an indicator. Finally, you claim that the index gives "undue weight to factors such as access to public transport": in fact, access to public transport is not a proposed indicator.
Hilary Armstrong
Minister for Local Government

fields.headline: In defence of Elian's homeland
fields.trailText: Are there no journalists left (One small boy bails out the old dictator, April 12) who know that there was a rightwing dictatorship under Batista in Cuba before the revolution? Or that the Castro government tried to establish good relations with the US, was rebuffed and turned to the Soviet Union and "communism" out of desperation.
fields.body:
Are there no journalists left (One small boy bails out the old dictator, April 12) who know: 1) that there was a rightwing dictatorship under Batista in Cuba before the revolution? Or that the Castro government tried to establish good relations with the US, was rebuffed and turned to the Soviet Union and "communism" out of desperation. 2) That, if one third of the population of Cuba would move to the United States if it could, the same could be said of the rest of Latin America, and indeed, eastern Europe, which is not "communist". The reason is not a desire for "liberty", but to escape poverty, largely a result of American policy.
Dorothy Stein
London
dstein@sas.ac.uk

 I recently interviewed a large number of people in focus groups in Cuba. They showed a very high level of political awareness. There were complaints about the economy, shortages, and the US economic blockade - some indeed wanted to leave. But people were also very aware of the achievements of Cuba, and did not want to see these jeopardised. They knew what had happened to the former Soviet Union and also to countries such as Haiti and Guatemala under the influence of America. As for the teenagers "going off the rails", my belief is that it would be easier to keep them on the rails in Havana than in Glasgow. In Cuba there are no street gangs, no serious drug problem or violent crime; the schools are calm and young people are not sleeping in doorways. A third of all their high school graduates go to university, and there are places in further education for the other two-thirds. The level of confidence and sophistication of many Cuban young people was extraordinary.
Dr Greg Philo
Glasgow University
g.philo@virgin.net

 Isabel Hilton's estimates of the numbers of Cubans living abroad and of those who might wish to leave are grossly exaggerated. The population of Cuba is 11.6m. Since 1995 the US interests section in Havana has received 500,000 applications for a visa to travel to the US, less than 5% of the population. The Miami Herald places the number of Cuban-born emigres living in the US at 700,000, again around 5% of the population.
Dr Stephen Wilkinson
Kingston upon Thames, Surrey

fields.headline: Bosom pal
fields.trailText: Louisa Young (Up front and personal, G2, April 11) bemoans the lot of the D cup woman, and advises her that she must hide away her assets under baggy jumpers if she is to be taken seriously.
fields.body:
Louisa Young (Up front and personal, G2, April 11) bemoans the lot of the D cup woman, and advises her that she must hide away her assets under baggy jumpers if she is to be taken seriously.

While I fully acknowledge her expertise in men's reactions to the well-endowed - or the under-endowed for that matter - I have carried out my own research on the general subject (in a sensitive and caring manner that befits Guardian Man) and I can safely say I have never heard any woman, anywhere, at any time express complete satisfaction with the bosom that nature has given her. It is either too big, too small or too far south.

I would be delighted to know if somewhere there is someone completely satisfied with her allocation, be it big or small.
Neil Simpson
Peterborough

Cambs

fields.headline: Let's be Frank
fields.standfirst: Dobbo is losingThe London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: You have to hand it to the Labour official who managed, with a straight face, to look at an opinion poll showing Frank Dobson third in the race to be London mayor and declare: "Basically this is really good news." If this is the good news, we would hate to see the bad.
fields.body:
You have to hand it to the Labour official who managed, with a straight face, to look at an opinion poll showing Frank Dobson third in the race to be London mayor and declare: "Basically this is really good news." If this is the good news, we would hate to see the bad. Mr Dobson was put one point behind the Conservative candidate, Steve Norris, in the London Evening Standard's survey - and only three points in front of the Liberal Democrat, Susan Kramer. To a pollster's eye, that means there is a real chance that Dobbo - now rebranded as Frank - could come fourth in a city that should be a Labour stronghold. That would be a terrible end to the career of a stalwart politician, but an even greater humiliation to the Labour party itself.

Why is Mr Dobson doing so badly? In part, because he has failed to make any idea or vision his own. Ms Kramer has become a trusted voice on transport: people listen to her ideas on the London Underground. Astonishingly, given his party label, Mr Norris has impressed with his feel for the capital's diversity: he has spoken eloquently on race. Frank Dobson is associated with nothing in the voter's mind - except Labour control-freakery. Yesterday's poll suggests a settled will has been reached: London wants to punish Labour's arrogance and Mr Dobson is the chosen scapegoat.

The beneficiary, of course, is Ken Livingstone. His ratings have slipped by 12% since the last survey, 19% since he first declared as a candidate. In a normal election, such a steep plunge would be terminal. But this is no normal election: even after this latest drop, Mr Livingstone is 34 points ahead of his rivals. He looks set to walk into office on May 4.

Even so, both he and Labour should take stock of these findings. The former GLC leader should reflect on why he has lost that chunk of support. He says it is a natural correction after an initial, unsustainable burst of euphoria. But it is surely also a reaction against the recklessness of some of his recent remarks: he caused needless offence with his quip about world finance killing more people than Hitler. If he wants to be mayor for all of London, he needs to raise his game before polling day. As for Labour, it should look closely at the poll numbers predicting it will dominate the Greater London Assembly. For that means that Labour is almost certainly going to have to work with Mayor Livingstone. It should begin to prepare the ground now.

webTitle: Maze veteran helps bring back rule of law to Kosovo

fields.headline: Maze veteran helps bring back rule of law to Kosovo
fields.standfirst:
Britain foots bill for repairs to prison destroyed by Nato air raids
Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Britain foots bill for repairs to prison destroyed by Nato air raids
fields.body:
The blast patterns from exploding grenades are still visible on the bakery floor. Cell blocks and gate houses have crumpled under the impact of aerial bombardment. In a basement, a spray of dried blood stains the wall.

Istok prison, Kosovo's largest detention centre, was attacked repeatedly by Nato war planes during last year's conflict. More than 20 prisoners and guards were reported to have died during the air raids and it now appears that scores more may have perished when Serb forces opened fire on inmates gathering for a roll-call.

But in two months the jail is scheduled to reopen under the control of a new prison governor, from Northern Ireland. Britain's Department for International Development (DfID) is paying £700,000 to repair the severely damaged complex as part of its £110m expenditure on Kosovo.

There is a desperate shortage of prisons in Kosovo to hold both war crimes suspects awaiting trial, and the few people already sentenced. Anyone arrested for a serious crime such as arson is released, because there are only 280 places in smaller jails in Pristina, Prizren, Mitrovice and in the American Camp Bondsteel.

Istok will provide space for 500 inmates, who will mainly live four to a cell. The new governor, Billy Irvine, is a veteran of Northern Ireland's troubles, having served in the Maze and Maghaberry jails.

Istok will contain only ethnic Albanian men. Serb prisoners are already separated for their own safety and sent to the jail in Mitrovice. Women and young offenders go to a special unit in Prizren.

The DfID was initially sceptical about using resources to lock up people, but then officials became convinced that a functioning criminal justice system was essential for Kosovo to return to normality. Istok may not be the first foreign prison to receive British government aid, but it is the largest of such penal projects.

"The aim is to rebuild the prison as fast as possible," said Dr Mukesh Kapila, the head of the DfID's conflict and humanitarian affairs department, while on a visit to Istok.

The DfID's cash has been spent on a broad range of projects in Kosovo. New runway landing systems have been installed at Pristina airport, a hospital has been re-equipped, damaged electricity sub-stations are undergoing restoration and UK organisations are disposing of mines and unexploded bombs. This year the department expects to pay out at least another £30m towards the reconstruction of Kosovo.

Istok prison, which stands in the Drenica valley, appears on arrival to be almost in ruins.

Built in the mid-1980s, it contained more than 1,200 inmates by May last year. Most of them were ethnic Albanians who were arrested by Serb forces on suspicion of being members of the Kosovo Liberation Army.

"Repairing this is all part of getting law and order back to normal," said Mr Irvine. "It will be Kosovo's most secure unit and should create jobs for 380 prison officers.

"The staff, mostly local Albanians, will have to be re-trained. There are 4,000 outstanding criminal cases in Kosovo, so we will have lots of sentenced prisoners soon."

As reconstruction progressed, evidence emerged of killings of ethnic Albanian detainees by Serb forces. "A number of former inmates have shown up in recent weeks, having just been released from Serb jails. They all say they were here during a massacre before the bombing," said Mark Pauline a Canadian official.

"The bodies of 97 prisoners were found in a mass grave outside the prison. The international war crimes tribunal is investigating the murders of 173 people here.

"We were told they [the Serb guards] took all the prisoners out on to the sports field for a roll-call. Then they opened fire. The wall behind is pitted with bullet holes. Afterwards they went into the cell blocks, throwing in grenades and firing into air ducts where people were hiding."

Because of the bomb damage, some of which was inflicted by the RAF, not all buildings can be used. Prison visits will take place in the old gymnasium, and a hospital is being improvised.

The need to retrain prison staff is another problem. After 1989, Istok's ethnic Albanian guards were progressively dismissed - the last Albanian on the staff went in 1994 - and replaced by ethnic Serbs.

Since the defeat of the Yugoslav army last year, most Serbs have fled to Serbia, leaving mainly ethnic Albanians to be recruited. Their experience may be five to 10 years out of date but Mr Irvine and senior Canadian prisoner officers working alongside him hope eventually to return the institution to Kosovans.

webTitle: Gay couple fights to be 'a family'

fields.headline: Gay couple fights to be 'a family'
fields.trailText: A homosexual couple yesterday launched a high court battle for the right to live in Britain as "a family".
fields.body:
A homosexual couple yesterday launched a high court battle for the right to live in Britain as "a family".

They challenged a Home Office refusal to allow "L", a Brazilian citizen who cannot be named for legal reasons, to enter Britain as an unmarried partner of "M", a British and Irish citizen.

Stephanie Harrison, for the couple, told Mr Justice Turner, sitting in London, that to deny L admission and order his expulsion negated M's own rights of residence in Britain.

She challenged the way the immigration authorities operated a Home Office discretionary policy which places a minimum time limit of four years for couples to live together "in a relationship akin to marriage" before they are treated as a family unit.

She described how L was originally granted leave to enter Britain for six months as a visitor in June 1994, and then allowed to remain as a student until July 1998. In June 1995 he met M, now 33, and five months later the couple started living together. But both men went abroad, and when L, now 28, returned in November 1998 he was refused leave to enter as a visitor.

Ms Harrison accused the Home Office of violating the couple's right "to respect for private and family life" guaranteed under the European convention on human rights.

The case continues.

fields.headline: Park status for South Downs
fields.trailText: Ramblers were yesterday celebrating a decision by the countryside agency to create a national park for the South Downs.
fields.body:
Ramblers were yesterday celebrating a decision by the countryside agency to create a national park for the South Downs.

The status is the highest level of rural protection available and will mean the area, stretching from Winchester, Hampshire, to Eastbourne, East Sussex, will receive more funding from the government and better management.

In 1947 a government committee recommended 12 sites for national park designation. Of these only the South Downs has still not received national park status.

The government announced its intention to create a national park in the South Downs in September and an opinion poll in December found that four out of five people supported the decision.

fields.headline: Sex bias ruling against LSE
fields.standfirst:
Lecturer who miscarried 'robbed' of promotion
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A university run by an academic who has influenced Tony Blair's approach to government was found guilty of sex discrimination yesterday for refusing to give a permanent job to an experienced business history lecturer shortly after she suffered a miscarriage.
fields.body:
A university run by an academic who has influenced Tony Blair's approach to government was found guilty of sex discrimination yesterday for refusing to give a permanent job to an experienced business history lecturer shortly after she suffered a miscarriage.

A tribunal ruled that the London School of Economics discriminated against Helen Mercer, 43, when it gave the promotion to a less qualified and younger male candidate.

It found the university's appointments procedure also discriminated against women indirectly by setting research output targets that might be incompatible with maternity leave.

The LSE's director is Tony Giddens, architect of the Third Way philosophy that has underpinned the prime minister's approach to government. A spokesperson said it was seeking legal advice on whether to appeal.

The case was brought by the equal opportunities commission on behalf of Dr Mercer. She joined the LSE in 1995 on a three year contract, after teaching at Leeds University and writing an acclaimed book on business history.

In 1997 an LSE professor reviewing her work said: "Helen's performance has exceeded our best expectations and, in my view, she has been a substantial asset to the department. I wish therefore to make a strong, positive recommendation that Helen Mercer should pass her departmental review."

Four months later, after she had a miscarriage, she was rejected for a permanent post and her suitability questioned. "The decision effectively ended my academic career. I felt robbed," she said.

Dr Mercer, who has a daughter aged seven, told the tribunal that concerns over whether she would break her career in future to have children were at the root of discrimination against her.

When she asked why she had not been given the job, she was told the other candidate would be better able to contribute to the next external assessment of LSE research, on which funding depended. This was astonishing, as her book had helped her department to obtain a top rating in the previous assessment, she said.

The assessment system did not take into account the breaks women needed if they wanted to have a family. "Universities wanting high ratings see women, especially those of a child bearing age, as a risk, despite their teaching ability and experience."

The commission said the decision sent a message to universities that women should be treated equally. Julie Mellor, the chairwoman, said women made up 51% of higher education staff but held only one in four senior posts.

David Triesman, general secretary of the Association of University Teachers, said the decision would "open the floodgates" to further cases. "It will make all vice-chancellors sit up and take notice. They know they might next week be sitting in the hot seat with a legal ruling against them."

An LSE spokesperson said: "We are surprised by the decision, and would never knowingly discriminate on grounds of sex. This is a principle embedded in our constitution that we strive hard to uphold. We received the decision at lunchtime on Tuesday. We are... considering what steps to take."

fields.headline: Ancient mirror unearthed
fields.trailText: One of the oldest bronze mirrors in the world has been found by a farmer moving a stone to free his tractor wheel. Under the stone, at Bryher in the Scillies, was a grave about 2,000 years old in which a sword was also found. The sword dates from 250-125BC. If the mirror was buried at the same time it would be the oldest of its kind ever found.

Under the stone, at Bryher in the Scillies, was a grave about 2,000 years old in which a sword was also found. The sword dates from 250-125BC. If the mirror was buried at the same time it would be the oldest of its kind ever found.

In most iron age interments mirrors were associated with female burials and swords with male ones. However, the Bryher grave contained only one skeleton.

fields.headline: Pop star's son found hanged
fields.trailText: The bass player of the 80s pop band Culture Club told an inquest yesterday that he felt a lapse in checks by staff on a prison healthcare wing had given his son the opportunity to hang himself.
fields.body:
The bass player of the 80s pop band Culture Club told an inquest yesterday that he felt a lapse in checks by staff on a prison healthcare wing had given his son the opportunity to hang himself.

Mikey Craig's son Keita, 22, who had mental health problems, died at Wandsworth prison, south-west London, on February 1, Westminster coroner's court heard. He was on remand in connection with a robbery.

Mr Craig said: "I met the medical officer. He was obviously very surprised by events. He mentioned Keita seemed a very normal guy, which was surprising really, given the information he must have had.

"I felt there was a lapse in time on the regular checks that were supposed to be made on Keita, and it was during one of those lapses that this incident occurred."

The case continues.

webTitle: East is best for Britart pack

fields.headline: East is best for Britart pack
fields.standfirst: White Cube: a project room for contemporary art
fields.trailText: They have not seen anything like it in Hoxton since the blitz. Madonna was there, so was Mick Jagger, and Elton John promised he would come along later. There were even rumours of a few artists when "Europe's hottest new private gallery" opened last night in London's east end.
fields.body:
They have not seen anything like it in Hoxton since the blitz. Madonna was there, so was Mick Jagger, and Elton John promised he would come along later. There were even rumours of a few artists when "Europe's hottest new private gallery" opened last night in London's east end.

White Cube 2 was launched in the glare of a kind of celebrity wattage more akin to a Hollywood film premiere. The movers and shakers of the art world, politicians, pop stars and actors trooped out to the unfamiliar territory of E2 for the party. And yes, there were no jellied eel canapes.

Owned by Jay Jopling, the old Etonian who acts for the biggest names in the Britart movement, the warehouse gallery's first show, Out There, reads like a who's who of 1990s art, with works by Damien Hirst, Gary Hume, Tracey Emin, Gavin Turk and Sam Taylor-Wood, whose work so impressed Jopling that he married her.

The most striking of the new pieces on show are Gavin Turk's Dead Che, a full-sized model of the dead freedom fighter, and Hirst's Rehab is for Quitters, a plastic skeleton that has echoes of Hymn, the 20ft, 10 tonne model of a man's torso with his organs showing which sold for £1m last month. There is also a new 21 panel painting, Tree Naked, by Gilbert and George, who live nearby and whom Jopling poached recently from the Lisson gallery. In another coup, Lucian Freud is expected to show one of his new paintings, Naked Portrait, next month at either White Cube 2 or the original White Cube gallery in the West End.

There has been a rash of gallery openings in east London in the run-up to the launch of the vast Tate Modern museum next month, when thousands of curators and collectors will arrive from all over the world. The exhibition at White Cube 2 in Hoxton Square opens to the public tomorrow.

webTitle: Academics stressed out by rising tide of bureaucracy

fields.headline: Academics stressed out by rising tide of bureaucracy
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: More than half Britain's academics complain of poor psychological health, often brought on by extra bureaucracy and changes in working conditions, according to a study published today.
fields.body:
More than half Britain's academics complain of poor psychological health, often brought on by extra bureaucracy and changes in working conditions, according to a study published today.

A national survey of 782 academics at British universities found that 53% reported poor psychological health, including stress, sleeplessness and depression, while 44% of university lecturers had seriously considered leaving higher education and 49% had considered early retirement over the past few years.

The survey, presented at the British Psychological Society conference, also found that 25% of academics had suffered a stress-related illness in the past year.

Gail Kinman, a psychologist at Luton University, and Fiona Jones, a principal lecturer in psychology at Hertfordshire University, compiled the study on behalf of the Association of University Teachers.

They found that three-quarters of academics who responded to their survey believed that their universities and working conditions had undergone too many changes in recent years. More than half thought the changes had been negative overall. Eighty per cent of the academics said they found their jobs more demanding, while 72% found they were required to work substantially longer hours.

The academics said the two main factors which were to blame for their poor psychological health were increased conflict between the demands of work and home and increasing bureaucracy in the profession.

Ms Kinman said: "I was very surprised by the results, which were the same across all age groups and between men and women."

David Triesman, AUT general secretary, said: "Over the last 20 years, for each higher education teacher the number of students has doubled while funding has been cut. This amazing level of increased productivity has come from staff effort and the resulting stress, coupled with poor pay, is grinding the profession down. How much more can they take?"

 Read the executive summary of the report at Education Unlimited.

Ms Kinman said: "I was very surprised by the results, which were the same across all age groups and between men and women." David Triesman, AUT general secretary, said: "Over the last 20 years, for each higher education teacher the number of students has doubled while funding has been cut. fields.headline: Female gatherers are born gardeners
fields.standfirst: Women's green fingers and evolution
fields.trailText: Women may be better than men as gardeners because of their evolutionary role as gatherers while their menfolk went hunting.
fields.body:
Women may be better than men as gardeners because of their evolutionary role as gatherers while their menfolk went hunting.

A study of the difference in spatial skills between the sexes found women to be quicker at picking out plants hidden among a selection in two out of three tests.

The 57 men and women who took part were not gardeners but were randomly selected and had little knowledge of plants.

Mick Neave, of Northumbria University, told the conference that in human evolution men typically hunted while women searched for plant food.

"This may have created a modern day sex difference, with men being better at finding their way around and females being better at locating certain objects.

"Other studies have reported a female advantage at finding objects, but ours is the first to use real plants in naturalistic settings," he said.

webTitle: Eggs stolen from rare sea eagle nest

fields.headline: Eggs stolen from rare sea eagle nest
fields.trailText: Conservationists fear two rare sea eagle eggs have been taken from a nest in Scotland despite a surveillance operation by police and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds.
fields.body:
Conservationists fear two rare sea eagle eggs have been taken from a nest in Scotland despite a surveillance operation by police and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds.

The eggs, which were a week from hatching, were taken at the beginning of the week on the island of Mull. Police believe they are destined for a private collection.

The sea eagle is the UK's rarest bird. There are only 20 breeding pairs in the country, all in Scotland. Their nesting sites have been included in a anti-theft operation run by the police and the RSPB, known as Operation Easter.

"The RSPB knows about this site and has been keeping an eye on it. Despite that the nest has been raided and the indications are that it was by people who knew exactly what they were doing," said Ewan Mathieson of the RSPB.

"The horrible thing is that the eggs were due to hatch in seven to 10 days, the birds will be well formed within them."

It was not clear whether there were two eggs or one in the nest at the time of the theft. Mr Mathieson said the female sea eagle would be traumatised by the loss.

PC Ronnie Sewell, a wildlife liaison officer with Strathclyde police, said the theft was despicable. "We will make every effort to track down those responsible for this theft and indeed anyone who travels to Mull with the intention of disturbing the sea eagle nesting sites."

Last month two men from Lancashire were arrested on Mull after they were seen acting suspiciously near a sea eagle nest. A report has been sent to the procurator fiscal.

webTitle: A man's charm is in his armpit

fields.headline: A man's charm is in his armpit
fields.standfirst: British Psychological Society: Male hunters' sweat may lure a mate
fields.trailText: Beauty is not, after all, in the eye of the beholder. It is in the nose - or more precisely, in the other person's sweaty armpits.
fields.body:
Beauty is not, after all, in the eye of the beholder. It is in the nose - or more precisely, in the other person's sweaty armpits.

Male pheromones secreted in underarm sweat can make men more sexually attractive to women, according to research.

The study, to be presented to the British Psychological Society's annual conference in Winchester today, found that women who are secretly exposed to male pheromones tended to rate men as being more attractive than they were rated by women who were not exposed to the pheromones.

The team, led by biological psychologist Nick Neave from the University of Northumbria, studied the effects of male sweat hormones on 32 female students. The women were tested both during menstruation and at mid-cycle, and 16 were taking the contraceptive pill.

The female students were asked to rate the attractiveness of various men, using written descriptions, drawn body shapes and photographs, while sitting in laboratory cubicles.

Half of the women were secretly exposed to the male pheromones, which were on cotton wool pads, which had been placed under the arms of healthy young men overnight.

The women who had been exposed to the pheromones found the men more attractive than their counterparts. But the biggest and clearest effect was seen when the women were shown photographs of men.

Those exposed to the pheromones gave an almost two-fold increase in attractiveness rating. This affect was particularly strong in women who did not take the pill but who were at mid-point in their menstrual cycle.

But perhaps the most surprising result found by Dr Neave and his colleagues was that the men who were of average or below average attractiveness benefited most from the use of the pheromones. Dr Neave said: "We used four pictures of men, three of which were of above average attractiveness and one who was below average.

"When women were exposed to the pheromones the above average men were rated slightly higher but the below average man suddenly shot up in the ratings."

Although the research confirmed that male pheromones can significantly affect women's sexual attraction to men, men with average looks may not necessarily benefit from exposing women to their sweaty armpits.

Dr Neave said: "My advice to less attractive males is that if a man sweats and comes into contact with girls who are mid-cycle and not taking the pill, he may see a small positive effect.

"But if he stops washing and using deodorants he will probably start smelling and lose far more friends than he would gain."

fields.headline: The best Catherine Keener scene
fields.standfirst: Being John Malkovich
fields.trailText: Being John Malkovich
fields.body:
Lotte (Cameron Diaz) has entered John Malkovich's brain through the portal found by her husband Craig (John Cusack). Craig's colleague Maxine (Catherine Keener) knows Lotte is "in" Malkovich, and gets the actor's phone number from a friend.

Once inside Malkovich, Lotte sees he is sitting in an armchair in his Manhattan apartment and hears him reciting lines into a dictaphone.

"But what I've been through, I am hungry as the winter. I am sick, anxious, poor as a beggar..."

As he continues, Lotte's voice is heard.

"So strong," she comments.

"...my soul," Malkovich continues, "has been full of mysterious anticipation..."

Lotte repeats the line. The phone rings.

"Yeah?"

"Mr John Malkovich?"

It's Maxine.

"Yes, who's calling?"

"Oh my goodness! You don't know me but I know you. I'm a great admirer of yours."

"How did you get this number?"

"Ah, well, it's just that I dream about you and even speaking to you now has got me excited."

"Listen," Malkovich mutters, "I really don't find this amusing. Don't call here any more, OK?"

"Wow! My nipples are at attention General Malkovich, Sir."

Lotte, who is experiencing everything, laughs.

"So, listen," Maxine continues, "why don't we have dinner tonight. Bernardos, 8 o'clock? I really want to see you, I just loved you in that jewel thief movie..."

Malkovich hangs up.

See also: Your Friends And Neighbors, Out Of Sight, Living In Oblivion, The Real Blonde

Don't see also: Survival Quest

Pointless trivia: Catherine Keener is married to Dermot Mulroney, with whom she starred in Living In Oblivion

webTitle: Scottish fees ruling sparks student rush

fields.headline: Scottish fees ruling sparks student rush
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Universities are reporting a sharp rise in applications from Scottish students since a decision by the Scottish executive in December to exempt them from up-front tuition fees.
fields.body:
Universities are reporting a sharp rise in applications from Scottish students since a decision by the Scottish executive in December to exempt them from up-front tuition fees.

Figures released yesterday by the universities and colleges admissions service (Ucas) showed that applications between December 16 and March 24 were 19% higher than over the same period a year before.

Tony Higgins, the Ucas chief executive, drew a link between increased demand for places among Scottish students and the decision to replace up-front fees with payments after graduation. Students from the rest of the UK will continue to pay the fees, currently £1,025.

"In December Scottish applicants were 2.5% down on the previous year. Scotland was showing the biggest fall in applicants among UK countries, but now it is showing the biggest rise," he said.

"We had more applications than usual from Scotland between December and March, which seems to indicate that many people were delaying their application until they knew either the recommendations of the Cubie inquiry or the Scottish executive's decisions on tuition fees."

That interpretation was challenged by the Department for Education and Employment.

A source said the number of Scots applying to start at university in September was almost exactly the same as last year. "Maybe a few hundred waited to see the results of Cubie, but that's hardly a sea change. It would not encourage ministers to feel there was any need to change the fee system in England."

But John Swinney, the Scottish National party lifelong learning spokesman, said: "These figures confirm Cubie's finding that the system of student finance imposed on Scotland by Labour after the 1997 election was discredited."

The Ucas figures showed 3,857 applications since December 16, compared with 3,236 over the same period last year. Total Scottish applications were 26,802, compared with 26,780 at this time last year.

 University vice-chancellors will today reopen the debate on top-up tuition fees by launching a broad inquiry into higher education funding, writes Rebecca Smithers .

The Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals, which represents the heads of all universities, is expected to announce that the academic Sir William Taylor will lead the review, which will be carried out by leading vice-chancellors and businesspeople.

Sir William, who is president of the Society for Research in Higher Education, was sent in to sort out crises at Thames Valley and Huddersfield universities. The group will oversee research which will inform the committee's future campaigns on university funding. An initial report is expected to be delivered in September.

The move marks a recognition by the broader university sector of the need for a rethink on funding. The Russell group of 20 universities, including Oxford and Cambridge, is already fighting for the right to charge higher fees in order to maintain standards in the face of international competition for the best students and researchers.

The education secretary, David Blunkett, sparked controversy earlier this year when he appeared to signal a policy u-turn by refusing to rule out the possibility that top-up fees might be introduced.

English universities are currently prevented from charging fees higher than the standard £1,025 a year payable by full-time undergraduates.

webTitle: Shergar mystery revived as skull is found

fields.headline: Shergar mystery revived as skull is found
fields.trailText: A retired milkman from south-west Ireland believes he may have solved the greatest mystery in the history of horse racing after spending Grand National day cleaning up a beauty spot.
fields.body:
A retired milkman from south-west Ireland believes he may have solved the greatest mystery in the history of horse racing after spending Grand National day cleaning up a beauty spot.

Tom Foley, an independent member of Kerry county council, found the skull of a racehorse in a deserted gully near Tralee last Saturday. He was astonished to find it was pierced by two bullet holes.

Police have now passed the skull to the Garda team at Naas, in Co Kildare, which is responsible for the inquiry into the disappearance of Shergar in 1983. They are expected to carry out DNA tests.

The IRA, in one of its most audacious plans, abducted the 1981 Derby winner from the Ballymany stud, in Co Kildare. They demanded a £5m ransom from the syndicate owning the horse, which included the Aga Khan. He refused to entertain the idea of bowing to the kidnappers' demands.

The abduction sparked a massive hunt, but, according to a former IRA terrorist, Sean O'Callaghan, Shergar was killed within days. He said the kidnappers had failed to make proper provision to look after the horse, which damaged a leg in a horsebox and proved impossible to control.

The IRA continued to pretend the horse was still alive. But as hopes faded, the late Detective Chief Superintendent James Murphy, who was leading the inquiry, uttered the immortal line: "If we find the body, we will treat it like any other murder investigation."

Mr Foley, who used to enjoy betting on Shergar, said yesterday: "I found the skull in a sack hidden behind a rock in a dip. I doubt anyone has been there for years. The lad with me is a farmer's son, and he knew immediately that the skull came from a racehorse.

"A vet has confirmed that the holes in the skull are pistol-shots. The question you have to ask is: why else would anyone use a pistol to shoot a racehorse? They are hardly being bumped off in such a fashion all over Ireland, are they?"

Des Leadon, the head of clinical pathology at the Irish Equine Centre, who has investigated a number of horse corpses that were believed to have been Shergar, said DNA testing would have to be used to determine if the skull belonged to the missing horse.

"We are keen to find Shergar. If we can show it is possible to identity him after all this time it may deter other people from kidnapping horses," he said.

Before the kidnap, Shergar was worth £10m. Several owners are understood to have failed to win insurance payouts because, with no body ever found, there was no proof that the stallion was dead.

webTitle: BBC is best judge of good TV, Smith is told

fields.headline: BBC is best judge of good TV, Smith is told
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke, the BBC's director general, yesterday defended the corporation's political independence, warning ministers not to interfere in programming decisions.
fields.body:
Greg Dyke, the BBC's director general, yesterday defended the corporation's political independence, warning ministers not to interfere in programming decisions.

Mr Dyke, whose association with the Labour party was criticised when he was considered to head the BBC last year, fired a strongly worded shot across the bows of Chris Smith, the culture secretary, who had said that the corporation needed more high profile successes.

Mr Dyke told the Voice of the Listener and Viewer's annual conference in London: "Well Chris, as we all know, it's not a minister's job to tell us what programmes we should and shouldn't be commissioning and showing.

"First, because politicians watch very little television, so who are they to judge? And second, because the BBC's independence has been jealously guarded over many years and will be equally guarded over my time as director general."

Last week, Mr Smith said that BBC1 needed to produce more "humdingers" like Walking with Dinosaurs and the recent costume drama Wives and Daughters.

Mr Dyke insisted yesterday that the corporation would continue to produce programmes that "only the BBC" could make. He revealed that among the next batch of quality programmes would be adaptations of Flora Thompson's Lark Rise to Candleford and Anthony Trollope's The Way We Live Now, as well as Kingsley Amis's Take a Girl Like You.

On radio, there would be a full day of programming to mark Shakespeare's birthday, including a new production of As You Like It starring Helena Bonham Carter, as well as classic serials including Moby-Dick and a new version of Alan Bennett's Forty Years On.

Mr Dyke added that, with the structural changes to the corporation initiated last week, he believed it would soon be making more of its programmes itself. Though the corporation was obliged to take 25% of its broadcasting from independent producers, takeovers and mergers had meant that the number of such companies was fast diminishing, and "the BBC will struggle next year to make the 25%".

At the conference, Mr Dyke said that, while the BBC was in an increasingly competitive market, with hundreds of new channels for viewers to choose from, it could retain its strong position only by remaining distinctive; and though it was important for the corporation to increase its commercial activities, they must not interfere with its basic role as a public service broadcaster.

"The question is, should the BBC be involved in the commercial world at all?" he said. "I personally think that it would be a grave mistake if we ignored the commercial world and ignored the potential for generating more money."

He said the dividing line between the BBC's principal function and its commercial side needed to be very clear. "The BBC has a real dilemma in that, but if we abandon public service, then what are we?"

He highlighted concerns about the government's plans to switch off the analogue signal some time between 2006 and 2010. Those who had not converted to digital by then would have to be provided with the technology to do so, he said. In his reorganisation of the BBC's management structure, Mr Dyke said he wanted to develop "one BBC" - an inclusive organisation that represented all licence fee payers adequately.

Yesterday, however, the Royal National Institute for Deaf People said the BBC was not doing enough to give adequate subtitling. On BBC1 and BBC2, 57% of programmes are subtitled, compared with 61% on Channel 4 and 64% on ITV.

webTitle: Resignation of orchestra chief stuns colleagues

fields.headline: Resignation of orchestra chief stuns colleagues
fields.trailText: Many in the classical music world were puzzled yesterday by the resignation of the chief executive of the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra, who has quit just as the orchestra is on the verge of emerging from a crippling debt crisis.
fields.body:
Many in the classical music world were puzzled yesterday by the resignation of the chief executive of the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra, who has quit just as the orchestra is on the verge of emerging from a crippling debt crisis.

Antony Lewis-Crosby, who has led the orchestra through six of its most difficult years, when only a sympathetic bank prevented it from going under with debts of £2.5m, is to leave without another job to go to.

The RLPO, one of the country's oldest orchestras and one whose previous chief conductors include the composer Max Bruch, is close to gaining stabilisation funding from the Arts Council of England which would wipe out its deficit.

One source suggested last night that the board of the parent Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Society decided Mr Lewis-Crosby was not the right man to lead the orchestra through the stabilisation process. But an Arts Council spokeswoman declined to comment, referring only to a statement which spoke of his "outstanding leadership" in Liverpool over many years and paid tribute to his "untiring contribution" to the RLPO.

"He has negotiated a position with the Arts Council and other partners that promises a very positive future for the orchestra," the statement said.

In a statement, Mr Lewis-Crosby said: "My circumstances are such that I can now make this move and, having achieved much in the last six years, I am looking forward to obtaining a new appointment...
