fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Man charged over son's death
fields.body:
Man charged over son's death

A 24-year-old man has been charged with the murder of his five-month-old son after an incident at a Newcastle Metro station, Northumbria police said last night. The baby was found with multiple injuries in a pram on Sunday, and died later in hospital.

Lawrences to hold service

The parents of the murdered black teenager Stephen Lawrence are to hold a public memorial service to celebrate their son's life. Neville and Doreen Lawrence will hold the service at the Trinity Methodist church in Plumstead, south-east London, on Sunday, seven years after Stephen, 18, was stabbed to death.

Noye jury sent to hotel

The Old Bailey jury trying motorway killer Kenneth Noye retired to a hotel yesterday to consider its verdict. Noye, 52, from Sevenoaks, Kent, denies murdering Stephen Cameron in an M25 road rage incident in May 1996.

George Best leaves hospital

George Best was allowed home yesterday after spending weeks battling a liver condition in a private hospital in Kensington, west London. The former Manchester United soccer star, 53, was admitted on March 8 with severe stomach pains.

Football boss wins damages

The vice-chairman of Derby County FC, Peter Gadsby yesterday accepted £150,000 damages and £200,000 legal costs under an agreement reached in his libel action against the former club director Stuart Webb. A high court jury was told by Mr Gadsby's counsel, George Carman QC, that Mr Webb had agreed to pay the money "to resolve this matter". The action related to a poison pen letter circulated to businessmen and people in public life.

£828,000 for chess piece

A 3in high ivory chess piece thought to be a thousand years old has fetched £828,750 at Christie's, three months after the early Islamic piece was bought by a dealer at a Midlands auction for less than £1,000.

fields.headline: Thousands of 'neglected' frozen embryos destroyed
fields.trailText: Thousands of embryos created and stored during fertility treatment are being destroyed because the couples involved will not respond to letters from clinics, asking what they want done with them.
fields.body:
Thousands of embryos created and stored during fertility treatment are being destroyed because the couples involved will not respond to letters from clinics, asking what they want done with them.

Brian Lieberman and colleagues from the University of Manchester and Manchester Fertility Services report in this week's Lancet medical journal on the fate of 1,344 embryos in two of Britain's fertility clinics. Two thirds of the embryos - 904 in total - have had to be destroyed once five years has elapsed - either because that was what the couple involved requested (29%) or in half the cases because the couple did not respond to the clinics' attempts to contact them.

There were 118 licenced fertility clinics by the end of last August. If the destruction rate is similar in all or most of them, the numbers that have already had to perish must run into tens of thousands.

The Manchester embryos were created between 1988 and 1994 at St Mary's hospital where the NHS funds treatment and the other at the private Manchester Fertility Services clinic.

During fertility treatment, more embryos are invariably created than are permitted to be put back. Under the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act, up to three embryos can be replaced. The rest can be donated to other couples or for research into fertility problems or they can be cryopreserved - frozen in liquid nitrogen. If the treatment fails, these embryos can be used for future attempts. Frozen embryos can be stored for five years, which can be extended to 10 years if the couple agrees.

After five years, the authors write, 1,344 embryos from 359 couples remained in storage. By the end of 1998, nearly half (177 of 359) of these couples had not responded to the clinics' efforts, including two recorded delivery letters, to contact them. Of the 182 couples who did respond, only 70 asked for the storage time to be extended - the proportion was much higher at the NHS clinic than at the private one.

Fifty-nine couples agreed to donate their embryos to other couples or to research, but 53 instructed doctors to destroy them. In total, 67% had to be destroyed.

"What are the reasons for this huge waste of long term cryopreserved embryos?" the authors ask. They speculate that cost could be a factor, because significantly more of the couples who did not answer letters were treated in the private clinic. Those who had succeeded in having a baby were more likely to want to keep their embryos for a further attempt than those who had failed.

fields.headline: Totally modern
fields.standfirst:
The Labour government is infatuated with "modernising" everything. It becomes meaningless

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The Labour government is infatuated with "modernising" everything. It becomes meaningless.
fields.body:
Writing nearly 50 years ago to his friend and sparring partner Cyril Connolly about Connolly's little magazine Horizon, Evelyn Waugh said backhandedly: "'Modern' has always had a pejorative sense in English. Horizon was the last (and first considerable) attempt to give it attraction."

He couldn't have guessed that there would one day be a British government in whose elaborate rhetoric "modern", "modernisation" and "moderniser" play central roles, and are anything but pejorative. But then even the most loyal supporter of the Blair project must sometimes wonder whether "modern" actually means anything - or how much attraction it really has.

Most of New Labour's rhetoric was dreamed up by people tone deaf to 20th-century history. You really don't prattle about a "people's princess" or "people's opera" if you remember who first gave us the people's car (Volkswagen), or what happened in people's courts.

"Modernising" is linked to the name New Labour itself, and the implication that what is newer or more modern must be better. This is demonstrably false. The Yiddish proverb which says succinctly "What comes after is worse" may be a little sweeping. But absolutely nobody, from whatever political perspective, believes that what comes after is always ipso facto better.

One of the simplest truths about history is that progress is not linear. Some things get better, some things get worse, usually both at the same time. In 1922, Italy had a newer government than in 1921, and in 1933 Germany had a newer government than in 1932. Were they better?

At any rate, they were, like New Labour, very conscious of their newness: the Third Reich was otherwise the Neue Ordnung, the New Order. Along with "new", the government talks about a Young Country. A video by that name was inflicted on the Commonwealth leaders meeting here. Leave aside the fact that we are a notably old country, both in terms of history and of demographic profile. Alastair Campbell must have temporarily forgotten another movement whose anthem was called Youth, or Giovinezza, the hymn of Mussolini's fascists.

But the crucial word for New Labour is modern. Often enough this is simply empty, an alternative for thought or action: modernity is its own justification. But even if the word hasn't necessarily always had a pejorative sense, its implications are dubious, or ominous, or worse.

Modernising might be as good a word as any for the astonishing coup or internal entryism which saw the Labour party taken over nearly six years ago by a leader who actively disliked almost everything about the party and its traditions. Startling as this was, it could be defended. A party which had lost four general elections in a row was scarcely a case of "if it ain't broke, don't fix it". Labour was broke and needed fixing, and if the modernisers did nothing else, they made the party electable.

The trouble came when the misty concept of modernising became an end in itself. When Blair denounces the forces of conservatism, he forgets that we are all, left and right, conservative in some ways. Radicalism can mean conserving what needs to be guarded, like our attenuated traditions of individual freedom. The licensing laws need modernising. Trial by jury does not.

And another glance back at the past century shows that when modernity isn't merely fatuous or empty, it can be something much nastier. Early in the 20th century, modernity was often connected with the broader reaction against the rational, which was such a striking feature of political and cultural life. This produced ultra-nationalism, bolshevism and fascism, not to say the Great War itself, as well as freakish artistic movements. The Italian futurists continually invoked modernity, and the politics of futurism were a very long way from liberalism. There was a clear link between futurism and fascism,

After Mussolini came Hitler, and a Third Reich which has been acutely described by the American historian John Lukacs: "It was democratic; and it was modern... in almost every sense of the word anti-traditionalist."

He cites the English travel writer Robert Byron, who visited Germany in 1938. Watching the Nuremberg rally, Byron was struck precisely by its modernity: "The whole ceremonial is of a remarkable kind... and it is new in that it incorporates, indeed is based on, the last resources of the age."

Our rulers are a touchy lot, and so maybe one should say the obvious, that in many ways the present government is doing a good job. I don't actually think that the Blair junta is fascistic, I just wish it would stop talking like it. They could take a harder look at a rhetorical vocabulary in which every single item was anticipated by the age of totalitarianism.

In 1924, the rightist German writer Oswald Spengler wrote a book foreseeing and commending a new order of national zeal and discipline, which would be born less than 10 years later. Prophetically enough, he called this The Third Reich, but only at the last moment. Almost until the book went to press, it was to be... The Third Way.

 comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Blair warns core voters to beware 'extremist' Tories

fields.headline: Blair warns core voters to beware 'extremist' Tories
fields.standfirst:
Angry Hague rejects NHS privatisation claim

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday fired the first shots of a year-long general election campaign in which Downing Street will attempt to mobilise Labour's traditional supporters by spreading scare stories about the dangers of a Tory comeback.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday fired the first shots of a year-long general election campaign in which Downing Street will attempt to mobilise Labour's traditional supporters by spreading scare stories about the dangers of a Tory comeback.

Amid fears that the Conservative threat is being under-estimated, the prime minister issued a blunt warning to his troops that Labour had a "lot to lose" if they failed to counter the extremism of William Hague.

Mr Blair was speaking as he launched Labour's campaign for next month's local election in which the party is expected to lose hundreds of seats won at the height of John Major's unpopularity in 1996.

But the prime minister made clear that his eyes were firmly fixed on the general election which is expected to take place next year. In a short speech to party supporters in Milton Keynes Mr Blair barely mentioned local issues as he spelt out how the Tories would reverse all of Labour's reforms at a national level.

Mr Blair said that the Tories "paid lip service" to the princi ples of the NHS, while laying plans for its privatisation which would force a pensioner couple to pay up to £87 a week for private medical insurance.

He quoted the shadow health secretary Liam Fox who said that people should take out medical insurance for routine services such as hip and knee replacements, hernia and cataract operations. These would cost pensioners thousands of pounds, dubbed by the prime minister "a Tory tax on being old".

"The Tories will force people to go outside the NHS because their irresponsible position on tax and spending gives them no alternative," Mr Blair said. "It is what the rightwing wants and their leadership is too weak to resist rightwing pressure."

Mr Blair highlighted the Tories' stance over asylum seekers, which central office is trying to turn into an election issue, as an example of their extremism. "The Conservatives are trying to exploit the issue of asylum, we are trying to deal with it," he said.

After his speech, Mr Blair unveiled a series of posters which trumpeted the government's achievements, including the minimum wage, the 800,000 jobs created with the help of the New Deal and the 5,580 new nurses. The prime minister said: "A lot done. A lot to do - and a lot to lose with the Tories."

Labour sources said that cabinet ministers would turn their fire on the Tories during the local election campaign because of fears that core voters are mistakenly under-estimating the threat posed by the Conservatives. "We do not want to repeat the mistake of the European campaign when we did not make the Tories the issue," one source said.

The Conservatives reacted furiously to the prime minister's accusation that they would force patients outside the NHS, saying that it was reminiscent of the way in which Labour spread scare stories during the last election about Tory plans to abolish the state pension.

Describing Mr Blair's claims as "totally false", Mr Hague said: "It is Tony Blair and his mismanagement of the health service who is forcing some people to have private operations due to delays and long waiting lists. These wild accusations will not succeed in covering up Mr Blair's abysmal failure."

fields.headline: Guardian site 'essential'
fields.trailText: Guardian Unlimited has been named the leading newspaper website in a magazine survey of the "top 100 essential sites" on the internet.
fields.body:
Guardian Unlimited has been named the leading newspaper website in a magazine survey of the "top 100 essential sites" on the internet. Internet Monthly magazine praised the Guardian's web network for "some of the best online reporting, but also film, sport, a great recruitment site, education and a searchable database".

It placed Guardian Unlimited 10th in the list of "sites you can't do without", with mostly search engines in the top 10. The survey appears in the May issue of the magazine, whose website is www.internetmonthly.co.uk.

webTitle: Mondeo man is forced to own up

fields.headline: Mondeo man is forced to own up
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The once-invincible Conservative party machine yesterday stood on what remains of its dignity after being caught out using a paid Commons researcher to pose as an ordinary voter in a party election broadcast.
fields.body:
The once-invincible Conservative party machine yesterday stood on what remains of its dignity after being caught out using a paid Commons researcher to pose as an ordinary voter in a party election broadcast.

Paul Morgan, who works for the husband and wife team of Nicholas and Ann Winterton, Tory MPs for Macclesfield and Congleton, was portrayed as a "punter" with that most symbolic of cars - the Ford Mondeo - in a broadcast which lambasted Tony Blair for not telling the truth.

Labour researchers at Millbank, who trawl their rivals' publications for flaws like wartime code breakers at Bletchley Park, were quick to cry foul with the help of the Mirror newspaper which tracked Mr Morgan to his day job.

To the paper's reported astonishment "Morgan showed no shame at attempting to dupe viewers" ahead of the May 4 local elections. Nor did party HQ which brazened out the difficulty.

"Paul has suffered as much as other voters," one party official told reporters.

Mr Morgan does not actually own a Mondeo and could not tell the Mirror how much (£43) it costs to fill a tank. But he does borrow one that belongs to a housemate and knows that Gordon Brown and world oil prices have pushed the cost up.

The real significance of the use of volunteers by the Opposition may be the cost of actors.

Both parties sometimes use them and one recent series featured the delectable Debbie, a staunch Tory, chivvying her wishy-washy New Labour husband, Chris about falling for Mr Blair.

It was the first such election broadcast featuring sexual activity - implied, not stated - and may have helped William Hague to his modest victory in last year's Euro elections.

fields.headline: Rank and file snubs Blair
fields.standfirst: One in three local parties boycott Labour conferenceNew Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText:
One in three constituency Labour parties will not send
delegates to this autumn's annual conference, which
Tony Blair plans to use as a springboard for his general
election campaign.
fields.body:
One in three constituency Labour parties will not send delegates to this autumn's annual conference, which Tony Blair plans to use as a springboard for his general election campaign.

More than 200 local parties have failed to nominate representatives for September's week-long showcase in Brighton in an unprecedented protest by Labour's rank and file. The seaside no-show is the clearest evidence yet of a backlash among party activists over the direction of the government and accusations that Mr Blair is riding roughshod over the interests of ordinary members.

A report by senior officials in Labour's Millbank headquarters to the party's conference arrangements committee yesterday disclosed that more than 200 of the 641 constituencies had not picked delegates.

The figure sent shockwaves through the party hierarchy and reflects growing disillusionment among members over Mr Blair's focus on middle Britain rather than traditional Labour voters.

The prime minister has also been accused of "control freakery" over his campaign against Ken Livingstone in London and attempts to influence post-devolution contests in Scotland and Wales.

A Labour insider said last night: "No one seems to be interested in going along to stand and clap speeches they don't really believe in. This revolt has been brewing since the election. The conference has become a US-style political convention instead of making policy.

"Millbank wants an audience, not activists. At least now they will have more seats to sell to corporate sponsors."

But a senior official close to Mr Blair said: "OK, there is a problem and a Livingstone problem across the country - though people have forgotten, after 18 years of the Tories, what happens in government.

"But if you think we are in difficulty look at the Tories. We can deal with something like this. They can't."

The Labour hierarchy is expected to go into overdrive over the next few months to persuade constituencies to put in late nominations. A spokesman said: "The Labour party is relaxed about preparations for this year's conference and we expect it to be as highly attended as it always is."

The Brighton conference will be used by Mr Blair to highlight Labour's achievements and outline its manifesto for an election in spring or early summer.

The conference has been progressively stripped of its policy-making role and activists claim it is increasingly stage-managed to allow ministers to look good on TV.

Their disillusionment was also underlined by a fall in the numbers standing for the party's policy forum, which the hierarchy sees as the best way of mapping out new programmes. Delegates will be elected unopposed in Labour's north-east and north-west of England heartlands, as well as for the youth sections in Scotland, and the east and west midlands. In Wales, where Mr Blair recanted his opposition to Rhodri Morgan's selection as Labour leader after his favoured candidate, Alun Michael, proved a disaster, no name was put forward for the forum's youth section.

The lack of enthusiasm by those who traditionally send out election addresses and knock on doors to get the Labour vote out will be very worrying for Mr Blair. Party membership is down to 387,776 from a general election high of 405,000, and is still falling as disenchanted stalwarts and converts leave.

The new finance director, Howard Attre, is to quit early. Officials said he was part-time and believes a full-time financial chief is needed, but fundraisers fear a financial squeeze as benefactors pull back from being named under tougher rules over political donations.

Discontent among the rank and file risks being heightened by moves to block Raghib Ahsan, one of the six anti-Millbank Grassroots Alliance candidates, standing for the members' section of the party's national executive committee.

fields.headline: Owz about that, then?
fields.trailText: Louis Met Jimmy | Ray Mears' Extreme Survival
fields.body:
When Louis Met Jimmy (BBC2), he met his match. Jimmy Savile wanted an inspirational, upbeat programme. "Imagine how many millions would cheer up and say, "That Louis Theroux, he's a fabulous geezer. Look at the wisdom he has extracted!'" What the fabulous geezer extracted was a bottle of rum (half-drunk) from Savile's kitchen cupboard and a packet of condoms (unused) from his luggage.

The battle lines were drawn. "What did I tell you about these people?" Jimmy said to his friend, Jim the Pill (a retired chemist). "Don't they keep lifting the toilet lid of life?"

Sir James and his Sancho Panza spent a week in each other's company, moving among Savile's many homes. (If there's one thing that interests me about that man, it's not his love life, it's his money). Leeds, where he was born. Scarborough, where his dead mother's clothes, regularly cleaned, still hang in her wardrobe, Glencoe, where he broke his ankle and cheered up no end, leaning on the hospital to allow the TV crew in ("Bear in mind I've given you a lot of machines") and mobilizing the press for maximum cheery coverage ("I think the story is Jimmy Falls Off His Own Mountain").

One night, avoiding more advice on how to be a better interviewer, Louis went to bed. Will Yapp, his director, however, sat up with Jimmy, watching hyenas on TV and getting a rare glimpse of the hard man. (The real secret of an interesting interview is to stick around until they think it's all over.)

Savile began to talk about his days as a dance hall manager in Glasgow. All the mannerisms, the bouncy bonhomie, the jokes blown like smoke rings from the big cigar were gone. The very tone of voice was different. "I invented zero tolerance. I wouldn't stand for any nonsense whatsoever. I was always in trouble with the law for being heavy-handed. Always. I tied 'em up and put 'em down in the bloody boilerhouse until I was ready for them. Two o'clock in the fucking morning."

Yapp asked if he threw them out. "Nobody ever got slung out of my place. Oh, I bollocksed them. I was the judge, jury and executioner. If a copper said, 'You was a bit heavy with that kid' or those two guys or whatever, I'd say, 'Your daughter comes in here. She's 16. She's not supposed to come into town but she does. If you don't want me to look after her, tell me and I'll let them dirty slags do what they want to her.'" ("You're right. You didn't give the bastard half enough, Jim. Thank you. Goodbye.") "Never got nicked. Heh, heh, heh! And I've never altered. I've got zero tolerance, me."

Which makes it all the odder that he detests a strong interview.

As he said to Louis, "You are abrasive, you are aggressive and you put people on the defensive. Learn to employ the other side of your personality, which is the pussycat side." The pussycat expressed a sudden need for a milk stout and left. Alone with the camera - and you're never alone with a camera - Jimmy did it his way. He said: "All I hope is maybe some young person somewhere sees all this and says, 'Hey, I thought I had no chance. But, if Jim did it, I can do it.' Makes it well worth while then. Maybe," he added, jerking his head towards the BBC and the bar, "it's a bit too yukky for them."

In spite of protests ("Are you really going to sleep with your hat on?") he insisted on sleeping in his camper van and his clothes. And oversleeping in the morning, to the agitation of Louis, who clearly feared he'd died in the night. The procurator fiscal would have been scathing. "Why, Mr Theroux, did you allow this elderly gentleman, who had suffered a broken ankle, to succumb to hypothermia?" You could clearly hear, from beyond the grave, the elderly gentleman's "Heh, heh, heh!"

Slow hypothermia is the likeliest cause of death in the Rockies (I understood a doctor to say that you must have the right reindeer) but a fast bear is, on all counts, a more exhilarating way to go. Ray Mears' Extreme Survival (BBC2) demonstrated basic bear-avoidance by taking good care not to go near one. If you do meet a bear, lie down and pretend to be dead (the bear may have a sense of humour) or jump up and down and scream at the top of your voice. Kipling recommended the latter method. He added, unhelpfully I feel, that it only worked with he-bears. A she-bear will rend you tooth and nail. Look. You are on your own here.

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Heinz salad cream ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Heinz salad cream ad says about you.
fields.body:
The ad: A young bloke is seen making his bed. As he lifts up the sheet, he discovers a mouldy old bit of pizza stuck to the bedclothes. He trudges downstairs to chuck it away, but decides to smother it in Heinz Salad Cream instead. And then begins munching on it. "Any food tastes supreme with Heinz Salad Cream" reads the endline.

The jargon: The commercial, which is part of a £10 million multi-media push, is aimed at getting Heinz Salad Cream in front of a new generation and making it the top-selling table sauce in the UK. (Yes, even beating Heinz Tomato Ketchup, apparently).

Personality: You are young and perhaps a bit trendy. You're into really cool websites and other such groovy young people's things. The product is sponsoring a nationwide comedy tour, in association with Jongleurs, and there will even be samplings at music festivals throughout the summer, so you get an idea of its new target market.

Financial status: Just like its ketchup older sister, Heinz Salad Cream unites people. Because it's so lovely poured onto pasta, or mixed up with mashed potato, or even served with barbecues - there really is something in it for everyone, regardless of social bracket, claims the agency.

Telling lifestyle detail: You could well be on a diet - Heinz Salad Cream has just half the fat, not to mention half the calories, of a serving of poncey Mediterranean-style mayonnaise.

Other relevant data: Last October, food trade mag The Grocer ran a speculative story about the product being axed, upon which The Sun instantly launched a "Save Our Salad Cream" campaign. As it happened, it was never actually under threat, but the current advertising activity was planned in the light of that heartening public response.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Devils' Playground | George Of The Jungle | Spellbound | Brazil
fields.body:
Devils' Playground

9pm, Animal Planet

The opening shots show an apparently sleeping wombat, twitching as it dreams. In fact it is dead, and without warning a bright-eyed, rat-like face bursts out of its abdomen - a Tasmanian devil, disembowelling its larger prey. Worse is to come though, as a young female devil is attacked and dragged into a burrow by a male, who then keeps her prisoner for three days, repeatedly mating with her as she howls in protest. Those with a belief that rape is a biological impulse might feel vindicated by this; for everyone else it's a natural horror film.

George Of The Jungle

(Sam Weisman, 1997)

7pm Disney

Brendan Fraser is in his element as a Tarzan-like apeman who is a banana or two short of a bunch: his only method of stopping when swinging through the trees is to hit one, face first. Leslie Mann is his jungle-fresh Jane and Richard Roundtree also crashes around in the undergrowth. Needless to say, children love it but the humour - soft landing in a pile of elephant dung, etc - wears a bit thin for the over-fives.

Spellbound

(Alfred Hitchcock, 1945)

7pm, Carlton Cinema

Brilliant suspenser about a psychiatrist (Ingrid Bergman) treating an amnesiac (Gregory Peck) who may be a murderer: her analysis convinces her he's innocent, but then again... With Hitch letting rip on the imagery - a long corridor of doors opening as the pair kiss; the dizzy, Dali-designed dream sequence - it's as colourful as black-and-white gets.

Brazil

(Terry Gilliam, 1985)

10pm, FilmFour

Following on from Time Bandits, Gilliam created another weird and wonderful world in this blackly comic take on Orwell's Nineteen Eighty Four, and earned himself real respect as a director. It's the story of Jonathan Pryce's Sam Lowry, a small cog in the great wheel that is the Ministry of Information in a shadowy, half-lit futureworld stacked and packed with heating ductwork: and the rebel in the system is the legendary Tuttle, played by the legendary Robert De Niro. A brilliant, dizzying fantasy.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Food Court | The People's Psalms
fields.body:
It's more than a decade since we learned to distrust what goes into our food, and since then our suspicions have mushroomed. Food Court (Radio 4, 1.30pm) brings John Humphrys' persistent questioning to the catering industry. How do you bake a cake with a three-month shelf-life and how come your salad is pre-washed yet still crisp when you put it in your basket? Expect the food industry experts to talk about our love of convenience at low prices; nutritionist Dr Sarah Shenker to scare you off lunch, and Humphrys to display his professional incredulity when he discovers why some of us prefer dried egg to fresh.

Can the Bible be relevant and yet retain its mystery? In The People's Psalms (Radio 2, 11.45pm) Richard (The Good Life) Briers and Rabbi YY Rubinstein discuss Psalm 131: "Lord I am not high-minded: I have no proud looks, I do not exercise myself in great matters which are too high for me."

fields.headline: Three of a kind
fields.standfirst: If it's inspired nonsense you're after, then look no further as Smack The Pony returns for its second series. Its stars are female, they're funny and - though no one believes it - they even like each other.  Lucy Barrick  met them
fields.trailText: If it's inspired nonsense you're after, then look no further as Smack The Pony returns for its second series. Its stars are female, they're funny and - though no one believes it - they even like each other.
fields.body:
'I was attacked by a big cow. Which was bad." Doon Mackichan, if it wasn't immediately obvious, is detailing the making of the second series of Smack The Pony. "And I got to drive a tractor. Which was good." Mackichan, along with Sally Phillips and Fiona Allen, returns to Channel 4 (tonight, 9.30pm) for more nonsensical sketches about - you guessed it - cows and tractors and quite possibly some other stuff. So what should we expect? She thinks for a minute. "Well, it's the same as it was before... but much more boring."

Smack The Pony may be many things, but boring it ain't. Although obviously starring (and mostly written by) women, its humour comes from absurdity, not gags about mammaries and menstrual cramps. And while experiences which are specific to women - putting on make-up, trying to run in high heels - may form the basis for a sketch, the jokes never come from the subject matter alone.

"When I did stand-up," says Allen, "I never did knob jokes, so I don't see why we would now." "Nobody really does those," Mackichan chips in, "or jokes about periods. Do they? Isn't it just a myth?" Allen shakes her head: "Oh no, they do. They do." But that's a million miles away from the stuff this lot turn out. They get particularly animated when discussing a sketch about a girl-band scoring a martial arts movie. "I do tae kwon do," Allen explains, "and I'd never got to use it until now. So we got to fly through the air and everything..." She trails off, smiling. The only real difference between series one and two that the trio will admit to is that, as Phillips puts it: "We all know each other now, so we're more confident and work better together. And we don't have to pretend to be nice first thing in the morning."

The positive chemistry between them is obvious, belying the fact that, although they had all done stand-up prior to the show, they'd never worked together before. "We were thrown together," Phillips continues. "It could've been a disaster, but it worked out in the end."

"Yes," affirms Allen in a deadpan monotone. "And now we're really all the best of friends."

Not that a lot of people want to believe it. "It's stupid," says Mackichan, "but it's incredible the number of people we get going, 'I bet you really hate each other. Go on - we just want to know about the bitch fights.' " Bitch fights notwithstanding, I wonder if they've felt they've been treated differently as comedians because they're, well, comediennes. It's obviously an emotive subject.

"We've got very different opinions on this one," Phillips muses. Fiona explains: "I've never ever understood that idea at all. The only time I ever experienced it was someone saying, 'Not bad for a girl' when I was doing a gig. But that was my mate, so I don't think it counts."

For Mackichan and Phillips, experiences have proved different. "I always got a lot of comments when I did stand-up," says the former, "although I did play a lot of laddish places. But I do think there's an idea that as a woman you're just not naturally funny..." Phillips interjects: "And I feel that I definitely have experienced some funny attitudes towards me. There's a group of lads that I grew up doing comedy with, who everyone knows as comedians. But whenever I do anything it's always "actress Sally Phillips", despite the fact I don't do any straight drama at all, ever." So what do the others, who both dabble in "proper" acting, think about the differences between that and comedy? "I'd rather have red hot pokers in my eyes than do Shakespeare," Allen mutters. Mackichan, on the other hand, is "happy either way - I'm a bit of a slag really." But when they're doing comedy, where do they see themselves fitting in among the ubiquitous slew of small-screen sketch shows? "I don't think we need to fit in anywhere," replies Allen. "It just is what it is."

Doon picks up the thread: "There was a weird synthesis between our first series and Big Train - unbeknownst to each other, we had a lot of similar ideas." "But that's about it," adds Phillips.

So, finally, what exactly do they enjoy about working together? "The best and worst thing," says Allen, "is that I couldn't stop laughing uncontrollably - which is great, but really pisses everyone off." For Mackichan, meanwhile, "being on set together, you do end up being like naughty schoolgirls. All that hanging about lends itself to mischief." And Phillips? "I love working with these two, but there are some drawbacks. If you're working with blokes, and you're the only girl, you get to do all the women's parts. Admittedly, you're only saying 'Do you want a cappuccino?', but you can do it in four different accents."

"Right," Mackichan goes on. "And then there's the old lady, the nurse, the secretary, the bitch... Oh, and the pre-menstrual girlfriend."

Luckily there won't be too many of those parts popping up in Smack The Pony. And, if they do, they'll be doing kung fu or driving a tractor as well as making the coffee.

The positive chemistry between them is obvious, belying the fact that, although they had all done stand-up prior to the show, they'd never worked together before. "We were thrown together," Phillips continues. "It could've been a disaster, but it worked out in the end." "Yes," affirms Allen in a deadpan monotone. "And now we're really all the best of friends." Not that a lot of people want to believe it. "It's stupid," says Mackichan, "but it's incredible the number of people we get going, 'I bet you really hate each other. Go on - we just want to know about the bitch fights.' " Bitch fights notwithstanding, I wonder if they've felt they've been treated differently as comedians because they're, well, comediennes. It's obviously an emotive subject. "We've got very different opinions on this one," Phillips muses. Fiona explains: "I've never ever understood that idea at all. The only time I ever experienced it was someone saying, 'Not bad for a girl' when I was doing a gig. But that was my mate, so I don't think it counts." For Mackichan and Phillips, experiences have proved different. "I always got a lot of comments when I did stand-up," says the former, "although I did play a lot of laddish places. But I do think there's an idea that as a woman you're just not naturally funny..." Phillips interjects: "And I feel that I definitely have experienced some funny attitudes towards me. There's a group of lads that I grew up doing comedy with, who everyone knows as comedians. But whenever I do anything it's always "actress Sally Phillips", despite the fact I don't do any straight drama at all, ever." So what do the others, who both dabble in "proper" acting, think about the differences between that and comedy? "I'd rather have red hot pokers in my eyes than do Shakespeare," Allen mutters. Mackichan, on the other hand, is "happy either way - I'm a bit of a slag really." But when they're doing comedy, where do they see themselves fitting in among the ubiquitous slew of small-screen sketch shows? "I don't think we need to fit in anywhere," replies Allen. "It just is what it is." Doon picks up the thread: "There was a weird synthesis between our first series and Big Train - unbeknownst to each other, we had a lot of similar ideas." "But that's about it," adds Phillips. So, finally, what exactly do they enjoy about working together? "The best and worst thing," says Allen, "is that I couldn't stop laughing uncontrollably - which is great, but really pisses everyone off." For Mackichan, meanwhile, "being on set together, you do end up being like naughty schoolgirls. All that hanging about lends itself to mischief." And Phillips? "I love working with these two, but there are some drawbacks. If you're working with blokes, and you're the only girl, you get to do all the women's parts. Admittedly, you're only saying 'Do you want a cappuccino?', but you can do it in four different accents." "Right," Mackichan goes on. "And then there's the old lady, the nurse, the secretary, the bitch... Oh, and the pre-menstrual girlfriend." Luckily there won't be too many of those parts popping up in Smack The Pony. And, if they do, they'll be doing kung fu or driving a tractor as well as making the coffee.

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip.
fields.body:
Life behind the screen this week shifted to Cannes on the sunny Cote d'Azur, except this year it rained - just as Londres last weekend got its first taste of summer.

The occasion was Mip-TV, another annual fixture in the TV calendar, and one where buyers and sellers of TV programmes converge on the glitzy Mediterranean town to engage in an orgy of networking, boozing, fine dining and business (not necessarily in that order).

Cannes plays host to a number of these bizarre gatherings throughout the year, with the Cannes film festival next up in May, followed by an advertising festival later in the summer. Then the TV lot descend again in October.

The TV festivals, unlike the glamorous film shindig, are dominated by wall-to-wall suits. It really is a gathering of those behind the screen, intent on staying behind the screen but making sure that they have some new programmes to put on it. So the sprinkling of celebs among the proceedings is always a welcome interruption.

This year, Vic and Bob were wheeled out to publicise the international launch of the (revived) Randall & Hopkirk (Deceased). Which they duly did with a photocall, drinkies and a dinner with selected hacks.

All was going according to plan, with the duo - plus writing partner and performer Charlie Higson - presenting themselves as relaxed and not intimidatingly cutting. The surprise discovery of a slug delicately balanced on a crisp lettuce leaf in the restaurant where the schmooze-fest took place did momentarily threaten to interrupt proceedings. Cries of "Le Monster!" in broad Geordie fortunately received no attention from the aloof French waiting staff. Life got a little flabbier later on when a very relaxed Vic, or Jim as we now like to call him, disappeared into a packed hotel bar with two fawning female accompaniments. Anyone seen him since?

 Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

Confession of day
Leader of the Commons Margaret Beckett admitted that prime minister's question time was not a "great advertisement" for the "intellectual qualities and capacity" of the house. She was responding to complaints from Labour MP Tam Dalyell about "ranting" during questions.

webTitle: Labour ponders how to deal with Livingstone

fields.headline: Labour ponders how to deal with Livingstone
fields.standfirst:
Party will adopt a wait-and-see policy if renegade wins

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and Ken Livingstone are engaged in an elaborate game of bluff over what each of them will do if the former GLC leader is restored to power in the capital on May 4.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and Ken Livingstone are engaged in an elaborate game of bluff over what each of them will do if the former GLC leader is restored to power in the capital on May 4.

Blair the democrat admits that he got it wrong in Wales. He will engage constructively with whoever London elects, even the renegade leftwinger whom most of his ex-colleagues deeply mistrust as a "gesture politician".

Officially Labour does not concede that Frank Dobson's campaign is doomed. Party loyalty and organisation, plus Ken's weakness for jokey gaffes, can still turn the tide even though yesterday's Evening Standard poll pushed Mr Dobson into third place on 15% - way behind Mr Livingstone's 49%.

But, while there is no detailed How to Live with Ken plan, thought is being given to tactics. They will wait and see how mayor Ken behaves: monitor his language, his appointments to key posts and his dealings with the 25-strong Greater London assembly in the crucial first two months.

Mr Livingstone is also adopting a positive tone whenever such talk arises. To the fury of ministers, Millbank officials and Frank Dobson's team, he talks as if he and the Labour party have just gone through a marital tiff, not an acrimonious divorce.

Thus he suggests that Mr Dobson and most of the other main candidates for mayor - including Steve Norris, Susan Kramer and Green candidate Darren Johnson - will all be offered jobs in his administration.

With 20 days to go to polling day it is a perfect pitch for an independent who wants to sound open-minded without being pinned down. To politicians in the main parties it is also a brilliant scam.

"Ken's a gang of one, which is good for campaigning but not so good for actually doing the job," says one Labour apparatchik. "Ken's not actually spoken to me about being in his team," says more than one of those offered a role via a Livingstone media interview.

Both Downing Street and the Brent East MP are bluffing. Mr Blair will want the London mayor's job to be a success - after all, it was partly his idea - but not at any price.

Conventional wisdom in the Labour hierarchy is that Margaret Thatcher's decision to abolish the old GLC saved "Red Ken" from municipal failure in 1986 and turned him into a popular hero. Mr Blair is determined not to play the Thatcher role next time.

Mr Livingstone bobs and weaves between offering key jobs to establishment figures like Mr Dobson and his running mate, Trevor Phillips, and suggesting that, for instance, the chairmanship of the metropolitan police authority will go to a black radical like Lee Jasper.

In reality that job is not in the mayor's gift. There are four "functional bodies" - covering police, fire and emergencies, transport and the London development agency - over which he has influence, but not control. Labour may be the biggest party on the Greater London authority, but will not have a majority. The GLA-mayor set-up has been created to foster cooperation and consensus, the avoidance of grandstanding politics of left or right in the discredited GLC. The budget has been tied down in a similar way, £3bn at the mayor's disposal (subject to GLA approval), compared with £5bn for the GLC - a lot more then than now.

"It won't work if the mayor says 'I have been elected, do what I say,' it will work if he or she says 'let's decide what we can do'," says one veteran of London politics. "There's a cross-party civic village in London, as in most big cities. But Livingstone doesn't know people in the civic village any more, he's been out of it too long," says another.

It is not just government which is watching and waiting. The mayor, of whichever party, must also deal with the GLA, with London's 32 boroughs, and with the cash-rich City of London.

"Whitehall and the City can both open doors to the right mayor. They can close them to the wrong mayor," one leading player said when the City's main fear was mayor Archer.

But City insiders speak in terms similar to Downing Street apparatchiks when they preview a Livingstone regime. "We have no desire to have anything but decent relations. We certainly think he'll be obliged to work with us because the City is so important to London's economy.

"But personally I'm not convinced he'll be able to resist confrontation with the City. If he does we will not take it lying down."

webTitle: Maverick loathed by many MPs on the left

fields.headline: Maverick loathed by many MPs on the left
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: When parliamentary Labour party chairman Clive Soley mentioned "Ken" during a recent Westminster meeting, he was shouted down.
fields.body:
When parliamentary Labour party chairman Clive Soley mentioned "Ken" during a recent Westminster meeting, he was shouted down.

"His name's Livingstone, not Ken," yelled leftwinger David Winnick to a chorus of support from fellow Labour MPs.

The unpopularity among his former colleagues of the clear favourite to be voted mayor of London on May 4 predates his decision to split with the party.

Although Mr Livingstone is a maverick leftwinger - in common with Mr Winnick - he has never been popular among fellow leftwing MPs, let alone Labour's right.

"Like a number of people who are generally on the left in the parliamentary party, I have always had many political suspicions about Livingstone's motives," Mr Winnick said last night."I have always viewed him as someone who is an out and out opportunist."

With bitter opponent Brian Sedgemore, the Hackney South MP, the animosity is personal as well as generational. Now 63, he was a prominent Bennite leftwinger when 54-year-old "Red Ken" was unknown. The Campaign group's Bernie Grant, who died at the weekend, once ran with Mr Livingstone for the Labour leadership, but later turned against him.

Tony Banks, the ex-sports minister, was a Livingstone ally on the Greater London council. He now regards his old friend as an egotist and chameleon - albeit what one MP called "one of the most proficient politicians in the country".

Hackney North MP Diane Abbott, at 46 on the other side of the Sedgemore generational divide, and Islington North's Jeremy Corbyn, are natural sympathisers. So is John McDonnell, once a critic from the left on the Livingstone GLC, now MP for Hayes and Harlington. None of these MPs is likely to jeopardise their careers by backing the independent campaign openly.

Mr Livingstone has sypathisers in assorted left splinter groups, artists and TV stars as well as in London union branches. But a serial Labour rebel in the Campaign group accused Livingstone of never being "one of us" even though he was a member of the faction.

Another old-fashioned leftwing party loyalist said: "That man lied to my face."

Mark Seddon, editor of Tribune, invited Mr Sedgemore to one of his weekly paper's regular dinners at a Soho restaurant last year, hoping the South Hackney leftie might find some common ground with Ken Livingstone.

The result was predictable. According to eyewitnesses in the Gay Hussar that night, Mr Sedgemore demolished many of the former GLC leader's economic arguments and got cross in the process.

But the mayor-of-London-in-wating refused to engage. "Ken never gets agitated, he never takes it on, he just parries," said one of those present.

The meal illustrated how the Pied Piper of Brent East - witty, astute and evasive - is a hard target to hit.

Mr Seddon hopes Mr Livingstone can be brought back into the fold which is what many party members and trade unionists want, if not parliamentary colleagues. "Tony Blair admitted at the weekend he made a mistake in Wales over Rhodri Morgan. It is different now Livingstone is an independent but there will be calls from party members for the rift to be healed."

Another Labour MP sees it differently: "The feeling on the left of the party is pretty vitriolic because Ken is treating the party as a buffet where he can pick and choose. No way are we going to welcome him back after this. He can forget it."

webTitle: Livingstone lead cut but Dobson slips to third place

fields.headline: Livingstone lead cut but Dobson slips to third place
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Support for the London mayoral frontrunner, Ken Livingstone, has dropped 12 points to 49%, according to an opinion poll published yesterday, but he maintains a commanding 33-point lead. Labour's Frank Dobson has fallen into third place behind the Tory, Steve Norris.
fields.body:
Support for the London mayoral frontrunner, Ken Livingstone, has dropped 12 points to 49%, according to an opinion poll published yesterday, but he maintains a commanding 33-point lead. Labour's Frank Dobson has fallen into third place behind the Tory, Steve Norris.

The ICM poll for the Evening Standard found only 15% of Londoners plan to vote for the official Labour candidate for mayor on May 4, though Labour is still comfortably in the lead for the Greater London assembly elections on the same day.

Both Mr Norris, on 16%, and the Liberal Democrat, Susan Kramer - who is up four points at 12% and yesterday claimed she could win on second preferences - have benefited from Mr Livingstone's loss of support since the last poll a month ago, but Mr Dobson has marginally lost ground over the same period.

Mr Livingstone, who is standing as an independent, predicted that the mayoral contest would be a "tight fight" now that his poll ratings were back to "realistic levels". He added: "I have always thought it would go to a second ballot and it would be a very close-run thing."

The former Greater London council leader will have been damaged to some extent by controversies over his finances and public pronouncements -the ICM poll was conducted in the wake of his remarks about international finance and third world deaths - but the net effect is that he is back where he was last November before the backlash over Labour's selection "stitch-up".

Mr Dobson shrugged off the statistically insignificant drop in his support, jubilant that voters were abandoning Mr Livingstone "in droves" and insisting: "As the seriousness of the campaign and the seriousness of the mayor's job become more widely known, I will do better."

Mr Norris agreed that there was now "a bit more realism entering the contest" and claimed that the election was now about "Steve v Ken - it's a good prizefight."

With Mr Livingstone back below 50% and his rivals locked in a three-way fight for second place, the focus on where the candidates' second preference votes go is likely to grow. If nobody wins more than 50% of the vote, the second preferences of all except the two frontrunners are distributed between them.

Ms Kramer claimed the momentum was with her campaign and seized on the latest polling results to insist she was the only candidate who could now stop Mr Livingstone, because she would take most second preference votes from the other two main candidates.

fields.headline: Robert Komer
fields.trailText: Robert Komer, sometimes known as "Blowtorch Bob", was one of the hardest of the hard men from America's lost war in Vietnam. A junior second world war intelligence officer turned CIA professional, Komer, who has died aged 78, was President Lyndon Johnson's first choice to supervise non-military programmes in Vietnam from the White House.
fields.body:
Robert Komer, sometimes known as "Blowtorch Bob", was one of the hardest of the hard men from America's lost war in Vietnam. A junior second world war intelligence officer turned CIA professional, Komer, who has died aged 78, was President Lyndon Johnson's first choice to supervise non-military programmes in Vietnam from the White House. But, in May 1967, he was sent to Saigon to drive forward the programmes euphemistically known as "pacification", "nation-building" and "revolutionary development".

High-minded as the intention might have been - to match communist propaganda with a western revolution of freedom - the CIA programmes earned a reputation for dirty tricks, assassination and torture. To quote the grim jest of the time, Komer set out to win the hearts and minds of the South Vietnamese people, but ended up acting on the premise that if you grabbed their balls, their hearts and minds would follow.

A single-minded and ruthless bureaucrat, he was responsible for what he himself, translating the Vietnamese phrase phung hoang, called the Phoenix programme. This was an effort to collect systematic information on the infrastructure of the National Liberation Front, the political organisation that controlled the Vietcong guerrillas.

In theory, it was supposed to identify political cadres, tax collectors and local officials, who would then be "neutralised" by South Vietnamese police or army units. Neutralisation was supposed to mean internment; in practice, many reporters and historians have suggested that it too often meant murder, either in firefights in Vietcong controlled villages, or in straight assassinations.

The programme depended for its information on a sinister system of interrogation centres in each of South Vietnam's 44 provinces, places with an unsavoury reputation for brutality and torture. It has been claimed, that as many as 40,000 real or suspected Vietcong were killed in the course of Phoenix. The figure is almost certainly inflated; but the inflation was itself the result of a system that grossly exaggerated figures of enemy casualties.

Attempts have been made to exonerate the CIA from responsibility for this fiasco on the grounds that control of the Civil Operations and Revolutionary Development (Cords) programmes were taken from the agency at about the time Komer went to Saigon. In fact, Phoenix remained a CIA operation until it was handed over to the South Vietnamese in 1973.

William Colby, Komer's deputy and successor in charge of Phoenix, said that his boss had been "brash, abrasive, statistics-crazy and aggressively optimistic".

He was certainly very much Lyndon Johnson's man, and when, in 1968, Johnson withdrew from the US presidential election, he made sure that Komer would survive the impending debacle in Vietnam. In deference to his long-standing interest in the Middle East, Komer was appointed US ambassador to Turkey, and awarded the national medal of freedom.

Komer was born in Chicago and brought up in St Louis. fields.headline: Giorgio Bassani
fields.standfirst: Italian writer whose novels - among them The Garden Of The Finzi-Continis - chronicled a century of liberty under threat
fields.trailText: Italian writer whose novels - among them The Garden Of The Finzi-Continis - chronicled a century of liberty under threat.
fields.body:
Much of 20th-century Italian literature has been dedicated to the business of remembering origins. With a sequence of stories, a volume or two of dialect poetry, or a childhood memoir, a writer stakes a claim to a territory, a city or a social milieu - the entire country, from the Alps to Sicily, can be mapped according to the local colour of poets, novelists and playwrights. The singular achievement of Giorgio Bassani, who has died aged 84, was to transcend all the various backgrounds which reached out to claim him for their own.

He was a Jew, and the Jewish experience in dark times is a significant element in his fiction. Even so, he eludes classification as a Jewish writer. He was a Ferrarese, alert to the features, both physical and moral, of life in the small towns of the lower Po valley, the Bassa Padana. But his evocations of Ferrara, and its surrounding landscape, possess a quality of detachment and an absence of nostalgia. Above all, he was a novelist, poet and critic, whose presence within the literary world of post-war Italy was defined by his distance from it.

It was as a pianist, rather than as a writer, that Bassani seemed likely to shine during an uneventful childhood as the son of a prosperous doctor. In his final school years, however, he imbibed the anti-fascist ideas of a group of young teachers, and, as a student at Bologna, he encountered further challenges to the spirit of Mussolinian bourgeois orthodoxy in the classes given by the art historian Roberto Longhi and the critic Carlo Calcaterra.

Encouraged by Longhi, Bassani began to publish articles in a local review, and in 1940 his first book, Una citta di pianura (City Of The Plain), was published under the pseudonym Giacomo Marchi, a disguise adopted in response to Mussolini's racial laws.

Bassani's involvement in anti-fascist operations increased as the second world war began, and in 1943, on the eve of Italy's surrender to the allies, he was briefly imprisoned as part of a round-up of dissidents. His marriage to Valeria Sinigallia took place soon afterwards, and the pair fled to Florence, where they lived, with the aid of forged passports, in two tiny rooms. Bassani managed to rescue his parents, and his sister Jenny, from the advancing Germans; the rest of his Ferrarese relatives perished in Buchenwald.

Not until 1956, and the publication by Einaudi of Cinque Storie Ferraresi (Five Stories Of Ferrara), did Bassani's true voice make itself heard among a wider Italian public. The previous 10 years had seen him working as a schoolteacher, and witnessed his false start as a poet, but the most valuable experience came from writing for the cinema. He also played a number of small film roles, whose techniques had a clear influence on his treatment of fictional narrative.

Recognition of a notable new talent came in the form of the Strega Prize, Italy's major literary award, given to Cinque Storie Ferraresi. The appearance of Gliocchiali d'oro (The Golden Glasses) in 1958 confirmed its author's promise, and when Il Giardino dei Finzi Contini (The Garden Of The Finzi-Continis) was published in 1962 his international status was guaranteed.

These works, together with their successors, Dietto la Porta (Behind the Door, 1964) and the revised Storie Ferraresi, which appeared, with two earlier tales added, as L'odore del Fieno (The Smell of Hay) in 1972, explained the world of the author's boyhood and youth against the background of official antisemitism.

The town of Ferrara and its inhabitants, like the entrancing Micol Finzi Contini (based, according to Bassani's mother, on a girl he had hoped to marry) and the homosexual Dr Fadigati, protagonist and victim in Gli occhiali d'oro, are realised with an extraordinary clarity. Yet both place and people are surrounded, in Bassani's treatment of them, by a more abstract dimension relating to the late 20th-century crises of dislocation, solitude and personal anguish. Perhaps the most remarkable aspect of his characters is that none of them, apart perhaps from Micol, seems in any way exceptional. It is Bassani's unique gift that their familiar urban ordinariness should make them, often frighteningly, so memorable.

In 1970, II giardino dei Finzi Contini was given a respectful film version by the veteran director Vittorio De Sica. A last full-length novel, L'airone (The Heron, 1968), opening out the Ferrarese prospect to embrace the surrounding terrain of the Po delta, seems gloomier in its austere engagement with contemporary existence than the more poetic embrace of prewar Ferrara made by its predecessors. Whether through pride - or simply because he had nothing left that he wished to say - Bassani relinquished fiction, and more or less abandoned writing altogether in the wake of L'odore del fieno.

The gesture was typical of a man whose sense of his dignity was always so marked. A striking figure throughout his life - he had been a brilliant tennis player, and his powerfully blue eyes earned the nickname "Celestino" for his fictional alter ego Bruno Lattes - he was well suited to be vice-president of RAI (the Italian national broadcasting network) and president of Italia Nostra, the heritage organisation he founded.

In another incarnation, as a reader and editor for the publishing firm of Feltrinelli, Bassani was instrumental in recovering the manuscript of one of the greatest Italian novels, Giuseppe Tomasi di Lampedusa's Il Gattopardo (The Leopard), which had been rejected in the 1950s as rightwing and old-fashioned. It was Elena Croce, daughter of the great Neapolitan critic and historian Benedetto Croce, who first showed Bassani Lampedusa's text, and his admiration for Croce inspired that respect for the past as a guide to the present which spans his Ferrarese narratives. Referring to Croce he once told an interviewer that he believed in liberty "like a religion."

Bassani, who at the end suffered from Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease, was a quietly insistent chronicler of our age's various menaces to liberty. He is survived by his wife Valeria, from whom he was separated, their two children and his longtime companion Portia Prebys.

fields.headline: Friedensreich Hundertwasser
fields.standfirst: Maverick architect building against the grain
fields.trailText: The world of architecture has always boasted mavericks, who produce buildings utterly outside the reigning aesthetic, barely complying with regulations, yet escaping ridicule or suppression through their childlike authenticity, embellishment and logic. Such was Friedensreich Hundertwasser, who has died aged 71, on board the Queen Elizabeth II en route from his New Zealand farm to Europe.
fields.body:
The world of architecture has always boasted mavericks, who produce buildings utterly outside the reigning aesthetic, barely complying with regulations, yet escaping ridicule or suppression through their childlike authenticity, embellishment and logic. Elemer Zalotay has a following in Switzerland for work of this kind, while Lucien Kroll attracted even greater attention in Belgium. Both were born about the same time as the Austrian artist and architect Friedensreich Hundertwasser, who has died aged 71, on board the Queen Elizabeth II en route from his New Zealand farm to Europe.

Born Friedrich Stowasser into a poor Viennese family, he was brought up by his Jewish mother; his father had been a civil servant and an officer in the Austro-Hungarian army, but died shortly after Friedrich was born. His mother sent him to a Montessori school for a year to develop his artistic talents; after the Anschluss with Germany in 1938, she put him in the Hitler Youth, thus saving both their lives during the second world war.

In 1948 Friedrich enrolled at the Vienna Academy of Art (where Hitler had unsuccessfully sought admission 40 years earlier). Although admitted, Friedrich left after three months, and avoided all further institutional education. He changed his surname to Hundertwasser - "sto" in most Slavic languages means 100 - and became an artist. Modifications to his first name continued, until at the height of the dis turbances of 1968, he hit upon Friedensreich, "peaceful realm".

Rejecting instruction, and scornful of the reigning modernism, he modelled his highly decorative approach on the art nouveau period, with swirling spiral compositions reminiscent of Gustav Klimt. He was denounced as decadent, but continued, and his work became remorselessly popular, selling well and being exhibited widely.

In 1951, aged 23, he was sufficiently important to be admitted to the Art Club of Vienna, and four years later, after the Red Army had withdrawn from Austria, he began his lifelong foreign travel, at first to locations where his work was exhibited, but later to destinations in Africa, Tahiti, Asia and the Pacific. When he became wealthy enough, he bought property in New Zealand and later spent much time there.

Hundertwasser became involved with architecture because he criticised it. In 1959, as a visiting lecturer in Hamburg, he denounced the aridity of modern architecture, ridiculed symmetry - by wearing different coloured socks - and described straight lines, horizontals and verticals as "the tool of the devil" and "the rotten foundation of our doomed civilisation". He denounced the professional institutions of architecture because they would not permit practice by amateurs. This, he said, proved that architecture was not an art, but a professional conspiracy.

Hundertwasser developed these ideas into his Mouldiness Manifesto, a document that enjoyed great popularity during the heyday of the counter-culture, and which introduced him to the American environmental movement, which he supported to the point where, in 1980, he planted 100 trees in Washington - on what he decided to call "Hundertwasser Day".

In the 1970s, aiming to break into the closed shop of architecture, he used his fortune and notoriety to establish himself as the leading European representative of an alternative, non-profes sional "organic" architecture movement. From the outset, he ridiculed and rejected rationalist and functionalist architectural theory, and scorned every manifestation of industrialised architecture with standardised, repeated components. He sought to create buildings that were giant versions of his own artworks, with chaotically disposed windows and cellular plans featuring rooms of different sizes and shapes, tortuous circulation spaces, undulating floors, balconies and roof gardens. The result was an architectural anthropomorphism that never succeeded in transferring convincingly to full sized, built form, despite the anarchic promise of the sketch and model stage.

Hundertwasser's best-known building - and the clearest illustration of his failure to eradicate straight lines - was the Hundertwasser Haus, a block of flats for Vienna city council, opened in 1986. With 50 apartments and modern communal facilities, it tries hard to obscure its conventional engineering shape by means of planting and non-organic embellishments, scattered windows, undulating stripes of colour and mosaics of broken glass and crockery. It was joined in 1991 by the Hundertwasser museum.

More successful in conventional architectural terms was his work in the Austrian town of Blumau, where he designed a thermal bath-house and was working on a vast leisure and housing park project at the time of his death. Hundertwasser was an artist who relied on attack and inspiration, and neither ever let him down.

He was twice married for short periods; both unions ended in divorce. According to his wish, he was buried on his New Zealand farm in what he called "the garden of the happy dead".

webTitle: No motive found as Italy's worst serial killer gets life

fields.headline: No motive found as Italy's worst serial killer gets life
fields.trailText: A compulsive gambler who hated to be alone has been given 13 life sentences for murdering 17 people in a six-month rampage that terrorised the Italian riviera.
fields.body:
A compulsive gambler who hated to be alone has been given 13 life sentences for murdering 17 people in a six-month rampage that terrorised the Italian riviera.

Donato Bilancia, 49, shrugged and sucked on a cigarette after a court in Genoa ordered that he never be freed for a blood lust that consumed friends and strangers and baffled psychologists.

His victims included four prostitutes, a newly-wed couple, two jewellers, two security guards and two women attacked in the toilets of moving trains. Bilancia strangled or shot them in a rage after he felt "swept by a fire" and a "bite in the head".

The court rejected a plea of diminished responsibility and pronounced its verdict after deliberating for five hours, ending an 11-month trial and satisfying the victims' relatives, who wanted him transferred to a harsher prison. An appeal has been allowed.

Bilancia confessed to the murders but could not give a motive. He did not attend court and watched the proceedings on closed circuit television in his cell at Chiavari prison.

The hunt for the so-called monster of the riviera gripped Italy after police suspected that one man was responsible for the corpses they began discovering in October 1997.

Thousands of police were drafted into north-west Italy and female travellers were told to be wary as the death toll mounted.

Bilancia, a dapper dresser nicknamed Angel Voice because of his rasp, was not suspected by friends or relatives, who knew him as courteous and unflappable.

He was a fixture at Genoa's backstreet gambling dens and Foce, its prostitute's quarter, and was a successful burglar. But he had no record of violence until 1997, when he was allegedly cheated at cards by two friends, Maurizio Parenti and Giorgio Centenaro.

He bought a .38 calibre revolver and ambushed Centenaro but the shock caused his friend to have a heart attack. Police assumed natural causes had killed him.

Bilancia broke into Parenti's home and shot him and his wife. He then tried to rob a jewellery shop, and shot two of the staff when they screamed.

At this point he acquired a taste for killing, psychologists said. His motive was uncertain. Prostitutes he visited alleged that he had a tiny penis and was impotent.

Bilancia, who lived alone, borrowed a friend's car and murdered four prostitutes - "one for each nationality that worked the streets".

His lawyer, Umberto Garaventa, said: "For me that man is crazy."

It was suggested that he was unhinged by the suicide of his brother, who jumped under a train with his infant son.

On the Milan-Venice and Milan-Genoa intercity trains, after losing hundreds of pounds at roulette, he followed a nurse and cleaner into toilets, unlocked the door with a pass key, threw a jacket over their heads and shot them. He could not bear to look at his victims' eyes, he said.

It was the murder of two "respectable" women that sparked the outcry and the creation of a police task force.

The squad tailed their suspect around Genoa's bars and streets, collecting his cigarette butts for DNA sampling. They swooped on May 6 1998 as he emerged from a routine hospital appointment.

Eight days later he confessed and spoke almost without pause for two days, mechanically cataloguing 17 killings with diagrams. The worst serial killer in Italian history asked if doctors could explain to him why he did it.

The squad tailed their suspect around Genoa's bars and streets, collecting his cigarette butts for DNA sampling. They swooped on May 6 1998 as he emerged from a routine hospital appointment. Eight days later he confessed and spoke almost without pause for two days, mechanically cataloguing 17 killings with diagrams. The worst serial killer in Italian history asked if doctors could explain to him why he did it.

webTitle: Row over Nazi conference splits Chile

fields.headline: Row over Nazi conference splits Chile
fields.trailText: Attempts by the Chilean government to stop a conference of neo-Nazis due to begin next Monday appeared to have backfired yesterday after human rights activists accused the government of giving free publicity to extremists.
fields.body:
Attempts by the Chilean government to stop a conference of neo-Nazis due to begin next Monday appeared to have backfired yesterday after human rights activists accused the government of giving free publicity to extremists.

The newly-elected socialist president, Ricardo Lagos, said last month that he would not allow the five-day gathering to be held in Chile, and on Tuesday the government banned about 100 pro-Nazi foreigners from entering the country.

The deputy interior minister, Jorge Burgos, said that some of those on the list faced outstanding arrest warrants and were being prevented from entering on suspicion that they might commit "inappropriate activities".

But leaders of Chile's Jewish community, who have fought to ban the conference since it was announced two years ago, say that the government's actions have led to a wave of free publicity for the extremists.

"I have stopped events like this six times without all this publicity," said Isaac Frenkel, a past president of Chile's Jewish community.

"You must fight every manifestation of Nazis all around the world, but in this case maybe too much publicity against them has made this more important than it was."

The leader of the pro-Nazi New Society Movement, Alexis Lopez, who organised the conference, said that six of the invited foreigners were already on Chilean soil.

"There are 30 invited guests and though the location has not been determined it will be in the south of Chile," Mr Lopez said at a heated press conference on Wednesday. He accused the government of operating double standards by blocking free expression "for which they fought [General Pinochet's regime] for 17 years".

Soledad Alvear, the Chilean foreign minister, justified the attempt to stop the conference. "This isn't just any old ideology, it is one that led to the death of millions of people in the second world war," she said. "To allow the... attempts to revive this political doctrine could lead to unfortunate consequences."

But a leading human rights lawyer, Hector Salazar, agreed with Mr Lopez, calling the government's position "an error".

"You can't apply repression to a group that comes to debate ideas, even if we don't like those ideas," he said.

"If we believe in absolute freedom of expression, we have to support this in the ugly cases as well, assume the risks of incorporating in our free society even those who don't believe in free expression."

fields.headline: Test examiners driven to protest
fields.trailText: Fearing for their safety, French driving test examiners have called a nationwide day of action to draw attention to the growing number of violent assaults they are suffering at the hands of unsuccessful candidates.
fields.body:
Fearing for their safety, French driving test examiners have called a nationwide day of action to draw attention to the growing number of violent assaults they are suffering at the hands of unsuccessful candidates.

"It's not funny. In fact it's fast becoming a very serious problem," said Laurent Grognu, the general secretary of the examiners' union.

The group is organising a protest march to the transport ministry in Paris next Tuesday.

"Of course anyone who is told that they have failed their test is bound to be a little unhappy," Mr Grognu said. "We understand that, and we're prepared for a little verbal abuse. What we are not prepared to stand for is physically being beaten up for doing our job."

The examiners' ire has been aroused by dozens of attacks by applicants furious at being told that they have not passed their test, which costs £400 on average in France. Unsuccessful candidates have resorted to using their fists and feet to make their disappointment plain.

Some have gone further. On Monday, police in Melun charged one 23-year-old male applicant with attempted manslaughter after he fired two rubber bullets at an examiner who told him that he had failed his driving test for the fifth time.

"Up until now, we were relatively safe from attack, although of course we hear threats and insults every day," said Jacques Samson from the Seine-et-Marne region, where examiners called a wildcat one-day strike last week.

"When I started this job 17 years ago I went to work whistling. Now when I go in, I'm shaking."

Mr Grognu said that while he appreciated the police's attempts to prosecute any assailants, all that was needed to improve matters was a simple change in procedure.

"At present, we tell candidates their result in the car," he said. "Why can't we just post it to them?"

fields.headline: Greece hands culture to 'King Gaffe'
fields.standfirst: Athens entrusts Elgin marbles to master brick-dropper
fields.trailText: The new Greek government appointed one of Europe's most pugnacious and clanger-prone politicians yesterday to oversee the delicate business of bringing home the Parthenon marbles from exile in the British Museum.
fields.body:
The new Greek government appointed one of Europe's most pugnacious and clanger-prone politicians yesterday to oversee the delicate business of bringing home the Parthenon marbles from exile in the British Museum.

The job of culture minister went to Theodore Pangalos, who during a spell as foreign minister last year sent waves across the Atlantic by calling President Bill Clinton a "shameless liar" for failing to keep his promise to solve the problem of divided Cyprus.

That fit of pique sent Greco-American relations into an unprecedented downward spiral and had western diplomats wondering whether "King Gaffe" had lost his marbles.

Soon after that he raised Turkish hackles by accusing Ankara of "dragging its muddy boots across the carpets of Europe", and lambasted the British media for its "disgustingly racist" portrayal of Greeks as hot-headed hedonists.

In 1995, weeks before Greece assumed the rotating presidency of the European Union, he chastised Germany for behaving like "a bestial giant with a child's brain".

Yesterday he lost no time in losing friends in London and Rome. Within minutes of the new government being sworn in, he declared: "We have to promote our big projects, starting with the return of the Parthenon marbles, which belong to us, and to create the archaeological areas that will change the heart of Athens so that Athens can soon become much better than Rome."

Never scared of a fight, Mr Pangalos, 62, said the battle to retrieve the 2,500-year-old marbles, brought to Britain by the Earl of Elgin and sold to the government in 1816, would require the creation of "the most suitable solidarity movement" in Britain.

"Greece also has to build the museum that will receive them," he said referring to the cultural behemoth Athens plans to erect by 2004, when it hosts the Olympic games. "Which we will do."

A man whose intellect is said to be as big as his girth, Mr Pangalos has earned himself considerable popularity at home by his outspoken ways. But his jaw-dropping clangers have not gone down so well with the rest of the west.

"He has a brilliant mind and is very talented, but he's also very unpredictable," said a socialist aide who spent years working alongside him.
