webTitle: South strikes rebel colours about to sink

fields.headline: South strikes rebel colours about to sink
fields.trailText: One of the last bastions of Southern rebellion crumbled yesterday when the only state that still flies the Confederate flag from its public buildings agreed under the mounting pressure of public protest to lower the nostalgic colours.
fields.body:
One of the last bastions of Southern rebellion crumbled yesterday when the only state that still flies the Confederate flag from its public buildings agreed under the mounting pressure of public protest to lower the nostalgic colours.

The South Carolina state senate voted to remove the flag from its present position over the state assembly building in Columbia and give it a less provocative location nearby, in front of a monument to the Confederate civil war dead.

If the lower house follows suit, the Democratic governor, Jim Hodges, a supporter of the compromise, will sign it into law. He described it as one more hurdle overcome.

The senate vote came on the 139th anniversary of the day when South Carolina troops fired on the federal garrison at Fort Sumter, near Charleston, beginning the four-year war between North and South.

South Carolina began flying the rebel flag, seen by many Americans as a symbol of support for slavery, during the civil war centenary celebrations in 1962. While other southern states have gradually abandoned the public display of Confederacy symbols, South Carolina has remained defiant, sparking a tourism and business boycott.

The compromise, which reflects pressure from local business leaders and national political criticism, includes removing the flag from both legislative chambers, but bans the renaming of public places called after historical figures.

That means that commemorations of such Confederate leaders as Jefferson Davis and Robert E Lee will remain, even though they have been targets of campaigns in other states.

fields.headline: Peruvian president accepts run-off vote
fields.trailText: Peru's president, Alberto Fujimori, bowed to international pressure yesterday, accepting that he will have to fight a second round of the presidential election against the opposition candidate, Alejandro Toledo.
fields.body:
Peru's president, Alberto Fujimori, bowed to international pressure yesterday, accepting that he will have to fight a second round of the presidential election against the opposition candidate, Alejandro Toledo.

After widespread allegations of vote-rigging, there were fears that Mr Fujimori would be declared the outright winner, with more than half the votes in Sunday's presidential election. There was a mysterious delay before the results began to be declared.

The US and some other countries warned Peru against fixing the election. Although the count has not been completed, it has now been officially accepted that Mr Fujimori fell just short of the necessary 50%.

The run-off is expected at the end of May or in early June.

Forcing Mr Fujimori into a second round is a substantial victory for Mr Toledo, an economist, who comes from the downtrodden Indian population and was relatively unknown just a few months ago.

Mr Toledo has the advantage of the tide running in his favour, but Mr Fujimori, who has been in power for more than 10 years, will deploy the whole government machinery, including the intelligence services, against him. Much of the press also tends to back the government.

In the weeks leading to Sunday's vote, Mr Toledo, 54, was the target of a smear campaign in which he was accused of everything from shunning an illegitimate daughter to being the architect of a financial pyramid scheme which impoverished thousands of Peruvians in the early 1990s. He has denied the accusations.

Mr Fujimori, 61, was popular early in his presidency, mainly for breaking the back of the Shining Path guerrillas. But disillusionment has grown, especially on the left, which is critical of his disregard for democracy and the legal process.

Mr Toledo said optimistically yesterday that the second round would be different.

"The international community is watching. The nation is watching."

fields.headline: Hamming it up
fields.standfirst: Belgian art work raises a stink
fields.trailText: A Damien Hirst-style sculpture wrapping 8,000 slices of Italian ham around eight neo-classical pillars in the Belgian city of Ghent has provoked fierce debate among residents of this picture-book town.
fields.body:
A Damien Hirst-style sculpture wrapping 8,000 slices of Italian ham around eight neo-classical pillars in the Belgian city of Ghent has provoked fierce debate among residents of this picture-book town.

Feelings are running so high that it is guarded 24 hours a day by a security firm and local students. Its creator, Jan Fabre, wants to leave the ham in place for at least three months to allow the meat to go off and attract swarms of flies.

"It will be fantastic with lots of flies flying around and worms crawling about. Then the pillars will really be alive," Mr Fabre told the Belgian daily newspaper De Morgen.

The redness of the ham, combined with the whiteness of its fatty rind, tricks passers-by into thinking that the grand pillars - which front one of the local university's oldest buildings - are hewn from expensive red marble.

On closer inspection it becomes apparent that each piece of ham has been painstakingly stapled to a polystyrene undercoat and each pillar then shrink-wrapped in cellophane to protect "the living sculpture" and ensure its pong does not offend members of the public.

Not everyone is amused. "I'm ashamed of this when there are so many hungry people in this town. That's not art," Willy Dossche, a local taxi driver, complained yesterday. "We pay so many taxes in this town, but for what? Nobody is happy about this."

Passers-by stop to stare and sometimes touch the pillars under the watchful gaze of the student guardian lolling in the shop doorway opposite.

Everyone has something to say about the pillars. "I think it's beautiful. It makes a stink as all good art does," said a local philosophy teacher, David de Roos. "Fabre wanted to contrast the truth of science, as represented by the university, with the fact that bodies rot."

"People now know that something big is happening in Ghent, so it has served its purpose," added an enthusiastic student.

Others, however, regard the pillars with disgust.

Ghent's cats and dogs have been more appreciative, and the student guards have been forced to drive away hungry pets.

Tourists also like it. An American, realising that the "marble" pillars are made of ham, does not pause for thought: "Lord have mercy, I have to get a picture of that."

fields.headline: Britain 'soft on Chinese abuses'
fields.trailText: The British government disappointed human rights lobbyists yesterday for failing to support a US-sponsored resolution condemning China's human rights record.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill and Peter Capella in Geneva
fields.body:
The British government disappointed human rights lobbyists yesterday for failing to support a US-sponsored resolution condemning China's human rights record.

The US had appealed to Britain and other countries to co-sponsor the resolution at the United Nations commission on human rights in Geneva. In the end it had to table the resolution on its own.

The Chinese government, which has been lobbying hard in capitals round the world in recent weeks, welcomed the British stance. An official said: "We have always attached great importance to dialogue between Britain and China on all issues, including human rights. We are opposed to confrontation. We prefer to talk."

The commission has never censured China, though it came within one vote of doing so in 1995.

The Foreign Office, denying that the government was afraid of risking trade relations with Beijing, said: "To say we are not critical of China is not true. We have opted for critical dialogue. By entering the process, the Chinese have accepted that human rights are a legitimate subject for discussion."

A vote on the resolution is due on Tuesday. Britain's voting intention is supposed to be a secret, but officials have told the US that though it would not co-sponsor the resolution it will work behind the scenes to try to get it passed.

The US assistant secretary of state responsible for human rights, Harold Koh, criticised Britain and other European governments for failing to co-sponsor the resolution. "If quiet dialogue is a successful alternative, I would like to see the results of that," he said.

Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International also criticised Britain.

webTitle: Iranian Jews 'confess' as spy trial begins

fields.headline: Iranian Jews 'confess' as spy trial begins
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: Four Iranian Jews admitted spying for Israel during a closed court hearing in southern Iran yesterday, a judicial official claimed. Their lawyer denied that any confessions were made.
fields.body:
Four Iranian Jews admitted spying for Israel during a closed court hearing in southern Iran yesterday, a judicial official claimed. Their lawyer denied that any confessions were made.

A total of 13 Iranian Jews have been charged with espionage in the case, which has sparked international outrage.

"The judge met four of the suspects this morning and they confessed to the charges against them and asked for forgiveness from the judge," said Hassan Ali Amiri, the head of the Shiraz judiciary.

But Esmail Nasseri, a leading defence attorney, said that the defendants did not formally confess. "They may have done so privately, but the judge did not announce any indictment for us to present a defence. We categorically deny any confessions were made."

The crime of espionage can be punished with anything from a six-month prison term to the death sentence.

Another three of the 13 Iranian Jews facing espionage charges also appeared before Judge Sadeq Nourani. The three, who were released on bail last year, were told to return for a second hearing on May 1, when all 13 - who include five Hebrew teachers, a teenage student and several shopkeepers - will appear in court.

The four defendants who allegedly confessed, and the remaining six suspects, who did not appear in court yesterday, are all still in custody.

Yesterday's hearing was closed to the media and to western diplomats who had travelled to Shiraz to monitor the case. When the session was adjourned, the judiciary and defence lawyers gave conflicting accounts of the outcome.

Karim Sadiqi, another defence lawyer, claimed that there was some evidence connecting the defendants to a spy network, but said that the charges were too severe.

"If there was nothing [substantive] in their files against our clients, they wouldn't have been served with a temporary arrest warrant," he said. "But the issue is this: the evidence against them is not sufficient to convict them of espionage charges."

The case has been riddled with confusion. Iran's judiciary has declined to reveal specific evidence to substantiate the espionage charges. "I can't say anything about the reasons they are charged because the case is linked to national security," Mr Amiri said.

However, one suspect was identified as the "prime suspect" in the alleged spy network, according to the official Irna news agency. Hamid Tefileen was said to have been spotted by surveillance teams and arrested in the autumn of 1998. Other arrests followed.

Speaking outside the court, one of the three suspects out on bail, Navid Balazadeh, denied spying and said he loved his country. "We belong to Iran just as Iran belongs to us," he said. He added that he was a former volunteer in the Basij, Iran's Islamic militia, which is supported by hardliners in the government.

Western governments, Jewish groups abroad and Israel, believe the defendants are innocent. Their outrage at the case has put enormous pressure on Iran, whose relations with the west have improved greatly over the last two years.

Many western diplomats in Iran believe that the outcome of the case could depend upon which forces within Iran's government prevail: moderates supporting President Mohammed Khatami, or hardliners who control the judiciary.

But according to Iranian legal experts, President Khatami and his allies have little influence over the revolutionary court hearing the case. They claim that, as a result, the defendants chose Mr Nasseri - a former revolutionary court judge - as their chief attorney in the hope that he can use his experience and connections to appeal to the judge for lighter sentences.

Western diplomats have warned that the verdicts could affect relations between their governments and Iran. "The west can live with sentences that involve prison terms," one said. "But if the death penalty is handed down, you may see ambassadors being withdrawn."

The consensus among many western diplomats is that the suspects are innocent. "All this chaos proves that the Iranians have no case. This is what I am going to write to my minister," said one diplomat.

"But the issue is this: the evidence against them is not sufficient to convict them of espionage charges." The case has been riddled with confusion. Iran's judiciary has declined to reveal specific evidence to substantiate the espionage charges. "I can't say anything about the reasons they are charged because the case is linked to national security," Mr Amiri said. However, one suspect was identified as the "prime suspect" in the alleged spy network, according to the official Irna news agency. Hamid Tefileen was said to have been spotted by surveillance teams and arrested in the autumn of 1998. Other arrests followed. Speaking outside the court, one of the three suspects out on bail, Navid Balazadeh, denied spying and said he loved his country. "We belong to Iran just as Iran belongs to us," he said. He added that he was a former volunteer in the Basij, Iran's Islamic militia, which is supported by hardliners in the government. Western governments, Jewish groups abroad and Israel, believe the defendants are innocent. Their outrage at the case has put enormous pressure on Iran, whose relations with the west have improved greatly over the last two years. Many western diplomats in Iran believe that the outcome of the case could depend upon which forces within Iran's government prevail: moderates supporting President Mohammed Khatami, or hardliners who control the judiciary. But according to Iranian legal experts, President Khatami and his allies have little influence over the revolutionary court hearing the case. They claim that, as a result, the defendants chose Mr Nasseri - a former revolutionary court judge - as their chief attorney in the hope that he can use his experience and connections to appeal to the judge for lighter sentences. Western diplomats have warned that the verdicts could affect relations between their governments and Iran. "The west can live with sentences that involve prison terms," one said. "But if the death penalty is handed down, you may see ambassadors being withdrawn." The consensus among many western diplomats is that the suspects are innocent. "All this chaos proves that the Iranians have no case. This is what I am going to write to my minister," said one diplomat.

webTitle: New York socialite rakes in $1m from her cats

fields.headline: New York socialite rakes in $1m from her cats
fields.trailText: Jocelyne Wildenstein, the former wife of a billionaire art dealer whose passion for plastic surgery made her face look feline, is expected to make up to $1m (£630,000) from yesterday's sale of her jewellery.
fields.body:
Jocelyne Wildenstein, the former wife of a billionaire art dealer whose passion for plastic surgery made her face look feline, is expected to make up to $1m (£630,000) from yesterday's sale of her jewellery.

The woman who demanded $200,000 a month to live on during her acrimonious divorce from Alec Wildenstein two years ago sold more than 40 cat, panther and tiger jewels from her Big Cat collection at Sotheby's in New York.

Mrs Wildenstein, 55, was nicknamed Bride of Wildenstein in press reports of the divorce because of her extensive plastic surgery. She reached an out-of-court settlement with her ex-husband last year.

Thomas Burstein, Sotheby's jewellery expert, said Mrs Wildenstein had decided to sell some of the jewels bought in the early years of her marriage in order to "simplify her look". In the auction house catalogue for the Magnificent Jewels sale she says her jewellery was inspired by the menagerie of big cat she kept at her 27,000-hectare (66,000-acre) ranch in Kenya.

A diamond and onyx "cheetah" brooch and matching earrings, valued at up to $90,000, were inspired by her pet cheetah Siri. She also sold her entire Cartier-designed "white tiger" collection, which includes a diamond and onyx brooch worth up to $100,000 with matching earrings, bangle and ring. She also sold a 16-carat yellow diamond ring. Bids started at $275,000-$325,000.

The jewellery sold yesterday forms only a fraction of a collection estimated to be worth about $10m. During their divorce hearing, the Wildensteins, who had been married 18 years, argued over how much Mrs Wildenstein had spent on plastic surgery.

After the settlement she said she planned to go into the perfume and jewellery businesses.

The Wildensteins are among the world's richest and most powerful art dealers, with a family fortune estimated at about $3bn.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Deaths 'caused by stowaways'
At least 54 people, many of them children, drowned and dozens are missing after an overcrowded cargo boat capsized off Jolo island in the southern Philippines on Wednesday night.
fields.body:
Deaths 'caused by stowaways'
At least 54 people, many of them children, drowned and dozens are missing after an overcrowded cargo boat capsized off Jolo island in the southern Philippines on Wednesday night.

Some of the 43 survivors found so far say that the Annahada overturned because dozens of people secretly climbed aboard the 72-tonne ship for the 80-mile journey to Tawi-Tawi. It is believed more than 150 people could have been aboard.
John Aglionby, Mindanao

France returns foreign trees
About 3,200 of the 5,000 trees given by American citizens to help replant the gardens of Versailles, which were ravaged by storms last December, have been sent back home by the French authorities because they are species known to harbour insects and parasites foreign to Europe.

"Unfortunately, certain species of tree are banned from entering the European Union because they are known to be possible carriers of bugs and parasites that are unknown in Europe," said Jean- Dominique Bayart, a government botanist. "These bugs would probably do more damage than the storms."
Jon Henley, Paris

webTitle: The show is now over when Fat Lucy sings

fields.headline: The show is now over when Fat Lucy sings
fields.standfirst: Three Tenors stagger on, but man who conquered the world booed from the stage
fields.trailText: When does a conqueror decide to stop conquering and live on his memories? It is a problem that Alexander the Great and Napoleon never solved until others forced it on them, and now it confronts the mighty Luciano Pavarotti too.
fields.body:
When does a conqueror decide to stop conquering and live on his memories? It is a problem that Alexander the Great and Napoleon never solved until others forced it on them, and now it confronts the mighty Luciano Pavarotti too.

From the moment that he made the operatic world sit up more than 30 years ago, Pavarotti has been the possessor of the most striking and beautiful lyric tenor voice of his era, to say nothing of a peerless vocal technique and an irresistible personality that have conquered the world without a shot fired.

But Pavarotti is not the artist that he was in the 1960s and 1970s, when he became - again without question - the most commanding Italian lyric tenor since Beniamino Gigli, and the years are taking their toll on the one thing without which even the man the Covent Garden stagehands call "Fat Lucy" would not be Pavarotti: the voice.

The 64-year-old is sparing now with his appearances on the operatic stage. He barely attempts what were once his signature roles, Nemorino in Donizetti's L'Elisir D'Amore or Rodolfo in La Boheme.

He sang Cavaradossi in Puccini's Tosca at the Met in New York last autumn, to affectionate but restrained notices, and he is listed to sing Radames in Verdi's Aida - a role that he once engagingly described as "like a pig" - there next January, 33 seasons after his Met debut in La Boheme.

But the truth these days is that the veteran's knees and now even the voice are now even more sorely taxed than his income. New York is now just about the only opera house in the world willing to collude in the Pavarotti show any longer. It is many seasons since he sang at Covent Garden and his "serious" recording career has long been a thing of the past.

Snobs will date Pavarotti's decline from 1990, and the first Three Tenors concert with Placido Domingo and Jose Carreras at the end of the Italia '90 World Cup, when his Nessun Dorma became the most popular recording by an operatic tenor since Caruso and he almost single-handedly opened the opera house door to thousands who would never have gone through it without him.

The Three Tenors show still staggers on, as do the increasingly improbable joint appearance benefits with stars from Aretha Franklin to the Spice Girls. But even these events are shadows of what they once were. If you listen again to Pavarotti in the first Three Tenors gig or at the Hyde Park concert the following summer, the voice still had amazing allure. But not now.

Opera buffs will say that things began to go wrong when he went outside his natural repertoire in the late 1980s, under pressure partly from the record companies and partly from his own ego. That was when he ventured on to Domingo's much larger territory, when he recorded Verdi's Otello - a role he never sang on the stage - and launched himself disastrously into Verdi's Don Carlo in December 1992 at La Scala, where the booing was heard around the world.

But Pavarotti's real problem is not mass popularity, or over-ambitious casting: it is simply age. Even the most artful tenors, such as Carlo Bergonzi or Alfredo Kraus, were able to defy nature for only so long. Pavarotti is no less artful and is even more miraculously endowed than they were. But there comes a point when even Pavarotti's time is up. Alas.

webTitle: Pavarotti, branded a traitor to Italy, tumbles from grace

fields.headline: Pavarotti, branded a traitor to Italy, tumbles from grace
fields.trailText: Few have scaled such heights of acclaim and adulation but that was no comfort to Luciano Pavarotti yesterday when accusations of greed, betrayal and fading talent tipped him into a spectacular fall from the world stage.
fields.body:
Few have scaled such heights of acclaim and adulation but that was no comfort to Luciano Pavarotti yesterday when accusations of greed, betrayal and fading talent tipped him into a spectacular fall from the world stage.

A series of body blows from the Italian inland revenue climaxed with a court ruling that he pay a £3m fine for tax evasion to a state that has branded him a traitor.

The opera singer may now face criminal charges and a trial. A tribunal in Bologna yesterday rejected his appeal against an "ungrateful" Italian state and ordered him to pay the missing tax, which dates from 1989 to 1991. Investigators are now poring over all his financial affairs.

Italians greeted the news with indifference and hostility rather than sympathy, for the tenor has fallen fast and far. The Pavarotti who straddled the world at the 1990 Three Tenors concert in Rome, alongside Placido Domingo and Jose Carreras, is a memory. A bitter divorce and shambolic performances have drawn catcalls and sapped his status as a cultural force to the point where he is seen more often in TV adverts than on stage.

Clashes with the taxman drained his popularity as it emerged that he pretended to live in Monaco to avoid paying tax on his estimated £300m fortune. The often-criticised finance ministry has been hailed for exposing his claim as false. The 64-year-old spends more time on his estate in Modena, where he owns a racecourse and restaurant, than he does in his small flat in the Mediterranean principality.

Few have rushed to his defence since a senior ministry official branded him a traitor to Italy. Tax authorities suspect Pavarotti owes them £5m from undeclared income earned in nine countries. The tenor argued that he should owe Italy nothing because he paid tax in those countries. Rather than settle quietly he chose to fight, provoking the Bologna tribunal to impose its huge fine.

In January Pavarotti agreed to pay £1.6m after losing another battle over tax. The tenor negotiated an agreement to pay back the tax and interest in 36 monthly instalments of £45,000.

Other opera singers including Katia Ricciarelli, Giovanni Raimondo and Pietro Ballo have been snared in the centre-left government's crackdown but none has endured the humiliation of Pavarotti.

His private life meshed with the investigation after paparazzi snapped him canoodling with his secretary, Nicoletta Mantovani, 31, in a hammock in the Caribbean. The singer's wife, Adua Veroni, 62, filed for divorce to end their 35-year-old marriage but a deal to share assets pending a final settlement disintegrated.

Ms Veroni, claiming partial credit for her husband's success, reputedly wanted £70m. Pavarotti said no and his wife, who is known to believe he was understating his income, collaborated with the tax authorities. Divorce proceedings have delayed his marriage to Ms Mantovani and further tarnished his image.

And with calamitous timing the tenor's voice appears to be failing. Critics who have lambasted performances as weak and off-key have been joined by formerly loyal fans. Accusations of arrogance, once accepted as the price of his gargantuan talent, have begun to stick. In January he was booed in absentia by Spanish opera lovers for failing to show up at a concert to honour fellow singer Alfredo Kraus, who died last year.

The next month Pavarotti plumbed new depths when co-hosting the San Remo music festival on the Italian riviera. A TV audience of more than 20m watched in disbelief as the singer stumbled through jokes and introductions.

Co-hosts tried in vain to waken him from his "oceanic stupor", one newspaper said. Another gave him five out 10. Listeners of a radio station were unforgiving. "Pavarotti, so long," said Giuseppe, from Milan. "Pavarotti managed to fill the stage but a wardrobe would just as easily have done the trick," scoffed Ivan, from Treviso.

The singer had more success at the beginning of the year in aa 100-year anniversary performance of Puccini's Tosca. In his first performance in Rome since 1992 Pavarotti sang the part of Tosca's lover, Mario Cavaradossi.

Critics found flaws but Pavarotti exuded the passion of old. Snuffles were heard when a vengeful state executed Mario by firing squad. The symbolism was not missed. After the final act the audience exploded into shouts of "bravi". That night, Pavarotti mused, was a one-off.

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15 | Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes | On the menu: carrageen moss | Food on the net | The taste test: peanut butter
fields.body:
Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15

New Emperor, 52-56 George Street, Manchester.
Tel: 0161 228 2883.

Yang Sing (34 Princess Street, Manchester 1. Tel: 0161 236 2200) may be Manchester's most famous Chinese restaurant (and, some say, Britain's best), but relative youngster New Emperor is catching up fast. You may not go for its warm, intimate decor - it's actually a bit on made-over Spartan lines - but the food makes it a serious contender. Dim sum at lunchtime is highly rated, and would allow it an entry under Quick Bites, but the rest of the Cantonese-based menu encourages a longer stay. Specials: one-course lunch, £3.80; superior two-course lunch, £12; set dinner, £15.50 (there's also one for £29.50).

Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Atlas Bar, 376 Deansgate, Manchester.
Tel: 0161 834 2124.

Now something of an institution, setting a cracking pace with the help of media and music types. Bright interior carved out of handsome Edwardian red-brick shell. Food is Italian-inspired. "Soups without shortcuts," proclaims the menu proudly. Ciabatta a mainstay, helped along with smoked venison carpaccio or tuna, artichoke and tapenade, or roast poached salmon with lemon mayo, all for under a fiver. Then there are bruschettas topped with smoked mozzarella, bolognese sauce or grilled aubergines and pastas such as baked gnocchi and pappardelle with sweet red peppers, and goat's cheese, all around £5.95. And that's before we get onto the dishes of the day. Deli attached. Also known as Irish moss, sea moss, pearl moss, irlandische moos, and lichene d'Irlanda.

On the menu: carrageen moss

Moss to eat? Surely not. It's not actually a moss at all, but a seaweed. Tufted and fan-like, gathered mostly on the coast of Massachusetts.

What the devil do we use a seaweed for? Not much on the home front, although it makes a damn fine jelly because it contains carrageenin.

Carrageenin? A muscilagenous gelling agent.

So who does use it then? I hardly dare tell you. Commercial ice cream, soups and salad dressings.

So manufactured products contain wholly natural ingredients? You don't get much more natural than carrageen, the invalid's friend.

I think I'm going to be sick.

Food on the net

www.chocexpress.co.uk

Easter is drawing near, but forget the last-minute dash for foil-wrapped eggs and click instead onto the chocexpress site. More pricey than supermarket, but includes fancy wrappings and a gift card, and orders accepted up to April 18 for Easter delivery.

Pros: Extra thick chocolate eggs with scrumptious fillings. Belgian chocs for £16.95, or the exclusive special collection for £18.95.

Cons: The site has a few technical glitches which may test the resolve of less chocolate-devoted browsers.

Delivery: Normally 1-2 working days, but you can order further in advance.

Charges: Delivery in the UK is included in the price - send more than one item to the same address and you save £1 on each.

The taste test: peanut butter
There is a debate as to who first inflicted peanut butter on an unsuspecting world. Some say an unnamed doctor from St Louis in 1890. Others blame it on John Harvey Kellogg in 1904. We Brits had to wait until 1932 to experience crunchy or chunky peanut butter. The rest is history.

fields.headline: No: 1615
fields.standfirst: Blake's Seven
fields.trailText: Blake's Seven
fields.body:
Age: Born 22 years ago, killed off at the age of three.

Appearance: Characterised by 70s superflicks, rayon costumes with triangular appliqué motifs and wobbly bacofoil scenery.

Status: Deeply silly space series about seven freedom fighters resisting an evil federation that has seized control of earth and its colonies, controlling them through sedative drugs and fear.

I love gritty, real-life drama. Tell me more. Roj Blake, the impressively quiffed leader, commanded the septet's space vessel, the Liberator.

And who were the seven? Well, there's Jenna, the Farrah Fawcett-lookalike pilot; maverick computer technician Avon; Vila, a cowardly thief; big, stupid Gan; and Cally, a telepath from the planet Auron.

That's only six. Well, I've never really counted Zen, the on-board computer.

Next you'll be saying Timmy the dog wasn't really one of the Famous Five! Don't be silly, everyone knows Timmy was a canine replicant accidentally transmogrified while visiting from the planet Zorg.

How did they meet their end? Drowning in some of Avon's foam bath lotion? No, that old dodgy soap staple, the hail of bullets. Motionless corpses leaving addicts on tenterhooks as to which characters would survive.

But surely none of them survived? Not unless you count the afterlife of Soolin, aka actor Glynis Barber, as one half of 80s cops Dempsey and Makepeace. And Gareth Thomas, the actor behind Blake, is set to play David Baddiel's father in his forthcoming series on Sky.

So there is a heaven! Well, there certainly may be a resurrection. Prompted by the series's continuing popularity on cable, the producers have announced they are to make a new movie for TV, and possibly another series.

Surely not enough to lure Blake away from Baddiel? There is no news as yet on whether Thomas will reprise his role, but Paul Darrow, who played Avon, is expected to be back with a foaming vengeance.

Not to be confused with: The Birmingham Six.

webTitle: Should I trust my partner despite his history of infidelity with others?

fields.headline: Should I trust my partner despite his history of infidelity with others?
fields.trailText: Forget his past
fields.body:
Forget his past

If you go into self-destruct mode you won't even get as far as trying to trust him. You seem to be already embarking on a pattern of insecurity and mistrust which will push him away, and you will inevitably lose him. Your question is: "How do I trust him?" I say: "How do you not trust him?" You mention his dubious past and yet you strongly praise his present virtues.

Trust is based on confidence, and you shouldn't have it tainted as a result of past hearsay. His past infidelities were a result of past relationships which you cannot change. You have described a full and rewarding relationship with someone you obviously love, which you are in danger of jeopardising if you don't let go of your own personal insecurities. You have no reason not to trust him. History is nothing. We live now.
Josie MawnBrighton

You must trust him

I write as a self-confessed serial adulterer who, 12 years ago, came to see the error of my ways and feel the deep pain I had caused others. I felt guilty and ashamed.

My conclusions also led me to see that adultery isn't a betrayal that is carried out in solitude; it actually requires the active participation of at least one other person; often more people are involved than the two main players.

You should consider two issues. Firstly, watching him like a hawk will almost certainly result in a self-fulfilling prophecy and he'll do something silly - men are like that. Secondly, as he gets older (and more emotionally insecure) it will occur to him that there are few things more ridiculous in this world than a silly old man losing his dignity with a woman half his age. Serial adultery is for people under 26.

Finally, he really does need to be trusted; this way he can rejoin the human race and this will prove he is a much nicer person than you give him credit for. Everyone deserves a chance. I was offered a chance by a woman who was told "she ought to know better" and we've been happy together for a long time now. I shall remain grateful that she didn't listen to others and become consumed by her own doubts.
Name and address supplied

He won't change

If you value fidelity, loyalty and trustworthiness above everything else, then, sadly, you have fallen in love with the wrong type of man. Promiscuity is a characteristic of the young, and if he hasn't grown out of it by his 30s he never will. The fact that this otherwise honourable and compassionate human being has two failed marriages behind him is not a good sign. And - surprise, surprise - he is years older then you!

Your relationship will disintegrate sooner, rather than later, if you continue to question him about his activities and to brood. The only way you could hope to salvage the relationship, if the affection and the mutual support it entails are worth salvaging, is by taking the conscious decision that you will stop caring if he is unfaithful to you. It is certainly not everybody's cup of tea and it would not be mine, but it works for some couples. Whatever happens, I wish you happiness.

I am in a loving relationship with a man who has a history of infidelity. It began before his separation from his second wife. He is some years older than me and it seems to me that his philandering was, in the main, due to a different generational approach to remaining in a marriage no matter how unhappy it was.

In all other areas of life he is honourable and compassionate. However, I find myself becoming increasingly distrustful of him. He tries to reassure me, but I now doubt that, after a lifetime of profligacy, he can commit himself to a relationship.

I am starting to question him about his activities and I brood on the situation in self-destructive ways. Is it possible to trust someone with such a history? If so, how?
Name and address supplied

Next week

My partner and I have been together for over two years. He divorced his wife eight months after we met. Our love has made us immensely happy, and has survived periods of extreme difficulty due to the pain and disruption it has caused his ex-wife and children (aged 16 and 12). He has a cordial relationship with his ex-wife and sees his children daily.

They know nothing about me, a decision my boyfriend took with my support. We don't live together since he feels this would interfere with his relationship with his children. We have only been on holiday together once, for three days, because he always spends his holidays with his son and daughter. I have found this understandable, but now, as the Easter break approaches, I feel we deserve some time away together.

Also, his holidays are spent with his former mother-in-law and her daughters as well as his children. He does not enjoy this, as his ex-wife's family haven't forgiven him. He loves his children and goes out of guilt and a sense of responsibility. Should I put my foot down, or simply hope our relationship will be normalised in time? Would it help him to put things into perspective if I spoke to him firmly?

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 0171 239 9935, email privatelives@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Philip Haas
fields.trailText: What was the first film you saw?
fields.body:
What was the first film you saw?

A Swedish film, Fanny Hill, that my mother took my sister and I to see. I remember saying in a very loud voice, "Is this a children's movie?" and everybody laughing.

Your favourite film?

I love Robert Altman's Thieves Like Us. It's a really beautiful, engaging film that has style and something to say in a way that only a film can do.

Last film you walked out of?

I started to walk out of The Phantom Menace, but my kids were there so I had to drag myself back in. I thought it was really extremely bad.

Most erotic movie moment?

There's an early Bertolucci film called Partner in which, if memory serves me right, a man and woman get involved in a romantic embrace near an overflowing washing machine. There's too much soap powder in it, so they're embracing covered in suds.

What's the most annoying habit in a cinema?

In LA it's the parking, but I live in New York so I'd say it's when you can't get a ticket for a popular movie.

When was the last time you snogged in the cinema?

Since I've been married for a long time, I'm sure I've kissed my wife many times in the cinema but it's not our favourite place to snog. I remember very erotic hand-holding from my youth.

What is your favourite snatch of dialogue?

There are a lot of tag-like lines, like Cagney's, "Made it, Ma! Top of the world!" that I shouted when I was a kid.

Which actor would you most like to be?

Sean Penn: I tend to focus on people I'm making a film with.

Which actress?

Kristin Scott Thomas.

When did you last hide under your seat?

I don't go to see thriller films.

The last time you cried?

A tear or two made their way down my cheek during Felicia's Journey.

What sort of book makes a good adaptation?

What one finds exciting in a book isn't necessarily something that one would find exciting in a book that becomes a movie. So I try and find books from which you can extract a film in a way that does justice to the underlying material or takes a detour and doesn't subvert the material.

Does collaborating with your wife on all your films make for a good relationship?

It's both intensely pleasurable and intensely row-producing. On a professional front it's good because we're rewriting the script even when we're editing it. In terms of our personal life, it allows us to see each other, but thankfully we've now graduated from having the editing table right next to our bed.

 Philip Haas co-directed Up at the Villa.

fields.headline: Jet Li
fields.trailText: Where it all began
fields.body:
Where it all began

In Beijing, where Li Lian Jie was born and started training at the wushu (martial arts) academy at nine. He won his first gold medal at 11, was world champion many times, and made his first film, Kids From Shaolin, in China in 1983. Li is now 36.

Big move (part 1)

To Hong Kong, where his first film as Jet Li was the colourfully-titled Iron Rooster Versus the Centipede.

Other great Jet Li titles

Dr Wai and the Scripture Without Words and the presciently-titled Once Upon a Time in China and America, in which JL goes west. Before too long it was "Will the last one left in Hong Kong turn off the klieg lights and tell the best boy not to come in tomorrow", as he made the trip for real.

Big move (part 2)

To Hollywood, following Jackie Chan, John Woo, Chow Yun-Fat and others too numerous to mention. Launched in traditional east-west style as a Triad boss in Lethal Weapon 4, before reaching serious top of the bill status in Romeo Must Die - also for action megameister Joel Silver - and described as a kung-fu Romeo and Juliet. Take that, you Capulets!

Big move (part 3)

He became a married man for the second time in LA in September and nowadays shows off his English on the Jay Leno chat show, like a Jet-setter should. It seems Chungking Express's Faye Wong wasn't the only one California Dreamin' in Hong Kong. It makes a change from having to throw himself into the Yellow river amid the ice floes for Shaolin Temple: "The fight scene took a week to shoot, so every morning we had to pour a bucket of icy water over ourselves. It took a week's medical treatment to regain full use of my hands."

Big move (part 4)

Jet is now in line to follow in the footsteps of kung-fu's high priest, Bruce Lee, as Kato, the role he made famous on TV in the 60s in The Green Hornet - a green-masked crusader with a karate-chopping sidekick in in a big-budget movie for Universal.

USP

His name fits billboards so much better than Arnold Schwarzenegger's and he's 10 years younger than Jackie Chan.

fields.headline: Acting the fools
fields.standfirst: For his new film, director Bertrand Blier wanted his cast to behave as badly as possible. The result was a riot - of laughs. Lanie Goodman sees Blier and some of France's best-known actors let their hair down
fields.trailText: For his new film, director Bertrand Blier wanted his cast to behave as badly as possible. The result was a riot - of laughs. Lanie Goodman sees Blier and some of France's best-known actors let their hair down
fields.body:
As usual, the restaurant La Maison du Caviar, a spot noted for showbiz and film celebrities near the Champs Elysées, is jam-packed with beautiful people. Michel Serrault (of La Cage aux Folles fame) steps into the plush, dimly-lit dining room, searches momentarily for his friends, then strides over to a table where fellow actors André Dussollier, Jacques Villeret and Jean-Pierre Marielle are feasting on blinis, smoked salmon and vodka.

"Did you save me the worst seat on purpose?" he barks at them. "There's obviously a hidden camera or you wouldn't all be sitting sideways, looking in the same direction!" Ignoring their bewildered protests, Serrault is clearly in a foul mood and intends to make a scene. He turns his back to the group and straddles his chair, breathing down the neck of an elegant woman at the neighbouring table. "There," he sighs dramatically. "Now I'm in the picture too!"

"Cut!" says director Bertrand Blier, who can barely contain his laughter. This scene is just one among innumerable confrontations between a group of ageing male movie stars, who play "themselves" in Blier's latest dark comedy, Les Acteurs (The Actors). In a parade of France's biggest names in cinema, everyone from Gérard Depardieu and Alain Delon to Jean-Paul Belmondo and Michel Piccoli turn up unexpectedly in the film's free-floating intrigue, partly set on the streets of Paris.

However, most of the real "action" - if you can call it that - takes place within the timeless red velvet walls of this famed restaurant, painstakingly reconstructed in the hangars of the Epinay studios. With its revolving door for entrances and exits, it's also the perfect theatrical setting for all hell to break loose.

As it happens, the stage is a central part of Blier's world these days. Ever since his groundbreaking 1974 drama, Les Valseuses (which launched Depardieu's career) the director's eclectic mix of caustic humour and sentimentality has produced international hits such as Preparez Vous Mouchoirs (awarded an Oscar for best foreign film), Tenue de Soirée and Trop Belle pour Toi.

It has now been a full four years since the director's last film, Mon Homme, starring his ex-muse Anouk Grinberg, which was a disappointing commercial flop. Only recently, after the rousing success of his satirical play, Les Cotelettes (The Cutlets), which he both wrote and directed, did Blier feel ready to contemplate a new project in cinema.

"I had this strange idea," Blier explains, puffing on his pipe between takes. "I've always wanted to make a film on my profession - to show actors the way I see them when we work together. I thought it would be amusing to invent a story where they could finally play their own roles. Of course, it has nothing to do with their personal life," he adds. "It's the legend, the myth, that interests me - how actors are able to penetrate into their audience's imagination."

Not surprisingly, Blier's cast of "veterans", as he puts it, ranges from 50 years old to seventysomething. "I chose this generation because it's my own," he explains, "but also because the older they get, the funnier and more moving actors become. Their faces have been sculpted by life. They've finally mastered their art, but still act like a bunch of kids."

He looks up distractedly at his four leading men at the table, whose off-camera banter has the 50-odd extras in evening dress tittering into their champagne glasses of watered-down apple juice. "There's no message in this film - absolutely nothing for critics to interpret," Blier states with a provocative half-smile. "Actually, I've been trying to come up with a reason for making it, but haven't found one yet. It's simply based on the desire to laugh with these actors."

Indeed, the entire plot seems to revolve around a banal incident that occurs within the first few minutes of the film and quickly escalates into a major crisis. Jean-Pierre Marielle, a tall, greying, bearded man well-known to the French movie-goer, is sipping an espresso at La Maison du Caviar, and decides it's too strong. He orders a small jug of hot water, but it never arrives. He panics. His entire career is suddenly in jeopardy because the waiter has ignored him. "The actor that nobody sees and nobody hears is a goner," says Blier. "A weak delivery is his number one anxiety."

Marielle disappears and drags a stranger into the restaurant to order the jug, which comes right away. A heated discussion ensues among these grumpy, oversensitive stars about the quintessential weaknesses that unite them. "I drink," declares bug-eyed comic actor Jacques Villeret (Le Diner des Cons), known to have a penchant for alcohol. "So does Depardieu," someone chimes in, and they nod in assent. But Marielle will not be comforted, and becomes so paranoid that he tries to convince Michel Piccoli that his wife is having an affair with the waiter who slighted him.

Just how exaggerated is Blier's portrait? "In the beginning, Blier told us nothing and there was no script," confides André Dussolier (Trois Hommes et un Couffin, Melo). "We soon realised this was not really about us, but the obsessions an actor has on a set. I always worry about trying to do my best performance ever. The more films you make, the harder it gets."

"We try to invent," Michel Serrault says, "but we're an endangered species. For the time being, we lie to ourselves, but someday 'real actors' will no longer exist. We'll be replaced by hi-tech special effects and animated monsters."

Describing his film as a "post-Buñuel" bordering on vaudeville, Blier has gleefully obliged his cast to indulge in their wildest dreams, no matter how puerile. Depardieu, who has a motorcycle crash on the Champs Elysées, belligerently tells the cops off; Pierre Arditti attempts to strangle a gushy matron admirer who is trailing him; Jacques François, an elderly distinguished character actor, holds up a restaurant and curses at the top of his lungs; Sami Frey steals the wheelchair of a legless war veteran and amuses himself in rush-hour traffic, feigning spastic convulsions.

"Whenever actors promote their films, they always say, 'Oh, it was marvellous', whether it was or not," Blier smirks. "In this film, it's never marvellous. The actors continually ask each other: 'So, how are things?' and the answer is always the same. 'Terrible!' "

At the same time, he concedes that there's an inevitable power that comes with the profession. "I purposely chose the restaurant La Maison du Caviar because I wanted to convey that actors live a charmed life - and it's true! I was once with Mastroianni in Venice and, as we were leaving Harry's Bar, he told me: 'Walk very quickly - otherwise, we're done for.' I was right behind him and watched the women fall down on their knees, left and right, as he crossed their path. That's also what an actor is, a superman."

Curiously, this is one Blier film where homosexuality is a favourite topic of discussion, but women are never brought up. "Because they have much more important problems!" Blier laughs. "Like the jug of water!"

In fact, only a handful of French actresses - such as Josiane Balasko, and the rarely-seen Maria Schneider of Last Tango in Paris fame - have been included in the script. Blier had originally envisioned making two separate films based on the same concept, but ultimately decided that a mockery of French actresses might be too problematic. "We would have had to worry about the lighting, the make-up, who looked the prettiest... it wouldn't have been as funny."

Behind all the cantankerous clowning, Les Acteurs has its dark moments. "What kills actors is indifference!" is the battle cry, and the only solution is to eliminate the jaded or ignorant movie-goer. The actors accost passers-by to ask their opinion on Patrick Dewaere, Blier's fragile hoodlum hero who committed suicide in 1982. An unsatisfactory response warrants death - one man is nearly shredded to pieces in the ventilator of an underground parking lot until he redeems himself by praising Depardieu.

"There is always some good and some bad in my characters," Blier contends. "Take Les Valseuses - they were dreadful, but there was something endearing about them as well. Actors are special cases because of their egos. They're very tender and very mean, and have a hard time listening to others. It's better if they're the ones doing the talking."

Blier should know. As the son of renowned actor Bernard Blier, he was always in their midst, though repeatedly told that acting was "a horrible profession". "This film is a tribute to my father, he taught me everything," he says gravely. In the final scene, Blier plays himself, dressed in his habitual parka, jeans and checked cap, shooting a night scene on a deserted street. The crew starts up the rain machine, but the take is ruined because an actor has forgotten to switch off his mobile. "It's for you," he says, passing the phone to Blier. "Hello Papa," the director murmurs. The moment is magical, as if it were somehow perfectly normal that departed celluloid legends (Bernard Blier died in 1989) have privileged access to phones.

What kind of reaction does Blier anticipate to this freewheeling itinerary through French actor's country?

"People always say I make black comedies," he smiles. "Les Acteurs is more like a pink nightmare. I'm trying to film life, and you have to remain very modest behind the camera." A sigh escapes him. "If only the audience has as much fun as we did..."
fields.bodyText: As usual, the restaurant La Maison du Caviar, a spot noted for showbiz and film celebrities near the Champs Elysées, is jam-packed with beautiful people. Michel Serrault (of La Cage aux Folles fame) steps into the plush, dimly-lit dining room, searches momentarily for his friends, then strides over to a table where fellow actors André Dussollier, Jacques Villeret and Jean-Pierre Marielle are feasting on blinis, smoked salmon and vodka. "Did you save me the worst seat on purpose?" he barks at them. "There's obviously a hidden camera or you wouldn't all be sitting sideways, looking in the same direction!" Ignoring their bewildered protests, Serrault is clearly in a foul mood and intends to make a scene. He turns his back to the group and straddles his chair, breathing down the neck of an elegant woman at the neighbouring table. "There," he sighs dramatically. "Now I'm in the picture too!" "Cut!" says director Bertrand Blier, who can barely contain his laughter. This scene is just one among innumerable confrontations between a group of ageing male movie stars, who play "themselves" in Blier's latest dark comedy, Les Acteurs (The Actors). In a parade of France's biggest names in cinema, everyone from Gérard Depardieu and Alain Delon to Jean-Paul Belmondo and Michel Piccoli turn up unexpectedly in the film's free-floating intrigue, partly set on the streets of Paris. However, most of the real "action" - if you can call it that - takes place within the timeless red velvet walls of this famed restaurant, painstakingly reconstructed in the hangars of the Epinay studios. With its revolving door for entrances and exits, it's also the perfect theatrical setting for all hell to break loose. As it happens, the stage is a central part of Blier's world these days. Ever since his groundbreaking 1974 drama, Les Valseuses (which launched Depardieu's career) the director's eclectic mix of caustic humour and sentimentality has produced international hits such as Preparez Vous Mouchoirs (awarded an Oscar for best foreign film), Tenue de Soirée and Trop Belle pour Toi. It has now been a full four years since the director's last film, Mon Homme, starring his ex-muse Anouk Grinberg, which was a disappointing commercial flop. Only recently, after the rousing success of his satirical play, Les Cotelettes (The Cutlets), which he both wrote and directed, did Blier feel ready to contemplate a new project in cinema. "I had this strange idea," Blier explains, puffing on his pipe between takes. "I've always wanted to make a film on my profession - to show actors the way I see them when we work together. I thought it would be amusing to invent a story where they could finally play their own roles. Of course, it has nothing to do with their personal life," he adds. "It's the legend, the myth, that interests me - how actors are able to penetrate into their audience's imagination." Not surprisingly, Blier's cast of "veterans", as he puts it, ranges from 50 years old to seventysomething. "I chose this generation because it's my own," he explains, "but also because the older they get, the funnier and more moving actors become. Their faces have been sculpted by life. He looks up distractedly at his four leading men at the table, whose off-camera banter has the 50-odd extras in evening dress tittering into their champagne glasses of watered-down apple juice. "There's no message in this film - absolutely nothing for critics to interpret," Blier states with a provocative half-smile. "Actually, I've been trying to come up with a reason for making it, but haven't found one yet. It's simply based on the desire to laugh with these actors." Indeed, the entire plot seems to revolve around a banal incident that occurs within the first few minutes of the film and quickly escalates into a major crisis. Jean-Pierre Marielle, a tall, greying, bearded man well-known to the French movie-goer, is sipping an espresso at La Maison du Caviar, and decides it's too strong. He orders a small jug of hot water, but it never arrives. He panics. His entire career is suddenly in jeopardy because the waiter has ignored him. "The actor that nobody sees and nobody hears is a goner," says Blier. "A weak delivery is his number one anxiety." Marielle disappears and drags a stranger into the restaurant to order the jug, which comes right away. A heated discussion ensues among these grumpy, oversensitive stars about the quintessential weaknesses that unite them. "I drink," declares bug-eyed comic actor Jacques Villeret (Le Diner des Cons), known to have a penchant for alcohol. "So does Depardieu," someone chimes in, and they nod in assent. But Marielle will not be comforted, and becomes so paranoid that he tries to convince Michel Piccoli that his wife is having an affair with the waiter who slighted him. Just how exaggerated is Blier's portrait? "In the beginning, Blier told us nothing and there was no script," confides André Dussolier (Trois Hommes et un Couffin, Melo). "We soon realised this was not really about us, but the obsessions an actor has on a set. I always worry about trying to do my best performance ever. The more films you make, the harder it gets." "We try to invent," Michel Serrault says, "but we're an endangered species. For the time being, we lie to ourselves, but someday 'real actors' will no longer exist. We'll be replaced by hi-tech special effects and animated monsters." Describing his film as a "post-Buñuel" bordering on vaudeville, Blier has gleefully obliged his cast to indulge in their wildest dreams, no matter how puerile. Depardieu, who has a motorcycle crash on the Champs Elysées, belligerently tells the cops off; Pierre Arditti attempts to strangle a gushy matron admirer who is trailing him; Jacques François, an elderly distinguished character actor, holds up a restaurant and curses at the top of his lungs; Sami Frey steals the wheelchair of a legless war veteran and amuses himself in rush-hour traffic, feigning spastic convulsions. "Whenever actors promote their films, they always say, 'Oh, it was marvellous', whether it was or not," Blier smirks. "In this film, it's never marvellous. The actors continually ask each other: 'So, how are things?' and the answer is always the same. 'Terrible!' " At the same time, he concedes that there's an inevitable power that comes with the profession. "I purposely chose the restaurant La Maison du Caviar because I wanted to convey that actors live a charmed life - and it's true! I was once with Mastroianni in Venice and, as we were leaving Harry's Bar, he told me: 'Walk very quickly - otherwise, we're done for.' I was right behind him and watched the women fall down on their knees, left and right, as he crossed their path. That's also what an actor is, a superman." Curiously, this is one Blier film where homosexuality is a favourite topic of discussion, but women are never brought up. "Because they have much more important problems!" Blier laughs. "Like the jug of water!" In fact, only a handful of French actresses - such as Josiane Balasko, and the rarely-seen Maria Schneider of Last Tango in Paris fame - have been included in the script. "There is always some good and some bad in my characters," Blier contends. "Take Les Valseuses - they were dreadful, but there was something endearing about them as well. Actors are special cases because of their egos. They're very tender and very mean, and have a hard time listening to others. It's better if they're the ones doing the talking." Blier should know. fields.headline: Beauty and the beastly
fields.standfirst: It's gorgeous, it's Japan's biggest hit ever, and it's not Pokémon. But will prejudice against violent manga cartoons prevent us seeing Princess Mononoke?
fields.trailText: It's gorgeous, it's Japan's biggest hit ever, and it's not Pokémon. But will prejudice against violent manga cartoons prevent us seeing Princess Mononoke?
fields.body:
It's the most successful Japanese film ever made. Indeed, it's the second biggest non-English-language film in the world, behind only Italy's Life is Beautiful. Roger Ebert, America's answer to Barry Norman, called it "one of the most wondrous films I ever hope to see". Janet Maslin, recently-retired veteran critic of the New York Times, described it as "an exotically beautiful action film, amazing to behold". Over in France, Cahiers du Cinéma compared it to the Kurosawa classics Rashomon and Hidden Fortress. So why won't Britain see Princess Mononoke?

The answer may not be unconnected to the fact that Mononoke is animated. In Britain, Japanese animation is seen as either schlocky "manga" that clogs up the shelves in video stores, or the cheap factory animation that ruins children's television.

The most lucrative of these mass-produced imports, Pokémon (derived from a Game Boy cartridge), has just spawned a big screen spin-off - it's gaudy, it's jerky, and the story is well-nigh impenetrable to outsiders. Surely Japanese animation par excellence?

Mononoke might change the picture, but we'll never know. The distribution rights for the US were bought two years ago by the Disney-owned Miramax. In the UK, they were passed to Buena Vista, the Disney's distribution arm. However, Mononoke is no Disney-style film. The story, an intricate myth-allegory about the twilight of the gods in medieval Japan, is morally ambiguous and extremely violent - especially the title character, a knife-carrying, wolf-raised girl who wars on humans and would eat Disney's cutie-pie heroines for breakfast.

For its US release, Miramax hired British fantasy writer Neil Gaiman to do an English script, and produced a dubbed soundtrack voiced by Claire Danes, Billy Crudup, Gillian Anderson and Minnie Driver. The film was released in America with a PG-13 certificate, previously reserved for the toon likes of South Park.

Despite excellent reviews, Mononoke stayed marginal, earning only about $3m (its Japanese box-office, in a country with only one-tenth of the cinema screens, was about $160m). The film fared proportionately better in France, where it had a middling release with even better reviews and many packed-out audiences. Then again, France has a more open-minded attitude to Japanese animation (properly termed "anime", not "manga") than either America or Britain.

The decision not to release Mononoke here, in the view of Mark Schilling, author of Contemporary Japanese Film, denies us a chance to see a seminal piece of Japanese pop culture. "For the Japanese film industry, Princess Mononoke is a major, major movie. It demonstrated that film-makers need not appeal to the lowest common denominator to have a box-office hit. It successfully defied the industry conventional wisdom that animated films are only one element in a 'media mix' strategy. Instead of animating safe properties from other media, the director, Hayao Miyazaki, and his company developed their own ideas into a stand-alone film.

"The whole tendency of the mainstream Japanese domestic film industry is conservative and insular," Schilling continues. "Mononoke shows what one small group of creative and savvy people can accomplish by thinking outside the industry box. For world cinema, it's a stunning example of what Japanese animators can accomplish with a small fraction of a Disney animation budget, while violating many of the 'rules' Disney considers sacrosanct. There's a lesson there somewhere."

It is undoubtedly true that little is known outside Japan about its domestic animation industry. The most popular anime TV series, for example, in Japan is the never-ending Sazae-San, a gently humorous family show about a 23-year-old housewife, rivalling The Waltons for conservatism. It recently passed its 1,500th episode.

Most anime is made for children and teenagers (plus a growing population of adult fanboys) but the range is still wide. Girls' (shojo) anime is a huge category, from fluffy fantasies about magically-empowered heroines to dramas like the immensely popular Rose of Versailles, whose heroine, Lady Oscar, is the cross-dressing guardian of Marie Antoinette. Not forgetting the biggest children's icon of all, Doraemon, a friendly robot cat created by Hiroshi Fujimoto, who appeared in more than 20 movies and countless TV episodes.

Other popular anime categories include teen romances, crime capers (one of which, Lupin, made it to British video) and a ceaseless stream of sports dramas, such as Aim for the Ace! (tennis), Slam Dunk (basketball) and the hit Tomorrow's Joe (boxing).

Schilling believes Mononoke would go down well in Britain. "I don't see why not - unless Brits hate the sound of Claire Danes's voice." (Danes's flat performance as the title character was the most criticised aspect of the Miramax dub.) "But the distributor would have to mount a powerful marketing campaign to broaden the film's appeal beyond the handful of anime fans."

Japanese animation, however, is dogged by its reputation for explicit sexual and violent material. As early as 1971, Angela Carter was writing in New Society that Japanese comics "appear to be directed at either the crazed sex maniac or the dedicated surrealist... pictorial lexicons of the most ferocious imagery of desire, violence and terror, erupting amid gouts of gore, red-hot from the unconscious."

In fact, pornographic comics - including the notoriously sadistic and misogynist titles - have always been a minority in Japan. One of the first anime screened in Britain - a sci-fi adventure called Battle of the Planets - was severely edited for violence, with shootings, fist-fights and general mayhem all carefully excised.

In 1983, direct-to-video anime - known in Japan as OAVs or Original Animation Videos - began to appear. These included the notorious demon porn-horror film Overfiend (or Urotsukidoji, to give the Japanese name). A popular myth was that Overfiend is shown on Saturday-morning TV in Japan. In reality, it's a minor, adults-only video, but it was taken to be representative on its British release precisely because its content was so disgusting for a cartoon.

Can this British view ever be reversed? Interestingly, Buena Vista has bought the rights to other Miyazaki films, and two - Kiki's Delivery Service and My Neighbour Totoro - much more suitable for kids than Mononoke - are doing well on US video. However, again Disney has no plans to bring them out in Britain. Apparently there's simply no market. It seems strange, given the range of animated product in Britain this Easter. Yet in Britain at least, it seems Mononoke will remain one animated never-ran. Perhaps our island simply isn't ready for a cartoon feature with no songs, no happy endings, and a story closer to Kurosawa than Snow White.

fields.headline: Going ape
fields.standfirst: It all began with a guy in a gorilla suit: Tim Radford on the evolution of natural history movies
fields.trailText: It all began with a guy in a gorilla suit: Tim Radford on the evolution of natural history movies
fields.body:
Three years before King Kong, there was Ingagi. It was a real-life, documentary account in 1930 of an expedition into the Belgian Congo by somebody called Sir Herbert Winstead of London.

Ingagi packed the US motion-picture halls. "Has the Ape Man been Found?" ran the ads in Chicago. "Gorillas! Wild Women! Apparently Half Ape! Half Human!" Crowds came especially for the last 10 minutes of the film, which purported to show a tribal sacrifice of a woman by native Africans to a 600lb gorilla. Variety reported that the "suggestiveness" of gorilla scenes guaranteed Ingagi a "sure box office". Congo Pictures Ltd sold the rights to RKO after the film grossed $23,000 in a week at one San Francisco cinema.

The film offended American naturalists and the Hays Office - not because of the sexual innuendo or bestiality but because the gorilla scenes were quite obviously a compilation of stock orang-utan footage and a man in a gorilla suit. The film was faked at a zoo in California and the actresses were girls in what the showbiz trade used to call "blackface". The Chicago Tribune thought the cinematography so awful that it just had to be "the real thing and not a staged adventure".

Gregg Mitman, a US science historian, tells the story in a new book called Reel Nature, which makes it quite clear: violence and sex win every time, and fakes beat reality any day. Merian Cooper and Ernest Schoedsack of RKO got the message of Ingagi, hired an actress called Fay Wray and an even bigger gorilla suit and set to work on the "most awesome thriller of all time". In 1933, they sold King Kong as fiction.

But gorilla tactics began long before Ingagi. The first wildlife documentary was called Roosevelt in Africa. Made in 1910, it shows the great ex-president and naturalist Theodore Roose-velt planting a tree in Kenya, watching giraffes and hippos at play and the courtship dance of a bird. There is a scene with a serval cat, but the lion footage had to be spliced in from a still taken with a flashlight. It didn't play in Peoria. People expected to see Teddy the white hunter "slaughtering lions and tigers and wallowing in their gore".

A Chicago entrepreneur called Selig went one better. He got someone to impersonate Roosevelt, faked a scene of a lion being shot and carried away by native porters, and had a success on his hands. "There is no doubt about this lion," said the critic of Moving Picture World. "He stalks majestically about the picture, thus enabling an audience to realise how a lion would look, not on the warpath, but peaceably ambling about among natural surroundings."

That's natural history movies for you. Show life as it is, and the punters yawn. Fake some drama and you have a winner on your hands. The ultimate natural history movie - well, it is scripted and carefully cast and $800m was spent on the sound stage - is Disney's Animal Kingdom, in Florida. There, with the help of 1,000 animals, 100,000 transplanted trees and some African music on the loudspeakers, Disney's "imagineers" have synthesised the African veldt on the Florida flatlands: nature, this time round, as drama.

The actors couldn't get more authentic; the theatre itself is the fantasy. How the wildlife documentary got from Roosevelt to Disneyworld is a story of charlatans, hucksters, crooks, imaginative cameramen, brilliant zoology and shameless appeal to the sex and violence of life as cinema audiences have grown to expect it to be. Mitman, of the University of Oklahoma, tells the American version of this lurid celluloid safari. The David Attenborough tradition of real naturalists and real film footage was born out of all this - and mostly ignored. Konrad Lorenz did something called The Ethology of the Greylag Goose. Alexander Korda and Niko Tinbergen, the scientist who inspired generations of zoologists, worked with John Grierson on The Private Life of the Gannet, which raked in a net profit of £220 after an 18-month run. One of Tinbergen's book spin-offs from his filmic career pursuing seabirds was marketed in the popular press as Sex and the Single Gull.

The public wanted drama, tenderness, comedy, sex and violence - or at least a perm of any three from those five. Disney moved from Bambi and Thumper to apparently authentic crowd-pleasers of the True Life Adventure series such as Beaver Valley, Nature's Half Acre and The Living Desert. Hollywood, meanwhile, auditioned for Lassie and Rin Tin Tin. Even when the nature documentary grew up and got classy, the sales pitch carried on coarsely. Time-Life Video advertised Attenborough's The Trials of Life with a clip of killer whales snatching sea lion pups off the beach and the voice-over "See up close how the law of the jungle is kill or be killed... find out why they call them animals!"

Mitman, born in 1960, grew up on films starring Flipper the dolphin and the underwater adventures of Jacques Cousteau. They set him off on a course of marine biology and then into the history of science, from which vantage point he began to see how movies had shaped his own attitudes towards nature.

Meanwhile, out there in the real world, a huge tragedy is taking place. Most of the megafauna movie stars are being extinguished, or are surviving only in national parks and reserves. That is why he prefaces his book about nature on film with a visit to Disney's Animal Kingdom.

"There is something very troubling about what that says about our kind of relationship to nature," he writes. "It may be the only way it can exist - that is the more chilling side. I remember hearing a story a couple of years ago. I was talking to primatologists about an effort to create a CD-rom library of primate behaviour, and the justification was so they could study these animals even when they had become extinct. To me that is a chilling statement about where we might be headed. The future is maybe us making nature films in Disney's Animal Kingdom."

 Reel Nature: America's Romance with Wildlife on Film, by Gregg Mitman (Harvard, £18.50).
