There, with the help of 1,000 animals, 100,000 transplanted trees and some African music on the loudspeakers, Disney's "imagineers" have synthesised the African veldt on the Florida flatlands: nature, this time round, as drama. The actors couldn't get more authentic; the theatre itself is the fantasy. How the wildlife documentary got from Roosevelt to Disneyworld is a story of charlatans, hucksters, crooks, imaginative cameramen, brilliant zoology and shameless appeal to the sex and violence of life as cinema audiences have grown to expect it to be. Mitman, of the University of Oklahoma, tells the American version of this lurid celluloid safari. The David Attenborough tradition of real naturalists and real film footage was born out of all this - and mostly ignored. Konrad Lorenz did something called The Ethology of the Greylag Goose. Alexander Korda and Niko Tinbergen, the scientist who inspired generations of zoologists, worked with John Grierson on The Private Life of the Gannet, which raked in a net profit of £220 after an 18-month run. One of Tinbergen's book spin-offs from his filmic career pursuing seabirds was marketed in the popular press as Sex and the Single Gull. The public wanted drama, tenderness, comedy, sex and violence - or at least a perm of any three from those five. Disney moved from Bambi and Thumper to apparently authentic crowd-pleasers of the True Life Adventure series such as Beaver Valley, Nature's Half Acre and The Living Desert. Hollywood, meanwhile, auditioned for Lassie and Rin Tin Tin. Even when the nature documentary grew up and got classy, the sales pitch carried on coarsely. Time-Life Video advertised Attenborough's The Trials of Life with a clip of killer whales snatching sea lion pups off the beach and the voice-over "See up close how the law of the jungle is kill or be killed... find out why they call them animals!" Mitman, born in 1960, grew up on films starring Flipper the dolphin and the underwater adventures of Jacques Cousteau. They set him off on a course of marine biology and then into the history of science, from which vantage point he began to see how movies had shaped his own attitudes towards nature. Meanwhile, out there in the real world, a huge tragedy is taking place. Most of the megafauna movie stars are being extinguished, or are surviving only in national parks and reserves. That is why he prefaces his book about nature on film with a visit to Disney's Animal Kingdom. "There is something very troubling about what that says about our kind of relationship to nature," he writes. "It may be the only way it can exist - that is the more chilling side. I remember hearing a story a couple of years ago. I was talking to primatologists about an effort to create a CD-rom library of primate behaviour, and the justification was so they could study these animals even when they had become extinct. To me that is a chilling statement about where we might be headed. The future is maybe us making nature films in Disney's Animal Kingdom."  Reel Nature: America's Romance with Wildlife on Film, by Gregg Mitman (Harvard, £18.50).

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Run Lola Run | Felicia's Journey | Romance
fields.trailText: Run Lola Run | Felicia's Journey | Romance
fields.body:
Run Lola Run
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Columbia Tristar Cert 15
****

The most urgent film you'll see all year: Breathless would have been the ideal title but Godard bagged it years ago. Simple but very stylish, Run Lola Run imprints itself on the retina. The cinema has always loved a race against time and, in Germany's biggest hit for many years, Tom Tykwer gives you three for the price of one.

It kicks off with Lola receiving a frantic phone call from her boyfriend, who has left a bag containing 100,000 marks on the tube and has 20 minutes to replace it or risk serious damage from his underworld boss. Cue Lola's mercy dash, set to a pulsating score, also by director Tykwer, that's like a heartbeat.

Like Groundhog Day and Sliding Doors, this gives you alternative plots, depending on tiny changes in Lola's race against time, and wraps it all up inside 80 minutes. The star (Franka Potente) has an incredible pumping running style, brilliantly displayed by Tykwer's hyperactive camera. She does more running than acting but with the assistance of a bucketload of henna, makes a charismatic presence with a scream that can break glass (echoing The Tin Drum from the German cinema's 70s heyday).

Lola was nominated for a Bafta but Potente might have been put forward for a 400 metres gold too. Tykwer has other tricks: a cartoon running Lola links scenes, and passers-by whose lives interact with her Berlin sprint get a life history in stills that flash by in seconds. An exhilarating original and with very little dialogue, subtitleophobes needn't worry.

Felicia's Journey
Rental and DVD (£15.99)
Warner Cert 12
***

Not quite a match for his last two films, Exotica and The Sweet Hereafter, but another sombre, thoughtful and largely satisfying film from Atom Egoyan, featuring a creepily effective performance from Bob Hoskins. Hoskins underplays as effectively as Ian Holm did in The Sweet Hereafter.

He plays a slow-talking Brummie in a Morris Minor who helps a pregnant, homeless Irish girl searching for her boyfriend. Teenager Elaine Cassidy is convincing as Felicia, who is told by her father, "You're carrying the enemy within you", after being impregnated. It's unsettling, echoes a lot of Egoyan themes - alienation, grief and the inability to escape the past - and is pieced together with skill and economy in the Canadian director's multi-layered, unflinching style. It might not please viewers in Birmingham, as a glowingly green Ireland is contrasted with a desperately grey Midlands full of gasometers and car parks.

Romance
Rental, retail (£16.99) and DVD (£19.99)
Blue Light Cert 18
***

Famous for the graphic nature of its sex scenes, as with The Idiots, it seems you can show much more if it's in a subtitled art film. Romance is stuffed with sex - though there's no hint of the "joy of" - it's about nothing else. It includes endlessly provocative statements from Caroline Ducey, the lead actress, from whose point of view we see everything, and whose voiceover comments on the action.

The film is a rare chance to get an uninhibited female view of sex, a topic Hollywood steers well clear of. The result, however, seems uncomfortably close to an archetypal male view of a mixed-up, sexed-up woman, eager to be exploited. Here are some of Ducey's statements: "I don't love the guys who screw me. I detest them"; "Why do the men who disgust us understand us better than the one we love"; "Love between men and women is impossible". There's even: "Maybe I want to meet Jack the Ripper."

It's hard to imagine a male writer getting away with putting words like these in a woman's mouth without a storm of protest. French writer-director Catherine Breillat gives Ducey a husband she loves who won't have sex, hence the penises in best supporting roles. But the shocking visuals come later on - a gynaecological examination and a birth so physical you feel exhausted just watching.

webTitle: To live and die in law-school

fields.headline: To live and die in law-school
fields.trailText: One legal thriller gets knocked off its chart-topping perch and is replaced by another legal thriller. Which prompts the question: is this all because of an influx of Ivy League law-school grads from back east, who flooded into Hollywood from the late 1980s onwards?
fields.body:
One legal thriller gets knocked off its chart-topping perch and is replaced by another legal thriller. Which prompts the question: is this all because of an influx of Ivy League law-school grads from back east, who flooded into Hollywood from the late 1980s onwards?

These people were once content to stay in Manhattan and pollute Wall Street but, at some point, they realised that all the heavy cash was out here in California, lying in the streets, growing on trees and falling from the blue, blue skies. All you needed was a law degree. And so they came...

Old-timers in Hollywood didn't go to law school. Raoul Walsh served his apprenticeship by getting caught up in the Mexican revolution, losing an eye, and playing John Wilkes Booth in Birth of a Nation. Nicholas Ray was a junkie, a musical researcher in the south (he was friends with Leadbelly), and a committed political activist before his move west. Roman Polanski spent half his childhood running from the Nazis. The German exiles - Lang, Wilder, Ulmer, et al - arrived in LA with nothing, having fled the very real possibility of dying in concentration camps.

Even the old-time studio heads had to overcome formidable obstacles such as poverty and profound anti-semitism before they could build empires and start acting like bastards themselves. And did they have law degrees? Did they bollocks.

I'm not saying that the absence of legal qualifications among the participants is the reason they all made great movies, but I bet it helped. After all, given the choice, would you prefer to see White Heat, In a Lonely Place, Rosemary's Baby and Sunset Boulevard - or The Client, The Rainmaker, The Firm, The Chamber, A Few Good Men, My Cousin Vinnie and The Devil's Advocate? (If you prefer the latter group, why are you bothering to read this?)

The first list comes from a time when artistic impulses and life experience enriched the movies, the second is a testament to the fact that most quasi-artistic impulses are now directed toward deal-making and marketing campaigns, not toward the movies themselves. And the now horribly familiar lawyer-hero seems to have become a projection of the producer's ideal self.

Actually, having made all these insane generalisations, I have to admit that both Erin Brockovich and Rules of Engagement, its replacement at the top of the chart, are a cut above the garden-variety Grisham-isms of the aforementioned titles.

Rules of Engagement has ageing enfant terrible and former movie-brat William Friedkin - no lawyer he - at the helm, and the ever dependable Tommy Lee Jones and Samuel L Jackson on the marquee. Jackson is the bemedalled war hero who finds himself accused of 83 counts of murder after opening fire on a hostile Arab crowd during the evacuation of the US Embassy in Yemen, and Jones is the ex-drunk combat pal he hires to defend him at his court martial.

Friedkin leavens the legalese with two excellent, horrifying action sequences, the first a flashback to Vietnam in 1968, the second the disastrous embassy massacre. Neither they, nor the rock-solid performances by the leads (and by the ferrety Guy Pearce), are enough to make Rules of Engagement a really good movie (like Erin Brockovich) but the time passes swiftly enough.

I got to meet Friedkin last summer on the Rules set at Paramount Studios. To be honest, I wasn't that anxious to do so because, although I've seen French Connection so often I can lip-synch the whole thing (including the car-chase) and think his To Live and Die in LA is one of the best movies ever made about this town, I'd also just read Peter Biskind's scabrous account of Hollywood in the 1970s, Easy Riders and Raging Bulls.

Biskind depicts Friedkin as far and away the brattiest of the movie brats, all Vesuvian tantrums and Himalayan ego, insanely demanding, hard on the help and harder still on his womenfolk. But the man I huddled with between takes could have been a totally different person. The rail-thin peacock of the 70s was a little plumper, but the expensive haircut and tailoring still conveyed the impression of sleekness, and there was none of the vehement, cocksure tone that characterised his utterances back when he was Whelp No 1.

He wasn't prepared to discuss Biskind - he blanched a little when I mentioned it - but otherwise he was a dream host. He walked me over to the sound stage where Welles made Citizen Kane - a holy of holies for both of us - and later introduced me to Jackson, a magnificent modern-day Hannibal in his Marine corps uniform, and to Jones, who just looked psychopathic.

Friedkin beamed like a schoolgirl when I told him how much I admired To Live and Die in LA. With its counterfeiting, lawless lawmen and super-saturation of greed and vice, and given Friedkin's experiences in this city (he could use the same title for his autobiography), it's always seemed like a personal manifesto. "My own internal landscape certainly matches the one in the movie very closely," he said a little dourly, "perhaps because I think that life in general, not just my movies, is a moral wasteland."

His next project is Night Train, a biopic of hard-luck heavyweight champ Sonny Liston. There was a whiff of Friedkin's own life in his summary of Liston's. "He was desperate to be the best and, against all the odds, he pulled it off for a while, but he was never accepted by the public. And that's not something you can train for."

Elsewhere this week the studios were clearing out the last few small movies before the spring release schedule fills up with big-budget nonsense next weekend. James Toback's new hip-hop movie Black and White didn't make the chart, but anything Toback does is worth watching. As the director himself pointed out, people leave his movies talking, arguing, fighting - provoked and enlivened by what they've seen. Plus, in Black and White you get to see Robert Downey Jr get bitch-slapped by none other than Mike Tyson.

That's gotta be worth $7.50, unlike the shit-obsessed wrestling comedy Ready to Rumble at number six, which earned atrocious reviews all round, or Return to Me, a romantic comedy starring the ultra-bland David Duchovny and Minnie Driver, which I do not plan to endure.

Bring on next weekend, which sees the release of Ridley Scott's Gladiator and Mary Harron's American Psycho. Colosseums and chainsaws...I like this menu already.

fields.trailText: Not for the first time we confused the two American congressional bodies that once elicited testimony on purported communists in US public life, When America was well red, page 6, Friday Review, April 7. The director Elia Kazan "betrayed his Hollywood comrades" not to Joseph McCarthy, who ran the Senate's investigations sub-committee from 1952-54, but to the House of Representatives' committee on un-American activities (Huac), a far more long running and deeply rooted entity. It was to the latter committee that most whistle-blowing was done.
fields.body:
Not for the first time we confused the two American congressional bodies that once elicited testimony on purported communists in US public life, When America was well red, page 6, Friday Review, April 7. The director Elia Kazan "betrayed his Hollywood comrades" not to Joseph McCarthy, who ran the Senate's investigations sub-committee from 1952-54, but to the House of Representatives' committee on un-American activities (Huac), a far more long running and deeply rooted entity. It was to the latter committee that most whistle-blowing was done.

In a piece about the British Library's acquisition of Laurence Olivier's archive, page 11, April 6, one item mentioned was the late actor's RAF logbook. To clarify, while most wartime logbooks were RAF issue, Olivier served in the Fleet Air Arm.

Contrary to our report on page 11, April 8, the BBC's director general, Greg Dyke, did not as a young man work as a race relations officer for Wandsworth borough council in London. Rather he was, in the 70s, on the staff of an independent body, Wandsworth Council for Community Relations.

The name of Zimbabwe's leading opposition figure was garbled in a comment piece on page 22, April 5. He is Morgan Tsvangirai.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: Capital enters Border battle
fields.trailText: Capital Radio yesterday entered the contest for control of Border Television with an agreed £146m offer for the company.
fields.body:
Capital Radio yesterday entered the contest for control of Border Television with an agreed £146m offer for the company.

The bid pulled the rug from under Scottish Radio Holdings which had hoped to win the recommendation of Border directors by increasing its own offer from £114m to £141m earlier this week. The Scottish Radio board is meeting this weekend to decide whether it should come back with another offer.

David Mansfield, Capital chief executive, described the acquisition of Border as the "perfect deal" for the company. Capital has the irrevocable backing from 25.3% of Border shareholders including local newspaper business CN Group.

"Capital's strategy is an open book," Mr Mansfield said. "We are a radio group and we want to grow our analogue business in the UK. This adds the north east, north west and east midlands, all very large licences with very good growth prospects."

Capital is offering 92 shares for every 100 from Border with a cash alternative of £13 a share. During the day however, the value of Capital's paper offer plunged from £13.52 to £12.35 as its own share price slumped by 8%.

Scottish Radio's offer of five shares for every six in Border was yesterday worth £12.50.

Analysts said the volatility of the market meant the cash offer could be key. Scottish Radio's current bid has a cash alternative of £12.75.

Paul Corley, Border chief executive said his board was fully behind the Capital bid. "Capital recognised the strength of the business going forward and is very good at building radio brands," he said.

Capital said it intended to keep Border's television interests and would leave the current management team in place. The expectation is that it will dispose of the business after the next Broadcasting Act which is likely to alter the limits governing media ownership, due in 2001.

Mr Mansfield shrugged off suggestions that Capital was overpaying. "We are pretty good at valuing radio stations and have a track record of growing the audiences of recent acquisitions. We haven't suddenly thrown our principles away."

Shares in Border climbed 35p to £13.17.

fields.headline: Rage Software
fields.trailText: Rage Software did little to calm a nervous computer games sector yesterday when it announced a £6.4m fundraising and strategic shift that will wipe out a forecast £5m pre-tax profit.
fields.body:
Rage Software did little to calm a nervous computer games sector yesterday when it announced a £6.4m fundraising and strategic shift that will wipe out a forecast £5m pre-tax profit.

In the six months to December 31, Rage made a pre-tax loss of £641,000, against a profit of £610,000 a year before, on a turnover of £2.7m, down from £3.1m.

Investors already reeling from two recent Eidos profits warnings marked the shares down 11% to 48.5p, 1.5p below the price at which the 13.5m new shares are being issued. A month ago Rage shares, which have enjoyed a good run over the past year and become a bulletin board favourite, were trading at 80p.

But house broker Teather & Greenwood is adamant the strategic shift has been misinterpreted and the shares oversold. fields.trailText: The acting head of the IMF defended globalisation as Washington braced itself for Seattle-style protests. Stanley Fischer said it could become a dirty word but that the process was the only way to raise incomes around the world. "Trying to stop it will make people worse off rather than better off," he said.

The acting head of the IMF defended globalisation as Washington braced itself for Seattle-style protests. Stanley Fischer said it could become a dirty word but that the process was the only way to raise incomes around the world. "Trying to stop it will make people worse off rather than better off," he said.

Both the IMF and World Bank have been nettled by claims that globalisation and liberalisation harm the poorest nations. Mr Fischer said: "We have the same goals as the demonstrators... to reduce poverty all over the world."

webTitle: MPs reject IMF attack on Brown's Budget

fields.headline: MPs reject IMF attack on Brown's Budget
fields.trailText: Backbench MPs yesterday backed Gordon Brown in his row with the International Monetary Fund over whether the March Budget boosted inflationary pressures.
fields.body:
Backbench MPs yesterday backed Gordon Brown in his row with the International Monetary Fund over whether the March Budget boosted inflationary pressures.

But the Treasury committee criticised the chancellor for obscuring the impact on the tax burden of benefit changes, especially the £4bn working families tax credit.

MPs backed Mr Brown's claim that the Budget tightened fiscal policy over the next two years compared to the 1999 Budget forecast, easing pressure on the Bank of England to slow the economy by raising borrowing costs.

On Wednesday the IMF claimed the Budget would stoke growth and inflation, describing it as "regrettably pro-cyclical", a charge the Treasury rejects.

The cross-party committee agreed with the Treasury assessment: "The fiscal stance will be tighter in 2000-01 and 2001-02 than forecast in Budget 99." However, in the longer term the Treasury was set to loosen the purse strings.

The committee rebuked the Treasury over the way it accounted for the new working families tax credit in the Budget and demanded a review of the way it is presented. At present, the WFTC shows on the tax side of the Treasury's balance sheet, as a tax cut. Its predecessor, family credit, went in the spending columns as a benefit. That lowers the tax burden, which by the committee's estimates is rising.

 The argument over whether the government could have helped talk down the pound by reining in its spending was reignited yesterday by the CBI. Its director, Digby Jones, said 30,000 jobs had been lost in the tourism industry because the strength of sterling was making Britain expensive for overseas visitors.

"The government must ensure that businesses have as great a chance as possible of being successful. That means not taking risks with inflation by over-reacting to pressure to raise public spending, such as we saw with the recent Budget."

fields.headline: Meacher rules out water mergers
fields.standfirst: Domestic consumers miss out in competition plan
fields.trailText: Government plans to increase competition within the water industry are unlikely to affect domestic consumers for some years, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Government plans to increase competition within the water industry are unlikely to affect domestic consumers for some years, it emerged yesterday.

Michael Meacher, the environment minister, revealed that only industrial and commercial users would benefit from measures the government plans to introduce.

This would enable the health, safety and environmental problems to be identified and solved before competition was extended to the domestic market.

Mr Meacher also poured cold water on company hopes that the next director general of Ofwat, the industry watchdog, would take a more favourable attitude towards mergers within the industry. "We do not think it right to dispense with or modify the current merger provisions," he said.

Ian Byatt, who has bitterly opposed takeovers in the industry, steps down in July. Mr Meacher said that Mr Byatt's successor would be announced within the next couple of weeks.

The government's green paper on competition in the water industry in England and Wales, published yesterday, invites comment on options for making the industry more competitive.

These include expansion of common carriage, which allows companies to supply a customer using a rival's pipe network, and a new licensing regime to make it easier for companies to enter the market.

It accepts that there will be an increased risk of "operational failures" including lowering of water quality as more organisations use the same pipelines, and stresses the need for a system to establish where legal responsibilities lie.

The green paper also has a set of "more radical options" which include restructuring the industry to separate the monopoly elements such as underground pipes and treatment works from competitive activities such as supply and service, as has been done in the gas and electricity sectors.

The government has decided to allow more big water users, including large hospitals, to get supplies from companies other than their local water company. The threshold for such deals has been cut from 250m litres to 100m litres a year.

The industry was disappointed that after a long review, the government had not come up with firmer proposals.

Chris Mellor, managing director of Anglian Water, said that Mr Meacher had missed an opportunity by keeping the lid on mergers.

He said that a smaller number of water companies, with the ability to compete with each other, could realise economies of scale, reduce prices, and promote competition.

webTitle: Boots seen as new Marks & Spencer

fields.headline: Boots seen as new Marks & Spencer
fields.trailText: Boots has had a rough ride over the past two years. The company makes all the right noises about trading, talks tough about the threat posed by the likes of Wal-Mart and is wading in with ventures such as its Advantage smart card, its Handbag.com e-commerce business and this week's joint venture with the Pru's Egg banking offshoot to launch a credit card.
fields.body:
Boots has had a rough ride over the past two years. The company makes all the right noises about trading, talks tough about the threat posed by the likes of Wal-Mart and is wading in with ventures such as its Advantage smart card, its Handbag.com e-commerce business and this week's joint venture with the Pru's Egg banking offshoot to launch a credit card.

But the shares are in dire need of the sort of tonic that Boots the Chemist stocks on its dietary supplement shelves. There is much talk that Boots has more than just a touch of the Marks & Spencer about it. A couple of years ago that would have been an accolade, but no longer. The comparison now conjures up images of an old established, patriarchal retailer which is less nifty on its feet than it might be and is a touch arrogant.

From a high of £10.55 some 15 months ago the shares have slumped to little over 500p - a level last seen in 1995.

According to brokers Credit Suisse First Boston, worse is to come. Yesterday CSFB analysts urged Boots investors to sell, on the ground that the shares are heading down to 400p - the price they were at the start of the 1990s. The CSFB analysts say their latest research "questions the sustainability of BTC's operating and financial ratios".

These, they say, include a declining number of customer transactions and falling market share "in important categories such as over-the-counter medicines and toiletries".

Chairman Lord Blyth has been very bullish on the threat posed by the supermarkets to his traditional business. His customers are loyal, he has said. They will stick with Boots.

But CSFB says that grocery retailers are taking far more of Boots' traditional business than previously thought. It reckons that even partial abolition of resale price maintenance on medicines would benefit the supermarkets.

CSFB points out that 90% of Boots group profits come from BTC's operations, so a slight downturn has a huge effect. Despite the recent share price decline, say the analysts, the downside risk has still not been fully discounted.

fields.headline: Passing the buck at Arcadia
fields.standfirst: Too many brands for same shoppers
fields.trailText: Arcadia's plight, so chief executive John Hoerner would have us believe, is everyone's fault but its own. He blames everything from the amount of new out of-town retail space to savage discounting and the inability of male shoppers to buy clothes without advice from their womenfolk for his group's slide into the red.
fields.body:
Arcadia's plight, so chief executive John Hoerner would have us believe, is everyone's fault but its own. He blames everything from the amount of new out of-town retail space to savage discounting and the inability of male shoppers to buy clothes without advice from their womenfolk for his group's slide into the red.

This is a group with an annual turnover of £2bn. It has approaching 2,000 high-street outlets and more than £1 out of every £10 spent on clothes by British shoppers is in one of his shops.

It also owns 50% of Zoom - an e-commerce joint venture with the Daily Mail's publishers Associated Newspapers - which for almost every other business spells value. And although most of the group's shops are rented, it still owns the flagship store at 214 Oxford Street, which is reckoned to be worth £200m.

But the shares are now changing hands at less than 50p, and the group is valued at just £88m.

Yesterday, as he axed Arcadia's dividend, Mr Hoerner even managed to lay part of the blame for the group's woes at the door of Sir Ralph Halpern, who left the company in 1990. "One of the reasons we are suffering today is a decision taken ten years ago to sell off all our stores and reinvest the money elsewhere," he said.

It is true that the middle market in which Arcadia operates has been hit by the toughest of trading conditions. They have taken their toll on other retailers too - Marks & Spencer for one. But not all have suffered to the same extent - look no further than Next.

Arcadia, which is now one of the most lowly valued retailers in Europe, insists it has done nothing wrong. Mr Hoerner still says he did not overpay when he handed £150m to Philip Green for the womenswear stores that were once part of the Sears empire. With hindsight, he says, the timing might have been better.

Actually, with hindsight, the price should have been a lot lower.

Even with his shiny new BrandMax strategy to restructure the business -which will mean one in four of his stores pulling down the shutters - Arcadia will have 14 high-street brands. The company has collected fascias with the same enthusiam as a bargain hunter at a car-boot sale. No matter, says Arcadia, they are all run independently and they can all be profitable.

But many are so close to each other in their target markets it is hard to see how they can avoid taking customers from each other. At best it must make the decision where to concentrate scarce resources most efficently almost impossible. Mr Hoerner has been criticised for not taking decisive action more quickly, and says he has never even considered stepping down.

His chairman Adam Broadbent is his chief cheerleader. "You need the best team you can get, especially in these circumstances, and that is what we have under John's leadership," he said yesterday. No shareholders or bankers have voiced any concerns about Mr Hoerner's position, added the chairman.

Frankly, that is a worry in itself. If institutional shareholders can sit back and watch the value of an investment dwindle from 450p to less than 50p without any worries whatsoever, then they are failing in their duty.

Catching up

BT is certainly prepared to splash the cash these days. Not only has it become the first company to offer more than £5bn for one of the third generation mobile phone licences being auctioned but it is planning on spending £4bn over the next three years expanding its European backbone network.

The European drive is part of a wide-ranging restructuring at BT which the company describes as radical and which will help it to ride the crest of the next wave in communications.

Critics however wonder if the changes might not be too little too late.

True enough the division of the UK fixed business into wholesale and retail should help provide sharper operational and regulatory focus. The creation of four new business units in high growth sectors and the planned flotation of the directories and e-commerce business, Yell, may help investors gain a better understanding of the underlying value of the company than that implied by the recent share price performance.

Yet it is hard to avoid the feeling that BT, rather than leading the way, is now having to run quickly just to catch up with some of the competition. Deutsche Telekom, for example, is already well advanced in its plans to float its internet and has pencilled in an initial public offering for the mobile phone business for later in the year.

There was disappointment in some quarters, too, that only Yell is definitely on the stocks for a listing this year though BT is clear that the structure will help it float others in due course.

What BT has to show is that it has the capacity for vision and innovation as well as a strong balance sheet. Otherwise shareholders might, rightly, become impatient.

webTitle: Aid fails to dent global poverty

fields.headline: Aid fails to dent global poverty
fields.standfirst: Half world's population lives on $2 a day
fields.trailText: The World Bank admitted yesterday that the goal of halving global poverty over the next 15 years would prove daunting as it unveiled figures showing half the world's population survives on less than $2 a day.
fields.body:
The World Bank admitted yesterday that the goal of halving global poverty over the next 15 years would prove daunting as it unveiled figures showing half the world's population survives on less than $2 a day.

James Wolfensohn, the bank's president, said higher levels of growth, a halt to rising inequality, and action to tackle the spread of Aids were vital if the target of cutting the number of people in absolute poverty to 14.5% by 2015 was to be met.

Mr Wolfensohn said the percentage of people in poverty had fallen from 28% to 24% in recent years, but the increase in population meant the actual number of people in poverty had stayed the same.

The bank's world development indicators, released yesterday, showed that a sixth of the earth's population - primarily those in North America, Europe and Japan - received nearly 80% of world income, an average of $70 a day. Meanwhile, the 57% of the world's population in the 63 poorest countries received only 6% of world income, an average of less than $2 a day.

Mr Wolfensohn said the scale of the challenge varied from region to region, but the overall task was "very daunting", particularly in Africa, the Middle East and Latin America, and that the provision of universal education would be crucial to attacking poverty.

"I think if we can do things like education, if we can attack the health issues, and if we can deal in countries with the legal structures and the social structures, then we have a chance of doing it. But I do not underestimate how big this challenge is going to be. It is going to be enormous."

The bank's indicators revealed that the number of people surviving on less than $1 a day has remained steady at 1.2bn since 1987. The proportion of underweight children - a measure of malnutrition - fell from 32% to 27% during the 1990s. "Such progress is encouraging, but slower than hoped for," the bank said

It said most countries had succeeded in reducing infant and under-5 mortality rates, but that between 1990 and 1998 13 countries experienced worsening rates; many of these were in Africa where civil strife and the spread of HIV/Aids compounded the effects of poverty.

Mr Wolfensohn said curbing the spread of Aids had become "a major development challenge, if not the most important development challenge facing us in Africa today".

According to the bank, 50m people have now been infected with the virus, of whom 34m are still alive. About 23m of them live in Africa. It said there were five countries with infection rates of over 20% and 21 with rates above 7%, and that growth rates in those nations would fall by 0.4% a year.

"Life expectancy is now declining in a host of countries after decades of progress. In several nations it is already 10 years shorter because of HIV/Aids," said. "In the hardest hit countries such as Botswana and Zimbabwe, it will soon be 17 years shorter than it would otherwise have been."

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Peter Davis yesterday got his first chance to announce supermarket sales figures and good they were too. J Sainsbury saw a healthy 7.2% increase in the 12 weeks to April which included a strong performance from Homebase.
fields.body:
Peter Davis yesterday got his first chance to announce supermarket sales figures and good they were too. J Sainsbury saw a healthy 7.2% increase in the 12 weeks to April which included a strong performance from Homebase.

But the man from the Pru turned Sainsbury chief executive failed to impress a sceptical City and the country's second largest supermarket saw its shares fall 7p on the day to end at 325p.

Some analysts expressed disappointment that the real "Peter Davis" effect had so far failed to materialise. Given he has only been in his post for a month this is not surprising. More worrying is a belief in some quarters that the underlying trend on sales continues to be on the decline. By contrast Safeway was up 6p higher at 216p after WestLB Panmure said the food retailer offered better recovery prospects than its larger rival.

This helped the FTSE 100 index limp into positive territory late in the day. It closed 6.2 points higher at 6,357, well off its 6,381.9 high, but above earlier lows of 6,268.4.

All the other indexes registered losses and it was another miserable session for the technology sector, with Techmark down 174 at 3,719.84. This was not helped by the Nasdaq index in the US recording its second biggest points fall ever on Wednesday.

Overall trading volume on the London market was a healthy 1.493bn shares in 114,418 transactions. It was swollen by another day of active trading in FTSE 100 index heavyweight Vodafone Airtouch (up 11p at 323p) with over 300m shares changing hands.

However, UK blue chips remained cautious overall, with dealers noting that the predominant emotion in the market remained fear. J Sainsbury saw a healthy 7.2% increase in the 12 weeks to April which included a strong performance from Homebase. fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Courtaulds jobs at risk
fields.body:
Courtaulds jobs at risk

Courtaulds was last night on the brink of shutting two of its lingerie factories in the Midlands and Northern Ireland, with the loss of over 300 jobs.

The company said it was about to start consultations to see if there were "any realistic alternatives" to closing its factories in Derby and in Markethill, Co Armagh. The Derby closure would affect all 252 workers, although some functions and about 40 jobs could be moved to a sister factory at Selston, Courtaulds said.

The Markethill closure would mean the loss of all 116 jobs.

Pound hits manufacturing

Manufacturers are increasingly worried about the impact of the pound on overseas orders, the British Chambers of Commerce warned yesterday.

"Confidence in domestic and export market growth in coming months has slipped," it said in its quarterly survey of the economy, which showed that manufacturing growth is cooling. It said a further decline was expected in coming months. "This is another warning signal on sterling for both the government and the Bank of England," it said.

Hardest hit was Northern Ireland, which is the most exposed to competition from the euro.

Preussag may want Thomson

The prospect of an all-German battle for control of Thomson Travel loomed yesterday, as Europe's biggest holiday operator Preussag refused to rule out a bid for the company.

Thomson is already fighting off a £1.45bn takeover bid from C&N Touristic, Germany's second largest tour company.

Reports yesterday suggested Preussag was interested - an idea which most observers had ruled out on competition grounds. To launch an offer for Thomson, Preussag would have to sell its 50.1% stake in Thomas Cook, a move most analysts view as unlikely.

Vodafone chief for board

Vodafone chief executive Chris Gent and finance chief Ken Hydon are among four Vodafone representatives who have been invited to join Mannesmann's supervisory board. The other two are chairman Lord MacLaurin of Knebworth and German-based lawyer Wilhelm Haarmaan.

A Dusseldorf court is this week expected to rule on whether they may join the board.

Versailles report due

PriceWaterhouse Coopers, the receivers for the collapsed trade finance group Versailles, have called a creditors' meeting for Wednesday.

It is thought the creditors will be told that the outlook for recovering large amounts of money is not encouraging. The creditors may form a committee to represent their interests and should Versailles prove impossible to salvage a liquidator may be appointed to distribute any money left after the banks have been paid.

webTitle: Govan bids too high in MoD ferry contest

fields.headline: Govan bids too high in MoD ferry contest
fields.trailText: A German shipbuilder has undercut a British bid to build new ferries for the Ministry of Defence, unions were told yesterday.
fields.body:
A German shipbuilder has undercut a British bid to build new ferries for the Ministry of Defence, unions were told yesterday.

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers confirmed the setback when he met unions which are alarmed at the prospect the Govan shipyard in Glasgow being beaten in the battle for the MoD order.

He said he would do everything in his power to keep the contract within the British shipbuilding industry, union leaders said.

However, a Glasgow firm was last night reported to be part of the consortium undercutting the Govan bid. Reports named the firm as Andrew Weir Shipping.

Five British yards are expected to join the race for another contract, to build two MoD landing ships worth £130m. The MoD is expected to confirm today that yards in Glasgow, Birkenhead, Belfast, Tyneside and north Devon will be invited to tender for the vessels, which are due to enter service in 2004.

Govan's owner, BAE Systems, is involved in a consortium which is one of four bidding for the contract to build six roll-on roll-off ferries.

There has been speculation that the order for four ships might be spread around the British yards involved in the other consortiums, including Harland and Wolff in Belfast, Cammell Laird on Merseyside and Swan Hunter on Tyneside, instead of going solely to Govan.

Danny Carrigan, Scottish secretary of the AEEU engineering union, said after the meeting with Mr Byers: "He advised us that there is a German concern, and they are cheaper." However, Mr Byers had not verified reports that the German bid undercut the British one by as much as 50%.

Mr Carrigan said the union side was satisfied that Mr Byers was aware of the importance of the order to Britain's shipbuilding industry. "He is looking very closely to ensure there is a level playing field."

Mr Byers had agreed to meet unions next week when the he travels to Edinburgh for the annual conference of the Scottish Trades Union Congress.

The MoD order, worth up to £1bn over 20 years, is being fought over by four consortiums. The six ferries - four of them to be newly built- would be supplied, maintained and operated by the winning bidder, but made available to the MoD at its request whenever the need arises. PA

fields.headline: Government clips City regulator's wings
fields.trailText: The government was forced yesterday to clip severely the wings of the City's chief regulator, Howard Davies, executive chairman of the Financial Services Authority (FSA).
fields.body:
The government was forced yesterday to clip severely the wings of the City's chief regulator, Howard Davies, executive chairman of the Financial Services Authority (FSA).

After opposition from Conservative and Liberal Democrat peers, the Treasury agreed to subject the authority to the requirements of a limited company rather than those of a "body corporate".

The government also suffered a five-vote defeat when the opposition parties combined to insist that the FSA be required, if appropriate, to hand out ex-gratia payments when a valid complaint has been made against the FSA.

Conservatives and Liberal Democrats believe the watchdog needs to be more accountable and fear that if it is given too much power London's competitiveness as a financial centre could be threatened.

Despite earlier opposition, the government agreed in principle yesterday that the role of the FSA chairman and chief executive needs to be more distinct. Ministers also accepted that it would be possible in future for the role of FSA chairman and chief executive to be split. Mr Davies will also be expected to have a large element of non-executive scrutiny at board level.

Earlier, Mr Davies had said there were no examples in the international world of a regulator reporting to a non-executive part-time chairman. He fears his status would suffer in comparison to that of Eddie George, governor of the Bank of England.

In the Lords, the government accepted that the FSA should operate under the Companies Act and that it would be required to comply with the generally accepted principles of corporate good governance.

webTitle: Yes. No. Don't know...  Charles Saatchi in his own (sparing) words

fields.headline: Yes. No. Don't know...  Charles Saatchi in his own (sparing) words
fields.trailText: Charles Saatchi refused Gordon Burn's request for an interview for this series, but agreed to answer a few questions by fax...
fields.body:
Charles Saatchi refused Gordon Burn's request for an interview for this series, but agreed to answer a few questions by fax...

Gordon Burn: "Blame Charles Saatchi." That's what Damien says about the scale of the Stroud space and the empire he is very astutely building. Is there any element of competition between you?

Charles Saatchi: No.

GB: I've been told you see art history as going: Pollock - Warhol - Hirst. True?

CS: Yes.

GB: Where does the secret of Damien Hirst's genius lie?

CS: On his pillow.

GB: There were probably three cubists, four abstract expressionists, three pop artists. How many YBAs [young British artists] will there be?

CS: Don't know.

GB: What is the most recent gossip you've heard about Charles Saatchi?

CS: He'd been shot dead in Miami. But it turned out that was Versace.

GB: "He just doesn't like anything to be said about him that isn't incredibly bland praise." [Art critic Matthew Collings] True?

CS: True.

GB: In your 1994 Turner Prize speech, you said young British art might be vulgar sometimes, but then aren't we all? When was the last time you were knowingly vulgar? Is driving a Roller vulgar?

CS: a) Too often; b) Very.

GB: "Charles Saatchi really is the single most powerful force in the rise of British art, more than any artist." True or false? Is history, posterity and how you will come to be viewed something that looms large?

CS: a) False; b) Who cares?

GB: Would it make life a bit zestier if you had more competition in the marketplace? Do you still feel that there is virtually none?

CS: a) Yes; b) Yes.

GB: Saatchi, in Christopher Booker's prescient phrase, is a neophiliac: a perpetual gorger of the briefly new; a junkie for shift and change and forward propulsion. Is this how you see yourself?

CS: Ghastly, but yes.

GB: "Charles is aware of the marketability of art," London dealer Victoria Miro has said. "Other collectors want to hide that side of their activity." True? If so, why?

CS: a) Yes; b) Don't know.

GB: What is your feeling now about the Neurotic Realism show? Some have said they felt it was an attempt to launch a "synthetic" movement.

CS: Good artists.

GB: A number of the artists have complained to me about the tattiness of the press flyer sent out announcing Ant Noises. Why was it so cruddy?

CS: Cruddy? Moi?

GB: When did you last use public transport?

CS: British Airways to New York.
